But the wait was so worth it. Their portions are decent and the food is delicious. Love their Thai green Iced tea. Service is fast even though the place is understaffed! Definitely recommend.

Manhattan club decor serving Thai food in Jackson Heights. It is an interesting combination but no complaints since food is good and prices are OK (prob more expensive than other restaurants in the area though).Phed Ma Kham (roasted duck in tamarind sauce) - is not too sour and very generous portion on the duck. Texture of duck was excellent.Labb Gai (ground chicken salad) is also recommended (but maybe just slightly too salty for my taste.) Smells like it has fish sauce but I don't think it is indicated in the menu, so be sure to ask if you are allergic to fish sauce.The manager's Thai accent is really cute! Reminds me of my days living in Southeast Asia.
The food is delicious.. the appetizers are super good.. niece ambience. Quick service.

Kitchen 79 is a great Thai restaurant. First of all, the place is beautiful. It looks like it can turn into a lounge at night. The service was friendly and the food was also really good. The calamari and beef pad thai were delicious. They do not have their liquor license yet, but they do allow you to BYOB. Their thai iced tea was also served in a large mug. I will be back and I wish them alot of success.

In a neighborhood full of great Thai places, I am amazed that people like Kitchen 79. I guess I should have walked out when I saw the place was full of white people... I prefer the real deal and not food dumbed down for white people taste buds.That said they also don't know how to cook. My husband ordered the Duck in Red Curry....the duck was soooo chewy that the effort needed to eat it wasn't worth it. I sent back my Tom Yum soup because I thought they brought me the wrong soup...it was sweet!!! They assumed since I am white I wouldn't want it spicy...they came back with the same soup with Hot sauce in it. Service was also bad - people come and plop down a dish and walk away...no mention of what it is or if you need anything.The only thing I can think of that makes this place likable is the nicer decor than the other places in the hood. Arunee is 1000x better and is not even truly authentic thai...but not as "white" as Kitchen 79.

Nice decor. Food was good. The service was adequate. The problem with highly rated yelp restaurants is that your  expectations are so high that it never meets the expectations.  I went for lunch and had one of there set lunch menus. This is never the way to judge a serious  restaurant. I will try to drop by for dinner and give it another go.

Favorite Thai restaurant in the Jackson heights area. Amazing lunch special deals. In addition to the usual soup or salad add on, they give you a range of delicious appetizers to choose from (minced chicken dumplings, fried crab wontons etc). My go to dishes are som tam and chicken pad Thai. Service is fast and friendly. Decor is beautiful and modern as well. A great place to dine in groups or solo! They are also on seamless.
Favorite place by far in Jackson Heights. The way the mix the flavors is amazing. Service is quick, prices are reasonable and people working there is friendly.

Wow. The reviews for this place were spot on, just like the Wall Street Journal article. In our quest to find Tom Yum noodle soup, this is as good if not better than the ones in Bangkok. The Tom Yum noodle soup had everything I wanted, the perfect amount of heat, the minced pork and peanuts to give it the noodle soup its texture, and the smoothness of the noodles. Although the journey to Queens is a bit off the far end, I would recommend anyone coming here for authentic Thai. I can also say with a straight face that the other dishes are just as good. Although there wasn't much room left in my tummy, I wouldn't mind ordering all this deliciousness back to the city. 5 out of 5 on this one. Keep it up Kitchen 79!!!
This place has the BEST mango sticky rice in Jackson Heights. Period. Fried calamari is one of my faves here too. They also have sangria with Lychees in them

One of the first 5s that was a no-brainer!The customer service is so wonderful here. Our waitress was super knowledgeable and offered suggestions when she saw I could use it.We ordered the calamari, basil rice w shrimp, and green curry chicken. Everything was excellent! I mean, this is the Thai food you will craze for weeks to come. Tip: they are serious about their spice so if your not, just order mild levels of spice on everything.

Excellent straightforward american-style thai food.  You won't find much in the way of exotic here, but what they do have is very solid.I would normally give it 4 stars for excellence but I'm bumping it up since they allow you to order right from yelp (why don't more places do this?) and they actually read my notes when I asked for NO ICE in the thai iced tea.  That kind of attention to detail carries over into their whole operation I'm sure.
Just a single word - "Awesome!"Food, service, taste everything is good. Go for it!Some people might find it little expensive but I say it's worth!

One of my 5 stars review. My friends and I went there just to get some Thai deserts after our Brazilian lunch. We arrived there about 2 pm. The restaurant look busy but the waiter have us seated right away. We told him that we only wanted to have deserts he said it ok not a big problem then he recommended us to have mango sweet sticky rice, coconut ice cream and banana A la mode they was really delicious and beautiful plate. And we got Thai ice coffee OMG what a big mug coffee and tasty. Service was great, staff was very friendly and accommodated   The restaurant is very chic, clean and beautiful decorI definitely come back again when I go to Queens .

Awesome new place around the neighborhood. Great ambiance and awesome hostesses. I love that there's no need to ask for water. They provide you with your own jug. Lol. I love water. Overall a great clean restaurant. New favorite spot in my neighborhood.

I live in the neighboring apartment complex and dropped by since this place opened a week or so ago. This space now occupies where Arunee Thai used to be and has been completely renovated from head to toe. The space, now, features an interesting full black and white, almost Alice in Wonderland theme complete with a rams head clock and b&w tiled flooring, tables, and chairs.Lunch specials are completely worth the price at $7.50 for chicken, pork, tofu or $8.50 for shrimp and beef. Specials come standard with a choice of appetizer and entree. The lunch portions are generous with many different options to choose from. We had the Pad See Ew with Beef fried spring rolls. Pad See Ew was not overly oily and had a subtle bell-pepper flavor. I had the curry pineapple fried rice - very fragrant and well-seasoned fried rice. Can't really go wrong here. Curry puff appetizer was more or less a curry empanada served over a small salad. Thai Iced Tea was not cloying but served in a huge mug - delicious! Service is very homey and nice; We were greeted, seated, and waited upon with such genuine care and compassion. They checked up on us without being overbearing and made sure our water was filled constantly. Currently, closes at 11PM but they are waiting for their liquor license to arrive in a few weeks before pushing back the hours. I saw that they had 6 different types of beers on tap behind their bar so the alcoholic in me is excited! More to come as this place gets busier and busier - welcome to the neighborhood!

5stars! My favorite Thai restaurant, Ive tried many Thai restaurants in Queens and city. Kitchen 79 is definitely my favorite. The place is nice and clean, their food is delicious, good portion, and reasonable price. I love their spicy glass noodle salad, yum!
Had Quay Key with shrimp (medium heat) with curry puff for luncheon special and it was awesome. The staff was A+ all the way. Bargain price but not bargain food or service. Try it!

This place was amazing!!!!  I had their Thai ice tea and it was the best and huge!  Their Khao Soi and was so good.  The decorum is sheik and nice.  Since their prices are so reasonable and their food is super delicious I would start going here more.  I would highly suggest this place to all that love Thai food.
One of the best thai restaurants in Jackson Heights! Cute and cozy environment. Great date spot. Summer rolls and drunken noodles were superb. Great fruity drinks as well and service was good.

This is right near my home and I can't believe I haven't come here sooner. I love this place! Their lunch special is so great!! Their staff is so friendly and nice. I had the crab wonton appetizer it was so good, and the drunken noodle with chicken and I loved every bite of it. I'm going to be coming back here often deffinetly. Very delightful.

Found a gem in Jackson Heights! The service was attentive & friendly. The black & white decor's sleek & comfy. We started off with crispy spring rolls, curry puffs, & fried calamari... All delicious, crispy & well seasoned. My only gripe was the small portion... 5 pinkie size spring rolls & 3 small puffs an order had us craving for more! The fried calamari was a good portion for 2 & came in a super cute cone shaped dish. Dinner was a solid A... Chicken Pad See Ew & Shrimp Green Curry were both ridiculously good! Notable Fav's... *Lychee Red Sangria & *Lychee Creme Brûlée... Just WOW!
Clean and cozy atmosphere and delicious food! Fresh and tasty perfect for the rainy and cold weather!

Came here over the weekend to meet with some friends for drinks and apps... So we thought!  I was the first to show up and was greeted by friendly staff.  Sat by the bar to wait for the rest of the group.  While I was debating whether to order Thai ice tea or not, a cold glass of water was placed in front of me.  I was impressed and grateful for that simple offer/service while I waited.  When the rest of the party arrived, we took quite a moment to decide as there were too many choices to choose from.Finally decided on calamari (Pla Muk Tord), mango salad (Yum Ma Mong), flat noodles w/chicken and squid (Guay Tiew Khua Gai) and deep fried fish (Pla Toad Yum Ma Mong).  Can I just say, we cleaned out our plates!!!! Everything was so good!  The calamari was just right, lightly breaded & seasoned.  The mango salad was sweet, savory, a lil on the spicy side & perfect.  My friend really wanted the mango salad AND papaya shreds, so for a small addtl $ they added it for us without grief.  If you're the type to stay safe and order Pad Thai, please, be adventurous and get the Guay Tiew Khua Gai.  You won't regret it. Promise.  And last but not least, the FISH!  It was soooo sooo good that the only thing left on the plate was part of the head/a bit of the tail.  Some might be weirded out by it but I'm sure you'll do the same when you get there.  Highly recommend this spot for your tummy and chic decor for your eyes.  Oh and they make a killer white sangria!

So, I ordered the flat noodles with gravy "sauce" and and what they sent was basically a soup and I didn't see broccoli anywhere, it didn't look like the picture and they sent the noodles in a box so they sticked to each other and was hard to eat, flavor maybe 6.5/10

Excellent service! Easy to find meter street parking. Clean bathroom. Modern decor. Excellent choice of music just loud enough to drown out everyone else's conversation except for my date. Great lighting. Now for the food: Coconut water-unusual presentation extremely delicious.Curry puff-flaky, well seasoned and the dipping sauce was amazing.Deep fried shrimp cakes-excellent.Pad woon sen beef-amazing the texture of the noodles was perfect.Pineapple shrimp fried rice-amazing flavor and the rice grains were perfect not mushy or hard.Crispy soft shell crab-incredible.Roasted duck in tamarind sauce-the best duck I've eaten in my life.fried ice cream coconut flavor-delicious and I was shocked when they lit it on fire! I hope this place never changes. Whenever I want Thai food this is my new go to.
Wonderful service. Owner and servers are very friendly. The food is some of the best thai I have ever had. Give this place a try! The pad sei eew is fabulous!
Love this place. Friendly staff! Good food. Reasonable price. Beautiful decor. And clean. You won't be disappointed.
Nice little spot. Food is fresh. Decor is shnazzy. Service is cool. Nice lunch specials.

Sometimes words can't describe how delicious the food tasted. It is one of the best Thai food restaurants out here in Jackson Heights, Queens. I been here twice and the food has not disappointed me. The mango salad was fresh and spicy.  The pad sew ew was on point very delicious and tasty. My sister had the pineapple fried rice. It had curry which made it taste better and she was very satisfied with the taste and the portion size.  I also tried their banana beer: it's very good and aromatic.The Thai ice tea comes in a mug. I will definetely be back to get some in the summer time. I also love the dessert menu:  must try the creme brulee of lychee: so different but tasty. The decor was very modern and the atmosphere is perfect for a date or a girls night out. Excited to try out more of their menu.
This is one of my best Thai Restaurant in Queens. Dishes are all good and liked the service too. Very quiet place and nice place to hangout with your loved ones.

My friend and i was in the area and came across this place. We both like our dishes spicy. So we went in and ordered our basil fried rice and drunken noodles. We asked for it to be spicy. That was a mistake! It was sooooooooooo spicy. After two spoons we were crying and couldn't eat anymore. The staff was so polite and was nice enough to change our dishes and made it regular. This time around i wasn't able to eat it because everything was burning lol. I took it home an it still taste great.  The staff was pleasant. The place is clean and the food was great. I gave it four stars because it's important for people to know how spicy is spicy. The staff should inform the guest before they place the order.

Thanks to Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao for opening! We got our Shanghaiese food fix tonight! See below for we ordered for take-out!! A7. Scallion Pancake E12. Fried Rice Cake with Shredded Pork B1. Pan Fried Pork Buns (6)A13. Crispy Shredded Turnip Ham Puffs (4)  Surprisingly GOOD!!!  E1. Shanghai Fried Udon Thick Pan-fried Noodles with Bokchoy, Shredded Pork, and House Special Sauce F1. Nan Xiang Soup Dumplings (6) (Signature Pork Soup Dumplings)F2. Crab Meat  & Pork Soup Dumplings (6) E8. Pan Fried Crispy Noodle w. Seasonal Seafood Although we didn't get to sit-in and enjoy the food on premise, we are happy to eat at home knowing we are all safe and sound. APPRECIATE and grateful for all the GOOD food on our table! I must try their SPECIAL soup dumplings next time!!! Note: Currently, they require that all customers order directly from online because they do not take cash or credit in the restaurant.Stay safe! Stay strong! Stay positive! Stay hopeful! Stay SANE! We can get through this Pandemic 2020!!

My first time ordering soup dumplings for delivery and it wasn't the worst. All the good flavors are still there but the soup is just not piping hot. Pro tip: microwave it for a little bit and it'll warm up and taste infinitely better. The fried noodles, scallion pancake with beef, and tendon in chili oil were some of my favorites! Delivery was efficient and didnt take more than 45 minutes. I'll be ordering again!
You can now order online and pick up at the restaurant. Food is still as fresh as ever at the new location on the corner.

I've been coming here since I was small, and they always have great food. The last location sometimes lacked the hygiene that is expected of such a popular restaurant, but their new location is both clean and has the quality of the food. Wait times are minimal for such a popular restaurant, and food comes timely after you order it. The soup dumplings are known by anyone who lives in flushing, and they are a must get. Their chow mein tastes like any other place's chow mein, but all chow mein is great. Would definitely recommend to any visitors and if you are a local and haven't eaten here, what are you waiting for?

My third time eating here.  Twice at the new location under new ownership and once at original location.  At the original location, I had their Xiao Long Bao (regular and crab), pan fried dumplings and stir fried shanghai noodles, they didn't have the braised beef noodle for some reason or another, which was what I really wanted.  At that time, I didn't understand all the hoopla about this place.  Compared to You Garden or Joe's Shanghai, the XLB was just about the average and no much different than the latter.  I still prefer Joe's XLB.Second time eating there, they closed the old location and opened up under new management at the new location.  I ordered the lucky 6, pan fried dumpling and braised beef noodle soup.  The beef noodles were on point.  The lucky 6 XLB was different and enjoyable.  Pan fried dumplings were good, skin wasn't too thick and good amount of meat.Third time, was recently with Covid19 Pandemic restrictions in place.  Ordered braised beef noodles and pan fried dumplings.  Beef noodles is consistently on point.  But the pan fried dumplings didn't meet my expectations this time around. Are they going to use the pandemic as an excuse?  The skin was thick and doughy, not cooked through, didn't stay on the pan frying long enough, and not much filling, even the dollar dumplings stalls are better than this!  I don't expect that from a Michelin rated restaurant as they proudly advertise with the postings all around the restaurant.  I could of went with a higher rating but how can you mess up something so simple like pan fried dumplings?!?

Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao used to be small restaurant that was across the street but I am really glad they expanded to take over a bigger store. Unfortunately, the quality and ambiance of the new store is catered much more to tourists and non-locals. Try the new tri-colored Xiao Long Bao but it definitely isnt the same. The cold dishes and the soymilk are the sleeper trys here. Sad that their expansion doesn't bring forth the same quality or ambiance that their small store across the street once did.I nostalgically remember going to their original stores with my friends after work and just catching up with good food and good drinks.

I went to this place with a group of friends in NY. As a person who lives far away from "real Chinese food". I have to say I was so excited when I was in Flushing seeing all the busy restaurants and stores. Xiao Long Bao is incomparable. I love it so much. The only downside is that this was a quite popular place. So the waiting hours can be very long.

One on the best places on Flushing to go for Xiaolong Bao (Soup dumplings). The name of the restaurant remains a classic but the restaurant has made some great exterior upgrades. They opened up their new location just down the street from the previous restaurant. The new place is very different, with 2 floors and everything looks nice and brand new. It feels like a more upscale restaurant. Can't say enough about how nice they made their new restaurant. Another thing is their service has gotten better as well. The servers at the previous location were curt and not very friendly.The food quality has gone down just a bit. Overall, they serve very similar menu items. I would definitely recommend the Signature Pork XLB. I also like the Crab Meat XLB, but I am usually the only one in my group that likes these. I think the Lucky 6 is an interesting concept and a good looking picture, but most of the other types of baos taste pretty similar. For instance the scallop one only had a small piece of scallop in the middle of the same pork meat bun. The truffle one tastes interesting but all in all, I'd still go for the classic pork baos. Also, be ready to wait for a long time to get seated. They don't take reservations. It's located in One Fulton Square, and is walking distance from the main parts of Flushing. Overall, I miss the food from the previous restaurant, but enjoy the overall feel of the new one better.

Somewhere between a 3.5 and a 4 for me. I came here with my family on the weekend of Lunar New Year. On a cold and rainy winter day, this place provided comfort in the form of some tasty Chinese food. I also enjoyed the lunar decorations on the first floor. We got a variety of dumplings, appetizers, noodles and desserts. My favorite item was the noodle and beef with shredded pepper (no soup), robust and flavorful with a slight kick. If you're in the area, it's worth checking out.

I was a huge fan of their old location. This new restaurant is bigger and cleaner. For 2 people, we waited 40 mins on Saturday for lunch. We got the original Pork Soup Dumplings and a sampler 6 different flavors. The dumplings came quick but luke warm as if it's been sitting out for a while... Each dumpling had a good amount of broth. Nothing beats the classic pork. It tasted exactly how I remembered except the dough is now a bit thicker.  Their new flavors were overall okay. I wouldn't get them again. The scallop had a whole piece of scallop! The chicken was mild. The truffle was good but with only a hint of truffle. The gourd had a slight crunch and the crab was very fishy. There's a $30 card minimum which I guess is better than not accepting cards at all. I can see myself returning often.

Came here again by to give this place another chance..... the food here was pretty bad.The beef crispy noodles were way to oily! The sauce wasn't even sauce... but instead 90% oil.....The soup dumplings also were very disappointing.... Feel free to check out my pictures... THIS PLACE IS ALL FAKE MARKETING LIKE TIGER SUGAR MILK TEA! Lmao!#Truthbomb #NoOffense

I Love my wife, but I vowed that it will be a while for me to wait on a long line for anything. I was tramautized by the Yayoi Kusama's Festival of Light 2017 - David Zwirner NYC. (5.5 hours in the freezing, wet, cold!). Nan for short, ALWAYS has a long ass line, so I'm always like " Nope we are not waiting!". This week, by some weird phenomenon - there seemed to be no line in Nan and come to think of it, Flushing looked eerily empty. We jumped on the opportunity to get us some soup dumplings...=)Boy were we happy! The Lucky Six and the Signature are what was needed to satisfy our dumpling cravings. The quick service eased any reservations we had.Nan is a, go to, for some fresh soup dumplings. The wide variety of flavors, provide for a delicious treat. The moderate pricing is a plus, and the speedy service will have those fresh dumplings in your mouth in no time!

Came here on a very rainy and windy Saturday on Chinese New Year Day. It was busy as expected from reading the rest of the reviews. We waited about half an hour which wasn't as bad as we expected it to be.We got the Husband and Wife Special and two orders of the Lucky Six Soup Dumplings so we both got to try each of the flavors they had to offer. The Husband and Wife Special is sliced beef and tripe served in an oily spicy sauce. A very good appetizer to start out your meal. The main reason to come here though is their famous soup dumplings. They had various flavors to choose from and we couldn't decide on which to get so we got the Lucky Six Soup Dumplings. This included Signature (white), Crab Meat & Pork (white with orange tip), Black Truffle (purple), Chinese Squash (green), and Scallop (orange). The Black Truffle was the least soupy as it's essentially truffle oil and you know how expensive truffle can get. My favorite was the scallop. The most interesting one was the Chinese Squash as it tasted like Chinese squash, although there is pork in it.Overall a very wonderful experience. I read that this place was cash only, but that is a lie as they gladly took my credit card as payment. Gotta get those travel points so I can eat more food!

Boston is a soup dumpling desert, but fortunately Flushing isn't *too* far.The xlb here are bigger than most, and compared to Din Tai Fung the filling is much richer and fattier. The really big difference though, is that all the other dishes here are also good, whereas the non-xlb dishes at Din Tai Fung can be uninspiring. The fried 蔥油餅 are crispy, flaky, and chewy. The 生煎包 are crispy and juicy, if not exactly filled with soup. Even the appetizers, such as beans and tofu or beef tendon and tripe, are thoughtful and well-executed.

After abruptly closing this past Spring, Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao is finally back and better than ever with a new menu and flashy décor. Located a block from the original location in Flushing, their new digs are finally large enough to house the demand. Their menu is littered with "must have" dishes but their soup dumplings are the star attraction. For a taste of everything soup dumpling wise, order their Lucky Six Soup Dumplings where you get one of each of the follow dumplings: crab, pork, chicken, black truffle, chinese squash and foie gras.Parking will be tough street wise but there's a parking lot nearby where you can park using the meter. Additionally, the 7 train lets you off a mere few blocks away.

Super new and clean location. Still on prince street except down the block. Definitely a lot of options for soup dumplings and boy are they juicy!!! I opted to share the truffle soup dumplings and while I tasted the truffle in the soup dumplings, I wasn't particularly impressed. The little bits also reminded me of black sesame. I also tried their Pan Fried Pork Buns and they're super doughy but still very juicy. The rice cake with cabbage and pork was delicious.  I guess for flushing prices, this soup dumplings spot may be a bit more by like a dollar or two difference but it's honestly worth trying. I wish I came with a larger group to sample more dishes. Also this is cash only! Didn't see any atm inside the restaurant.

The closure of Nan Xiang last year broke my heart, it was such a great place to eat and never wavered in its quality or its reasonable prices that allowed all diners to eat their wonderful soup dumplings.  After waiting a few months to go after their grand re-opening in their new space a few doors down, I am happy to say that nothing's changed except the decor.The new space is wonderful - bright, modern, more spacious than their prior location.  You can still take a peek at the pros making their XLB in the middle of the restaurant.  While the space looks deceptively large from the outside, it actually is about the same as the old space (the first floor is just waiting area only with dining on the second floor).  We ordered the usual favorites - pork soup dumplings, fried pork buns, soy milk and spicy beef and tripe.  Happy to report that everything is as excellent as the prior location.  Soup dumplings have the same wonderful soup and delicate skin, pan fried pork buns are crispy on the bottom and fluffy on top with a delicious pork filling.  Spicy beef was full of lean slices of beef and not swimming in chili oil like some other establishments.  Soy milk was fresh and not overly sweet, definitely the best I've had this side of Taiwan.  Prices here might have gone up 50 cents per dish for some or remained the same for others.  Menu has gotten a few new items too like the multicolored XLB sampler as well as chicken XLB and black truffle pork XLB.  Most definitely will give those a shot.  Also, it looks like they take credit cards now so its not cash only anymore (WOOHOO).  Service was actually even better than it used to be as it looks like they're more organized and now use iPads to help with the ordering.  What can I say other than it's great to have them back.  Thumbs up again.

Okay, came back here again since I was craving the pancakes with the meat and wanted to try other items.This time the pancakes with meat was not as good as I remembered, I think because the pancakes were a bit overdone so it tasted a bit too dry with no softness.We got the bean curd with the Chinese celery - I saw they had this in their back entrance and I usually love this dish, but I didn't like their version because it was super bland. The places I go usually has a bit of kick to it and this one didn't.We got the soup dumplings again and I really wish they can work on their chili oil here. The dumplings would taste so much better if they just fix the chili oil. Their chili oil, not sure if it is bought or they make it, but the chili oil itself is just too thick. It has too much seeds and not enough oil or kick. Joe's has really good chili oil and so does Mimi Cheng's - if they can replicate their chili oil, then this place would improve tremendously.We also got the steamed fried buns - we didn't care for this dish at all, the filling wasn't good and neither was the wrapper.Chili Pepper and Pork Noodle Soup - it was cold, so I wanted something brothy and ordered this and again, standard but we did enjoy it. The meat was tender and nice, and flavour was good.Overall, not the best soup dumplings I ever had, since the wrapper should still be more delicate and filling can be more flavourful and definitely work on the chili oil recipe to make the dumplings better.

Came here on a Saturday afternoon with two friends. We were giving #110 while they were calling #85. It took about 40min to get to us.I like the new location a lot better. The menu has more variety and the service is super speedy and accommodating. We got the soup dumplings wIth six diff flavors (would recommend if you're not sure if you like soup dumplings), the pancacke wrapped beef is delicious, would recommend! We got the salty tofu pudding which was very well done (so soft!). The stir fried rice cakes was also very well done.Maybe I'm not THAT into Shanghai food, I thought this place is good but overhyped. Will admit that compared to manhattan Chinatown places, the soup dumplings are better.

I have to say, this new location is prettier and just a little bit bigger than the old one. Brought my boyfriend and my friends here cause they wanted soup dumplings. I went on New Year's Eve around 2pm and it was packed. The wait was 30 mins for my group of 4. They offered us to look at the menu and circle what we want so we can order right away when we got seated.We order three different soup dumplings. The lucky six, nan Xiang soup dumplings, and crab/pork. The nan Xiang and the crab meat one was good and very juicy. The lucky six was different but definitely worth trying. In addition we ordered the scallion pancake with sliced beef cause it was a pretty popular one on yelp so we gave it a try and I'm glad we did! It was delicious! We also orders the pan fried pork buns and pain fried pork dumplings. Both were good. For the noodles we got the pan fried crispy noodle. We also order fried rice cake with shredded pork and I really loved the veggies that was in the rice cake. If you don't mind waiting, this place is a good location to try soup dumplings. It's a little pricey compared to the one I go to in chinatown.

I came to Flushing for the first time to specifically visit this place for lunch at the suggestion of my friend. (It turned into a food tour and a quick visit to the Queens Botanical Garden, which is free during the day until March.)It was worth it.  Not sure what else I can really add to the thousands of reviews, but here goes...The space is very nice and rather large. We waited about 35 minutes for 2 to get a table.We ended up getting three dishes.  First,  A11. Fried Chinese Chives Box (Chinese Chives, Shrimp & Egg).  This came out piping hot and I almost burned the roof of my mouth.  Let it cool down a bit, but this had good flavor.  I also used it as an opportunity to try the chili paste and the siracha-ish sauce and taste test them.  Those sauces together are great and I used them a lot on the second dish too.Second, E9. Pan Fried Crispy Noodle w. Pork, Shrimp & Fish Fillet.  This dish was really good actually.  The crispy noodle was underneath the rest of the sauce and seafood. I highly recommend it.  The fish fillet was the best part.  Even some scallops ended up in the mix too. goes well with the sauces they place on the table.Third, F6.Lucky Six Soup Dumplings (6), which is a variety pack of dumplings: Signature + Crab Meat & Pork + Black Truffle + Chinese Squash + Scallop.  These were very good.  I think the black truffle was the most interesting of what I tasted. I also learned you drink the soup up from the top of the XLB instead of making them explode in your mouth, lol.All in all, the food and service were great.  We didn't feel that rushed to leave.  Pro tip - The entrance is on 39th street at ground level.  Don't try to enter from the exit that is up the stairs that you see off of Prince St.  They need a better sign.Pro tip 2 - Wash your hands after the bathroom.  Saw a bunch of people not do that as I was at the sink wiping the sweat off the top and back of my head. (from the temperature of the food, not the spice)

Like many others, I was really sad when I heard that Nan Xiang had closed "permanently"....and then thrilled when I heard they were planning to re-open at a different location! Woot Woot!! The new location is much more modern and beautiful!  They do NOT take reservations, and this place gets packed!  First come, first served - you get a number (dim sum style) and your number will be called when your table is ready.  On this Friday night, 15 of us waited for a table and the wait wasn't terrible;  however, we got there early, at 5:45.  At first, we were told they may have to split our large group into two groups, but in the end, they managed to seat us all together.  Kudos to Nan Xiang for accommodating us! Of course, with the relocation and the booming Flushing rent, prices have gone UP!  Their menu has been refreshed to include old favorites as well as some new items.  No matter what you order, you're sure to be wow'd!  Everything is freshly made and delicious!Our shared menu tonight:~ Lucky Six Soup Dumplings (Signature + Crab Meat & Pork + Black Truffle + Chinese Squash + Scallop + Chicken) - I thought these were unique, visually appealing, tasty and fun to try but, honestly, I prefer their Signature pork soup dumplings the best!  Still, a must try at least once.~ Scallion Pancake w.Sliced Beef - these were outstanding and came with a delicious hoisin sauce. One of my fave dishes!~ Pan Fried Pork Buns - They make these one order at a time (literally), so if you order more than one order, they will not be served at the same time.  Standard dish but tasty!~ Husband & Wife Special (sliced beef & tripe served in spicy sauce) - cold appetizer; this was a great dish but I didn't really find it spicy at all.~ Chicken in Wine Sauce (Bone-In) - Good, but the wine flavor was very mild.  Good texture.~ Four Happiness Sponge Tofu (Braised Tofu served with bamboo shoots and wood ear mushrooms) - another cold appetizer.  Delicious dish!  Different and fun to try.~ Sticky Rice Sui Mai - I found this very bland but once you add a little chili oil to it, they were fantastic!~ Pan Fried Beef Dumplings - standard and ohhhh so satisfying.  Pan-fried to perfection.Overall, the quality and flavors of each dish were fantastic.  So many more items on their menu to try - I will definitely be back!  Service and hospitality were pretty good, considering how insanely busy it is in the restaurant.  Everyone is hustling!!  It was a little chaotic trying to serve 15 of us, but they did a great job on this busy evening.  Again, so glad that Nan Xiang has reopened!

We finally hit up the new Nan Xiang and it took me by surprise. The inside is very different from the old location just up the block on Prince. The old spot was just like any other cheap low cost Chinese restaurant you would find in any Chinatown around the world. Quick bite and leave was the atmosphere in the old joint. The new Nan Xiang however is the complete opposite. I must say the inside is pretty damn nice compared to what it use to be. I actually wanna sit and take my time dining. The space in the new Nan Xiang is much more open, good lighting, very clean, excellent service, and reasonable wait time during a high capacity lunch hour on the day after Christmas.The food was more or less the same as the old spot. Some items tasted a little heavy on the msg. All of us became very thirsty on our way home. The scallion pancake with sliced beef is still pretty good. The soup dumplings tasted the same as before. I also ordered their pan fried noodles with seafood. It wasn't bad but it wasn't that great either. I wished it had more quality seafood, perhaps some scallops, squid, octopus, and larger shrimps. The noodles were pan fried well, good crunchy texture but it just lacked some of the key seafood ingredients.Verdict - The new Nan Xiang reminds me a lot of Din Tai Fung. The decor, lighting, wall fixtures, everything just seem like a copy of what Din Tai Fung does. And for a full disclosure, I am not a big Din Tai Fung fan to start with, I'm simply comparing the atmosphere between the two businesses even though they are not in direct competition with each other. The best part of Nan Xiang during this particular visit was the service. Our waitress was extremely polite and kind to our table. If you dropped your chopsticks, needed to refill yo ur water or tea, she was on it before you could even turn your head to realize she already done it. She was playful with my son, she was absolutely amazing and I didn't not expect this kind of service from Nan Xiang and from most Chinese restaurants in Flushing in general.The downside of Nan Xiang are two minor things that can be overlooked but is worth mentioning. Not enough restrooms. This new location can seat a lot of people and there always seem to be a long line for the restroom. Parking, for me this is not a problem because I don't mind parking at Sky View center and walk over to Prince St. But for those who wanna park are the municipal lot across the street from Nan Xiang, good luck!! Street parking is a disaster too due to the heavy construction around the block. Parking at the Sheraton sucks. So I would highly recommend parking at Sky View and take a short walk over, it's not that bad.

I had Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao when I was studying in Shanghai. I remembered it was the best soup dumplings I ever had and I was so happy when I saw that it is open in NYC. I went there on Sunday late morning. The line is long but it is durable, 45 mins wait. Food - Obviously Soup dumpling is a must eat at this restaurant. However don't forget to try their pan fried pork buns! It is amazing. The skin is thin and the filling is so tasty. I ordered the Shanghai shu mai and It was meh.Overall I highly recommend this place. It tastes the same as the one in Shanghai

Came here on a Sunday night and it was booming. This place does live up to their hype. We had to wait 30mins, but it was probably only 20min because people who put their name down ended up leaving so it we got seated faster. The food was made fresh, everything came out steaming hot and of course delicious.Pro:-Beautiful atmosphere-Great service. They are quick taking orders, refilling waters, and getting the check-The food is fresh and delicious. Every fish we got we enjoyedCons:-Long wait but worth it-Not really a con, but since the food is made to order you'll have to wait longer for it to come out so I cant really be upset here-Prices were kinda high and we splitted with a group of friends, but again it's still worth coming to try this placeTips:-Put in your name then walk around Flushing instead of waiting inside but come back a little early just in case people leave and they call your name earlier-Order one of everything and share/split with friends, family or your date

I was definitely more of a fan of Nan Xiang pre-reopening but it's still not a bad choice for a meal in Flushing. What's new: more upscale atmosphere and higher prices. Nan Xiang was notorious for cheap, but delicious food back in its glory days. The service was subpar, but the food was delicious and quick. Service definitely has improved from before, and the entire ambience is a lot nicer, as the restaurant rebrands itself more on class. Doesn't feel as much as a hole-in-the-wall which was definitely part of its old charm. They have a new 6 XLB sampler with 6 different flavors. I'd say try it once, but it's definitely not a repeat purchase. The scallop one is their regular pork XLB with a mini scallop in the middle. The truffle one actually tastes like a truffle pork XLB, super rich and umami, I definitely would not be able to eat more than one. I'd recommend sticking to the pork XLB (definitely get the crab if you like seafood, I always preferred the crab over regular) and the Shanghai Udon. The shanghai udon is the perfect slightly greasy, but flavorful noodle dish with pork and bok choy. Great for sharing.

My friend has been hyping up Nan Xiang for months and I didn't believe the hype at first but... after waiting in line for an hour... my life (and standards for XLB) really changed.I hate waiting in line for food and it's never WORTH waiting in line for food but wow. I see why Nan Xiang is Michelin recommended. Affordable but with amazing quality food. Their standard XLB is simple and perfect but the truffle XLB really blew me away. I never had anything like it. The truffle was very flavorful and really came through, I ate a whole tray myself. Anyway the scallion pancakes with beef was also the best one I've had, with the pancake being crispy and flakey, yet still soft and the beef being oh-so-flavorful.Now I can't go back to other XLB places :(

Welcome back Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao! They took over Rong Restaurant's space at One Fulton Square. The renovation was gorgeous from the waiting area to the upstairs dining area. Damn, the restaurant was super duper packed when I arrived. Luckily, there was a guy in front of me waiting to get a ticket. When I got my ticket, holy moly #170 and the wait time was about an hour. Don't go by the TV monitor which kept saying now seating #41 when the guy started calling out numbers in the 100s SMH!  I grabbed a seat for my dad so he wasn't standing by the doors as we waited for my mom to come back from her errands. Apparently, there was a texting option but the guy didn't let me know about it until I found out 30 mins into waiting for a table.  I overheard a few people saying that there were plenty of emptied tables so why aren't they seating customers to speed things up. I was so annoyed that when a number was called and no one came forward you skip that number rather than going back to that skip number down the line...how rude!My parents and I waited for almost 2 hours. I don't think that I ever waited that long at their old location. I was frustrated like the other customers waiting there. Finally, the guy called #170 and we hurried through the crowd and went upstairs to be seated at our table.There was already a line for the restroom...ugh I have to wait even more! I came back to the table and my parents wanted to order food already because they were starving. I wasn't interested in their Lucky Six Xiao Long Bao at all which I have seen pictures on their Instagram. Wow, the food comes out quickly from the kitchen from the moment you place your food order. Food: A14. Red Bun Puff - hubba hubba *mama like* the flakiness and it was stuffed with a lot of red bean paste E7. Crispy Noodle with Seasonal Seafood - too many vegetables...barely any shrimp...not enough delicious crispy noodleF2. Steamed Crab Meat & Pork Xiao Long Bao - I am only a fan of this kind of xiao long bao...usually when I am sucking up the soup that it supposes to be HOT, not lukewarmB1. Pan Fried Pork Buns - usually when I bite into one of them...the soup would be bursting out of the bun B10. Vegetable Wontons - this used to be one of my favorites but not anymore because the taste isn't the same and broth of wonton soup was bland...comparing pictures from their old location to today's...huge difference ::sad face::E8. Rice Cake with Shredded Pork & Preserved Cabbage - this was a yummy dish but we were too stuff so we took the leftovers home What my parents and I ordered today was just a hit or miss. We definitely will be back to try the rest of the menu.Note: You will be spending more of your time just waiting for a table!

A new upgraded space but still pretty decent Xiao Long Bao place in Flushing. There are three different types of Xiao Long Bao entrees. Signature, Crab and Pork, and their colored one that has different types of flavors (Signature, crab, black truffle, scallop, chicken, and Chinese squash). Another great dish is the "Four Happiness Sponge Tofu". Good flavor to it and not too salty. Their braised beef noodle soup was not worth it. Service was ok - they were very good at refilling your tea, but our waitress was rushing us to order when we first sat down. We didn't have any time to look at the menu and see what else they had.

Flushing really needs a Din Tai Fung. I was never really a fan of Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao. I came here back in November with a friend and the wait time was not bad... around 15-20minutes. Service was prompt and servers came around to constantly offer tea refills.Appetizer:Jellyfish with some vegetable I forgot the name of- oily Colorful soup dumplings- I couldn't taste the flavors that were listed on the menu except for the truffle and the crab ones. The truffle one had a lot of truffle flavor which was really nice. I would definitely come back solely for the truffle soup dumplings.Fried Noodles w/ Chicken- portion is biggg. Couldn't finish. It was ok.

This place's XLB are some of my favorite I've had around Manhattan / Flushing! There will almost definitely be a wait (around 30 mins on a Saturday night around 9pm), but it's worth it. We ordered the pork XLB, crab XLB and the shanghai pan fried udon noodles. Of the dishes, the crab XLB was my favorite.The skin of the XLBs here are very thin but held up well. It also was not soggy and there was a good amount of meat in each. The shanghai noodles tasted pretty normal, but the good noodle quality was noticeable (very firm but also chewy).The new location itself is very clean and the service is pretty friendly / quick. You can see people making the XLB near the seating area which is a nice touch. I would definitely recommend this spot if you are around Flushing as they are also open quite late. My only suggestion would be to fully utilize the screen they have to call out numbers as the lady who was shouting numbers was sometimes hard to hear since the restaurant can be a bit noisy, but would also call out incorrect numbers at times since I guess she couldn't read some of the handwriting causing some confusion.

The new place is definitely nicer but their soup dumplings are just above average. The skin is dry and the soup inside is very fatty. We tried the colorful new dumplings which are unique. The truffles and chicken ones were great. I think you can only get them if you order the colorful variety though. Service was good in that they fill your tea often but they also take away the plates quickly when i wasn't done with the sauce. They seems to rush you out and put down the bill before i finished my last dish.Come early to avoid the wait otherwise it's definitely not worth waiting more than 30 min.

Must try: F1 Signature Pork Soup Dumplings!Why: Heavenly! I ordered Signature Pork Soup Dumplings and Pork & Veggie Wontons in Spicy Peanut Sauce, both came out in less than 5 minutes. Yes, I had both all to myself and it was filling! The pork in both were juicy and tender. For the soup dumplings, I appreciate that the soup inside wasn't steaming hot, just hot enough where you can blow, slurp, and bite without burning your entire mouth! The dumpling skin was thicker than I remember but it was still a little bite of heaven in each bite. I also loved the spicy peanut sauce for the wontons - not too creamy or overpowering.Notes: They definitely upgraded from their previous location. This one is bigger and fancier. The service seemed better than before. Servers were super nice and attentive, always refilling tea with a smile. My server also anticipated extra napkins without me asking. We came on a Sunday at 11am and was seated within minutes. We never felt rushed because 30 mins later there was a long line.

We visited Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao at its new space on the southwest corner of 39th Avenue and Prince Street, in part of the Fulton Square development. I liked the new location more than the food. The restaurant was in a "soft opening mode" during our most recent visit, but still charged full price. Food: OK (3 of 5). Dishes We Had:- Pan Fried Pork Buns (生煎包): Very greasy. - Shanghai Pan Fried Udon (上海粗炒麵): A small and greasy serving, but pretty good. The udon noodles here are slightly harder and chewier than usual.- Steamed Lucky Six Soup Dumplings (六品小籠包牌): the included colors were beige (regular pork soup dumplings), beige with a little sprinkle / crown of ginger (crab meat / pork), orange (pork and scallop), yellow (chicken), dark grey (truffle), and green (squash).- Nan Xiang Soup Dumplings (南翔小籠包): regular pork soup dumplingsThe soup dumplings were only OK. Aside from the truffle soup dumpling, MSG seemed to unpleasantly influence the flavors of the various soup dumplings, emphasizing sharpness over depth of flavor. The worst for me was the chicken soup dumpling, where the MSG served to sharpen a raw chicken flavor. The crab meat / pork soup dumpling had little crab flavor. The restaurant serves soup dumplings without a bamboo steamer lid -- which means the dumplings should be eaten quickly, because the open air dries and cools the dumpling skins, and leaves the dumplings more susceptible to breakage. I'd like to see the restaurant include a bamboo steamer lid with the soup dumplings, so people may comfortably eat at their own pace.Service and Atmosphere: Very Good (4 of 5). Service was very good. Our food was brought out in a timely manner. Tea is complimentary, and staff constantly refilled our tea cups. The new space is lovely, especially the lobby, and the seating is comfortable. Nan Xiang offers free VPN-friendly Wi-Fi. There are two well-maintained unisex bathrooms with ADA grab bars, and an additional sink for handwashing directly outside the restroom area.Other:Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao is an extremely popular destination, so wait times may be long during peak periods. The restaurant's dining area is on the 2nd floor. During our visit, the ADA chair elevator in the restaurant lobby (the 39th Avenue entrance) wasn't functional yet, but there is an elevator outside and behind the restaurant, in the Fulton Square common area (Prince Street, between 39th and Roosevelt Avenues). However, someone in your party will still need to visit the lobby to obtain a queue ticket.

Best Xiao Long Bao I've had!I can't even describe what it was, but something about their typical Pork XLB were amazing. However, I had decided to try their Lucky Six Xiao Long Bao because I had never seen flavors (and colors!) like these anywhere else. And WOW was it amazing. The initial reason as to why it caught my eye was because of the Truffle Soup Dumpling. I am a sucker for anything Truffle, so I was EXCITED to try these. After finishing all the dumplings, I'm shocked to admit that my favorite were actually the Chinese Squash & the Foie Gras Dumplings! The Truffle was delicious, but honestly didn't feel like it naturally blended/worked well with Xiao Long Bao in general. I was a big fan of the way the Squash was blended in and worked with the flavor of the XLB by adding a nice light sweet touch onto the dish. And the filling of the Foie Gras was also fun & delicious in its own way. Either way, the SAMPLER IS A MUST TRY!I'm shocked to add on that the Scallion Pancakes are also the BEST I've had. The sauce along with it went GREAT, and isn't the typical sauce I'd get with the dish. If I'm being honest, the sauce tastes as if it's nothing but Hoisin Sauce, but it was still a great dip for the best Scallion Pancakes regardless!My table also ordered the Pan Fried noodles with Beef, and the Handmade Steamed Dumplings. Nothing was too special and stuck out about these, but they were delicious nonetheless.

Finally NaN Xiang has been upgraded! We stopped by NaN Xiang on Black Friday night, and the line was super long. We waited, though, since we wanted to check out the new place. 45 minutes later, we got seated. The dining area on the second floor is spacious with the dumpling gallery in the middle. They have new items like Lucky 6 Soup Dumplings which come in 6 different flavors; pork, pork and crab meat, scallops, chicken, Chinese squash and black truffles -- definitely a must-try. We also got an order of pork and crab meat soup dumplings along with spicy bamboo shoots and wood ear mushrooms AKA black fungus. It's amazing how something sounds so disgusting would taste so good!There are 3 issues I noticed during this visit though: 1. Wheelchair elevator in the front is not working. Instead, you have to take an elevator in the back. 2. Queueing system is not being utilized. 3. They claim their credit card processor is not working, so it's cash only for now!

Hands down. The best XLB I've ever had. I've been on the hunt for authentic, mind blowing xlb lately, and this has to be the best I've tried. The wait does get pretty insane, we were a party of 3 and we waited for over an hour. However, ITS WORTH THE WAIT! The service really makes up for it. The waiters were so nice and friendly, constantly asking us if we needed more tea and reminding us that our order will be ready shortly. The XLB - we each had an order of the pork xlb. It came out hot and steamy. The skin was so thin and had a great texture. It was slightly chewy but nothing overwhelmingly distracting. The pork stuffing was very generous- every bite had a huge chunk of meat. The soup, omg, the soup was so creamy. Usually xlb soup is on the clear side, but the soup that oozed out was a creamy broth. It made the experience that much better. Everything melts in your mouth, and compliments each other so perfectly. Only $24 for all of us, such a fantastic deal and amazing dinning ambiance. Everyone must come to this place!!! Hands down the BEST.

Nan Xiang soup dumplings has re-opened in a beautiful new location!  New item!  Truffle soup dumplings!  A must get!  A must try!  An interesting taste sensation.  Quite a tasty deep earthy mushroom flavor. They have pretty much the same menu as before, except for the addition of several new soup dumpling flavors:  signature flavor (pork), crab and pork, chinese squash, chicken, black truffle, and foie gras (which is seasonal and limited).You can order the (F5) Steamed Lucky Six Soup dumplings (6), which is one dumpling of all 6 flavors.  All the dumplings had a nice generous amount of soup inside so be careful when eating.  The new dumplings are all different colors.  Quite pretty.  Instagram food pic!Green one.  Chinese squash dumpling had a taste I wasn't particularly fond of.  It was ok at best. Yellow one.  Chicken soup dumpling.  Also ok.  As far as flavor, I'd prefer the signature pork soup dumpling.Orange one.  This is supposed to be the foie gras dumpling, but it is seasonal and limited.  So instead this was a seafood pork soup dumpling.  There was a whole small bay scallop mixed within the pork filling.  This was good.  A nice sweet/ savory seafood flavor to the soup inside.  But I would have preferred to try out the foie gras dumpling.Saving the best for last!  The black truffle one.  It had a nice rich mushroom/ truffle flavor.  So good.  Must eat more of this!  Get it!Don't want to forget to mention the signature pork dumpling.  The white dumpling.  It is good. Pork and crab soup dumpling.  A white dumpling with a spot of yellow on the tip.   it's ok.  Could use more crabmeat in the filling.  A few other restaurants add more crab for texture and flavor.  Not a favorite here.  On to a few other dishes on their menu:A pan fried noodle dish.  Good flavor.  Portion was small.  A bit too oily.Pan fried pork buns.  The small amount of meat filling was a bit bland.  Dough was slightly under-cooked making it have a bit of sticky mouth feel.  Pan fried bottoms: a few were barely fried, the others were overly fried dark brown.  Too oily on the bottom.  Maybe they need a napkin on the serving plate to soak it up, or use less oil.Service:  Great.  Very efficient.  Very helpful.  Lots of staff everywhere.  Tea is constantly refilled.Decor.  Love the decor.  The first floor lobby is very beautiful with artificial handcrafted trees.  And there is a beautiful mini waterfall out front.  A walk up the stairs brings you into the dining room.  A beautiful new modern asian decor.  Antique designed chairs have their name etched in them.  The back of the dining room has some nice comfy booths. Nan Xiang is still in it's soft opening.  Open from 10am-10pm for its soft opening.Getting a table:   Walk up/ or get in line to get to the podium.  Get a number from the attendant.  On weekends the large waiting area will be jam packed with people.  Expect to wait at least 45 minutes at popular hours.Final note:  Some dishes were great.  Others were just ok.  Not worth a really long wait for a table.

Nan Xiang was never my go-to spot for XLB, so I wasn't one of the many devastated people when its old location closed down. This new, much larger and modern location with a larger menu, however, did spark my curiosity and made me give it a try. Our party of three had to wait around 30 minutes on a Friday night, which was to be expected. We ordered two orders of the XLB (typical pork & a new pork/chinese squash one), beef noodle soup, and the shanghai udon noodles. We enjoyed them all and I was actually very impressed with their beef noodle soup! I wasn't expecting much, but my friend said she always ordered it from here. I can see why. It's worth a visit!

TLDR; Truly the best soup dumplings in New York! We came around 5:30 pm on a weekend and waited for 15 minutes. You just have to get your ticket number from the hostess and wait at the seating area which is pretty spacious. For 2 of us, we ordered:-Nan Xiang Soup Dumplings (6p) which is their signature pork soup dumplings. -Pan Fried Dumplings (6p) -Braised Beef Noodle Soup (not pictured) Soup dumplings were delicious! It's nicely made--it doesn't come apart like other places. I'll definitely order more of these next time! I would skip pan fried dumplings; it was good, but no surprises there. Braised beef noodle soup was amazing! Perfectly seasoned and full of flavor! Overall, it was worth that hour trip and I'm already ready to go back. Don't forget to bring cash--they do have an atm inside too.

I'm glad this place reopened in a location that has a lot more space. The renovation definitely makes it seem more high-end but I question if it is being overly hyped up. Since they have reopened, everyone has been rushing to eat here so there may be a long wait. However, for a party of 5, I only had to wait about half an hour for dinner on Saturday night. The staff takes down your name and phone number, then hands you a piece of paper with a number. Usually, I love places that use the system of taking down phone numbers to inform you that a table is ready but they didn't use it at all. If they called your number and you were not there, they would proceed to the next number. They did go back and recall out numbers that were missed. I waited inside the lobby area so when they called out my number, I was there but I never received a text prior.The decor may be nice but the set up isn't that much nicer. The tables and seats were pretty crammed next to each other. I sat at a booth and the table was so close to the seats that it was hard to slide in. The staff was also quite busy so if you need anything, you really have to get their attention. The food also came out pretty quick after ordering and came hot to the table.One of my favorite cold appetizers is the spicy beef and tripe, which really isn't very spicy. It has great flavor and they definitely nailed it. The scallion pancake with beef is one of my favorite warm appetizers and it was very flakey and had a thin slice of beef. The soup dumplings is the highlight of the meal, of course. I tried the lucky 6, a new addition to their menu, which are the colorful soup dumplings that is being posted everywhere. It had a regular pork soup dumpling, crabmeat and pork, scallop and pork, chicken, truffle and pork, & squash and pork. Each one definitely had some flavor stand out based on what it was made of. They also all had lots of soup inside. However, I feel like the skin was pretty thick on these dumplings.Overall, the wait really wasn't very long and if you come with a party of 2, it is likely that you will be seated much quicker. Food was still of good quality and taste. I recommend coming for sure! & Plus, the different flavors of soup dumplings are fun to try.

Nan Xiang was my and friend's go to whenever we were in Flushing.  I was kind of disappointed that this place closed, as my other go to places also disappeared as well...But look! They're back again with a more modern look~ IG enthusiasts, foodies, and hipsters would flock here...by the way restaurant accepts only cash.I like the aesthetically pleasing tableware, the small spoon for the ginger/vinegar sauce was not as practical as the old metal spoons they used to use.  In addition to modern decor, more items were added to the menu.  Pork XLB (6 dumplings): Decent, though I feel it does not taste exactly the same versus the past, the skin did not rip apart (good), and soup had satisfactory flavor---wished there was more soup.  I remembered the old dumplings gushed out soup that filled 3/4 of the typical Chinese soup spoons.  Now it seems more like 1/4 the volume.  Yes, I'm the type of person that would pierce my dumpling and pour the soup onto the spoon in order to enjoy a gulp of flavor.Scallion pancake with beef: Delicious but had less/thinner sliced beef from what I've remembered, extra hoisin sauce with the fried crisp pancake satisfies my soul.Pan fried noodle with shredded chicken: An ok dish, but pales in comparison to the other itemsOnly thing lacking when I visited was service, it was a bit chaotic.  When seated, we were not given any tea while other later seated parties did.  Had to request twice just to get tea, and they only pour the tea instead of providing a kettle (4 sips from the cup and you would need to hail a wait staff to refill).  It was hard to get wait staff attention at times.  It seems as if the wait staff walked where ever, there wasn't a specific person assigned to certain tables or area.  Also witnessed one female customer being dumbfounded when a waiter ignored her twice.Usually when ordering XLB, vinegar with ginger slices are served with it.  The older location shifted from serving saucers with vinegar and ginger already poured in to saucers with only sliced ginger with vinegar at the table to pour yourself.  But with this location we didn't get any ginger at all!  We and other customers had to ask the waiter for the ginger slices.It would be helpful to leave a note on the door near the elevator side of the building to indicate to go to the opposite end of the restaurant to be seated.  Upon entering me and a few other parties did not know about this and waited by the door until a server informed us.I'm not gonna lie I do miss the simplicity of the older location, it gave a more simple vibe.  Overall I would still visit here (decent XLB and scallion pancakes calls out to my soul), next time I'll venture out and try the colorful XLBs.  I'm hoping service will improve to match the restaurant environment.

One of the best soup dumplings I've had in NYC Must visit this spot at flushing, Queens for amazing soup dumplings and pan fried noodles! We got the chicken soup dumplings, steamed vegetables dumplings and panfried udon noodles with vegetables  Everything was so good! Perfect for the winter season! We also got the Tsing Tao beer, my favorite Asian beer. The servers will make sure your tea cup is never empty! Their Chinese tea is served on the house and is great!

Very good! Really affordable and authentic for the most part. Good soup dumplings, the scallion pancake with the steak in the center is the best! Very crispy and awesome umami flavor.Seems like there is always a wait. But went pretty quick on a Sunday at 300. Waited about 15 minutes. Apparently this is now a bigger place than it used to be. They do have a lot of tables and food comes out quick but I didnt feel rushed. Wait service was very nice too. We both got the soup dumpling variety plate with 6 different dumplings. I wasnt crazy about the crab and truffle one. The truffle one just surprised me because that truffle oil flavor I am used to in Italian food not asian food where the flavor comes more from the mushrooms. It was just an odd combination for a soup dumpling. I liked the chicken, vege and scallop ones the best. Also the complementary tea they serve is great too. I had like 5 refills. Great place to go when your out and about in flushing!

Soup dumpling is not a huge thing in Chicago. Did a little research before deciding where I wanted to get XLB. Everywhere and everything was pointing to Nan Xiang and I was super convinced that this is the place to check out. We already had Joe's Shanghai on our last NY visit so opted for new place to try. Came on a Saturday night at around 7:30-ish and already a full house waiting to get seated. Luckily, we were able to put our name down for a wait list and come right back since our hotel was nearby. The wait area, not much of a waiting area. Only a few seats available and anywhere you stand, you're guaranteed to be standing in someone's way. Our wait was estimated to be a 35 minute wait for a party of 2 but it went by quicker than expected and felt like we only waited 15 minutes. The dining experience is upstairs which has expanded from their old location as I have read. Almost thought this new location wasn't going to be open in time for us to give it a try. We were able to experience two types of XLB: pork and crab meat. Between the two, I preferred the pork XLB better but nothing about it wowed me. The crab meat had a lingering taste that I did not enjoy like it was too fishy. The outer exterior skin is actually a lot thicker than what I am used to. I'm not much of a vinegar person but something about NY vinegar just made me like a bit more. It was an A-OK meal. Seems to be overrated IMO.

Highlight: appetizers and nice ambienceI honestly had really high expectations for this spot because friends raved about their original location so I was excited to give their new location a try.We waited about 45 minutes on a Saturday night for a group of 6. The hostess calls the numbers really quick so if you are not there, you might lose your spot in line. We ordered a variety of soup dumplings, noodles and appetizers to share. I love their spicy beef and tripe and beef with scallion pancake. I also reccomend the noodle with shredded beef and pepper. However, their soup dumplings were underwhelming. There is something off about the recipe they use for the xiao long bao skins because it was a tad too thick and chewy. For some reason, their truffle xiao long baos are EXPLOSIVE so be very careful when you bite into them. It exploded for 2 of my friends LOL. Overall, I was not impressed with their xiao long baos. I do like the creativity of the Lucky 6 xiao long bao (scallop, chicken, truffle, pork, crab, and squash) in terms of flavor but I cant get over the texture of the dumpling skin.

Loved this place! I don't come to Flushing often but so glad I came here. Pretty good sized restaurant although my party of 2 still had to wait a short while but only 20 minutes or so on a Saturday night. Ordered a ton of food, including of course the soup dumplings and they did not disappoint. Better than most I've had in Chinatown. All of the other food was pretty tasty as well, got a tofu dish, udon lo mein (which was really good), and a few others. Even though I ordered way too much for 2 people, the bill was also just over $40!! Extremely affordable, good food, and really satisfying soup dumplings! Made me want to go back to Flushing more often :)

I used to come to Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao when they were located across the street all the time. I would always rave about how great their food is, and how much I absolutely love their very basic dish: noodles with scallion sauce. Today was the first time I came to their newest location, and I'm afraid to say they've missed their mark on that dish for me. It was missing flavor, and probably a touch of salt when they fried their scallion, because I couldn't taste that same great taste that made me always want to come back for more. Also it was literally one of their cheapest noodle dish for $4.25, and now it's $2 more, which I'm willing to pay for, if they can get the flavor back. I'm aware that some of their chefs all went to another restaurant in Flushing, but I was disappointed this dish wasn't consistent to what I've always remembered it to taste. Outside of that, we got their chicken soup, which had ginseng, goji berries, chicken and a starchy potato that I can only name in Chinese. It was very flavorful and reminded me of the soup my mom would make us. We also got their special XLB with the 6 different pieces. Honestly, the only one I liked was the green one, which was their Chinese Squash XLB. The truffle was way too overpowering, and I couldn't eat it. Next time I will just order the XLB with only the Chinese squash. Their scallion pancake with pork slice is always good, as well as their pan fried pork bun. I actually prefer the pan fried one to the steam bun ones. Overall, I give this place a 4/5. I took a star off for service because they definitely need more servers. It took about 10 minutes to get our change back, and when asked about it they had to ask about 3 other people in order to get to the bottom of the situation. Also it took us quite some time to get our soup, which was one of the first items we ordered.

When I first found out Nan Xiang had closed down without realizing they were renovating, I was extremely upset. But with months of waiting, my friends and I successfully caught their soft opening at the brand new location, which is just down half a block from the original location. They have a number ticket system for waiting since they don't take reservations, except, we were able to get a number for our large group of 13 people via phone. We were in transit to the restaurant about 1 hour before when we attempted to make a reservation. When we arrived, we waited for about 25 mins which isn't too bad. That's a pro-tip for large group - Call them ahead of time to get a number so you are already on the list. You may still end up waiting for some time but at least you are ahead of the game (Disclaimer: Rules may change after soft opening).The seating area reminded me of Din Tai Fung, a popular Taiwanese dim sum chain in Asia and California. The soup dumpling makers stood behind an open glass window cubicle where everyone can see them. This was pretty cool. We ordered 12 rounds of xiao long bao because they were the highlight of the meal. I particularly enjoyed the chicken flavor (F3) because it was different and the broth in the dumpling was so hearty. They actually ran out of that flavor after we ordered 2 sets. Different flavor had a different color bun so it's safe for those who are allergic to crab (shellfish). Other appetizers worth ordering: cucumber salad with garlic sauce (C4), spicy beef and tripe (C1), and pan fried pork buns (B1 - warning: this takes a long time to make so order it right away). Next time, I will be coming early to try out the breakfast menu.

This place has the ABSOLUTE BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS EVERRRRRR. I've had other "world famous" soup dumplings at a few other restaurants, but nothing compares to the soup dumplings here. The truffle are my favorite but they are all delicious. I love the flavor of the soup and the meat/filling. My other favorite here is the Pork and vegetable wontons in spicy peanut sauce. I can't get enough of it. The peanut sauce is just perfect without being too overwhelming and taking over the whole dish. The soup dumplings and wontons in peanut sauce are definitely must-try's. I also got the jellyfish with turnip cold side dish and the cucumber salad with garlic sauce. Both are very light and refreshing which compliments the carb-y stars of the show (dumplings and wontons). The Michelin guide title of this restuarant is well deserved.

I came here today on a friday afternoon around 1pm for lunch. I was quoted a 40 mins wait for a table of 2, which I didn't mind since I had errands to run. I was given a number and by the time I came back, the hostess said only 2 tables were ahead of us. Within 5 mins of waiting, our table was ready. We were led upstairs. The decor and ambience definitely improved from it's old location. Much cleaner and modern looking. What we ordered? Lucky 6 dumplings- definitely very appealing, ig worthy and colorful. In terms of flavor, perhaps the black truffle was my favorite. Everything else tasted the same to me.Pork and vegetable wontons in spicy peanut sauce- this was actually very good. The wontons were very plump and meaty. The sauce wasn't spicy at all. Good thing they had chili oil on the side.Salted soy milk- i loved this! Mixed with pickled veggies, anchovies, fried dough... I could eat 2 bowls of this! I only wished I had the fried dough to dunk in it instead but they said they ran out for the day. Crab meat and pork soup dumplings- can't go wrong with this.The only thing that I would say that's different is that the texture of the dumpling skin was rather thick. I did notice that the dumpling was filled with lots of broth so maybe they had to make the skin thicker to hold the liquid? I personally prefer the dimpling skin to be thinner. The food also took awhile to come out and they forgot about our last order of the crab meat and pork dumplings. It was not until we asked about it and then it finally came.  I also didn't like that the tables were so close to each other as I could hear other peoples conversations and vice versa.

Highly Anticipated... NanXiang XLB is BACKKK. The new location is only a few steps away. Came for the soft opening and was not surprised by the line (but only had to wait about 15mins for a table for 3).The food... A. The XLB's got an upgrade. There are more filling options now (black truffle oooooh) you can choose. There is also a sampler, where you get 6 diff fillings (original, crab, black truffle, gourd, chicken (mine had wasabi in it), and fois gras (limited ed). The fillings all tasted good; the original tasted "cleaner/fresher" if that makes any sense; BUT the skin was a tad bit thicker (maybe its due to the new chefs wrapping it in the showcase). The scallion pancake and the shanghai udon noodles tasted exactly the same. I was told its the same chef from the OG place. yay!The service... A+. This is where things changed LOL maybe its the small break the waitstaff received or more pay, but danggggg everyone was so chipper and happy! all i saw were smile and heard laughter lol it was kind of different from what i was used to hahah these ppl were happy to be there and it shows!im happy NanXiang is back. With this revamp and update, i feel like they will be the... dare i say... DTF of NY hahah!

It's not like the good old place.  We went during the peak hr around 7:30pm on a Saturday time.  Line was out of the door.  We waited over 45 mins and got seated.  We are believer in waiting makes the food taste better.  Unfortunately, it was a huge disappointment.  The Scallion noodle tasted very bland.  We ordered the crab meat dumpling and a varieties dumpling which included 6 different flavors of dumplings.  The crab meat dumpling was average but the "6 diff flavored dumplings" all tasted alike, not thing special. The soybean milk tastes very watering. Did the original chefs quit during the transfer of location?Never ever go back this this place again.

They closed for awhile,And finally open again, so I decide to go there from BK.We went there on Saturday around 3:30 pm, still need about 30-40 mins wait, but you can leave your # and they will call you when your table is ready. So we put our number and went out to get some drinks. And they calls us after 45 mins.Steamed lucky 6 soup dumplings include signature, crab meat& pork, black truffle, Chinese squash, chicken and four gras (seasonal limited)All the soup dumpling has lots of soup in it. Taste really really good. But out top favorite one was chicken one. The chicken broth was really rich in flavor. Highly recommend!For appetizer we got pressed tofu with Chinese celery and husband and wife special. Both taste really good, and not too oily. Pan fried pork bun: we were little bit disappointed . The dough was too thick. And bit dry. Scallion pancake with sliced beef.Very crispy scallion pancake, but the beef was bit too thin. But still taste good.Over all the quality was good, the service was good. And their soup dumpling taste amazing. Definitely worth to wait and try!

Solid five stars for the new location! Shiny new space, friendly attentive waiters, and the same delicious food but in a better setting. My husband and I wanted to check out the grand opening soft launch on a Friday night at 6:30. We waited about an hour for a table of two. Luckily there is ample waiting space after you get your ticket with a number. you'll have to wait there as they won't text you. Don't be an amateur- check out the menu as you wait and figure out your order.Once we got seated at a spacious booth for four, we ordered immediately. Black agaric mushrooms, beef tendons, sliced pig ears for a few cold starters. All flavored well and not salty! Then of course, the very instagrammable Lucky Six: truffle, chicken, foie gras (fattened duck liver), crab meat, squash, regular. All had pork in it and were good, but not better than the regular soup dumplings! We would however go back for six of the truffle ones. The others were good, plenty of the same yummy broth in each dumpling, but the flavors could have been pronounced.We also got the oh so perfect scallion pancake with beef and crunchy noodles with pork. The sweet manager looked worried and asked if we were ordering for two?? When she saw that we finished, she said she was very impressed lmao!Overall worth the wait and immensely glad the food is on par with the old location, and that prices didn't shoot up either. (At the old nan xiang, the staff weren't mean, but they weren't nice. And we always felt rushed to pay when we were still finishing. We didn't feel that at new nan xiang, whew!)They'll definitely give Shanghai You Garden and Joe's Shanghai a run for the money again. Welcome back to the neighborhood, nan Xiang!

Nan Xiang reopened at corner of 39 ave and Prince Street. ( less then 200 feets from old closed location).  It's a soft opening and their menu increased to more varieties of Xiao long Bao ( soup dumplings). It is still very good by Flushing nyc standards.
