I felt they trying go toward the Din Tai Fung level now but almost as good. The skin on the Bao was ok not as thin as Din tai fung but bigger and more filling. Service was good but long wait as expected.   Xiao long Bao is worth 4 stars but had a drunken wine chicken to go and it was super dry and chewy. Definitely not prepare right. I had to take a star away for their poor preparation of this chicken.The chicken is going to trash.No credit card yet in soft opening See photos and click helpful

Had an overwhelming craving for soup dumplings one fateful weekend and we're sure glad we decided to come to Nan Xiang. We visited their previous location just up the block when they were still running the business out of a modest, run down shack. They're classy now - the newly renovated restaurant is spacious and much more luxurious . Their interior vaguely reminds me of Din Tai Fung in California as you can observe the employees making soup dumplings in an open kitchen on the second floor. There was a ridiculous line when we arrived and we waited for close to an hour for a party of 2. It was well worth it though. We ordered 2 appetizers including the spicy pig ears and jelly fish which funnily tasted better when combined as opposed to separately. We also ordered three orders of soup dumplings: 2 of the pork and crab and 1 of the lucky 6 which includes, you guessed it, 6 different varieties of soup dumpling flavors. I believe the flavors are on rotation (?) and the ones we ordered included: chicken, squash, truffle pork, crab, and foie Gras. Each was tasty and unique in its own way, and I enjoyed all of the ones I tried.Each order came with 6 dumplings and my oh my they were possibly some of the best I've had in NYC. I thought the taste and quality rivaled that of Joes Shanghai although honestly in terms of value I think Joes Shanghai still has them beat.The service is the reason I docked one star - we received our food pretty quickly however the water refill was spotty and I gave up on our waiter when they failed to deliver on water refills after our meal already ended.

Probably the best soup dumplings I've had thus far and the prices were very reasonable. When I think of soup, I think of overflowing of yummy goodness- that is the dumplings here. Definitely will be back when I'm flushing. Parking was quick - theres a municipal lot right across the way with $2.50/hr spots.

I heard good things about the XLB and their lucky six basket looked o so pretty. Nan Xiang is in their soft opening phase and the menu has a decent selection of XLB, noodles, hot and cold appetizers. We ordered jellyfish, scallion pancake with beef slices, sticky rice shumai, and pan fried steam buns for appetizers and 4 baskets - truffle, chicken soup, pork, and lucky 6.The jellyfish and turnip cold dish was heavier on the turnip than jellyfish and had a taste I couldn't quite pinpoint.The scallion pancake with beef slices was one of the better dishes we tried. The pancake was crisp and not heavy or oily with a tangy hoison sauce in and on the side.The sticky rice shumai were savory and soy saucy and very similar to the rice wrapped in lotus leaves you'd find at dim sum. The pan fried steam buns were fluffy and the bun wasn't too thick with a good bun to pork ratio.Now onto the xiao long bao -- they were just okay. They were good, but pretty average. The soup was plentiful and the meat savory. Unfortunately, the flavors weren't distinctive enough from each other except the chicken soup dumplings which were lighter and slightly gingery in taste.

Best soup dumplings in NYC! Called and made a reservations a few days in advance. Glad we did because there were a lot of people waiting when we got there around 12:30 on a Sunday. It's a large restaurant with lots of natural light. Very clean. We tried 4 types of soup dumplings: pork, pork and crab, squash, and truffle. They were all excellent - the pork was lean but juicy, perfectly prepared. The pork and crab had a strong crab flavor - much better than pork and crab soup dumplings I've had elsewhere. The squash was great, with shrimp and pork in it, and very unique, served in green wrappings. The truffle were my lea at favorite, but I don't really like truffle flavor. We also had pan fried pork buns which were perfectly prepared and juicy, great steamed vegetable dumplings, chive pancake, scallion pancake with beef - the best I've ever ha, fresh tasting and flaky, crispy noodles with vegetables, cucumber, and tofu with mushrooms. Can't wait to go back and try more!!

Went here with 3 friends. I have not been to Nan Xiang since the last location across the street closed down.Well this new location is much cleaner, it's very nice with an upstairs dining room and a bigger downstairs waiting area. All waitstaff is equipped with an iPad for taking orders and all the food came out in a timely fashion.I ordered the variety xiao long bao since I wanted to try some new flavors. I had the scallop, the chicken and the veggie. My favorite was the chicken one. The soup in all of them was pretty good. We also shared the scallion beef pancake sandwiches which were perfectly crispy and flavorful and not soggy at all like other places.We also shared the crispy noodle with seafood which was pretty good. All the seafood was cooked very well maybe just a tad bit oily for my taste but everyone else were happy.I was also happy since I checked in and they gave me a small rat for the chinese new year that you could stick on your window. It was very cute! I will be back! Happy Lunar New Year!
Tasty food as always! The soup inside the Xiao long bao warms my heart! It even taste amazing in take out.

The best meal I've had in a while. Absolutely incredible. From the services to the food this place is awesome. I found this place on yelp and couldn't believe the good reviews it received. When we got there the line was huge so you'll probably always be waiting a little for a table but they are fast so don't worry. The dining room was large with booths as well as shared seating.My dad and I ordered the pork and crab steamed dumplings. They were delicious! We also ordered the cucumber salad which was perfectly fresh, crunchy and had so much flavor to it.We ordered the noodles which were I think the best noodles I have ever tasted and I've had a lot of noodles in my life haha. You have to order these! Everything about them was fantastic. Lastly we ordered the pancake with beef and it was ok. I would definitely not order this again but it was still good just not as amazing as the other dishes we ordered.

I found this wonderful spot on my last adventures out to queens, New York. Coming from Texas there isnt too much of an opportunity to try soup dumplings since they are only carried at particular places. It seems there is an abundance out in New York though especially out in queens, I stumbled in on a rainy afternoon midday for a snack. And per the reviews this place has been around for awhile, they even have some awards for the last 5 years by that famous Michelin man. So this is the place to be for soup dumplings! I went on a Tuesday afternoon so it wasn't too packed yet, I do forewarn you though if you are spending less then $30 to bring cash. This was a mistake that I made after ordering the variety of different colored soup dumplings came to realize. The colors I believe of the soup dumplings are nothing but mere show to indicate what type of stuffing is inside. My favorite had to be the original pork and most of the other meat offerings or vegetable offerings tasted the same to me. I was so pleased with service and the soup dumplings we went back on Saturday the following week with  my family. Be sure if you are going on Saturday to show up early if your party is larger then 6. It's about an hour wait but well worth it!

Nan Xiang has been on my list for years! This past weekend, I finally got to try it (at the new location) and was not disappointed. To start, the new location is huge and awesome. The place is very clean and the decor is authentic. Upon arrival, you get a number a wait. Wait time for 2 on Saturday night during the Lunar New Year celebration was only about 15-20 mins. Once we were seated and placed our order, in just minutes we were served our first dish and the rest to follow. All dishes came out timed perfectly, so that nothing got cold. The serving staff was also very pleasant and helpful. For our meal, we ordered:Crab Meat & Pork Soup Dumplings (6)Lucky Six Soup Dumplings (6)Pan Fried Crispy Noodle w. Shredded ChickenHandmade Steamed Pork & Cabbage Dumplings(8)Everything was incredible and tasted just like the dishes we had in Shanghai. This place is perfect and I can't wait to go back!

Meh. I've experienced better. 1. Crab pork dumpling: crab was very lacking.  It was a small dot of crab on the pork filling.  Didn't really taste much crab.  The pork filling itself was lacking in flavor. Shanghai Yu Garden makes this much better. 2. Beef tripe: Chewy and dry. Lacking sauce and flavor. Zero3. Red oil bamboo: I always had this dish here and it was really good.  This time in the new location it was dry and red oil had no taste. Not spicy. Zero4. Scallion pancake: deep fried, that itself gets a zero. Should have been griddled on light oil.  It was so unpleasant to eat.  so oily.   5. Chive Pocket: also deep fried like empanada. Oily oily oily.  zero.6. salty soy sauce: it's not salty and very lacking. ZeroI do not recommend this place.  Not going again.

I remember being so sad when I found out the original location was under renovation and later closed down for good. I seriously thought I was never going to find a place like this again. So you can imagine my surprise when I found out that the restaurant didn't close and only moved down the block. Whew.. thank god!The new restaurant is ten times better than it's predecessor. It's bigger, cleaner, and wayyy more spacious. The interior and decorations are mind-blowing. Literally a scene(ry) out of an ancient Chinese drama. The food is also way more delicious than I remembered. The Signature Pork Soup Dumplings and the Pan Fried Dumplings are moist and juicy and the meat juices just ooze out of the dumplings at the very first bite. Be careful though, the dumplings can get quite hot!!

The noodle and the dumplings taste great. I like the crispy texture of the noodle. The dumplings were fill with crab and pork. It is juicy with soap inside. Being fill with crab  was tasty and fresh. The pork dumpling has soaps being in your mouth to feel the quality of the dumpling. The service was great

Nan Xiang is perhaps the best traditional Chinese breakfast/brunch sit-down spot (that offers friendly and efficient service) in Flushing.  Most dishes are done well. Some of my favorites are Soy milk with crispy dough (light crispy kind, not the non-crispy super doughy choking you to death kind), scallion pancake with sliced beef, crab meat/pork soup dumplings, crispy shredded turnip (sold out the last 2 times I was there for lunch), fried rice cakes, noodles with scallion sauce. Even after the location upgrade, the prices are still relatively affordable comparing to new restaurants in flushing.  There's a huge improvement to the prior location in turns of decor, seating comfort, cleanliness and customer service. Expect a wait during peak hours - 3 of us waited 40 mins on a Sunday around 12pm.

Very happy I tried out this place for dumplings. Loved the pork dumplings. My friend got the Lucky Six soup dumplings,so she was able to try out all of the flavors. Truffle was her favorite by far. Cucumber salad was very refreshing. Scallion pancake was delicious. We were very happy with the quick service. Only had to wait for about 15 minutes for our table and we got there around 6pm. Clean dining area. Would recommend.

We were so sad when they closed and so excited when we heard they had reopened. We visited with my parents who loved the original restaurant. First the restaurant is much classier than the last place. It is nicely decorated with lots of light from the large windows. The servers are no longer surly ladies with a pad and pen but friendly people with an iPad taking your order. The price has gone up but the food is still excellent. The Xiao Long Bao is just as tasty now as it was then. The meat is flavorful and the soup overflows if you try to pour it out on the spoon. The other dishes are just as good. The scallion pancakes are big and crispy. The salty soybean milk is still authentic. The sweet soy milk is subtly sweet. Overall the quality is still good and I am grateful for that.

This is a wonderful dumpling place. Can't go wrong ordering scallion pancakes and any type of dumpling. Warm, fresh, and steaming! The tea is refilled which is a nice added bonus! Def must go if in Flushing area

Unfortunately I never got to try the soup dumplings at the OG location of Nan Xiang, but I was happy for them when they moved to a much more spacious location down the street. These new digs with its open kitchen providing a glimpse of soup dumplings coming to life resembles a Din Tai Fung, a far cry from the humble beginnings of Nan Xiang.The seating process was pretty straightforward, with a quoted time depending on the party size. The 30 minute wait for a party of two was pretty much on the money, and since a menu was provided during our wait we were ready to order as soon as we were seated.Starting with the soup dumplings, the flavor was pretty good but the dough was a bit too thick. Anyone who has soup dumplings before knows there is a risk of spillage due to the thinness of the dumpling skin - a thick skin minimizes such accidents, but at the ultimate expense of the dumpling skin. While the crab meat and pork dumplings were great, I would not recommend the Chinese squash dumpling on the account of both taste and texture. As for other dishes, I quite enjoyed the pan fried pork buns, beef tendon in chili oil, and pan fried crispy noodle with seafood. I should also note that service was a bit frantic, which probably lead to a couple dishes not making their way to our table without pointing it out to a server. I would chalk it up to growing pains after the move to this new location, so hopefully these issues sort themselves out after a few weeks.

Upscale Shanghai style dumpling & noodle spot. This is a restaurant, not a stand, but they also don't serve any hot meat or vegetable dishes. However, there are several cold meat dishes - and they're great.Our party of four had a tasty meal on New Year's Day 2020. Cold dishes: beef tendon in chili, poached chicken, cucumbers in garlic sauce. Hot dishes: xiao long bao, pork with snow cabbage noodle soup, 3-meat fried nian gao. Service was very nice. We all agreed that all the food was delicious. The xiao bao not so hot they burn your mouth but heated enough to be flavorful, and full of tasty soup. Nian gao and noodle soup were also awesome. We loved the flavorful noodle soup broth! But interestingly enough, my personal favorites were the cucumber salad and beef tendon. A plus: the bathrooms were nice and clean. Plus 2: The space is nicely decoratedA little challenge: Dining room is on the second floor. But there is a personal elevator that can be put into service for a diner who needs it. A big challenge: by the time we arrived at 5pm, along with the rest of Queens, the wait for a table was 40 minutes long. Note to self: next NYD go early!This place serves Shanghai breakfast too, which is a rare find in NYC. I look forward to an early-in-the-day visit to give it a try.

I flew into New York on a Sunday afternoon last month and decided to get some dumplings on my way from the airport to visiting friends in Queens. I remembered enjoying Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao a few years ago, and figured it'd be a good place to grab a quick solo lunch. I was surprised to find a long wait when I showed up just before 3:00. I'd apparently stumbled on its grand reopening in a new location after a closure of several months. I ended up waiting about a half hour for a seat, but I was happy to get my soup dumpling fix.The place was big and attractive, a considerable upgrade from the old location, which I think was much smaller and homier. The restaurant was slammed, but I thought the crowd was well managed, and I found the staff very nice and welcoming. Service was fast, but not at all brusque. My only gripe is that the restaurant was cash only, with no ATM on the premises. I had enough luggage that I didn't feel like rolling to a bank, so I made do with the $20 I had in my wallet.This limited my options somewhat, but thankfully $20 was enough to cover two orders of dumplings with a 20% tip. I got all soup dumplings, one order each of the pork and the pork and crab. (I wanted to try the sheng jian bao, but there was like a half-hour wait for them anyway. Next time.) Both were delicious. The soup was piping hot, but I managed not to scald myself, and it went down beautifully. The meat was juicy, and the dumpling skins were great, on the thicker side, up to the task of containing all that melty pork.It'll probably be another few years before I make it back to Flushing, but when I do, I'd like to revisit Nan Xiang with more money in my pocket and maybe a friend or two to help me take down more of the menu. I'd recommend it if you're craving dumplings. The place is fun and bustling, and the xiao long bao are delicious.

Finally made my way to flushing with my friend from out of town and knew we had to stop here. First, our hearts broke because we thought it was closed.....until we looked down the street and noticed the new location. It was about 2pm on a saturday, we put our name down (for 2) and were told an hour and a half to 2 hours so we went to some other shops nearby to kill time. We came back after about an hour and our number had already been called, so just a warning to everyone, those times could be well above what they turn out to be. The hostess was kind enough to still seat us! The seating area was nice and open, with big windows and lots of room. You can also watch the chefs prepare the dumplings which was a great touch. We ordered about 5 or 6 dishes and they came out staggered. We of course tried to wait for all of the dishes so we could get a beautiful picture for yelp...this was a challenge and I dont suggest it at a dim sum place. The bottomless tea was greatThe cold cucumber salad was delicious, the scallion pancake with beef was mouthwatering, wasnt a huge fan of the shanghai shumai but thats just personal taste, the dumplings were delish. But one sad thing happened on this day....our soup dumplings NEVER came. Turns out an alarm in the kitchen went off and they had to hold off on cooking. I will say this, the alarm went off in the restaurant and NO ONE got up, would you get up for an alarm after waiting almost 2 hours for a table?? Our waiter was so kind to bring us more cold salads while we waited to see if they could cook, but it never happened. We did get to try the tofu cold salad and it was DELISH. Why one less star? My tea. I ended up getting hair in my tea cup, not my hair and definitely not from the tea leaves. And sometimes our waiter disappeared for awhile which slowed down our ordering. That being said, I'm ready to go back and finally get to try the soup dumplings.

When I found out Nan Xiang reopened, I already knew this place was the FIRST on my list when I land in New York and so I held in my hunger... Sat through the pain... And the rest? Well, that's history!After coming across the multicolored XLBs on my friends' social media... I couldn't help but to get my friend and myself some of these too! Out of the six, I knew I had to go for the black truffle, as I am a sucker for truffle myself :-) (and no regrets!)East Coast to West Coast Tip:As someone who's moved to the west coast recently, and has only had DIN TAI FUNG all the freaking time, sorry Din Tai Fung but please move out of the way! You can't compare this place to DTF especially price and quality-wise! Yes, the XLBs are larger but there's definitely more soup in Nan Xiang's than DTF. That already beats it. Plus, the portion to price ratio is awesome.Ambience: The new location definitely speaks for itself! It's wonderfully rebuilt and the location is only half a block away from the old restaurant! Well, that's convenient. The restaurant isn't too loud and is perfect for family or friends get-together for a simple dinner. Luckily my friend and I didn't have to wait so that was a great start to our dinner.Food: Firstly, it is amazing. We started with the scallion pancakes (as it has been our go-to since a long time ago) and it's something I cannot have elsewhere. The beef is so soft and the crispiness from the pancakes compliments it so well. Then the sauce... Yup, no words. The braised beef noodle soup is so perfect for cold weather!! The only issue I had with it is that the noodles felt like it's been sitting there for too long.. a little too soft for my taste. The soup may be bland to many, but it was perfect for me -- warm and hearty! And then the XLBs... From the Lucky Six multicolored, the black truffle was my favourite! Since I shared with my friend I can only speak from the black truffle, green squash, and the chicken. The squash one you cannot really taste the veggie until the end, and the chicken just tastes like a normal pork xlb. The black truffle is just amazing... I can have one whole plate for myself, ty. Good quality food, and fair price. Definitely worth it!Service: Since it's busy, the servers are always up and running around. However there's always someone coming around to refill your cup of tea, which is the best thing for me. I dearly missed you Nan Xiang, and now I'm back! Aaaand... I will be back... You already know it. Until next time I come back from California :-)

I have been coming here since this place Was literally  a hole in the wall (10 years ago) so I know their product and food  very well. They closed down the old shop and set up a newly renovated restaurant a block down on the corner of Prince street.What to say ? Hmm.. here goes:Service and decor- a lot of fancier and the service is more efficient ( they still have the 3 ladies rolling up out the soup dumplings with a window to view). Food came out fast and there were no issues with wrong food being being served to the wrong table (the old restaurant had That issue in my experience)Food quality - the restaurant is pretty much known for their soup dumpling so why else would you go there is you're not having that .. their noodles are good asWell as some of their hot and cold appetizers ( see my posted pic). Compared to the old restaurant, didn't see negative change in food quality so that is good news as I have been in other restaurants where they renovated and moved,  but the food quality went downhill afterwards.price - well as you know, restaurant renovations don't come cheap so the new restaurant will be is a little more expensive than what we previously  had paid in their old restaurant. I would say that the Menu price went up roughly a dollar or so on average. Wait time - we came in on a weekend around 11:45 AM and it was packed due to the restaurant's popularity with the locals and with the tourist. From when we got our number to be call to when we actually got seated, the wait time was roughly a solid 45 minutes. Overall, I would give this place a solid 4/5 stars. Only reason why 4 stars is there I actually had a better XLB elsewhere .. Shissh... suppose to be a secret ..
I came here for the chocolate soup dumplings and they were really something . A great take on Chinese dim sum . I also had the wontons with hot chilly sauce but deff enjoyed the chocolate ones more

I was in search of some great food places in the Flushing area and came across this place through Yelp. I had done research the past few days and since I was in the area, we decided to give it a go -- I'm pretty glad I did!We were shopping at the Skyview Center and saw it was just a block away, so we went for it! Upon walking in, it looked pretty busy and we grabbed a number, table for 2! I'm guessing other parties were a bit larger, as we only waited about 10-15 mins. The service goes by pretty quickly.Here's my review on the food:Signature pork XLB: you can't go wrong with the classic XLB, however if you're a seafood person (like me), just go for the crab & pork XLB!Crab & pork XLB: YAAASSS. Juicy & tender crab and pork filling, drizzle a little soy sauce & chili oil over the top... *droooooling*Shanghai pan fried udon: I was a little skeptical as the description says "shredded pork" but they just mean thin sliced pork. We gave it a try as it was on the picture side of the menu, and I was so glad we did! This was def a 10/10 for me. The noodle weren't super soft but I didn't mind the texture! I really enjoyed the bok choy & pork with the flavor and seasoning of the noodles.Chicken herbal soup: your typical chicken soup, looks really fresh and the flavor was good! It was a good side dish to finish our dinner.Cold sweet soy milk: it was nothing special about their soy milk, tasted like all the other soy milk drinks I've tried at other asian restaurants. Still good though!Wonton tossed in chili oil & peanut sauce: a big NO for me. My boyfriend ordered it and when it came, it wreaked of peanut. He then realized we overlooked the description saying it had peanut in it. We're not allergic, but I'm not a big fan of peanut in my savory foods. I made a comment to the waiter that we didn't like it (my boyfriend tried just one) in hopes they might take it away and off our bill, but nope.. no biggie though, it was our fault for not reading carefully. Lucky 6 dumplings: Ehhhh.. I'd pass on ordering this again. I guess it's okay to order if it's your first time for the pictures but overall, I wasn't a big fan of the tastes. I'll stick to my crab dumplings. Love the color of the skins though.Overall, we spent $75 including tip. We definitely over ordered but I brought the remaining dumplings I didn't finish and had it as a late night snack! I would definitely come again but keep my ordering to a minimum.

I haven't been making it out to Flushing as much as I would like to, but the reopening of Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao may change that for me. When I came here recently, it was worth every minute spent riding the 7 train across town. Make sure to get there a bit earlier than you plan to eat so you can put your name down and then maybe grab milk tea or something nearby. The dish they're most known for, Xiao Long Bao, is done better here than anywhere else I can find in NYC. Don't let this trick you into ordering only XLB though, as many of their other dishes are also delicious. Their husband and wife special and pan friend noodles were both absolutely delicious as well.

We came here specifically for the colorful dumplings. The wait was around 30 minutes on a Tuesday night .. I guess because it just recently open. The food is average and the staff were just rude. They gave us the wrong food and didn't change it upon our request. Overall experience 5/10

have heard many great things about this place (pre and post tax evasion shut down LOL) and i finally got to try them out on Thanksgiving day (bless chinese people for opening their doors at all times). We were queued to wait and seated within 20 min. The six color XLB is beautiful and a great way to sample all the types they had. i preferred their crab meat + pork dumpling over the signature pork-only dumpling. Squash was yummy too.their crispy bottom bao could've been crispier on the bottom but the meat was flavorful and not tough. occasionally service was spotty (forgetting to serve water) but otherwise they were quick. cash only still lolplenty of seating! will definitely have to come back. reminds me of a less sterile din tai fung haha

I have heard many great things about this place, and wanted to check out the food here for myself. The ambience is casual and family-friendly. I ordered the jelly fish salad, lucky six soup dumplings (Signature + Crab Meat & Pork + Black Truffle + Chinese Squash + Scallop) and the original soup dumplings. There were a lot of soup broth inside the dumplings, and the broth was very flavorful. The only downside about this place is the service. Since they are famous and so crowded, it took me a while to be able to order the food, and the waitress totally forgot about bringing out the jelly fish salad if I didn't remind her several times. I highly recommend trying the soup dumplings here but make sure you come before 10 am. When I left the restaurant, there was a long line waiting outside even in the cold.

I remember the old spot, was so crushed when they shut down. The new spot is ten times better now, they accept credit cards which is nice. More tables and seats, more staff, larger kitchen, they get you in and out and have a good flow.  The wait wasn't bad at all.  Service was stellar and on point, took the baby with us and they were very helpful and had high chairs.  Food was amazing, we over ordered but didn't regret it at all.  Got every kind of dumplings (pork, crab and pork, assorted) and our go to dishes, beef tendon in spicy oil, scallion pancakes with sliced beef, beef fried udon noodles.Our drinks were filled at least 8 times by the end of our meal. They came by and kept the table spectacularly clean, even with our kid making a mess.  Food was amazing, again; stuffed to the point I could not move and still wanted more.

Updated review for Nan Xiang 2.0. What can I say? I was a tad bit worried when I stepped in. Have been a patron of the original place for over a decade, I was hoping that this place wasn't just Nan Xiang in name only. The decor is completely different. Gives off a Din Tai Fung feel mixed with your typical newer Chinese restaurant that's trying very hard to remind you that you're in a Chinese restaurant with all the Asian decorations and design. The service has stepped a lot since the old place. Even though we got in right before they were set to close shop, they sat us down and served us. The service quick and not pushy. (Side note: it was nice to see some of the original servers working in the new place. I didn't know them personally nor did I have any attachments to them but I did feel bad when the old shop closed and people lost their jobs. So yea it was nice to see that they're back.)Now for the food! First of all the tea was served in the perfect temperature. Not boiling hot and not room temp or cold. Just perfect. We ordered some of our usuals from the old spot: Cucumber Salad with Garlic Sauce, Noodles with Beef and Shredded Pepper (dried), Braised Beef Noodle Soup, and of course a stack of the Pork Soup Dumplings. The Cucumber and Braised Beef Noodles were just like I remembered if not better. They included 5-6 giant chunks of beef with my order and I was actually done with the noodles before I finished the beef. Fantastic!The Noodles with Beef and Shredded Pepper now includes scallions and scallion oil like the Scallion Noodles. My wife loved the upgrade! Another win!Now finally, the soup dumplings. The skin (dough) is thicker than I remember. It isn't as tender as it used to be but it actually held together a lot better than the older version. (I remember breaking 3 out of 6 dumplings back then no matter how careful I was and it always made me sad.) The thicker skin held the soup inside the dumplings better but I did enjoy eating the older version better. It's not a total fail nor is it a win for me on this point. It was kind of a trade off. The flavor is still there but not quite as rich as it was before either. Overall I really enjoyed our meal tonight. I am happy that Nan Xiang has made a glorious return to Flushing and I hope they keep up the good work in the future. This is a 4.5 star review from me and I look forward to returning again and again until I am a ripe old man.

Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao used to be a place where our family would often go when our parents visited us in NY. As a Shanghainese family, there's a lot of comfort in eating the food that we were so familiar with, and the taste and price were both excellent. It was sad to hear that they had closed, so when we heard that they were reopening, we knew we had to stop by.The trip itself started off rather strangely. We walked in through the back door, which had no sign indicating that it was the back door. At first we were quite surprised that it seemed pretty empty but then walked to the front of the restaurant and realized that there was a huge number of people waiting. We got our number and was told 20-30 minutes (this is on a Sunday afternoon around 3 PM). Since we were already here, we figured we'd just wait since it didn't sound like a terrible wait. We ended up waiting exactly 30 minutes for our table to open up.The whole experience felt very rushed. We were given dirty chopsticks and tea that was lukewarm. The waitress, who was in quite a hurry, even spilled some of the tea as she was serving us. For the three of us, we ended up ordering five dishes.1) Spicy Bamboo Shoots: 3/5 - The flavor was okay, but I do love bamboo. Overall, I think the flavor seemed only okay since it wasn't salty enough.2) Scallion Pancakes with Sliced Beef: 5/5 - Probably my favorite dish that we ordered. The scallion pancakes were perfectly crispy and the sauce to dip it in was a nice touch.3) Rice Cakes with Preserved Cabbage and Pork: 2/5 - This used to be one of my favorite dishes at Nan Xiang. However, again, it was not salty enough and the rice cakes were a little on the softer side than I remembered them to be. I felt like they were much chewier in the past.4) Shanghai Siu Mai: 2/5 - The sticky rice in the siu mai had very little flavor. The skin was also a bit too soft, in my opinion (almost a little soggy). 5) Pork Soup Dumplings: 3/5 - The soup dumplings were good but far from being the best that I've had, either at Nan Xiang themselves or at another restaurant. The skin was way too thick for my taste. Saltiness and flavor-wise, though, this was fine.We also tried to get the Salted Soy Milk but they said they ran out. Also, it said their credit card machine was broken ( unsure if it's always broken or just happened to be broken today ). With all the other options in the Flushing area, probably won't be returning.

I came a week or two after their grand reopening in their new location. So take this all with a grain of salt, since they did just move locations and likely hired a lot of new staff. The new location is super nice, the interior looks kind of like of knock-off Din Tai Fung. They even have the clear window where you can watch the dumplings being made, just like DTF. We came on a Saturday at around 1pm and were told the wait was 30 minutes for a table. The lobby was full of people also waiting  for a table. About 40 minutes later, we were seated and promptly ordered the pork Xiao Long Bao. We tried to order the turnip puffs, but unfortunately they ran out right before we ordered, which we were super bummed about. The XLB came in around 15 minutes, fairly quickly, and looked absolutely beautiful. The ginger that they served with them was super fresh and thinly sliced. It was all set up for success. However, upon consumption, the XLB tasted pretty average to me. They were definitely good, but not deserving of the unbelievable hype I'd heard about this place - everyone told me this was the best XLB in Flushing! Also, the vinegar they provide was weirdly sweet and made for a discomfiting eating experience. Really not a fan of sweet vinegar.After we finished eating, we asked for the check multiple times, and it ended up taking ten minutes to get it due to a seeming lack of coordination. There also seemed to be a lot of people hovering around the waiter station with nothing to do? The place honestly seems overstaffed. However, everyone we interacted with was super nice, and I'm sure that the check issue will be a nonissue further down the line. This place was good, but I feel like I maybe missed its best days when it was a smaller shop. Personally, I preferred the XLB at You Garden.

Affordable price, authentic taste, and great customer service. Nan Xiang checks off all the boxes of a great restaurant. Pros:-great taste -waiters are approachable and ready to help-true to authentic cuisine Cons: -long line -portion size is smaller than I would like-certain side dishes are a little pricey

Still 4 stars for food but 3 for service. Asked for water. Brought 1 cup.  Were the four of us supposed to share it?  Asked for more cups. Silly. Asked for more water and tea twice. No one just came by to pour at our table. Diet Coke never came either. Asked 3 times. It was on the check though. Lol. They took the charge off. Waited longer for our to go noodles than the time it took for us to eat our dinner in. Cannot complain about the food though. The soup dumplings are still the best in the city. And the scallion  pancake with beef is heavenly. It's my 14th time here and of course we will be back.
My daughter took us there once after my vendor's treated there, theirs tastes is even not really like the Shanghai Nan Xiang . But it ok in NY

So happy this place re-opened! The new place is bigger and it's not even a block away from the old location, you can't miss it, its right at the corner. It has two floors, one for waiting and the second one for dining. They renovated the place and upgraded. It's so much nice and cleaner. Servers are much nicer too, seems like they got rid of the rude servers from the old location. The food is still the same tasty and cheap. Soup dumplings are my favorite, they're different than other Chinese restaurants. The scallion pancake, fish cake dish, pan fried noodles are my to go always. The only thing is whenever I go, they don't serve the hot sweet soy milk :(. Overall is a nice atmosphere and the wait is 30-40 mins on the weekends night, regular days there's no wait.

Update 11/2019- RIP original NXXLB! My assumption is that the brand was sold to new business owners, and the old staff was lost. They're really milking their Michelin recommended status from 2009-2017. But I guess there's a reason it was lost in 2018/2019. The soup dumplings are no longer thin and moist with tasty soup - they are thick, dry, tough/chewy and the soup is basically bland. I had to load it with vinegar soy to add the flavor. The crispy noodles were not crispy. They were drenched with sauce and super salty. Decor/aesthetics improved significantly, but the quality decreased significantly as well. I was quoted a 30 minute wait and waited 55 minutes to get seated! Not worth the wait. Overall disappointing as I was actually really excited for their return.

The OG of Soup Dumplings finally reappears in Flushing. Location was upgraded, new menu items added (colorful soup dumpling skin / new fillings) and this is where the positives end. Prices definitely increased ~$2 an item, soup dumpling skin is no longer thin and silky (its tough and thick now) and soup dumplings itself is no longer flavorful as it used to be. Overall a disappointing re-opening. Ps: It was a soft opening today- so hopefully they can rediscover their touch once they fully open!

Northern CA has always been lacking in the XLB game so I definitely wanted to find a great XLB place while visiting family in NY!  I am jealous that they live so close to this place because it is an XLB MECCA.  We visited the newly remodeled location which is pretty spacious, but we still couldn't get a table for our larger party on a Sunday afternoon at 3pm... unless we wanted to wait over an hour which doesn't bode well for hangry hangry people.  Fast forward to 11pm, we were seated in ten minutes.  It was worth the wait!  The XLB wrappers are perfectly thin yet strong enough that none of the abundant delicious soup will leak out.  Pork stuffing was also tasty, both the original and crab flavor.  I do not recommend the variety XLB because the pork overpowers the other flavors.  The cold garlic cucumber salad was also excellent, I definitely taste a secret ingredient puts it above other similar salads.  Nan Xiang, will you come to CA???

I'll tell you what, the xiao long bao (XLB) here ain't joking around. I'll let the pics I took do the talking but the soup in those things - not only are they plentiful and bountiful but they're so flavorful as well. Wow, I was seriously impressed. This might very well be the very best XLB I've had in my life. The Lucky Six that we got was fantastic and allowed us to get a sample of the various flavors they had. The black truffle one has to be my favorite. All the of the items we got were really good actually. We went at 9:30am and there was already a wait of 5 min. By 11am when we left there were hordes of people already waiting. You can tell this place is busy every day and it's easy to see why. If you're ever in Flushing, you need to try this place out just for the XLB alone.

This is the best place to get scallion pancake with beef. You MUST try this! I've been here countless times despite the long wait. Why? Everything that I've had here hits the spot. It's that good. Every dumpling and noodle soup just makes me say "mmmmmmh!" And now that there's a warm (or cool, depending on the season) receiving area for waiting, I would dare come here when the cravings arise.
New location, same great taste. Love the modern Chinese decor. It's definitely a better hangout now. My base is always the scallion pancake with beef - perfectly crispy and chewy.

I'm a sucker for Xiao Long Bao. Ever since I saw the late Anthony Bourdain smash on some on TV. I made a point that I shall try them out and ever since, I am addicted.Which brings us to this place. After shopping around at the Skyview Center Mall. The hubby and I worked up a pretty darn good appetite. We saw a few spots slinging these yummy delicacy, but for some reason, this guy wins.Let's do the food shall we.Beef Tripe:     A bit on the spicier side. These light meaty pieces can definitely destroy a small city. It's that good.White Wine Chicken:     I love this stuff... only thing missing is the liquor and fizzy water. Definitely worth ordering.Fried Udon:     Since the restaurant didn't have any rice for some odd reason. We ended up ordering these guys. Perfect chewy texture on the noodles and the flavors were totally amazing. Definitely a yes if you're looking for carbs to add to the spread.Pork Xiao Long Bao:     These are my new favorite thing in the world. Be careful when eating these because the soup comes out like hot lava. Then dip them in the sauce for a life changing experience.Crab Xiao Long Bao:     Its super interesting. The flavors are super poppy and my hubby favors these over the other. I love the seafoody finish.The restaurant is a typical no none sense spot. You come in, you get seated. Wave at a server and bark your order.I totally enjoyed my dining experience here. Also, dont forget that this is a cash only joint. Also,, their big sign isn't in english. So be on the look out.Thank you so much for reading my review. I hope this helps with your decision making experience. Enjoy your awesome yelptastic day!!

The new place is beautiful.  Clean, spacious.  Service was great, very attentive.  The food was delicious.  Location was great, in the middle of flushing.  A lot of desert places close by for afterwords.  The pricing was inexpensive.  A lot of pros. The parking sucks, but it is close to mass transportation.  The big downside of this place is that it's a cash only place, nearest atm is 2 blocks away.

Food: 5/5I first tried this restaurant when it was 1/3 of its current size. The line/wait can get ridiculous on the weekends but their soup dumplings are one the best I've ever had. This place is called Nan Xiang XLB for a reason. They have pork and crab soup dumplings and both are fantastic. They also offer a bunch of other dishes. I recommend the pan fried udon or the scallion pancake. I'm also a pretty big fan of their cold appetizers. I personally enjoy the spicy tripe and their bean curd. Both are highly recommended.Make sure you order the XLB first. It's made fresh and takes awhile to make it to your table.Service: 4/5I've never had a bad experience here. The service gets a little slow when the place gets packed but that's understandable. The staff members are usually very attentive and accommodating.Ambiance: 3.5/5This place was renovated upon expansion. The place is pretty plain and the tables are awfully close together. Their XLBs make it worth it though.

One of my favorite places in Flushing. Reasonable price and good food.They moved to a new place, everything got upgraded. I kinda miss their original place, where was more simple. Their new types of Xiao long bao were not as good as their traditional ones. I would recommend people just get the regular one or the crab one.DO NOT come during the weekend, it is crazy busy during the weekend. Weekdays were fine.They pour tea to your cups constantly, and it's fast to get your food.

It's always wonderful coming back to our favorite spot for soup dumplings and standard  Shanghai food dishes. Back when they were at their original location, we visited many times and enjoyed the service and quality of the food each time. The soup dumplings are always a hit as they were juicy and filled with delicious scalding broth. Make sure you eat it with care and pair it with some sweet black vinegar. My favorite appetizers are the Wood ear fungus and pickled cucumbers. Both dishes are fresh and vibrant. They definitely prepare your palette for the heavier savory dishes. Do try any of their noodle soups. The Braised beef and pork chop noodle soups are well portioned and perfectly balanced in terms of chew, slurp, tender meat and broth. Though we didn't order it this time, the scallion pancakes and stir fried udon are always a hit with us. On top of everything, they were gracious with my wheelchair bound grandmother and provided adequate wheelchair accessible seating right away.The elevator takes you to the back entrance so if you need seats, make sure you go through the main entrance on the first floor. Thanks for a wonderful meal!
Soup dumplings are a must Beef scallion pancakes And basically anything on the menu. Hits the spot everytime

Waited like an hour for this place on a Sunday just to try their colorful soup dumplings. It was interesting and all of them were pretty good. I like how you can try different flavors but the downside is they don't tell you what color is what... But it's worth a try if it's like 15 min wait. Their braised beef soup noodles is good too!

I'm so excited that my favorite place for soup dumplings has re-opened in a new, bigger location. They also changed their menu to include BLACK TRUFFLE soup dumplings and a delicious Crispy Shredded Turnip Puff. There's always a long line but they turn over tables pretty quickly and it's honestly worth the wait!Service is quick once you get seated. As soon as you place your order, they just keep coming out with your dishes until your table is packed full with everything you just ordered. They also have a breakfast menu that I can't wait to come back and try.Unless you want to just "get it for the 'gram", the Steamed Lucky Six Soup Dumplings is not worth it. Save a few bucks and just get the Signature or Crab Meat & Pork Dumplings instead.

We do enjoy good dim sum every now and then. Some say you must travel to Flushing to get even better price, more dish offerings, and more authentic dishes. The inside was not too big but not too small either. You could see into a part of their kitchen with staffs preparing steamed dim sum dishes. A staff brought us complimentary hot teas as soon as we were seated. They were quite efficient, well, maybe too efficient... Within a few minutes of us sitting down, they came and asked if we are ready to order. Wow! And, the food came out SUPER fast! We had Steamed Pork Buns, Scallion Pancake, and Cucumber & Garlic. I really liked the pork buns, which was more like soup dumplings. Scallion pancake was very fresh with nice crispy-ness to it. Simple flavor that was very comforting. Cucumber & Garlic was super refreshing, and gave a nice balance between more meaty and oily dishes. We added one more dish, Pan Fried Dumplings. They were nice fat babies, had real weight too it! They were super meaty and juicy, almost as juicy as soup dumpling. The portion is generous and we were very full. The staffs were not overly friendly, but again, very efficient. They kept the complimentary hot tea refills coming, without us asking for it. The food was very tasty, and very affordable too. They are CASH ONLY so make sure to bring cash!

I was excited to hear that nanxiang xlb was opened again for business as they had the best xlb in town. If there were 2 words to describe my experience it would be underwhelming & disappointing. It was as if I were eating an amateur's work, the top of the xlb were so thick I can barely taste the contents. They did a great job with the aesthetic makeover but they have executed poorly on getting the right staff.

3.5/5 based on my first visit during their soft opening.We are 2, ordered iced soy milk 5/5 （冰豆浆）, sticky rice shumai 3/5 (糯米烧卖), crab row soup dumpling 3.5/5 (蟹黄小笼包), hot soy milk 热豆浆 (out of stock at ..11:30 am...so we get a little for free), Fried dough stick 2/5 (油条) and pan fried beef stickers (牛肉锅贴) 1/5 and Drunken chicken 4.5/5. For free items: tea 0/5 (PLEASE CHANGE TEA SUPPLY), Chili paste on the table 5/5.I wanted order salty black rice roll (咸紫米饭团) from the menu, but they didnt have it, they also didnt have all kinds of noodles, otherwise I wanted try their scallion oil dry noodles (葱油拌面). I really like their iced soy milk, it is the best one I ve had so far. I like their chili paste but there is no dish on the menu is a good match with it... I hope I can steal some then go to buy a pork and egg steamed rice roll (广东早餐肉蛋肠粉)to eat with it. I am not a soup dumpling fan, they have crab meat and row in the dumpling but I just dont think the taste is good, I like their soup dumpling skin though, I also had soup dumpling from another famous Shanghai restaurant "Shanghai You Garden" in Flushing, theirs are worse, I dont get it why I can taste out strong white pepper inside. I asked my BF, he think the crab row soup dumplings we had here are pretty good. I doubt and asked again, he said Cant I have my own opinon, I think they were ok but it was not worthy for the wait. (We only waited 20 minutes, that is nothing for me.) Ok for soup dumplings, My comment is ...There are a thousand Hamlets in a thousand people's eyes!Be careful their beef stickers, especially you are expecting the beef stickers from Nanjing (七家湾牛肉锅贴). their beef stickers skins were not cooked done, I bite and saw the raw dough layer. ahhhhh. anyway, it is a good place you can have many different dishes with small portion for breakfast or lunch if you like Shanghai food style, their menu is simple so it is friendly to Non-Chinese, no dish is hard to understand.

We were staying in Flushing last week for 6 days and ate at this restaurant 4 times! What awesome XLB in all different flavors! Perfectly juicy contents and larger than your typical soup dumplings. On our most recent visit, we had party of 9 on a bustling Friday night. Waited about 40 minutes to be seated. The wait staff were efficient, responsive and professional. The restaurant interior was clean and well maintained. We loved the Nan Xiang Soup Buns, the Crab & Pork Soup Buns and the Lucky Six (photo)! The handmade pork/cabbage dumplings were as pretty as they were delicious (photo). Our group kept adding additional orders of the scallion pancake with beef... although I thought it was a bit greasy. Next, the puff pastries were simply heavenly -- red bean puff and turnip ham puffs were made by expert hands!  These particular dishes were my favorites -- any one of these would be enough to bring me back! We had several other dishes that were also very well crafted and very tasty... Overall a great foodie experience!

[this place recently re-opened right by their previous location] I love xiao long bao a lot and oftentimes, when they're in the Upper East Side locations, it's hard finding them for cheaper and good quality prices? Anyways - this place is one of my favorite xiao long bao places. I've been going to them since I was in high school (I'm in college now!!) and they've kept their consistency with quality. I always enjoy coming here because their service is fast and the people are always polite. Since I have a large family, we ordered a few dishes (see below). Try it out for yourself!!

This place used to be better imo and i am bias to joe's shanghai dumplings--so fair warning before reading my review. Of course you still need to order the xiao long bao here. If you come here and don't order them you're doing yourself a disservice lol. The dumplings are good if you like less fatty soup and thinner skin. It also only comes with 6 i believe vs 8 at joe's shanghai. For me, these dumplings are not filling i need like 2 orders by myself honestly. We also ordered jellyfish, fried bun with chives, rice cake with shredded pork and shanghai noodles. The jellyfish was fine, nothing special but nothing bad to say, comes with turnip/white radish? The fried bun with chives my bf's cousin ordered. This was interesting had cut up noodles in it and i love chives but it didn't wow me. On the other hand i enjoyed the rice cake and noodles, but i also ordered this knowing i generally like these types of dishes. Loved the rice cake, not too mushy and tasted great with the pork. The noodles were good (like udon) but oily affff by the time we got to the end of the plate which i'm used to but can be kinda gross for some people. Overall still yums but i think people hype it up a lot.

I've been craving for good Xiao Long Baos since my last trip to Asia, which was almost 3 years ago. So you can assume that my desire for them was almost turning into an unhealthy lust.The Xiao Long Bao here are pretty expensive but they are SO GOOD. I don't really believe in 5 stars, but I really do think this place is special. Everything that we ordered was SO GOOD. The Pan Fried Pork Buns were the perfect start to the day and the Chinese pancake w Sliced Beef made me weak! That being said, we also ran out of stomach space before we hit the REAL flushing Chinatown- I'm sure that there are older restaurants/hole in the walls that could make Xiao Long Bao as good, if not better, for a cheaper price. You just have to look!

Great! It's relocated half a block down from its old location not hard to find. The new place is very spacious and aesthetic. Great for pictures."instagram"Scallion Pancake w/ Beef - They did a makeover on it. Sauce is on the side and the pancake layer is a bit more crunchy. Although this was a soft opening they sort of skim on the beef Crispy Seafood Noodle - Crunchy chewy and goodCrab Xiao Long Bao - The dumpling skin is more tainted orange. But overall a good soup dumpling.Lucky 6 XLB - I would say great for photo but overly hype. Only would prefer eating the truffle, crab, and pork. The squash one didn't make the taste or texture any different. The worst one was the foie gras. Apparently I'm not sure if it's on purpose but I had a heavy blow of wasabi flavor. I couldn't even recognize what I was eating. Although it's limited but try on your own risk.Overall I pretty much enjoy the new location for the deco! Good go on relocating and making a huge difference on decorating.

Best soup dumplings in the city!I really like their new location! It's very spacious and the ambiance is good. There's this cool indoor tree by the waiting area. I highly recommend getting their regular pork soup dumplings. So good! The Lucky 6 Soup Dumpling set allows you to sample different flavors like truffle, scallop, squash, chicken, and crab meat. Of those, I particularly enjoyed the scallop soup dumpling. Can't wait to go back for more!!

Truly sad to hear this restaurant is closed, it serves delicious food with amazingly affordable prices. I am glad to hear it's re-opening across the street! The service is okay, they were not very attentive to us but they were very polite. The food was amazing though! We shared the scalllion pancakes, and I had flavorful stir fried udon. My boyfriend had noodle beef soup which was SO good! The broth was extremely tasty and seasoned very well. I would visit this place again in a heartbeat.

So glad that they re-opened! I went there frequently a few months ago but since I couldn't go out for a few months, I didn't have any option. I was hesitated to order soup dumplings for takeout because I was afraid that it would be cold by the time it got to me, but they actually retained their heat fairly well. As delicate as the soup dumplings are, none of them broke during the delivery process (special thanks to the delivery person)! I also ordered some pan-fried pork buns and they taste amazing because of the crispy bottom. Despite needing the food to be delivered, the food still tastes authentic and it makes me crave soup dumplings again. I would definitely recommend this if you never tried soup dumpling before and want some new tastes now!

Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao is definitely one of my favorite soup dumpling restaurants in Flushing!The food is delicious and leaves me full and really satisfied every time! I always order the pork bun xiao long bao. So delish! I'm not the biggest fan of the crab meat with pork for some reason. I also order the spicy beef and tripe for those spicy lovers! Leaves the mouth slightly burning though!Other appetizers I've gotten are the scallion pancakes with beef. So. Delicious. I also get a dish of noodles and my usual go to dishes are Shang Hai pan fried noodles and seafood udon noodles! The seafood udon noodles usually come off a bit too oily for me so I'm always hesitant with ordering this dish.Everything is relatively cheap and affordable for the amount of food I've ordered. The restaurant is also has a lot of tables but when it gets to prime time, the restaurant gets packed! The wait is never toooo long for me though even if there is a wait, it's usually pretty quick and they take your order as soon as you're ready. Therefore, the service is great! There may have been times my friends and I had to wait a bit for the waiters attention but I'm overall very satisfied with Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao!I continuously go back for soup dumplings when I'm craving, and I definitely recommend!P. S. This place is cash only!

A special trip was made to Flushing for this highly rated joint.  It was worth experiencing the sucking of the abundance of juicy and tasty broth inside their "Xiao Long Bao",  thicker was the skin in holding the hot liquid.  Disappointing was the rest.Packed the front room was on this Thursday night, so we were led to the side room. Nauseous I was immediately of the stench of uncleanliness and worse when seated in front of a bin of dirty rags.Tasting after changing tables, good were the "XLB"; doughy "pan fried pork buns";  garlicky, stale tasting "cucumber & garlic"; and, ok was their "Rice Cake with Pork & Preserved Mustard".While reviewing this, I am here to say that it is wrong of believers expecting to receive bad service at all Chinese restaurants, for its simply not true.  Unpleasant and rude was our server in all respects that evening.  I'd left if I wasn't a guest.  cheers!

This is a pandemic-era review.We always enjoyed going to the previous, smaller location and were glad that the business was able to move to a bigger space. The food is still tasty, a basic set of breakfast/lunch/snack standards that will be familiar to anyone who's been to Shanghai.Unfortunately, the current setup for food pickup is inefficient and unsafe. Let's start with the physical aspects. The food is being delivered from behind a screen at the top of a staircase. The staircase is not wide enough for two people going up and down to stand six feet apart. At the bottom if the stairs, there's enough room for two or three people to stand safely apart from each other.This wouldn't be such a problem if the food were being prepared efficiently for prescheduled pickups. The restaurant's website does allow for scheduling at 15-minute intervals. However, both times we've come the food has been significantly delayed. This means more time standing around in an increasingly crowded space with potential disease exposure.Making matters worse, the restaurant has a tablet where people can walk in and order - so they pick their dishes and then have to stand around for at least 15-20 minutes waiting for the food. The crowding is just unacceptable right now. You can easily have ten people in a space that's safe for half that number.For people who pre-order, it's not clear which orders are ready when you walk in. You have to weave your way past the other customers to the top of the stairs, find someone - it's not always easy - to check on your order, and then, if it's not ready, go back down the stairs again past the same people.The ordering system seems to have left the staff befuddled. Some people are picking up by number, others by name. The whole thing seems pretty random, and the communication from the staff is minimal.The last time I went, I waited 15-20 extra minutes for a pre-scheduled order. The woman who brought it to the table said it wasn't ready, so I kept waiting. Then a man came by 10 minutes later, and when I asked what was going on, he brought the woman over and asked her. She said the order actually was ready, so I left thinking that I'd waited an extra 10 minutes in that unsafe environment for no reason. But when I got home, presto, one of the items was missing.In the half hour that I spent at the restaurant late morning on a Saturday, only three orders were brought out. That's a pretty poor showing at a peak time of the week. We really want these folks to succeed, and we know it's not easy right now. But please, don't put your customers at risk.
Fell off since the renovation and relocation. Pig ear is still the best hereSoup dumplings lost it.. mad me sadBut the service is so good, everyone is very attentive and on point.

I really really like this place.  My two friends and I arrived at 11:30am after our Daiso outing.  The place wasn't empty but it wasn't crowded either.  The hostess showed us to the room next to the entrance.  They served us hot tea as soon as we sat.  My friends and I ordered 2 orders of soup dumplings, 2 cold appetizers, scallion pancake and vegetable dumplings. The total was $35.50.  The soup dumplings were delicious.  The skins were thinner than other shanghainese restaurants I had been to.  I will definitely go back there.
Feel good good. Affordable and delicious. Food is served fresh and quickly! CASH ONLY!Soup Dumplings, udon noddles and the scallion pancakes are my norms! Check it out.

I believe one of the factors that affects good experience includes good timing. And this was fortunately given to us when we came to Nan Xiang's.We arrived around noon time on a busy saturday.  It was a plus that the restaurant had municipal parking just across from it where we were able to park with no hassle. Other street park only allowed an hour of parking but this lot allowed 3. As soon as we entered the restaurant, there were no lines. And since we were only a pair, we got to sit right away. The area was divided into 3 and we were seated at the middle. It was a busy aisle but it also turned out perfect for us. We were close to the kitchen where we could see "the making of the dumplings" (handmade!) and we were close to the cashier for easy payment. The service that day was very good as well. We didnt have to call for water refills as they were pretty attentive, which was a bit of a surprise to me seeing as how the place got busy as soon as the clock hit 12.For the food, like other reviews said, they do come out quick and some only seconds! The baos came first. Boy were they very soupy! The dough held them perfectly and they were still piping hot! A few got ripped as I took them out of the containers only because I wasnt patient enough in taking them out carefully. We had both pork and crab xiao long baos. Although, im allergic to crab, i found that it was more tastier than the pork. We also ordered pan fried dumplings. They tasted amazing! I love how the dough was made. Still had a very good chew despite that it was fried. It was one of my favorites there. We also had the beef scallion pancake. They were good but was too greasy.Overall, we had a very good lunch there. I appreciated that the menu was not too extensive so picking out which food to get wasnt so confusing. Would definitely recommend the place and would like to be back whenever im by flushings.

This place seems to have lots of popular from yelp and tourists. As you walk into the shop, there are multiple awards from yelp and Micheline star posters plastered all over the cashier/waiting area. I personally think this isn't the best Shanghai spot as the soup dumplings were not my favorite. The skin on their dumplings were too thick and the soup is average. Seeing so much popularity from this place, I had higher expectations but sadly it has not met my standards. So if you do want to try great soup dumplings definitely check out Shanghai asian manor in Chinatown! P.S. this isn't an ad, it's just my honesty recommendation

these soup dumplings will never be as good as the chinatown joes shanghai soup dumplings. however, these get the job done and the restaurant also offers other breakfast favorites of mine.i love the salty rice rolls from here. the rice is soft and sticky on the outside, the inside is salty and flavorful. this is literally my favorite breakfast item on any chinese menu. cant go wrong for breakfast - they have a comprehensive menu including scallion pancakes, salty soybean, dumplings, and fried cruller sticks (you tiao). i also enjoyed the cold sweet soybean milk, but prefer it to be thicker - the one here is more watery and thinned out.this new location is elevated. literally. theres a second floor up in this b!! tables and seats are new too. staff is so incredibly nice and welcoming. i will be back! reminds me of Shanghai You Garden, although i'd probably prefer their free order of soup dumplings :p

We came on a Saturday evening and the wait was about 30 minutes. You get a number and you have to be there when they call your number or they'll skip over you. In our wait time I walked to the nearby peking duck sandwich stall to grab a bite and made it back in time.I'll be honest I don't think I ever had soup dumplings before so this is my first experience. We ordered both the crab and pork ones. It came in portions of 6 so that was perfect to share between a group of 3. We only ate about 4 dumplings each in the end, and I felt I could eat more. I feel like I could have eaten at least 6-12 dumplings to be satisfied.We ate them without paying attention to which meat was which and in the end they tasted the same and none of us really could tell we were eating different things. My friend said the dumplings were small in comparison to others they had. As a first time xiao long bao tryer I thought they were good. The broth was nice and flavorful and you HAVE to pour in some of that sweetly sour vinegar sauce to eat with it (the flavors contrast so nicely). The skin of the dumpling itself was thick and chewy, I kind of expected it to be softer. The meat itself was ok, not as soft and tender as I thought it would be, but not bad. Overall good soup dumpling, makes me want more. This place was so hyped up but it didn't really meet the hype for me. Don't get me wrong they were really good soup dumplings, just nothing spectacular.

One of the best places to go in Flushing if you are craving soup dumplings! Each order of soup dumplings comes out freshly made and they are constantly rolling them out of the kitchen. The scallion pancake with sliced beef was hot and crispy, making it a solid appetizer if you're looking for something to share before the start of a meal. My mom loves Shanghai Pan Fried Noodles and they made it perfectly here - she loved it!Will definitely stop by again in the near future!

Party of 7. We ordered five cases of xiao long bao, including two of the colorful ones, one filled with truffle, and the rest were regular ones. We also ordered several appetizers: "drunken" chicken, seaweed, beef tendon (? or was it ligament), cucumbers, and jellyfish with turnips. We also ordered a plate of Shanghai stir fried udon and stir fried nian gao. Food was alright. Not too bad. Everyone at my table commented that the drunken chicken needed more flavor. Appetizers had a decent amount of food although the Shanghai stir fried udon was demolished in a matter of seconds. Overall food could've used better flavor. The spicy dishes were not spicy at all and this is coming from someone that has a super low spice tolerance. Overall service was okay, food came after a decent amount of wait time. We ended up having to search for the pot of tea and pouring our own tea. The wait for a table was insane. They did a good job trying to speed up the process and having people look at the menu ahead of time, but the food was a little disappointing. I would not want to wait for over half an hour again for this food.

So there was a queue once we arrived at the restaurant. Got my name on the list and the lady said 15 minutes. After 20 minutes passed, I went in to check where we're at in terms of waiting for a table for three of us. The lady said another 5-10 minutes. Ok so we waited about 10 minutes. Still no call. I went in again, she said, 5 more minutes, they are cleaning our table. Oh good Lord! At this point I was hungry on the verge of hangry. I kept my composure and go along with the flow. We got sat before this other customers who got sat like a minute after us, but for some reasons, she took in their orders before us! And of course their foods came out before us! Dafuq?!Anywho, the food wasn't all that great to bribe about. Would not return.

Came here while I was looking for great dumplings in Flushing. There was a lot of hype surrounding it, and I honestly was not disappointed! We got here at 4 pm on a Friday night and didn't have to wait for a table. By the time we left around 6pm, there was a bit of a wait to get in.The food service here was really fast. They gave us tea while we were waiting. I came with a vegetarian person, and they had a lot of options on the menu. We ended up getting scallion pancakes, veggie noodle soup, veggie dumplings, and a cucumber side dish. I also got the classic soup dumplings (because why not) and they were very delicious! We got tons of food for less than $25, which was way more than enough for 2 people. It was crazy! Would highly recommend coming here if you are looking for dumplings, or if you are in Flushing for any reason. Be sure to come early, else you'll have to wait.

Finally got the chance to try Nan Xiang and they're now my favorite XLB spot in NYC!! We ordered 3 lucky six soup dumplings and 1 crabmeat soup dumpling, scallion beef pancake and beef tendon in chili sauce. The beef tendon was a cold appetizer and was very flavorful. Their scallion beef pancake was so crispy and cane with extra sauce on the side. Can't ever go wrong with this! The lucky six soup dumplings come with one of each: crabmeat, pork, chicken, truffle, scallop and chinese squash. Many come for the truffle and I'm a HUUGE fan of truffle in Italian/French dishes, BUT THIS AINT IT. I've tried truffle soup dumplings before and I stand by my opinion that the flavors DO NOT match! Steaming the truffle takes away the natural aroma and brings out too much of a regular mushroom flavor- which is fine, but not what I look for in truffle flavored dishes. Also, they use black sesame to make the skin black and you can actually taste it, which I didn't enjoy. On the other hand, the scallop and original crabmeat pork flavors stood out the most to me. Their crabmeat had so much crab and was so creamy and flavorful compared to most other places' crabmeat soup dumpling. The scallop was also really good because it had a sweet scallop taste to the regular pork. And yes, it comes with a small fresh scallop inside! We came all the way from Brooklyn just to try Nan Xiang and I'd come to Flushing just to order racks of their original crabmeat XLB!!

A friend recommended this place and it wasn't a disappointment at all. My boyfriend and I got the lucky 6 soup dumplings, nan xiang soup dumplings, the shanghai fried udon and the soy milk. The food here was delicious, the soup dumplings are definitely bigger here compared to din tai fung. I think DTF has better traditional soup dumplings. I did enjoy the different flavors of the lucky 6 soup dumplings. My favorite was the crab meat! I recommend going for the crab meat dumplings over the pork. I wished the spoons for the dumplings were a tiny bit bigger. I also liked the udon, it wasn't anything crazy and probably be better with minced meat. The soy milk was also really good, I recommend trying it out here(really different from store bought). The service here was good, staff was very tentative. The interior of the restaurant was really beautiful especially with the window of the dumplings being created.

Came on Thursday night in a group of two. We were seated very quickly. This place is brand new and very clean, which makes us feel very comfortable. We ordered the signature pork soup dumpling, beef scallion pancake, Shanghai fried udon, and the pan fried pork dumpling. Everything is so good especially the pork soup dumpling. The skin is one of the thinnest that I have ever had. Would definitely recommend to try! The service was so quick and attentive. Everyone was nice. Can't wait to visit again!

Everyone raves about their soup dumpling but their star dish is their pan fried buns. Omg the pan fried buns are so juicy and tender and when you bite into the buns it's a bit crispy. It's literally the best pan fried bun ever. Their soup dumpling is good but to be honest it taste just like any other soup dumplings.We also had their rice cake with veggies and pork that was a decent average dish. Their spicy tripe and beef was pretty good as well. The spicy level has a kick to it so I enjoy the dish as well. Don't forget their beef scallion pancake the pancake itself was flaky and crunchy with the beef in the center of was pretty darn good.So yes I'll come back for their pan fried buns.

One of the hardest problem that I have come across during this pandemic is having the lack of xiao long baos in my system. I am forever grateful for you guys being open and delivering during these hard times. I ordered the braised beef noodle soup and, of course, the xiao long ago. If I could re-live my first bite of the soup dumpling over and over again, I would. Absolutely delicious. Craving satisfied.
Delicious authentic food at a reasonable price. Has a nice atmosphere and servers speak both Mandarin and English! would definitely go again!

Came here today after the long await.. ordered the truffle soup dumplings, the spicy beef tripe(fu chai fei pean) the beef pan fried dumpings, the beef noodle soup and the crab soup dumplings along with two bowls of soy milk. Needless to say we definitely over ordered for two people. My sister raves about the truffle soup dumplings which was why I opted out of the colorful one, regret on my end because while I like truffle I don't love it as much as her and it was a bit too much for me. I did like the crab soup dumpling and would recommend that along with the beef noodle soup. The spicy beef tripe was really aromatic but lacked in spice for me, for some reason I feel as if it use to taste better when they were half a block away‍ I would recommend the soy milk but would have preferred to drink it out of a cup and have it cold instead of a bowl and hot. The pan fried beef dumplings were juicy but not amazing... they were just okay. I am just happy this place opened up again and I liked that there is a lot of seating and service was efficient, however I did remove one star because while I knew the lady handling the number downstairs has a hard job I didn't like the fact that she knowingly let people cut the line... if there's no reservations for this restaurant you shouldn't let people cut in line, this lady and this guys number were five numbers behind us and they had two people just like us but she let them go in first ...

Been wanting to check this place out for a while and finally did. We had the tasty steamed Lucky Six soup dumplings, pork/crab dumplings, scallion pancakes, pickled jellyfish & sweet sticky rice.  Would come back again.

Stop here for lunch, ordered Pan Fried noodle w seafood, received Shanghai Friend Udon w seafood and waiter complain about my incorrect order ‍ she look so mad. Food actually good, Soup Dumplings delicious. Scallion pancake w sliced beef yummy

Went for the first time today and was blown away by the food. We ordered the crab and pork dumplings, scallion pancakes with beef, Shanghai noodles, and the pan fried steam pork buns. EVERYTHING WAS AMAZING. Service was also fantasticI'm going to bring so many people here.

Had many reviews, so thought I check it out. We waited an hour to sit 2 people so it must be good, right??? The pan fried noodles were so soupy that it wasnt even crunchy - would not recommended!! However the scallion pancakes were actually cooked well, and one of the best I've had in NYC! But everyone comes here for the soup dumplings which were honestly 6/10! We have had better. Some of the dumplings were already popped when we picked it up, so the soup would come out. I'm not sure if it's worth the wait to come here, but if there's no wait then go try it!

Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao It was a rainy Sunday! If you arrive before 1pm and it's raining you're in luck! A table for four no wait. Little did i know that when I came back with a party of four and we waited 15 mins for our table. Saw that there were over 3000 reviews on yelp and I knew I had to try this place out. I had this back when I was in Shanghai and there was also a wait. So we ended up ordering takeout and ate it at the hotel. The pork steam dumplings in shanghai were small though. Alright back to this restaurant in NYC. All the items on the menu seem more breakfast type of food. What we ordered: Salted Soy Bean Curd: ($2.75) this tasted okay. Seem like they just threw it soy sauce on top of the soy bean curd. Scallion Pancake:($3.95) crunchy on the outside. Pan Fried Pork Buns: ($6.95) (6 pieces) order came out cold. Guess it's been sitting there for quite some time. Maybe we shouldn't have order this since we order dumplings. Rice cake with shredded pork and preserved mustard: ($7.95): basically what it states. Okay dish no wow factor to it. Shanghai Panfried Udon: ( $7.50) looked more like udon with beef and shanghai bak Choi. I like the Chinese style better with seafood. Steamed pork buns: ($6.50) not enough meat filling. Also we order crab too but when our order arrived, they messed up the order and gave us 2 pork dumplings instead of 1 pork and 1 crab. Not happy about that as they won't do an exchange for us.I don't know what the rave is about this restaurant but there are better soup dumpling restaurants out there. Service was mediocre. Food was okay. I had high expectations due to the amount of reviews but sadly disappointed.
