I...I can't believe it's back. After the worst 4 months of not having Nan Xiang, it's finally back.And what a comeback!First things, first -- Nan Xiang caved and delivered on some Insta-worthy soup dumplings!White: porkWhite with yellow (crab meat) on top: pork & crab meatGreen: Chinese squashYellow: ChickenPink: ScallopBlack: TruffleNote that you also have the option of just getting an order (6 pieces) of one type of dumpling.I've been coming here for years and it can do no wrong in my book, so just going to write everything that I love in my recommendations below.As for the long wait -- yeah, it's a little worse. At least before, if you saw people standing outside, you knew it was already packed. Now, it's super deceiving because there's so much room to wait inside that by the time you open that door and finally get a sense of how crowded it is, it's too late. You've already committed to dining there (just kidding, but you get the point).And they accept credit cards now! Time's are a-changing!Cailin's Recommendations- Breakfast: Scallion Pancake ($4.50): it's fluffy, but filling, so plan ahead -- like, don't order too much or else you won't enjoy it- Breakfast: Fried Fun with Chives and Egg ($4.95): it's delicious, but also filling, so plan ahead- Cold dish: Cucumber with Garlic Sauce ($6.95): I have yet to see another restaurant make this dish as well as Nan Xiang- Cold dish: Savory Pressed Tofu with Chinese Celery ($6.95): amazing amazing amazing- Noodles Soup: Pork & Cabbage Noodle Soup ($7.75): the amount of green in that soup is a STEAL- Fried Noodle: Shanghai Pan Fried Udon Noodle ($7.95): one of my favorites - it's not heavy on the sauce and it's so delish. The only thing it's missing is like more protein - it just has shredded pork- Fried Rice Cake: Rice Cake with Shredded Pork & Preserved Cabbage ($9.95): oh man, this is also a favorite of mine!- Soup Dumplings: I mean, the crab meat & pork ones ($8.25) are the best. The other ones are fun to take photos of (not the pork alone though, that one's boring in appearance and taste) so you can get the Lucky Six soup dumplings ($10.95 [for the Insta!]) and then you should another order of your choice (to satisfy your soup dumpling craving - one order is never enough!! It's like an addiction).Again, can't go wrong with this place.If you've read this far -- thanks! This is my 100th review! Whee!

New location. Grand opening this past week. The decor is modern. The wait is long. The food is bland. The service was terrible. We waited almost an hour for our 6 dishes. Our first dish was fast. The scallions pancake with beef came out cold. After that nothing. Who did we disrespect to get this terrible service. The soup buns is their bread and butter item. Everyone got their soup buns we had to wait. The old place was better food wise and service wise. To make up for their poor service they gave us an order of pickled cucumbers. I will give it another one more chance.

Loved this place so much! First, I was surprised about how big it was. You have to go upstairs for seating. It was incredibly busy, but the service was still great! Everybody spoke perfect English and was nice and checked in on me. Food was a little expensive, but definitely worth it! Some of the best pan fried pork dumplings I've ever had period. The food warmed me up a lot. The free hot tea was a nice touch too. Will be coming back soon! Thank you!

The food here was nothing special, the steamed meat buns were good but not extremely amazingly good! Service was pretty good- I went to the old and new location. The new location has the different colored soup dumplings but honestly they all tasted the same. The truffle ones tasted really nasty too me and I just felt like it didn't mix well together. Overall we ordered a good amount bill came out to $71 for just 2 people. The only thing that was reallly good is the beef pancake everything else was nothing I would go back for.

First off the food was delicious. Ordered two appetizer of pig eat and tendon; chewy and slightly spicy. Then the xiao long baos, a thin dough keeping in all the soupy goodness with a plump piece of meat inside. Ordered 4 sets of xiao long baos. 2 of the regular soup dumplings, 1 crab soup dumpling and 1 colorful variety of soup dumplings. I think I could eat these all day long. The things that brought it down was the dipping sauce. It had the usual soy sauce, ginger and vinegar but not enough vinegar and it was bit sweet. Maybe they are trying to cater to everyone, so less vinegar and adding sugar. The crowded long wait, maybe to be expected since it opened up not long ago. The bad positioning of their doors, they have two double doors and one isn't being used but people keep trying to open it even with a sign on it. probably since it's the door at the front of the restaurant. Lastly, why change a good thing. The last place was great and had its original charm. Other than those few things, it's still a good place to eat soup dumplings.

Having been here about a dozen time since 2015 and its always been good. Just came here recently with several friends on a Friday night. We got the soup dumplings but I have to say my favorite is the spicy beef and tripe.

Although they re-opened under the same management, they changed the skin of the dumplings to make it more instagrammable (colorful) which I felt  made the texture of the dumpling skin harder. All the other dishes tasted the same as before and I'm still a fan if this place (only when it's not busy).

This place was close down and then moved to the next block. Never went to their old location but came here to the new location recently and I'm super regretting that I hadn't came and try their food before! Great soup dumplings!!! There are other food options too on their menu but if you come with some friends, just get a few trays of soup dumplings and you'll sure be satisfied enough already!

Omg I was in total heaven after trying these soup dumplings! Ordered the crabmeat ones and wasn't sorry at all. Super thin dough, the soup inside was a perfect temperature. The flavor of the crabmeat was perfect in every way. Honestly they tasted gourmet. A definite 10 out of 10.

I've been waiting forever for them to relocate to their new location, and now they are at a soft opening stage (open from 2 pm on 11/2/19, open from 10 am on 11/3/19)The place is nicely set up with an open waiting area (much better than the cramped no seating old location!). The dining area is up a short flight of stairs and is more spacious, with a wonderful wood decor and name personalized utensils. Though they were busy, the staff were attentive and friendly. I ordered the Pan Fried Pork Dumplings (B2) and the Steamed Lucky Six Soup Dumplings (F5). The Pan Fried Pork Dumplings taste delicious, with a thin skin holding in all the juicy pork flavor. The skin was extra crispy, which isn't my favorite, but if you enjoy that crisp, this is a must.  The Steamed Lucky Six Soup Dumplings, according to the menu, consists of their Signature + Crab Meat & Pork + Black Truffle + Chinese Squash + Chicken + Foie Gras (Seasonal Limited) soup dumplings. The Signature is their regular one, which was good with all that soupy goodness. The Crab Meat & Pork had a very good seafood flavor, which overpowered the pork flavor. The Black Truffle had a good truffle flavor. Added that yummy mushroom-y flavor to the meat and skin. The Chinese Squash didn't really add to much to the flavor, and was nothing special. The Chicken had a lighter flavor than the regular Signature ones, and I did like this better than the Signature. I am pretty sure my last dumpling was not the Foie Gras. It had wasabi in it. I assume they probably didn't have the Foie Gras. It had a tad bit too much wasabi in my opinion, since that was all I tasted. Also, for some reason, they thought it was a good idea to put some at the top opening, so it hit my taste buds pretty hard when I took a bit. Overall, pretty good variety, and makes for a colorful picture!I am happy they have a nice new location, with the same delicious dumplings, in addition to the new flavors! I will definitely be back to try their other dishes!Update: Came again the next day with someone else! We ordered 2 orders of the Pan Fried Pork Dumplings (B2), Steamed Vegetable Dumplings (B7), Handmade Steamed Dumplings (B8), and Truffle Soup Dumplings (F6).The Pan Fried Pork Dumplings were just as good as the day before. We did get 1 of it first, and didn't get the 2nd order until we finished with our other dishes, but one of the staff was attentive enough to check up on the 2nd order for us (Shoutout to Alice!)The Steamed Vegetable Dumplings were a bit undercooked in my opinion, but were still tasty. Good lighter option.The Handmade Steamed Dumplings are smaller in size than the pan fried  dumplings, but they come with 8 instead of 6. Good bite sized portions with the same juicy inside.The Truffle Soup Dumplings were the star. The truffle taste is strong but not overpowering. Still cash only, but hopefully they start accepting credit card!
I will only say delicious. Need say not anymore as your own taste buds deserve a visit.

As a generally non-Chinese food eater and vegetarian, I found Nan Xiang satisfactory for a convincingly authentic Chinese meal but not something I would seek out again. For what it's worth, my brothers who are more into Chinese food than I am thought the cuisine was better than a typical Chinese restaurant.My brothers and I shared 2 orders of steamed vegetable dumplings, crispy dough, and a scallion pancake, and my brothers also ordered the udon noodles (substituted chicken for pork). The vegetable dumplings were warm, filled with various greens, and overall decent. The pancake was tasty but greasy and the crispy dough well tasted like fried dough (not my favorite taste). I liked the hot tea served (instead of water) with your meal.Prices are cheap (the above was around $35) and service is quick. Note: This restaurant can get crowded. I came on Christmas Day and waited 45 minutes for my party of 3.

Be wary about going in the winter. I went recently during the weekend for lunch and it was like a zoo in there. They have a terrible system of having the party grabbing a ticket and waiting in the main room by the entrance. I feel bad for all the other guests who are sitting there cramped by all the people standing near the tables and waiting there as well.I ended up sitting in this room and as mentioned it was a winter day. As the door opened and closed numerous times my feet went numb as we sat there for about an hour.Do not get me wrong the food is awesome but they need to step up there system of having people seated during the winter.

The long awaited reopening has finally come. A bigger, trendier space, with an emphasis on service. It has definitely lost that family restaurant feel. Unfortunately, the food hasn't improved. The side dishes of pig ears and cold dishes were decent. The pan fried noodles were pretty good too, but the soup dumplings were a let down compared to their competitors. The skins are too thick and their special xlb with different color and flavor dumps are just for insta show and lack any real depth in flavor to differentiate themselves. If you're looking for good xlb, go somewhere else. Otherwise, their other dishes are average.

Yes. the soup dumplings are very good here. You don't need to read my review to know that. There are over 3000 reviews here so you know the soup dumplings are good. Very very soupy. Definitely get while you're here. I STRONGLY recommend their scallion pancake with the beef. Probably one of the best thing I ate all day. That includes the soup dumplings!CASH ONLYI don't recommend the stir-fry udon dish. It was very greasy and wasn't that great. Don't get the udon. Come for the soup dumpling and the pancake. 5/5 stars. Udon 1 star.

Don't waste your time. Coming from someone who grew up eating at Nan Xiang, I can tell you it's not the same was it use to be. Flushing has so many newer, better, and cheaper Xiao long bao restaurants. Nan Xiang does not live up to the hype it use to. You're  better off waiting at the other Shanghainese restaurants that offer better deals for better food. Not to mention that there service is not the best.

If you're in flushing and you're craving xiao long bao and don't really mind the wait, you should give this place a try. If you DON'T want to wait upwards of 30 to 45 minutes, I'd suggest somewhere else. After the constant hype i hear about this place I finally made it here to wait about 40 minutes for a table for 2. We ordered their Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao, and two noodle dishes. Honestly, the xiao long bao did not taste much different from other places I've had. Not to say that it wasn't good, but it just wasn't anything spectacular. Our noodle dishes were good as well, but again nothing I can't get somewhere else, and probably cheaper and better. If you've never gone and you're willing to wait it out, give it a try. Otherwise, I think this place can be skipped on my opinion.
Don't feel like the previous taste when there was in the old spot But still nice service and good soup dumplings

One of my soup dumpling spots. I always come here to fulfill my Shanghainese cravings. I always get the steamed pork buns, Shanghai pan fried noodles, scallion pancake with pork or beef?, and the cucumber with garlic. Everything tasted on par. The pancake with the beef or pork was a little bit in the saltier side. The cucumber and garlic is always sooo yummy. Crunchy with a hint of pickled taste. I was surprised to see that they have covered their tables with table cloth to elude to a fancier dining experience. The staff and service was swift and polite. They only take cash here so remember to hit up an atm before coming in.

I was sad when this place closed down at its original spot but happy to hear they reopened! Their new location is where the Rong Restaurant was located (they took over the building). I hear rumors that this Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao has new owners but I'm not sure. Overall the quality is still really great! The beef dried noodle was my favorite, not too spicy which I liked. The flavor is delicious! A must try! Overall very happy my favorite soup dumping place is back in business!
RELOCATED 1 block away to One Fulton Square Mall. Opening Fall 2019.Not sure how the new location will be but the old one had great food for a decent price and not so great service.

So happy nan Xiang has opened in Flushing. I've tried tons of soup dumplings and Nan Xiang easily has the best I've had in all of NYC. Definitely worth the trek out to Queens and will be coming back often. Might be a bit crowded during peak hours though!

Craving some dim sum? Head to Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao. They have some really good steamed buns, dumplings and noodles to fill your belly. They give tea here for free and the service is very friendly. I ordered the chicken soup dumpling as well as the veggie steam dumplings. It was really good, i couldn't have ask for a better din din. The soup was so hot and tasty, like I was slurping the juices of chicken heaven. The veggie dumplings were surprisingly really moist and tasted like meat, but wasn't. This place is a hidden gem in Flushing, Queens.

btw the beef stripes used to be my favorite dish(used to be spicy), now it's not even spicy at all. Wonton in hot oil peanut sauce is NOT spicy at all,barely taste the hot oil, mostly peanut sauce. The wonton skin is better than most restaurant. They were able to keep the fried dumplings same quality as before, crisp outside juicy inside. BUT we were so thirsty even an hour after eating, just guessing from the m.s.g.  (Suggesting bring your own bottle water in case)

I've been eating at Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao for years until it closed last year. The place is solid and has been so for a while until it became a coveted tourist destination. Now you'd expect a 30 minute or so wait time to get seated.That aside, the food is good. But not drastically different than the other XLB places I've been to in the area. Not a huge fan of their recent branding with the glorified XLB fillings. People I know order them once for the sake of trying them but are often disappointed and return to the original pork/crab fillings.

delicious soup dumplings. the wait is not long. I love their cold soybean drink. You got to get it quick before it sells out. I also recommend their pan fried udon noddles with seafood. their new location is much better and has more room. very nice!

First time coming into the new restaurant. So glad to see it back. CASH ONLY! There's an atm in the "lobby" when you first walk in. The differences from the first shop are pretty crazy. The basic pork soup dumplings were delicious! Even on a Tuesday at lunch time there were still lots of people. Tried the truffle XLB-- if you LOVE truffle this is perfect for you. I definitely say it's worth trying once. Definitely coming back and still top 2 favs for XLB.

Call me bougie but I always get the xlb with the crab. To me, that's what the smart money gets. It costs a little more, but luxury doesn't come free. Live a little. Treat yo self. Love yo self. The plain ain't no Thang. Basic.ok I'm out of cliches, but I say this because some ppl are unimpressed by the basic xlb here, but that in itself is because it's basic. I'm rarely impressed by any spots basic xlb. It's just a bigger plain dumpling. Boooring. There's no richness of the crab... what the Chinese call that xian flavor. A little lesson in the word xian. The character is made up of the combination of the char years for fish and lamb. Hence this is a flavor that is different and novel so to speak. So in a nutshell, the two flavors of meat and seafood together create another flavor. But I digress... Try it once and u  prob won't ever go back. Unless u got a shellfish allergy. Then I would advise against it.Other things here that are good include the rice cakes with pork and preserved veg. Also the noodle soup with fish and sour cabbage. Also the beef with peppers noodle soup. Always my go tos. The scallion pancake with beef isn't bad. But I mean, go big or go home. Why settle for basic things? Save your money and use some elbow grease at home. You can do it. I believe in you. Human potential is limitless. The new location doesn't feel the same tho. Weird setup. The wait is usually ridic too. Well seems that way based on all the ppl waiting. I never have dined in at the new location yet. Smart money goes strait up the stairs and orders to go from the counter. Fast and (quickly) furious... ly eating.... Before all the peasants in the waiting area even find a place to rest their tired, hungry legs to continue their anxious wait for a table. You'll love the look on them newb faces as u leave with food in hand. Yeeeeeeet!

Very attentive service - constantly refilled our tea.The soup dumplings were good but not as good as they tasted in the old location  the meat and soup are still great, but the dumpling skin is too thick now.

New location, new looks, new customers. I was at the recent soft opening of this restaurant and I was not disappointed. I've been going to nan Xiang since it was at the old location across the street and the quality of the food has remained the same and as delicious as ever. The decor looks great. It's bigger, there's more seating. I waited at most 10 mins on line for a table for 2. While waiting on line, I noticed a lot more non-Chinese dining here in comparison to the old location. I assume the restaurant has gained a lot of popularity which is a good thing.  (Owner, if you are reading this, your prices better not skyrocket, for the sake of your loyal customers who've been with you since the beginning. Service for a Wednesday night was super quick. The restaurant was at capacity during the dinner service. The staff who brought us to our seat did kindly remind us that it is a cash only restaurant.

Love the new location which is across the steer now, more space, no longer are the seat bunched together. The food are still on the same level. Tried the new truffle Xiao long boa, nothing special. But their original stuff are still good.

What kind of brunch restaurant runs out of most of their brunch items before 1?Came here with my family as we were huge fans of the original restaurant. We were seated at 12:20 on a Sunday afternoon, proceeded to order 7 dishes, and all of them were sold out...We got the six colored dumplings and they all tasted the same - only the black truffle one tasted slightly different and that's mostly because truffle has a strong flavor to begin with. The rest tasted the same as the regular dumplings We waited for 45 minutes, and there's still a whole crowd of people waiting to eat and probably waiting for longer. Overall experience was mediocre, would have given three stars but dropped it down to one because of the missing dishes and mediocre food. Service was good though, and their pumpkin cake was great. If you're looking for nice decor, come here. Otherwise, go to Shanghai You Garden or Yi Feng Yuna if you're looking for quality shanghainese food.

My family, boyfriend, and I had lunch here in Aug 2018, and absolutely loved it! The service was like most Chinese restaurants - inattentive and curt - but we came here for the food. Dumplings: We ordered pork XLB, crab XLB, and Shanghai shiu mai. The XLB here are very soupy, and the soup itself is very meaty and flavorful. The pork in the pork XLB has a strong taste of ginger. The crab XLB has a strong crab flavor (almost suspiciously strong - hope it's from actual crab and not crab flavoring.) Chilled side dishes: chilled tripe was delicious and rich in spices. Only critique would be the numbing spice needs to be a lot stronger. Garlic cucumber was also great. We also ordered the beef wrapped in scallion pancake, Shanghai udon, spicy beef noodle soup, and soy milk. Everything was delicious and inexpensive. Definitely will be returning next time we visit NYC!

I'm so glad this place opened up again! This was my favorite soup dumpling place in flushing and I was really sad when it closed. This new building is a lot bigger and fancier! The interior is organized with lots of seats! Even then, there can be a long line during  busy hours. I went with a friend on a Tuesday night and thankfully didn't have to wait to get seated. We ordered the regular soup dumplings, pan fried crispy noodles with beef and scallion pancake with beef. The soup dumplings are just as good as I remembered! The scallion pancake was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The crispy noodle had a lot of sauce so it was really salty, probably won't get it again. Overall, this remains my favorite place to go for soup dumplings!

My husband and I went to the new location on a Saturday for lunch. The wait was 30-45 min and the waiting area got really packed. We didn't see fast turnover. It's also odd that when they initially call your number, it's a standby call. So you wait again at the stairs until they call your number again to finally go upstairs. Service was fast and efficient. We got the crab and pork dumplings, beef and spicy pepper noodle soup, and the special 6 soup dumplings. All dishes were just okay. The crab and pork dumplings really didn't have crab in it. The special dumplings all tasted the same to the point that we forgot that they were even special. It's a great concept but they all kinda just tasted like pork dumplings. The skin of the soup dumplings here are also pretty thick compared to other places. The soup just tasted like carton beef broth that they threw in some peppers and beef. It did have a good peppery kick but without deep flavors to the broth and a bit to oily. They also mixed up our orders so we got the colorful dumplings first which were lukewarm. Then a while later they brought out the color dumplings again along with the crap and pork dumplings which were piping hot. So I guess we got someone's unwanted order of special dumplings? There's def better soup dumplings in nyc in our opinion.

If you're looking for good Xiao Long Bao.. this is the place to go. The line is hit or miss and luckily for us there was no line. We went around 3pm. We had all the kinds of Xiao Long Bao and we were not disappointed. You can make a paste of soy sauce and spicy sauce to give it that extra umph. mmmmm I'm hungry just thinking about them! How did you like it?

My gf and I had a great experience the first time  we tried this place.  The staff was nice and accommodating, and the food were delicious.  I cannot say the same, however, the second time.  There is this one staff who is a bit short, kid-like and with poor demeanour by the name of Lin has completely turned a great experience to a terrible one.  Granted that we knew the shop was nearly closing and that my gf and I were about to finish our meal, he told us that their shop is closing soon and that next time we should come in early.  As much as the food tasted great, it wasn't anymore and had left a bad after taste. Maybe I'll try again next time, but it won't be anytime soon. There are many other great restaurants with great customer service in that building complex and around the area.  I do hope that Lin gets proper training and learn about good customer service.

Yes, Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao is not only worth the trek to Flushing, but also the wait once you arrive.  The food was excellent.  In order of yumminess... My favorite dish was the Shanghai Pan Fried Udon.  They had an incredible "charred" flavor that made it very special.  Next, the Steamed Pork Soup Dumplings.  Everything about them was excellent - the flavor of the broth, the thickness of the noodle, the fresh ginger/vinegar mix  - yes, yes, yes!  The pork and cabbage rice cakes came next; however, I added chili oil to bring it to the next level.  We also enjoyed the sides of bamboo (had a lovely cinnamon flavor), garlic cucumbers, and scallion pancakes (although - these were a little on the oily side for me).  Looking forward to coming back again soon to try more dishes (and repeat some :)).

As a native Shanghainese girl, I know soup buns. And this place was a let down. I have visited the old location a few times, and thought it was decent. But today, I was very disappointed. To be fair, the filling and soup did have good flavor, but the skin was very thick, almost 2x thicker than it should be. It was like eating a regular Bao zi, not a soup bun. The ginger slices for the vinegar were also too thick. The  other dishes were also very blend. The salted soy milk was watery and lacking/needed more crucial ingredients. Overall: the staff was much nicer than the old location; Decor is nice; value is ok, not great. I hope they can improve on their soup bun's skin thickness.

Stopped in on a Friday night with a few friends, and had a wonderful experience here.  It's a very clean, spacious and bright restaurant, first of all!  Overall a much better, more comfortable ambiance than anything you would find in Manhattan's Chinatown.We ordered 3 different types of XLB (crab, truffle, and pork), and out of the 3, the crab was surprisingly my favorite!  I'm glad for the truffle one it was only $11 -- I saw it on the menu and was surprised because I had once paid 2X that for 6 truffle soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung in LA...  These were much larger and way more delicious.  The most notable thing for me about these dumplings too was not only that they were well-sized, but also that they held together the best of any XLB I've had.  I love Joe's Shanghai for the flavor and portion size, but I always found myself sadly accidentally tearing them (and I admit, part of that's on me!).  For me, this was a definite plus!We also ordered a few additional dishes, like the seafood and chicken pan fried noodles.  I preferred the seafood one, but the chicken was still just as good!  I grew up eating these Cantonese-style pan fried noodles from my dad, and can say that they were very reminiscent of what I was used to!  For $11 this was well worth it.I got there late and my friends were already seated, so I can't weigh in on how bad the wait was, but from what I understand it was about 30-45 minutes.  But that's to be expected, and I'm glad the food lived up to it all.  I'll definitely be back!

Very happy they are back! Food quality is the same deliciousness we all know to love from this place. Inside is very beautiful they really lucked out in a better location. Im happy to see new menu items as well. The new soup dumpling variety is a worth a try.

This place is good for its price and taste. Not too salty compared to other chinese/asian restaurants. We were luckily seated  right away as I am always seeing this place full especially during weekends and dinner. For their soup dumpling, I must say I have tasted better soup dumplings and I think a lot more authentic. Will definitely come back if I am craving for inexpensive chinese food.

The furniture are nice with their name. The tableware are all with their name and very nice.  The food price you Could say cheap compare irvine where we live by.  Because the price is cheap and you will can't help to ask more food, the total will make more than you expect. Something like , you were suppose to pick up some food but at the end you finished.  It was so good. The servers are organized. Basically on different positions, they only do one thing and make it perfectly. Like one girl hold the tea pot and go anywhere try her best to find if anybody need hot tea to refill. The food come in quick and hot. It's just perfect.

Absolutely wonderful restaurant. The service was speedy and everything was delicious. I ordered the Shanghai Udon and the Black Truffle Xiao long bao. Both had amazing flavor that's hard to beat. I'd say they give Joe's Shanghai a run for their money.

Love love love this place. It was hard to find as the sign is in a different language. However, who cares once you find it and walk into this restaurant it will make your mouth water. My husband and I came in and was seated immediately. However, the place does get busy and there might be a wait. We were given menus with pictures of everything. My advice is definitely get the soup dumplings. I have never had them and my husband raved about them. There is a reason for that, they were amazing. We had gotten Singapore noodles which was good as well. Everything we got was delicious and came out hot and in an appropriate time. The service was great and refilled our tea and water whenever it was empty. The only thing that was not posted is that they take cash only. So just make sure you have cash.

Even better than before! Ordered my usual scallop pancake, soup dumplings (the original), braised beef soup (spicy). Everything was fast first of all, the soup came first and the scallop pancake after and it was hot and delicious. I asked for it spicy, and they didn't bring it but there is chilli oil  at the table. Soup dumplings after and it was so good, not too hot but still so good. They now also take card, just one card though. Love the space and the new servers. Run don't walk right back in.
Best steam dumping un the town, and real Chinese traditional breakfast, such as soy water, Dofu-hwa, deep fired bread stick, pot package....

In town for Chinese New Years with my family, came here off of a suggestion from a friend whose uncle lives in Queens. We were seated immediately (weekday evening). Ordered a couple cold dishes, beef noodle soup, chive pockets, Shanghainese rice cakes, scallion pancakes, 2x xiao long bao, potstickers, and pan fried buns. Food came out fairly quickly and we had no issues ordering more. Our favorites were the (regular) xiaolongbao and the pan fried buns. Sooooo juicy and piping hot. Skin not too thick and the filling was tender, not overworked. Some of the best that I've had in the US. Chive pockets were excellent as well, although they looked deep fried (we are more used to pan-fried). Everything else was pretty good, but nothing special (in our opinion). Would definitely go again!!

This place is really good, I think everybody know , it is always busy, so I recommend avoid peak hours. Not sure what happened to the kitchen or the sewer the day we went there , there was a very distinct odor that was not welcoming to my nose and appetite at all. Hopefully that was temporary.

I'm really disappointed that the quality of the new location is lower than the old location. My family had been going to Nan Xiang for two decades (since it opened in the original spot); I still remember when it just opened. We loved the XLB, stir fried rice cakes, scallion pancakes and the tofu pudding. When it closed suddenly, my entire family was devastated. I went with my mom to try the new location about two weeks after it opened; we waited 35 minutes for a table and ordered our usual: the pork XLB, the 6-flavor XLB, rice cakes and the egg/chive pancakes. My mom noticed immediately that the XLB dough was thicker and less pliant, and I noticed the pork meat was not as silky as it used to be. The 6-flavor XLB was a marketing gimmick - we couldn't taste any difference in flavors except the scallop one had a tiny piece of scallop. Everything was bland and tasteless. The rice cakes were also tasteless - couldn't even tell it had been stir fried -- it could have been just been boiled and then tossed with edamame and mustard greens and some oil and that was it. We don't usually need to salt our food when we eat out, but we needed to add salt because it clearly hadn't been seasoned. The egg/chive pancakes were OK - thick pastry but not crispy; not that much filling. Service was terrible - our plate settings had chopsticks, but no spoons despite ordering the XLB; and it was impossible to track someone down for help and for water refills. Waiting for the check to come took nearly as long as our actual meal did. We will not be back; the wait is not worth it, and other good XLB places have opened in Flushing or elsewhere in Queens to fill the void.

This place was recommended by a good friend to try something different with eating dumplings. Only dumplings i eat are in soups. But at this restaurant the soup is inside the dumplings. I was kind of skeptic if the dumplings would even taste good to try. Man oh Man oh Man took a bite from the top of the dumplings slurp the soup and flavors bursted into my mouth. Best dumplings I ever had hands down. The other dishes was also delicious but the dumplings was what really impress me!

I love this place! This is probably my favorite soup dumpling place so far (I like it better than din tai fung!). Last came I came, it was a group of 6 and we waited for about 30 mins around 1pm. This time it was a group of 2 and we waited about 5 mins. I don't think this place takes reservations. The soup dumplings are solid. I like the texture and flavor of the dumplings. I LOVE the soy milk and you tiao here. The soy milk reminds me of the ones that my mom makes at home. The you tiao are light and crispy. Last time, I also got the cucumbers which were light and a good break from all the heavy dim sum foods. We also got the beef noodle soup which was really good. The beef was very tender and fell apart easily.

The new location is more upscale compared to the old location. Definitely expect a long wait especially on the weekends. Service has upgraded a lot too! The waiters constantly refilled my tea, kept checking on my table to make sure our order came out and always asked if we needed anything. The food is good as usual and the prices did not increase. I loved that they added new flavors of xiao long bao (soup dumpling). I tried their black truffle soup dumpling and it was so flavorful and yummy, I highly recommend!

A great little place along the streets of Flushing. My boss and I stopped by for a quick lunch while waiting to check in at the hotel nearby during our business trip. To my surprise, even at 2:30 pm there was a wait for a table. When you walk in, the restaurant is cozy but very energetic. You have the aunties wrapping the XLB in the corner of the restaurant where the streamers are and waitresses running around to take orders. We ordered the original xlb of course as well as the pan fried buns and two side dishes, bean curd and marinated seaweed. Original Xiao long bao:These surprisingly, were delicious! The soup within the bun was well seasoned and the meat filling was nice and soft. One thing that I didn't like however, was that the skin of the dumpling was a little too thick for my liking. Overall though, this is my favorite of them all. Pan fried buns:Nothing much to comment about here. The bun itself was also a little too thick and it wasn't as juicy as the others I've had in Cali. Flavor is good though and meat was soft like the soup dumplings.Side dishes:Just ok. The seaweed tasted like it was drenched in spicy sweet and sour sauce but overall, not bad. It's good for an appetizer as it was intended to be.Definitely recommended for the xlb but other than that? Well that judgement will have to wait until next time I come back :)

"Soup Dumplings Supreme"Forget Joe Shanghai's --- this is the real deal.  Thin skinned, juicy, rich brothed, bundles of goodness await you here.The Great - Wonderful soup dumplings.  Crab and pork ones were truly fantastic, maybe the best in New York City.- Excellent pig ears- Also tasty and fresh steamed vegetable dumplings.  A definite to add to your meal - Chili beef soup was neither spicy nor spectacular.  So - so.The Not as Great1. Focus on the food, not the decor.  Expectations set accordingly, my reader.2. Unlike some other reviewers I thought the service was actually very good.  Next time I'm in Flushing, making a stop here again for the soup dumplings !
This is for the new location. Just as good as ever. They upped their cold dish game a bit. So goodo

The soup dumplings live up the to hype! My friend and I came on a Saturday from Manhattan for lunch, and we had no wait. It seems only larger parties usually have a wait, but it's pretty spacious inside either way. Food: My friend and I planned to share one portion of pork xlb and pig ears, but ended up getting another serving of the xlb. The skin was thin yet chewy and the inside was not too salty, which is something I've noticed other places have trouble with! The pig ears were pretty standard so I'm not sure how good the other food is, but it's worth coming here for the soup dumplings.Service: Pretty standard, our food came out pretty quickly. Atmosphere: Also pretty standard chinese restaurant, pretty spacious inside and has a bathroom. Overall, would come here again for the soup dumplings! Definitely lived up to the hype.

2day we have party of 3..My brothers & I..We waited on line about 45 mins long.Finally have our table..I sit next to a couple..These are the dishes We ordered..Bathroom have a line as well..Men & women share..I drank my tea no waiter/waitress Give us tea to  refill for our drink?So I asked the staff guy for Some tea..they finally gave us tea?their tissue everyone get 1 tissue?why so cheap should give 2 at least per person?Sevice pretty bad I say..They don't refill your tea?I need to ask them for it.food to me Was okay..Don't come on weekendscrazy Long line..have to wait..People waited on line blocking The front door..Others can't come in & out..They should have a host To do the wait on line .Instead of standing their..will i come to eat again?maybe..if it wasn't to busy?i think i heard someone screaming out loud?their always some idiot person being stupid childishnot mature..good thing is they have free wifi..i just did mineno need for password..just click on their name.

Came here for the 小笼包, and they did not disappoint! Each soup dumpling had a good amount of soup. The filling was delicious as well, and the skin had a nice texture. Good size, and good amount of food for the price.We also ordered the 生煎包, which was very meaty, as expected. There's also a little bit of soup in each bun, too. I loved the crunchiness of the bottom of the buns, you know it's good when they can cook the bottom right. Would recommend this place!

The best shanghai spot in New York so far. This spot is on the michelin guide recommended. And please don't compare this to Joe's Shanghai (more for tourists and non asians) because this one is more authentic. You can just see that more locals go to this one than Joe's Shanghai. I live in brooklyn, but willing to travel about 2 hrs to eat here. Highly recommend their pork crab soup dumplings, soybean drink (cold one sweeter than the hot one), scallion beef pancake, rice cake, panfried dumpling. Actually everything is pretty darn good!
This place serves amazing soup dumplings! I like how they allow for take-out. Great scallion pancakes.

The smile doesn't lie Amazing soup dumplings and addicting lychee  Congrats on your Grand Opening in flushing!One of my favorite food destinations to exploreHere we tried every type of soup dumpling they had! Love the view of flushing as well. Inside is really nice and plenty of table space to order lots of food

Service have improved quite a bit recently. There was eye contact and pleasantry such as "enjoy" with a smile. A smile! Last time we went our food was hastily thrown at the table like they couldn't bear the sight of us. Though I didn't mind that at all since my mind was fully occupied by how amazing the soup dumplings were. Quality is consistent every time. We liked all the dishes we ordered, such as regular dumplings, scallion pancake, soy milk, chicken soup, and marinated gluten. My favorite is still the soup dumpling (xiao long bao). I recommend spending a few more bucks for the kind with crab meat. I usually put a dumpling in a spoon and take a small bite to drink the soup first, then pour vinegar on top and slowly savor the rest. I still see people putting the whole thing in their mouth - the soup inside is really hot and will burn your mouth! There's a parking lot a block away and we were lucky to find a spot there every time we go.
Love love love these soup dumplings! Our go-to place all the time when we are craving these! Highly recommend and so glad they're finally re-opened!

Had a lovely evening with some great friends of mine! Had a heck of a lot of dumplings (pardon my french) and some fabulous scallion pancakes. The wait was about 20 minutes longer than stated, but the wait was definition worth it in the end! It was so fun catching up with my old flame (Adam) and other alumni of the Manhasset Cross Country program. Unfortunately, my tea wasn't refilled as frequently as I had hoped, thus leaving me parched, but I was able to adapt & overcome this road bump along my journey. So overall, it was a great experience so no complaints (except for my previous listings):)
The food was delicious Resturant and service was great!! I will most definitely recommend coming to this place.

Soupy buns!What did I getI went here for breakfast before my flight back to Orlando. I got the soy bean milk (sweet), xiao long bao, scallion pancake. The soy bean milk was tasty! It wasn't as sweet as I anticipated it would be, it was a big bowl though! If you get it hot it would come in a bowl like soup and not a cup. The xiao long bao are very juicy, really like them while they are hot, once it cools. The scallion pancakes were very oily, they are also good when it is hot. Bottom line is for chinese food, I like mine hot because so much oil was used to cook it that I like to eat it hot.EnvironmentIt is a small restaurant front but the interiors is very big. It is New York, I can't except some Orlando style seating! We did manage to find space for our carry on in the restaurant while we ate there thoughNiceness of the staffStrangely, the staff wasn't as friendly as I would like. I spoke in English and I felt like she didn't try to understand what I was saying. Minus one star for customer serviceDollarIt was pretty reasonable for meYes?Yes I would go back here for the soy milk and try other items on the list. #WendytakesNY #WendyWanders

I came to the store at 8am and it's pretty rare to find good quality breakfast this early in Flushing, NY. They have quick service and the hot soy bean milk with youtiao (deep fried breadsticks) is a must to get! Even though I went for breakfast, the full menu is available for order and I got to try their juicy unique Lucky Six Soup Dumplings! Very colorful and attractive but I prefer the original myself. I had a great time here and will come back again!

Nan Xiang XLB is a decent Chinese restaurant in the multitudes of Chinese restaurants in Flushing. Service is ok, the waits can be long, the food is ok to good. I've been here at least twice. Once in March, 2014, and last weekend.We had the XLB, rice cakes 4 years ago. I vaguely remember the food was ok to good and the crowd was mostly Chinese. The rice cakes were chewy and perfectly sautéed with soy sauce.Last weekend we went with another couple and a friend. The crowd was a mix of Caucasians and Asians. We had the XLB (crab and pork- 2), Pan fried XLB or Sheng Jian Bao  or Pan Fried Pork Buns (1), Scallion pancakes with beef (2). We all feasted before coming, so we didn't order a lot for 5 people. XLB- this was good. Thin skinned, hearty hot soup inside. Good flavors.Sheng Jian Bao or Pan Fried Pork Buns- This was ok. The bun was fluffy with a good crust on the bottom. The soup was good but I wanted more of it. And 2 of the Pork buns had raw pork inside. Maybe this isn't a good representation of Sheng Jian Bao or I don't like the thicker dumpling wrapping. Scallion pancakes with Sliced Beef- the first batch was ok. The oil was a little stale and there wasn't much sliced gelatinous beef inside. The second batch had the same stale oil but the beef plus the oyster sauce was heavenly! It was crunchy, savory and melded together so well! I loved it. instagram.com/snackchatn…

Nan Xiang used to be very reputable and one of my favorite soup dumpling spots in Flushing. Ever since they relocated a block away, they turned into a white-washed poophole. Truffle soup dumplings were mediocre at best costing more than $2 a piece, we expected way more than this black colored excuse of a soup dumpling. Just go Shanghai You Garden 2 blocks away for a delicious meal and you'll be saving about 60% off your meal. P.S. when you sell a pint of chicken soup for $8.95 you can go f*** yourselves.
Best soup dumplings ever...noodles were on point and the soup was very good...cucumbers were nothing specialJust expect to wait to get a table

It's back!! We panicked when they closed the restaurant and now can all breathe a sigh of relief because they're back! The food is just how I remembered and busier than the previous location. Of course get the Xiao long baos and now they have an added new mixed basket of fancy XLBs but stick to the traditional plain or crab ones. The scallion pancake was crispy and seasoned just right. The pan friend buns were a bit heavy but we couldn't top eating them.

Went over there last Saturday with my wife and our excitement, but came back with disappointment.  My wife and I are huge fans of their old location.  We couldn't wait to try our old favorite, fried rice cakes with potherb mustard, and the new lucky six(the source of all the hypes).To be fair, their soup dumplings(lucky six) are still ok, just didn't justify the hypes and the insane wait time.  However, what happened to the fried rice cakes? Did the chef spill the sugar bottle while cooking them?  MY GOD, the sweetness is "next level"!   Believe me, this is not an extravagance, you can literally order them for your dessert. Avoid ordering them! In sum,  I will probably go back in after a year assuming I am going to eat any soup dumplings anywhere else during the year, that's how I feel right now.

Overall: 3.7/5Time: BreakfastThe order:(1) Salt Sticky Rice Roll(2) Crispy Dough(3) Sweet Soy Bean Milk(4) Steamed Pork Soup Dumplings(1) Pork floss and crispy dough wrapped in rice. Very dry. The price for what you're getting is unreasonable.(2) Fresh by all means, the only real issue was that the dough was quite flat. Typically more fluffy and airy.(3) The sweetness and consistency was just right. Too often the milk is too thin and thus lacks flavor but theirs was rich and perfectly sweetened.(4) The skin was the perfect thickness to keep them from ripping, but not too thick so that the chewiness was balanced nicely. The meat and soup were very flavorful and not too greasy.* There are no teapots on the tables and the teacups are tiny. If you drink a lot of tea, the lack of attentiveness to the fullness of your cup can be frustrating. It's uncomfortable to have to ask for more tea so frequently.** This is not meant to be a comparison to the original location.

What an amazing place. I ordered the pork & crab xiao long bao(soup dumpling), the beef scallion pancake, the fried baos and the soy milk. xiao long bao: the wrap was the at the perfect texture while holding the delicate and delicious soup / meat filling. Beef scallion pancake: it has a prefectly crispy skin with a flavorful combination of beef, scallion and hoison sauceFried bao: this exceeded my expectation because even this contained soup in it. It was a pleasent surprise. Soymilk: it's a simple soy milk but it was good because of the way that it's cupped and also it was at the right sweetness I will be back when I get the chance to travel out to Flushings NY again. Unfortunately I was only able to capture one photo since I was too eager to try everything else.

We're came here around 11 a.m. on a Sunday, and it was already very crowded. For a table of three, we still had to wait about 30min. We were very excited to have this restaurant re-open since we loved the old restaurant. When we finally got seated, we learned that there was an issue with their frying vent, so a quarter of the menu was not being served (stir-fries noodles, etc.) and another quarter was sold out (all the Dou Jiang - Soy Milk). We were a little disappointed, but since we were here for the soup dumplings, we were pretty okay.We wanted to try all the different types of soup dumplings, so we got the Lucky Six. We asked the waiter if we should get the Truffle, but he said that we should get the Crab instead. Trying the truffle in the sampler set, it was a very faint taste, so glad that we didn't miss much. The skin seemed a little thicker than it used to be, but still satisfying to eat. We rounded out our order with Spicy Beef & Tripe, Cucumber Salad with Garlic Sauce (which suddenly has carrot in it now), Scallion Pancake with Sliced Beef, Pork & Vegetable Wonton with Spicy Sauce, and Bing Dou Jiang. We also got chicken in wine sauce to go. Recommend:Pork Soup Dumplings, Cucumber with Garlic, Scallion Pancake with Sliced Beef, and Bing Dou Jiang, and Chicken in Wine.Don't recommend:Wontons (too thick and not flavorful), Lucky Six (worth trying once and never again)The restaurant is still cash only, but now that they have new owners (still the same employees), they are looking to accept cards in the future. They had just re-opened on Oct 1, so they're still working out some kinks.Will be back in the future!

Go for the crab and pork soup dumplings, stay for the beer scallion pancake! Seriously delicious! Pro tip - it's cash only, but super affordable! Ordered way too much for 2 people and only paid like $35 with tip!  Your meal comes with unlimited hot tea, which I love! We ordered the crab and pork soup dumplings, obviously! As well as crispy dough (kind of like a light and fluffy churro without the cinnamon and sugar - very tasty), beef scallion pancake (so yum! Crispy and delicious), handmade dumplings (these were good!), as well as some veggie dumplings because everyone needs some greens in their life! Everything was super good and came out quickly. Highly recommend!

Thick-skinned XLB filled with lots of soup. There's a decent amount of seating available here, but you should definitely expect to wait during peak times. Came in looking for a table for 2 on a Sunday afternoon (rookie mistake) and saw tons of people crammed inside waiting. The good news? we were quoted at 15-20 minutes, which was surprisingly accurate.Got the standard pork and the crab XLB and both were delicious. Like, don't think twice and order these two delicious. I wish I had room for everything else on the menu because everyone else's tables were filled up with delicious looking food. Prices were extremely reasonable. There's a reason there are so many reviews of this place -- try it when you can!

Beautiful new location down the street! Best soup dumplings in flushing! We drive all the way from out East once a month just for dinner here. Can't go wrong with anything on the menu but our favorites are the crab soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, and pan fried udon.

Wow this place got a big upgrade! It's super popular still and because of its new opening it's even more popular but the food is still amazing! Soup dumpling FTW! It takes a little while for the food to roll out so go with friends so you can pass the time with conversation but you definitely won't leave without a full stomach
The best Xiao Long Bao I've ever eaten. Very juicy and fresh. Beef pancake is a must try. The restaurant is wide and clean. I wanna try other option of Xiao Long Bao.

Overall: have been here several times and will continue to come back because it's delicious, very reasonably priced, and soup dumplings!Ambiance: classic, casual, always packed and will likely wait, but worth it. Food: Classic pork soup dumplings are delicious . I like that they include ginger to complement the soup dumplings. I also enjoyed the scallion pancake pictured below. Simple, crispy, nice touch. I'll return ... it's just to good.

Went there with family,crowded as ever.As always we had soup dumplings,this time we also try the six different flavors one. Well there's nothing so special about the different flavors one.overall we are happy with the foods.service it's great and fast.

We had to wait 30 min for a table.The food was ok and not expensiveThe main problem was :we were 6 people, first person got his dish after 5 minNext 3 people got their meal after 25 min when the first person already finished his meal.The other 2 people got their dish after more than 45 min!

This place almost always have a wait period. They prepare and serve food very efficiently, you can get in and out of this place relatively quicker. Xiao long Bao was my favorite. I love the crab one the most. It had good flavor and enough soup in it. Pan fried pork buns are good too. I also love there scallion pancake with sliced beef. Fried bun with chives and egg had a lot less flavor than I would like.

As I scanned my yelp for recommendations far and wide for soup dumplings, I was summoned here by my fellow yelpers and drove an hour just to try this very well reviewed Mecca of "Xiao long bao". The hype is real, these are the best soup dumplings I've ever had! They're super "soupy", tender, thin skinned, delicately flavored little packages of goodness. When arriving, be mindful that the parking is very limited but there is a municipal parking lot directly across the street that was jam packed and many cars were stalking and circling desperately looking for spots. It took a good five minutes for me to get a spot. There are also parking garages in the vicinity but I'm not sure of the pricing. Back to the food... we started with ordering the fried bun with chive and egg which was sort of like a fried calzone stuffed with these tender scallion greens, chopped boiled eggs and these tiny little shrimp. The menu doesn't say it had shrimp as a listed ingredient so be weary if you have a shellfish allergy because that's exactly what happened and we were lucky to spot it before any real harm was done. The scallion pancake with beef was excellent, it was tender, crispy, soft beef slices with a bit of hoisin sauce. We ordered one portion of the Xiao long bao and after tasting it when it was cool enough, we immediately ordered two more portions. We also tried the stir fried udon which had good flavor from the hot wok, it was pretty good but a bit oily. Another thing worth mentioning is that their chili sauce is very good, not particularly spicy but a deep toasty flavor which compliments their food very well.

I like the new make over for this restaurant. I like that they added a few more different flavors for the buns and also different colors. It's a nice display. The food is also delicious with a great price.

I was visiting NYC and was also helping my friend to move back to California. We dropped off some items to his friend then came to this place for dinner at 11 PM. When we arrived I was surprised because the place is packed and more people are still coming in. The only thing about this place is that they only accept cash like many other Chinese Restaurant. Anyway, let's get down to the food.We ordered pig's ear, bean curd tofu, regular flavor and crab flavor XLB, Sheng Jian boa, and Shanghainese sticky cake with fermented vegetable with pork. The flavor of the bean curd tofu and pig's ear were really good. The XLB is better than Ding Tai Fung in my opinion. The regular XLB is juicy and the flavor was good. The juice doesn't taste like pure fat and greasy but was flavorful and doesn't make you sick. The Crab flavor XLB is also good, you can taste the shellfish flavor rather than just blend. The sticky cake and Sheng Jian boa were also really good. We walked out happy and very full.Overall I would recommend this place since their food is good. I think I made the waitress feel awkward cause I thanked her for getting us the food, tea, and other stuff lol.... but yea food is good!

DELICIOUS dumplings! Pan fried pork dumplings were soft inside and a little firm on the outside. Well seasoned with a tangy kick. The steamed pork dumplings had a thicker skin and were just as flavorful as the pan fried.  The scallion pancake sliced beef was my favorite! Juicy slices of beef basked in sauce, wrapped in a flaky and lightly crunchy crust. Absolutely yummy! All meals are served with fresh, warm tea. Service was quick and food was ready in less than 5 mins. Can't beat that!

It's better than Joe's Shanghai, and that's saying a lot. Best soup dumplings in the tri-state area and a cute little Shanghainese eatery in flushing just a block or two from the bustling Main Street.

Its been years since I last visited Nan Xiang, back then I had a pretty goo experience but never had a chance to revisit again. Unfortunately as with Yelp fames it seems it might have gotten bit over hyped. My experience here few weeks ago overall is probably decent at most and would have been worse if it wasn't for their great Xiao Long Baos. Since its gotten quite popular it was about 10-15 min wait on a Sunday around noon for 2 people with a number system. The hostess is pretty diligent as she comes out to announce next party every few minutes or so and is always on the move bringing people to their table definitely a plus on reducing the waiting stress :)We ordered various items from their easy to read menu with pictures, another a plus for a high volume restaurant like Nan Xiang. Their XLBs are definitely the favorite among our choices but really there are so many competitions around the area and in Queens that I didn't feel they were a step above everyone else'sThe other menu items are pretty good but nothing too memorable unfortunately. The pork chops were crispy and fresh but probably a little too greasy. The scallion pancakes I thought were a bit too salty overall and probably can cut back on the sauce a bit more. The beef strips noodle soup had quite a good texture of noodles but probably overwhelmed with the spicy green peppers.The waiter service were decent although not very attentive given how busy the restaurant gets, there were couple of times we had to ask for extra utensils and bowls but they did their best to oblige. I am curious about their breakfast items and might return for it in the future. I guess if we show up early enough for breakfast it might just make the dining experience a bit more pleasant.

Came here after their new location opened, I thought the taste of their food got much better not sure if it was just me, but they did raise their price a bit. They do get quite busy during lunch and dinner time. We went as a party of 4 and waited around 40-50 mins during lunch time. However, when it was finally our turn, we got seated quickly and the food came out quickly. I believe they also got a lot more people working comparing to their old location, so the customer service got a lot better too. I usually get the scallion  pancake and the chives cake. They make them so crispy and flavorful. You tiao is also one of my favorites when you eat it hot. FYI, they only take cash.

I don't like giving reviews on Yelps. Mostly, if the service/food is alright, I'd never leave review/comment or whatnot. However, this time, I have to leave a review about this restaurant. The outer layer of Xiaolong bao is dry and mushy. XiaoLong Bao is usually eating with the Chinese vinegar. And the vinegar is supposed to make it tastes better. However, the vinegar tastes way too sweet which makes it tastes gross. Not only that, the waitress, she didn't even give us shredded gingers. And I know that they recently just moved their store, redecorated and stuff. I don't understand why, for some reason,  the store still smells like paint to us. To sum up, it's just got worse comparing to before.

They accommodated 12 of us on a busy night pretty quickly. service was also really quick, the food started to come out 10 min after we ordered. There's a lot of options in Flushing, so it's hard to pick. This place has one of the best soup dumplings I've had. We got the pork and the crab and pork. But my absolute favorite dish, which was unexpected was the scallion pancake with sliced beef. The outside was crispy and the inside was airy and light with a delicious sauce from the beef. The price is also great for the amount of food you get. There may be a line outside the restaurant but give it a shot, it's worth the wait!

This is a place for non- Chinese customer to try Chinese food, don't bother to go if you want real Chinese food in flushing. It's a good place to chat with friends because there's long waiting time between each dish, and you may never get all your food at the end. So you can talk about each dish one by one,  and enjoy unlimited tea while waiting the last dish. Soup dumplings is not competitive to other places - 3 stars.Cold dish - 1 starOverall Service - 2 starBathroom - 1 starThe cold dish husband and wife special 夫妻肺片 is a classic cold dish. This one is bland, not enough chili flavor. Steamed lucky six soup dumplings is ok. Each dumpling taste slightly different, not amazed though. Only high light is the crab dumpling give more crab butter than other place. Truffle one smells strong, make sure you try it last. I do not know how the Pan fried dumplings we ordered taste like, because they were never served.The service was a mess, lack of management. We waited for 15 mins to get our cold dish after ordered, which is stored right next to stairs and waiter just need to simply put some in a plate. Then another 17 mins to get soup dumplings. After we finished all the food, had another 3 cups of tea, went to bathroom once, our pan fried dumplings was still not served. My friend told me he hear another table asked waiter why they got pan fried dumplings because they didn't order it. I guess the waiter served our dish to a wrong table. Come on, you guys stick a receipt on each table is for decoration purpose? Anyway, we decided to leave after another 20 mins wait.Please install your bathroom lock, it's not fun to see a man was doing his business when I opened a door. I mean install the lock come with the handle one, don't just added a crappy lock above it. Poor guy, he actually thought he locked the door D:
Waited 30 min before being seated, but well worth the wait! Ordered Crab & Pork Xiao Long Bao, Chicken Xiao Long Bao, Chicken Shumai, and Pork Pan Fried Buns

Mediocre at best. Being Shanghainese myself, I have tried authentic soup dumplings all over the place. As per usual, I feel like this is one of those restaurants that are overhyped just to please tourists. To begin with, I got two orders of soup dumplings, udon with pork, soybean soup and scallion pancakes with beef. The meat inside the soup dumplings tasted inauthentic, as if it were put out for awhile. The skin of the dumplings were thick too, which isn't supposed to be. The stir fried udon with pork was okay, nothing too special. Soy sauce, udon, cabbage, and pork. We ordered the soybean soup thinking it was going to be cold, but it was hot. There was nothing wrong with it, the sweetness was just right, which was a plus. Lastly, the scallion pancake with beef came with only 3 pieces. I thought it'd be more. The pancakes were unevenly distributed, so the last piece didn't really wrap much around the beef. However, the sauce was delicious.The service was fast. The workers were nice. However, at the end, when we paid (it's CASH ONLY by the way), they forgot to give us change and thought we didn't pay!! There was a miscommunication between the workers and if they hadn't trust us, we would've paid double. There are definitely better soup dumplings out there that aren't flooded with tourists.

Really affordable and totally worth it. Usually a lot of people and sometimes you won't get a table a lot of the time unless you wait a lot time and no reservation allowed. CASH ONLY! Nice food and good textures! Quite authentic but always missing a taste for example the grated garlic for the drunken chicken or the minced garlic with 2-3 slice of red chilli pepper with the pig ear. Lots of options and love the tofu dessert AMAZING! Not too attentive.
This place resembles a typical restaurant in China with its decor and tea service. There are more items on the menu from the previous location and expanded sitting area.

Service can be hit or miss but it's worth it. They are open late and take cash only as well. Dined here last night after arriving from Chicago, 11pm ish.First off, even their most mediocre dish we had was actually really good, the hand made boiled pork and chive dumplings.Their bean curd appetizer, homemade chicken broth, and soy milk were all delicious, flavorful, fragrant. Lovely on a winter night.We also had the Shanghai Shao Mais, tasty sticky rice dumplings with no meat. The Xiao Lung Baos are first off large, about 2 inches in diameter and packing tons of flavor. 4 people ordered 3 orders each, 2 crab/pork, and another pork. I suppose we could have kept going but our palates were satisfied for sure. Wonderful.Cost ended up being $20/person after tip. I'm glad I had just hit the ATM though.I'm glad this gem was open late in Flushing or I would have been sad pandas. Would check this place out for the Xian Lung Baos if you have the opportunity.

One of my favorite restaurants in Flushing because of the xiao long bao, noodles and side dishes.  They are all   all delicious and extremely affordable. When I went last, on Tuesday, we ordered the  xiao long bao with crab meat, the pork and veggie noodle soup (freshly made noodles yum), scallion pancakes (used to love them with the beef when I was still a  meat eater), turnip cakes, side dishes: jellyfish with turnip, spicy beef & tripe, seaweed & garlic.The steamed vegetable dumplings are delicious, love the chives, but not the best I've ever had. This might not be the fanciest restaurant in Flushing but you'll have a satisfying meal that won't break the bank!Tip: They allow you to bring your own wine

This place is so good and offers such good value for your money. A friend took us here because it is his go-to place in Flushing, and he has trusted this place to deliver cheap but delicious food for pretty much the past decade.We got the xiaolongbao, pan fried pork buns, scallion pancake with sliced beef, and rice cakes with shredded pork and preserved mustard. The xiaolongbao was very savory, but the skin was a little on the thick side. The scallion pancake with sliced beef was delicious, and the sweet bean paste on the inside was a surprise and added a good note of nostalgia for me. The rice cakes were good, although perhaps not as flavorful as they could have been and didn't have that much shredded pork. The pan fried pork buns killed me. They were so rich, even one made me feel really full all of a sudden. For that flavor though, it was worth it!

Recommended to me by some friends in the neighborhood, went on a solo date here. I was looking for some good soup dumplings and 3 of the 4 guys, said this spot. I order the steamed Pork buns, scallion pancakes, & the shanghai udon noodles. Start you with a tea.Food took no longer than 8 minutes to come out; nice & warm.Scallion pancakes were that perfect type of "fried" to add to the meal. Soup broth for the dumplings was hearty, and flavorful; if you like heat, their chili sauce is great.Lastly, my favorite were the Shanghai udon noodles. Great sauce, soft broccoli rabe, & flavorful chicken.Overall great spot, will be back .

Soft opening review: Just not what it used to be. Service is rushed and lacking attention. Food just doesn't taste the same as before. The new restaurant is missing the old traditional feel of the previous. The truffled soup dumplings has a nice truffle frangrance to it, but lacks much truffle taste. They forgot to give my party vinegar and ginger. But by the time we received sauce, the dumplings got cold. The scallion pancake with beef was missing beef! Wine chicken was dry. Hope they eventually figure it out, but currently they are not living up to the Nan Xiang name of the past.

The soup dumplings were pretty good but a bit overpriced. The crueller was really small, almost like a frozen churro and did not taste fresh. The sweet soybean milk tasted a little off, bitter aftertaste. The pickled cucumbers though were really good. I'll be back to try the other appetizers.

Really really good spot for Shanghainese food in Flushing. Albeit a popular spot, Nan Xiang knows how to keep quality high and service efficient. Great value for your money as the food here is really good for its price.I normally come here on weekend lunch and there's usually a line out the door. You get a ticket and wait for your number to be called. Smaller party gets seated quicker than larger parties as this place is relatively small (Even though they took up 3 store fronts). But the good thing is that their service is so quick and efficient that the wait time is usually short. Longest I had to wait was about 10-15 minutes. Hmm...what are some of my go to? I usually get two orders of their soup dumplings. The fillings of choice are pork and crab. The buns are delicate, soft and full of soup. What I also like is that the skin is not too thick like in order XLB places. They are always freshly prepared so you don't have to worry about getting frozen soup dumplings. Another favorite of mine here is the beef scallion pancakes. Crunch scallion pancakes paired with flavourful beef is something that I can get behind all day long. Just watch out for the grease that comes with it. Another must get in my opinion is their noodle soups. One of my fav is the shredded beef with pepper noodle soup. Generous amount of beefs paired with hot peppers are perfect ingredients for a cold winter day. For my sweet tooth craving and I think must gets are the hot soy milk and the dessert tofu (Dou Fu Fa). The soy milk comes in a bowl so you can dip your fried dough if you order some. The dou fu fa is skily smooth and the right amount of sweetness. Perfect way to end a meal with.I feel that you can't go wrong with the food here as they are cheap and good. Service here also isn't too bad as the waiters are pretty attentive and somewhat friendly. They mainly speak mandarin so I guess they'll be nicer if you spoke mando to them? Food here can sometimes get heavy because it is mainly carb base. So the food coma will hit you fast afterwards haha.
Doesn't make sense since they had an A rating and they were always packed!!  So sad they closedny.eater.com/2019/5/3/18…

If given a choice I would probably eat here for the rest of my life. I love soup dumplings, but this place is amazing. The dumplings never break on you until You actually eat it, other places break as soon as you touch it. The noodle dish was soooo good as well. The service was fast.
Warm soupy and delicious. Would return for the Xiao long bao. Almost as good as from Shanghai and you can see them making them.

Honestly, the xiao long baos aren't comparable to Din Tai Fung in Taipei. Is anywhere??? The meat inside wasn't to be desired and the skin was on the thicker side, unfortunately. The pan-fried dumpling meat was also pretty tough and not as tender as it could be. It kinda grossed me out. We got the cucumber veggie dish that was a nice pairing with all the meat dishes.I would spring for the soy milk and yo-tiao (fried bread) - that was a tasty starter. I'm not sure why this place gets so many good ratings... perhaps we didn't order the right things? I might try the scallion pancakes next time, but not sure I would come back.

Loved this place even when it was in the run-down building a block away. Now that they've moved into a space that matches the quality of the food, I could eat there nightly.The headline dish, of course, is the soup dumplings, particularly the "Lucky Six" variety set. I've tried it twice, with slightly different flavor combinations, and both experiences were excellent. My favorite was the foie gras, which is unfortunately seasonal and not currently available. When I asked the server, though, he mentioned it might be brought back in the future, so there's still hope!There were so many other excellent dishes that I couldn't hope to do justice to them all, but a few of the other highlights were the fried rice cake with shredded pork and chicken in wine sauce.
CLOSED ny.eater.com/2019/5/3/18…

NXXLB is one of the few "always mentioned" places in Flushing which live up to the hype.The move is to bring cash and go during the week or the afternoon. You should also tip well because people here are on top of their game and work hard. If you've had this type of food before I wouldn't suggest waiting in line for weekend lunch, unless you love people watching.Skip the XLB and go for the Shenjianbao, its pan fried, crispy on the bottom, soft, steamy on the top and moist on the inside.I don't understand why people always go for the XLB at Chinese restaurants, the pink oily goo that spills out all over the plate just kills it for me and the limp sack texture is also something I don't find terribly pleasing, but whatever, most things on the menu are good, just try not to get the noodles, go to a noodle house for that.

My co workers wanted to come here for lunch.I ordered crab steam dumpling and seafood pan fried noodle.Crab steam dumpling 4/5 stars: 6 Juicy dumpling with some crab meat inside. A yellow topping separates Crab from normal dumpling. Use the prong to pick up the dumpling and put a spoon underneath. It's an option to drizzle some ginger vinegar on top of the dumpling.Seafood pan fries noodle 3.5/5 stars: Not much seafood, but there were some shrimp, fish, squid, topped off with some sautéed cabbage. The white sauce was a little salty, softening the freshly fried noodle.Service was fast, but tea pot was not refilled 3.5/5 stars.Atmosphere and Price was decent. (3/5 stars)Don't expect to sit here for too long, because the tab will come before you ask.

This place had great food for a pretty affordable price! The servings were fairly big - larger than I was expecting. The service was really good. The place was pretty busy because the food was really yummy.

I used to love this place. I have been coming for years. I was excited when they reopened in a new location. However, it seems like the food had changed. The dishes I used to get are totally different now. I will give them another try but the pork with mustard greens was a completely different dish and the scallion pancake was not how they used to make it ( it tasted like the one I get at a regular takeout spot.. I think ownership and the chef might have changed. None of the original workers are there from what I could tell.  I had my food to go so I didn't noticed that my pork dish now had carrots, sauce, and other vegetables, none of which were mustard greens.

I've been here few times and I love their soup dumplings place. This restaurant is always jam pack but it's worth the wait! Ever since they moved to another location, they have added some new dishes to their menu, must try at least one. Their food of the taste is consistently the same. The prices has gone up a little. But that shouldn't stop you from coming.

This bustling joint in Flushing has (hands down) the best soup dumplings I've ever had.  I've been a frequenter of Joe's Shanghai for quite some time now and while it still holds a special place in my heart, Nan Xiang does it better.  Here's why:- Nan's xiao long bao are saucier.  Poking a hole in their pillows of gluten delight leads to a flood of delicious pork sauce that requires a skill level above and beyond what is needed at Joe's to not have it spill off your spoon.- Their crispy noodles are probably some of the best I've come across maybe ever.  A heaping, hot bowl of beef noodles with plenty of sauce and just the right flavour was more satisfying than anything.- They're quick on the tea, as you don't have to ask for it and it isn't a nightmare flagging down a waiter.  - Wait lines are still a thing here, but you're not going to be waiting an hour like you will over at Joe's.  The service also isn't as gruff despite both joints being cash only.  Though who can complain with their prices?!- Come, eat here.  This is a mainstay for me now when I head to Flushing.

Found on Yelp - thanks fellow yelpers! Came for dinner and the most difficult thing was finding parking. The food was good and tried the crab & pork xiao long bao which was very good, just as good as Joe Shanghai. The scallion pancakes were crunchy and the pan fried dumplings were very good. The pan fried udon was not great (I think they didn't wash the vegetables very wellAs I could taste grit in our order). All in all had a good time and the food was tasty but the grit was not awesome.

Can't bet the prices. First of all this is a cash only spot. The wait time was 10mins for us but it seems like a very popular place we're all ages are present .the food was very timely and the staff was very nice. I recommend the beef pancake so good . 10/10 for me .

Came to this spot with a large group of people on a Saturday due to the good reviews. Considering there was 10 of us, it took about 35 minutes before getting a table in the popular establishment.While looking over the menu they gave us free green tea to start. Got several dishes to share amongst each other:Steamed Pork Buns ($6.50) - thin layer of dough encompassing semi seasoned pork ball, good soupy interiorSteamed Crab/Pork Bun ($7.50) - crab meat is a little lost herePan-Fried Udon ($7.50) - thick noodles with heavy seasoning, good to pair with a meat dishRice Cake w/ Shredded Pork ($7.95) - balanced texture and filling meatService here is quick and the price-point is solid. If willing to wait, one of the better options for a sitdown.
