Very good place soup dumpling so good all very good very friendly staff udon very good advice to all

This was my first time here. Stopped by dinner with a friend. I wanted eat soup dumplings and my friend took me this place for that. I've tired eat soup dumplings at other places and this place wasn't bad but dumplings skin was too thick. We ordered a lot of food and food came out fast and they served very well. I've tired sweet soy bean milk, Chrissy dough, scallion pancake with slice beef, steamed crab meat and pork buns, pan fried dumplings, steamed pork buns. I liked scallion pancake with slice beef(I like sweet point)at this place and specially sweet soy bean milk tasted was little interesting to me, a pretty similar dish in Korea but it tasted different. I would give 2.5star if I could.

This is my new favorite soup dumpling place so far. I was a fan of Shanghai deluxe but then it closed down permanently. I've been searching for a backup in Chinatown but nothing really impressed me. Came here for lunch because of the awesome rating and review. There was a line when we arrived, but the line moves pretty fast, I was seated within 10mins for just two of us. ordered sweet soy milk, soup dumplings, pan fried dumplings, pig ear, chive pancake. The soup dumplings are big and thin skin, I love their soup dumplings because it's filled with so much soup and flavorful . the crab one also has strong crab flavor and you can see the crab meat. pan fried buns are crispy in the bottom and juicy inside. The only improvement is the pig ear that was not spicy which is a little bit disappointing. but in general. the experience was great. service is a bit slow from the high volume of people they are serving. small tip: cash only.

My friends and I stopped by Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao after the BTS concert at Citi Field and it was just the perfect end to an already perfect night. I was craving xiao long bao and had heard many things about this place so I was eager to check it out. It was around 10 pm and the place was still packed! Luckily we were able to get seated immediately.My friends and I ordered the Pig Ear, classic Pork Xiao Long Bao, and the Beef and Chili Pepper Noodle Soup to share. The Pig Ear dish was delicious! We ended up ordering another one because it was so good. This dish had the perfect texture and the restaurant did a good job of cleaning the pig ears so there weren't a lot of prickly hairs. The xiao long bao was excellent as well. They were filled with a generous amount of flavorful soup and the skin was just the right thickness. I would recommend passing on the Beef Noodle Soup. The soup was delicious and flavorful, but the noodles were flavorless and tasted a bit like sad spaghetti.Definitely stick with the classics like the Xiao Long Bao and skip on the noodles. If you are more of the adventurous type, try the Pig Ear as well!

Their signature soup dumplings did not disappoint, pippin hot soup inside perfect amount of pork with hot soy milk makes a good combination. Side dishes fried bean gluten and cucumber with garlic was delicious!!!Service was prompt.

This place had such good ratings, so on a late night out, we thought this would be a fantastic place to grab late night dinner take-out. Unfortunately, this turned out being a disappointment. We ordered their signature steam buns and some fried rice cakes. The wait was a bit long, although I must give it credit for being open late. The rice cakes were very thickly cut and did not take up sauce, which left the dish devoid of flavor. The rice cakes were completely white in color as well, which makes me wonder if it's seasoned at all. The buns were not very soupy either. Overall it was a disappointing (although reasonably priced) dinner.

This is not the best Shanghainese food I've had. The best ones I've had were in Asia so I guess I should not compare. This place usually gets pretty crowded.  We were there this morning when they first opened so plenty of seats, even plenty of parking spots from the lot across the street.  So go early!The food was fresh and hot. Good quality at a very fair price. Good eats!

I've been to probably 20 restaurants that serve so called Shanghai Style soup dumplings, mostly  around New York, some others around Boston, Chicago, Dallas (I know they're not gonna be as authentic). I grew up in Shanghai, been a big fan of it since the age of 4, left to US 20 years later. I think theirs is the most authentic. I don't know if there opening again or not.

Been coming to this place for a long time, this soup dimsum is one of my favorite place for my comfort food. Love the soup dumplings and the sauteed udon noodle( i think the noodle here is the best). So far this place never dissapointed me.

My #1 rule when coming here is to always get soup dumplings. The reason being... this store is known for their soup dumplings, but also it's very good and a unique eating experience. I definitely recommend the pork option, but they do have seafood options as well. Secondly, I am never full with just soup dumplings, so I always opt for another noodle dish to share or to eat by myself (if I'm really hungry). I always go for pan fried udon noodles, crispy noodles or rice cake with beef. These dishes are all under $10 and make you feel full. Because of this, this place is almost always crowded (esp during evenings and weekends). So be prepared to wait a little, but I personally think it's worth the wait. There's a little bit of everything for everyone.

Amazing place for soup dumplings! Decided to come due to hearing such good things about this place and I'm happy to say they definitely didn't disappoint! Came with a group of 8 and had a short wait of about 20-30 mins before we were seated. We ordered the Crab and Pork Soup Dumplings, the Beef and Tripe, and the Crispy pork buns. Definitely one of the best soup dumplings that I've had the opportunity to try. Each one was very flavorful and had decent portions. The flavor of the soup was exceptional and it was only enhanced by the chili oil and black vinegar. The service was good for how busy the staff was, you can definitely tell that theyre food is all they need to bring in customers! Would definitely return to get more soup dumplings and crispy pork buns! FYI - this place is cash only! Super cheap for so much food!

I had high expectations for this place based on the reviews but sadly I had a terrible experience with the food. We ordered pork dumplings and chicken dumplings... and as soon as we took the first bite we realized that the meat was completely RAW!!! It was seriously gross and dangerous. The chicken dumplings were extremely raw... and the pork dumplings were very undercooked. We came home not feeling well, and we're sure it was because of the uncooked meat. I will not come back to this place again.

Love coming here! My dad started taking me to this place about 3 years ago. It was his hidden gem that he only told me about right before he moved across the country!Youre usually seated immediately, if not you may need to wait about 15min. The food is so worth it! Its family style so be sure youre ready to share, but you dont have to! The soup dumplings are delicious and the rice cakes even better!I have to say i like Joes food better, but the prices here are incomparable!

Cash only! But worth the hassle..Came here couple times. Always full and lines but got seated quick. Great to order: - stir fry noodle- scallion pancake with or without beef- fried bun with chives and egg- fry dough- red bean pastry- Xiao long baoExcept the pastry, they all come with grease, but hey YOLO!

This place is a staple for me and my wife. We have been here a few times and the food is always good to  great. The soup dumplings here remind us of the ones we had at nan Xiang in Shanghai and are always good. The sesame pancake with beef is a hole run every time even if it's a little greasy. The seafood crispy noodle was a instant classic the first time we tried it so I suggest everyone to try it. With the food this good you know there will be a crowd and we go on Saturday nights so there is usually a wait but the wait is never long. The place is gritty and cash only so you gotta look past that to experience the great food that they serve.

So it's my first time here amazing food loved all the  food. Especially the soup dumplings. Loved the scallion paancske with beef AMAZING.  A little crowded  but it was on Chinese New Year!!! Highly recommend this place to snyone who wants to enjoy a great dumpling of any kind

I dragged myself to flushing on the subway and was pretty grumpy about it, but everything was okay when I had the pork Xiao Long Bao at Nan Xiang. The were soooooo big and tasty. I loved it so much and it was worth the trip to flushing. We only got the Xiao Long Bao. One pork and one pork and crab. Pork was better.

O M G. I love this place. If I lived in Flushing, I would probably come here once a week. I had one order of their pork XLB, Shu mai, and beef & chili pepper noodle soup. Everything was absolutely delicious!Their XLB is the best I have ever had. It was very fresh and everything about it was just so perfect *drool*. Just make sure to ask for the ginger sauce on the side with the XLB! The noodle soup reminds me so much of my mother's cooking. The soup has a good kick to it too. Service was great. There was immediate seating for two. I love how they gave complimentary green tea. The prices are very reasonable. DEFINITELYYY coming back when I am in the area again.CASH ONLY

What We Ordered- Hot Soy Bean Milk- Pork and Crab Xiao Long Bao Dumplings- Pork Xiao Long Bao Dumplings- Beef RollProbably would not order the hot soy bean milk again... they serve it to you in a odd shaped bowl. Why can't it be served in a cup??!? So hard to drink. Both XLB were delicious (although neither of us could taste the difference between the two). There were so much soup inside!! The wrapper is a little more thick but, it held all the juices together so I'll let it go. Would pass on the beef roll too. They drown it with sauce so it's overpowering. Just order the XLB. It's worth the long trip to Flushing!

Many years before when they opened this restaurant, it suddenly became a busy and successful business at Flushing. You always saw long line outside at the peak hours, with the waiting order numbers issued. For the most recent visit, I arrived early just to avoid the people flow.I ordered their brand Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) and pan fried buns. I was perfectly OK when the waitress told me that I may have to wait for the pan fried buns, cause I understand they should take some time. But to my surprise, it turned out that the fried buns came out first, which means the buns were pre-cooked and kept in the oven. In fact, they were lukewarm and without any soup inside. What a mess!But I have to say their soup dumplings are super good. I am a big fan of Xiao Long Bao, and would like to go any restaurant as long as I know they serve good Xiao Long Bao. My demands are simple: thin dough, decent amount of soup, and good flavor. To me, their soup dumplings are the best at town. Their soup dumplings are worth 5 stars no doubt, but other dim sum and the cash-only rule pulls one star down.Highly recommend to everyone!

So close to Joe's bao, the doe is not too dry or sticky. Having that said, the soup was just the right amount on the inside. I'm not sure of the other stuff on the menu but I would travel here for 40 minutes to get good dumpling rather than and hour into the city for Joe's (+god knows how long for wait.)Pro Tip: budget friendly place!!Update: Spoke to owner recently and the location is closed permanently:'(

FOOD: 7/10SERVICE: 6/10AMBIENCE: 6/10PRICE: $$RECCOMENDATION: wonton w/ spicy peanut sauce, "fried bun" w/chives & egg Overall everything was pretty good, I thought the xiao long bao was aiight. I've definitely had better but that "fried bun" with chives & egg was bomb af. The service was just like any other Chinese restaurant, kind of trash. If you don't know how to speak any mandarin then just point to the items like a fool like how I did. Not a bad place to lay in the cut.
Definitely good. 25 min wait mid-week even for lunch. Liked it. It's a new location about a block from the prior. I would go again.

This little place gets packed and expect to be seated at a table with another party of two. Service here was on point and they start you out with nice complimentary green tea which was perfect on this quasi a cold day. We tried the dumplings pan-fried which came out piping hot so be careful let them cool for a few minutes before you take a bite of them and scald your mouth like I did. I love the texture of the dumplings and the hot chili sauce on the table paired perfectly with them.Next we had the pancake with sliced beef and that was to die for. Nice crispy outside juicy meaty inside. Yum. Plus this place is very affordable!

We came here through the recommendation from some friends on the hunt for the best soup dumplings NY had to offer. We went here on a Saturday for lunch and though there was a large group of people outside their doors, their was turned out only to be about 30 minutes which wasn't bad. Everything on the menu looked really appealing and they had great prices to match. Though I would have liked to order everything on the menu, we were limited by the space in our stomachs. We ordered a soy bean drink $1.75, garlic cucumber $4.95, pork XLB $6.50, and pork and crab XLB $7.50. - The soy bean drink was tasted homemade and was a great start to our meal 4/5- The garlic cucumber is a MUST get. It seriously is so good. There is a perfect balance of garlic, cilantro, and cucumbers. The cucumbers were crisp and fresh and so refreshing to eat. 5/5+- The pork XLB was piping hot when they brought it out. It had so much soup in there and the meat was well seasoned. Nom nom nom, my only gripe is that the skin was slightly thicker than I would like it to be. I would have to rank this XLB as one of my top 3 places to get XLB 4/5.- The pork and crab XLB was just as good and soupy. I just wish there was more crab flavor. Overall really good as well 4/5.Considering the food quality, price point, and wait time, this is definitely worth a visit and a MUST try and totally worth the wait. Note, this place is cash only, so be prepared.

XLB is great! specially the pork ones, service is very quick even tho its always packed, my daughter loves their pan-fried dumplings! the only downside is that theirs always a funky smell, you eventually get used to it but at first its not so welcoming ...

It usually took me an hour to get here from the city. But it's all worth it. Basically everything you order will be great. I highly recommend their beef pancake, pig ears, spicy beef and tripe, and pan fried pork buns. They were so good and authentic. Tip: make sure you get cash before you come here, it's CASH ONLY. If you forget about it, there's a ATM inside the hotel cross the street. The service fee is around $2-3.5.

Checked out their new location on new year's day. We got there a little after 11 am and found huge crowd waiting around the enterance and stairs that leads to the main dining area. We then approached the hostess (a guy holding a clipboard) and told him how many of us, 30 mins he responded and handed us a piece of paper with a number on it. He was pretty spot on, he called our number after about 30 mins. We ordered soon after we settled down (looked at their to go menu while waiting to save time). We got four happiness sponge tofu, braised beef noodle soup, Shanghai pan fried udon, scallion pancake and 2 order of nan xiang xiao long bao. Sponge tofu came out first, followed by udon. I'm a big fan of their spong tofu, the flavor and texture are perfection, not too sweet and I can't get enough of it! Shanghai udon was good too but our toddler was having a hard time chewing it (our fault). Scallion pancake came out next and our little one was loving it! I, who dislike scallion in general, can't  get enough of it either because the amount of scallion in the pancake was not too overwhelming. Braise beef noodle soup came and we also liked it. It's not spicy for us but maybe for our LO it is. The beef was tender and noodle was perfectly cooked. The main star finally came, we all enjoyed it very much. We let it cool abit and when we ate it we were pleasantly surprised how the inside was still nice and warm. Our little one finished 3 of them. Overall, we are happy with our visit. Definitely will come back and will be our to go to place when we have guests in town.

The vast number of reviews of this place makes this a must-go if you are ever in Flushing. You have to try the soup dumplings when you visit. They were delicious and very flavorful. What the waiter didn't tell us is how big they were (despite us asking), so we ordered two plates for two people and we were stuffed (in addition to other dishes). In addition to the dumplings, we also tried Shanghai shumai and scallion pancakes. I didn't realize the shumai was mostly rice-based, so it was super filling without too much flavor. The pancakes were OK and I think it's similar to what you will have at other restaurants. The service is a little poor and our waitress wasn't very friendly, but with that aside, the food here is worth a try.Tips-cash only like other restaurants-soup dumplings are large

I love xiao long bao!!!! Juicy, steamy, hot and meaty! This is heaven! This place is fantastic! Everything is freshly made!I visited this location because the hotel I stayed in flushing(Hyatt) was like 2 mins walking distance so it was super convenient! Location wise, very accessible, indoor decor is ur typical chinese/Taiwanese cafe(cha chan ten style) or u can say dumplings n buns style if u would like, very casual. Price wasn't bad, level $$ in term of pricing but ofc it is also depends on what you order...I order the xiao long bao ofc, super juicy n tasty, highly recommending it! Just do it!Fried dumpling was also bit juicy as well, I like it too. Fried bun? Also juicy, meat was seasoned different ofc, this one is sweeter than the xiao long bao.Overall I really enjoyed this place, I would definitely go back to it! If my tummy could of fit more food I would definitely order more than I did!

BYOB and CASH ONLY!! Food is excellent as always. I usually order the soup dumplings and beef scallion pancakes but this time got some beef tripe in spicy oil, one of their delicious cold appetizers. Sooo good! He only thing is that we joined an existing table, ordered food and they just deliver.. no water nor plates..Came back, food was great, service is about 2/5 :(

Cash only. This review is solely for the XLB aka soup dumplings which were just OKAY. They tasted great, the pork was flavorful and yummy and not too greasy... BUUUUUT... they don't stay intact very well and the dumpling skin is on the dough-ier side. I prefer a thin skin that stays intact. If you like the thicker skin you might not like these either because they weren't super thick but right in the middle. I feel like the dough-ier thicker skin breaks easier because once it cools they dry out where as the thin skinned ones stay intact because they're slightly more stretchy and doesn't dry out. Overall service is exactly what you're used to at any Chinese restaurant in Chinatown or flushing, no fuss but they didn't need to be asked to refill our tea. I wouldn't come out of my way to eat here again, there are plenty of amazing soup dumpling places in Manhattan for decent prices. (6.50/6 dumplings here)

I went to this restaurant out of convenience; it was right next to my hotel in Flushing. Thankfully, this restaurant is also pretty late, even when nearby stores closed. The food here is pretty average, and their menu is rather limited for a Chinese restaurant. However, they prepare the food extremely quickly; your entire table's order will literally come out within ten minutes. Moreover, it is decently priced and not too expensive! The food would be more enjoyable if it wasn't too ready; we ordered a noodle dish and could literally see the oil dripping down the noodles. Other than that, the staff were very attentive and we were in and out of the restaurant within an hour!

Delicious & authentic Chinese food. I was worried about the wait time when we arrived and there was a lot of people waiting, but the turn around time for a table was impressively quick. The food also came out quickly and in waves so everything we got was hot and fresh. Highly recommend!

Y'all, I don't understand what the hype over Joe's Shanghai is. At Joe's, it's crowded and dark, you have to split tables with randos, and they serve their XLB over a bed of lettuce (which is cheaper for them, but makes your buns so soggy by the time you get to eat them!). Yes, Flushing is a little ways out but if you want good food, it is well worth the trek. Also, Nan Xiang is an easy walk from the Flushing Main St. station, and the 7 can take you straight into the city! My mom and I were torn over visiting either Nan Xiang or Kungfu Xiao Long down the street during our one Flushing dinner. We chose Nan Xiang in the end because its menu is Shanghainese through and through-- no chocolate buns (although props for creativity!) or other regional cuisine to pander to the masses. I think we made the right choice.We got an order of the scallion pancakes, potstickers, drunk chicken, garlic cucumber salad, two orders of XLB one meat one crab, and a cold sweetened soymilk all for $50 after tip. What a steal!! And we still had a potsticker and two XLB leftover, so the portions are quite mighty. I really liked everything we ordered-- the XLB were thin and didn't stick to the sheet lining the steamer. There's plenty of soup in them, so beware. The only thing is that the soup seemed more watery than oily and the XLB were a little on the large side (not conducive to popping them) but that's just me being a snob Shanghainese who has been spoiled over the summers in Shanghai! Their drunk chicken deserves special praise. My mom is a fiend for any chicken dish and she loved it. You can definitely taste the cooking wine which is great and the quality of the chicken is amazing. Notice how the chicken skin is yellow rather than white-- that's a GOOD chicken to use! Will absolutely visit again!!!

So I've been coming here for awhile and I must say, the food has lost two stars. The signature Shanghai stir fry was sitting on a bed of oil. The soup dumplings was mediocre. Even though this restaurant had back to back Michelin ratings, it just doesn't cut it for the taste. However, my favorite cold plate of beef tripe is still solid. The scallion pancake with beef is also tasty. I'm used to bad service in authentic Chinese cuisine spots, but today most of the staff was inattentive. Note: My rating is not based on the service. Things we had to ask for today: Tea. So basic right? Especially when it is 10 degrees outside. When the soup dumplings came, we had to ask for sliced ginger: TWICE. So our dumplings got cold and it just didn't taste good anymore. When we wanted to grab the staff attention, there were about five of them all on their phone. The staff wasn't rude, just wasn't attentive. Won't be coming back for awhile. There's Shanghai You Garden that tastes way better. No wonder their wait time is at least an hour.

I actually live right down the street and have seen this spot get crazy busy during spring and summer. Never ventured in because I'm not really to familiar with the different types of dishes or what to order. A buddy of mine invited the wife and I last summer so we finally got a chance to give it a shot as they are regulars.We were sat outside in the backyard patio area which was great, very quite and they even had a nice little water fountain. We let my friends gf do the ordering for the table, she just selected a few items and we all shared. I will do my best to remember what all we had but I can tell you this everything was fantastic and not to expensive (maybe $10 a plate). There was a cold seafood salad, chicken curry, sauteed pea shoots and a soup with shrimp.  Great experience we will be back again!

**** COVID review****- formerly one of the best thai places i NYC but I've been finding myself disappointed- not a fan of the massaman- the wings tasted cheap and frozen- cash only!   * ATM is onsite- I've had better basil friend rice- I've had better curry puffs as well- I loved the friend shrimp!

It has pretty decent Thai food. Not sure if it's a recent thing but I've come here on/off for the past 6ish years? Lately, the food doesn't seem to be great - it gets a lot more traction and is oftentimes very busy. Food still has the spice but it lacks depth of flavor. We ordered a few of the appetizers, the pad see ew and pad thai. Maybe it was a short period of time but the last year or so, we've seen the flavor and quality kind of diminish, hopefully they can turn it around.Also has a pretty small parking lot if you are driving.

I would like to say I've been to SriPraPhai plenty of times over the past 10 years, and I've found the food here has not kept up with my expectations. The food used to be amazing, and I really hate to say it, but I'm not a huge fan of SriPraPhai anymore. I would give their food a 3/5, granted I only ordered Tofu Pad Thai and had their Appetizer sampler. I also ordered their Thai Iced Tea, and it was way too sweet for me. The Pad Thai was not good, it completely lacked the authentic flavor that I'm used to when having Thai food, and it tasted like it was highly sweetened instead of salted. It certainly wasn't what I was used to. There are plenty of really good authentic Thai restaurants in Woodside, and this place isn't one of them for me. The service wasn't the best either. It was completely empty on a Monday night, and we were still rushed out. I wasn't nearly done with my food, and were presented with our bill about 20 minutes in. I guess we overstayed our welcome. It's safe to say, I will not be coming back for a very long time.
Every dish I've ordered here is delicious. My go tos are the papaya salad and basil chicken.

Good authentic Thai food!!!  Best Thai food in my opinion. Gets very busy during normal eating hours so best to come on off times. Staff seems to be running around a lot since many tables/ people to serve so service could be better. Food is spicy. Would definitely recommend. Downsides are the wait and the small parking lot. There is street parking nearby though.This second location of SriPraPhai is alot smaller but has much nicer decor. It also had its own parking lot which is great. And unlike the other location this one takes credit cards. The menu is identical to the other location.  They make a really delicious beef pad see ew and fried scallions. There's also a bar at this location so you can have drinks with your food. The staff is super friendly and attentive.  I really love this restaurant. The only reason I haveo it four stars is that they never have the mango sticky rice dessert.  Every single time it's not available.  They might as well take it off their menu.I had the pad thai noodles with shrimp, massaman beef curry, kao soy noodles with chicken, and the crispy watercress salad. All the dishes were delicious. Service was quick. Would highly recommend for anyone looking for good Thai food in Queens or Long Island.The go to thai spot authentic cuisine in a comfortable setting. Family dinners or a quick lunch.

So it was a stormy day of house hunting near by and my dad and I were starving. We always heard about this place and never got to try it so we walked in. The staff was courteous and sat us right away.PLEASE BE AWARE THIS PLACE IS CASH ONLY!!!!! Thank god I had enough cash on me walking in. They do a great job of making sure people realize this though by posting signs everywhere.We ordered chicken curry puffs to start. I thought these were pretty good and flavorful. I also really liked the vegetables and sauce that came with it to put into the puffs. I had the shrimp paste fried rice and my dad had the massamam curry. I thought mine was good but it really was one note and not too exciting. I also wasn't a huge fan that I had to mix everything together myself.My father's dish was amazing. Hands down the best massamam chicken curry I've ever had with huge chunks of chicken and potatoes and packed with flavor. This amazing dish saves the entrees.We wanted their sticky rice dessert but unfortunately they don't make it in the winter time so we will be back to try this and other dishes on this huge menu.*we were so hungry there are limited pics

Best Thai restaurant in Queens! Everything is delicious and there is outdoor seating too! CASH ONLY!Location: It is located in Woodside Queens. The restaurant is big with a lot of seating, there is a very cute outdoor seating as well for the summer. There is a huge line during weekend specially at night.Service: They are okay, some of them does not speak English so be patient. Food: PAD THAI: one of my favorite! Very authentic pad thai, it has extra cashews at the side, make it beef! SOFT SHELL CRAB: omg this is so good before it comes with coconut soup with squash but I guess during summer its mango salad! Both are delicious with the crab. MANGO SALAD: it is perfect combination with all the fried foods they offer, perfect amount of spice. FRIED WHOLE SNAPPER: the fish is big and well deep fried, combined it with mango salad! SAUTÉED VEGETABLES with FRIED PORK: the vegetables are not overly cooked and has a crunch on it, the fried pork belly are good addition to it. PINEAPPLE FRIED RICE: omg my favorite rice, so good you can eat it on its own! THAI ICED TEA: so creamy and add some bubbles for texture!Price rating: 6/10 very affordable but cash only!Best Thai restaurant for me! Everything is good! Good for family gatherings!
AMAZING! I love this Thai spot. The food is so good. There's been way more white people than usual the last few times I went, but the food quality is still consistent.

Food: 3/5I've been here multiple times but never left a review. They have a great lunch special deal -appetizer, entree, beverage for $15 but recently I stopped by for dinner. We ordered steamed chicken over rice, ground chicken basil over rice and a dark tendon soup.The food was good but not great. I requested my dish be spicy but it wasn't very spicy at all. The steamed chicken also had a slight smell to it. I wasn't a big fan. Never a bad experience here. Solid food all around. Service: 4/5The staff members here are great! Very accommodating and attentive.Ambiance: 4/5This is one of the nicer Thai establishments in the area. Great date night spot. They have a beautiful waterfall in the back near the bathroom. Very clean.PS: cash only

Best freaking Thai food in NYC. Period.I first got to know about this place from a foodie colleague of mine, and came for dinner here with him and a group of his friends. Apparently the Chef is an old Thai lady who doesn't give an F about anything but good food.. when she got nominated for the James Beard award she said "Who is James Beard?" After being wowed in my first encounter, I dragged my fiancee as well. She has a better palate than mine, so needless to say she was amazed too. The intensity and balance of flavors is astounding. The dishes are not complicated, but rather basics done right.There was not a single bad dish there, so no cons at all! Here's what stood out from my two visits. Also keep in mind they are cash-only! What to get:Crispy watercress and seafood/chicken salad (A6 on the menu I think)- Skip the chicken and get with only seafood. Perfect appetizer- sweet, spicy, crispy, savory all playing tango inside your mouth! I cannot praise this dish more.Tom Yum soup- Beautiful fresh acidity. Crunchy lemongrass pieces are great to chew on.Khao soi- screams freshness. So aromatic, and perfectly balanced by the creaminess of the coconut milk.Jungle curry- again, very very fresh and herbacious. Also the green peppercorns are awesome!Meh:Pad thai: I've never had a good pad thai. This is one of the dishes I was expecting to be wowed by here, but it was a-ok. Definitely better than then other pad thai's I've had, with a good charred flavor (from what I don't know), but meh otherwise.Keep in mind:Tell them what spice level you want, else they'll make everything mild. The highest level of spicy is not too spicy, but can vary based on the dish.

Before COVID me and my family were regulars at this place. However after ordering a pick-up few weeks ago we will most likely never come back here again. Our favorite things about this restaurant was the beautiful outdoor space, good food, and affordability. Now obviously the location part is taken away. When we ordered the food for pick up it was honestly just not good, everyone in our party found something wrong with their food that wasn't there before. Another thing is how overpriced it was this time and compared to what we used to pay, this was absolutely not worth it and way too much for what the food was. Most of it got thrown out and unfinished.

I am really not sure why there are over 2000 glowing reviews for this place. Yes the food is reasonably price. Yes the food comes out quick and hot. Yes there is a very extensive and wide selection to choose from on the menu. But I would say that is where the positives end. The food is really nothing to write home about. It is cash only. The restaurant is not much to look at.I don't think that it's any better than your average run-of-the-mill Thai restaurant. In this area of Queens that has so much to offer, I will probably not be back.

My favorite Thai Restaurant in the area and quite possibly in NYC! Came here for a friends Birthday celebration. I got the Duck Drunk Noodle and it was plenty to split between two people. My friends got Pad Thai, Ka-Soy and they were all delicious! This is a cash only restaurant but the price is right! The menu seems like it never ends and there is something for everyone! I look forward to coming back! I have been dreaming of the Lychee ice cream since the last time I went. Excellent food, service and very welcoming atmosphere.

FOOD: 7/10SERVICE: 6.5/10AMBIANCE: 8.5/10RECOMMENDATION: beef satayYou people on yelp obviously never had good Thai food before cause this place is a 3 star at most. The only thing I would order here again is there beef satay and the Kao Soy. I wish they gave more of the crispy noodles for the Kao Soy cause they only give like a bites worth. The crispy taro shreds, Pat see ew, basil fried rice, and shrimp egg rolls were also nothing special. The shrimp cakes tasted good but didn't have the chewy texture that most shrimp cakes should have. I should also mention that the service here was also kind of slow. Over all this place was just average to me. There are plenty of other thai places in NY that I would much rather go to.

My friend and I came out of our way to eat here. Overall... I thought the food here was okay. Not bad, but not the greatest thai food I've ever had. This place definitely has a lot of hype. We tried the drunken noodles, pad thai, and fish cakes. My pad thai was only okay. Could only finish 1/3 of it. Tip: Bonus outdoor seating that everyone that came in did. If you're in the area sure, but not worth going out of your way for.

This popular Thai restaurant in Woodside has the longest menu I've ever seen, complete with 5 pages dedicated just to desserts! They're particularly known for their Mango Sticky Rice, which sadly I didn't get a chance to try since mangoes are not in season. I'll definitely be back once it's available again and I can't wait to explore more of their dishes!My only gripe is that it's cash only and none of the dishes come with rice (you have to order it separately which makes this a tad pricier than  other Thai restaurants).

Although this is far for me, I am willing to go out of my way to eat here.  They also sell Vietnamese desserts to take out.Food is very good.  I have been here twice and loved it both times.I love the steamed fish with an unusual fish sauce based sauce.  We've had various dishes frkm here and you ca5 go wrong with any of them.I also like taking home desserts to go from their cooler by the entrance.  I like the pandan-coconut desserts.REMINDER:  They are closed on Wednesdays for lunch. (We've had errors of coming all the way just to find out they are closed)

Easily one of the best Thai restaurants in all of NYC. Don't get intimidated by the menu, and don't expect white table cloth service. They bash out excellent meals right and left. This place was recommended to me by a Thai woman, and it easily compares to those that I've been to in Thailand. People actually travel to queens to eat there, and for good reason. Check out the Thai grocery across the street. They have products that are difficult to find, even in flushing. Always smile, and say khob khun khap or kop khun ka.

Really, really solid Thai place. Lots of seating, quick service, and AMAZING food. We had- fried fish cake - papaya salad- crispy Chinese watercress salad- pad see-ew- pork leg- tom-zap: spicy & sour soup- pineapple fried rice- roasted duck green curry- yam, black rice & coconut milk dessertThe watercress salad, pad see-ew and tom-zap were highlights. There were 9 humans so we could order a big range of things and that was great. I recommend going in a group.

Great Thai food. The crispy Chinese watercress salad is a must have, although I wouldn't call it a salad. The drunken noodles are good. The curry puffs are just ok, in my opinion. Very busy place, always packed with Asians. Definitely worth the visit

Best thai restaurant in NYC in my eyes. Been going there for 15 years! They also have another location in Long Island but the one in Queens is the best one. The only thing they changed is the shrimp cake. It was so much better before. I don't know why they changed the recipe to the fried shrimp cake or got another brand of shrimp cake. But please bring the old one back!! My favorite is the crispy pork with Chinese broccoli and soft shell crab. The raw shrimp is very good too! Pretty much all of their stuff is good. Gotta try it! The garden seating area is also pretty nice in the summer. Check out the pics. Oh they are cash only.

Can I just start this review off by saying every time I step foot into this restaurant, it feels like I'm back in Thailand?The food here literally tastes exactly how my dishes tasted during my trip to Bangkok and Phuket. Literally. The pad thai was great. The minced pork with basil was amazing. Soft shell crab. The curry. The fried rice. Literally everything on the menu was amazing. The atmosphere is also resembles a small bustling restaurant in Bangkok - the waiters are all hyper but friendly, running around taking orders and dropping off food. I wish I could convey this atmosphere in words but you just gotta go there to experience it. Cash only by the way. Weird because their other branch out in Nassau county takes credit card, but the prices are also higher at the other branch. Maybe thats why.

*CASH  ONLY* but they do have an ATM inside and they are CLOSED on WEDNESDAY. :) Authentic Thai dishes with an extensive menu. There is so much to pick from that sometimes I don't know what to get and I get the same thing. Regardless it's amazing food. This is my husbands favorite restaurant and I can see why. The papaya seafood salad ( medium spice is very spicy FYI, well to me it is) is fresh light and perfect to start off with. Crispy pork is phenomenal with great flavors. Must order the fish w/ the sweet and sour sauce. Pair that with some coconut rice and it's outstanding. A great combo of flavors. The fish is very moist and it's fried so well that you don't have to worry much about the bones. Must try the coconut icecream which is homemade. It's a great ending to the evening. It's not overly sweet and it's topped with some peanuts and jellies. I ordered some to go as well.

I'll have to say it's around 3.5 stars.My first time here was with my family after my aunt had this on her to-go list for a while. We got lucky with parking, but you'll have to fight for street parking at certain times. Came again with a friend a couple of days ago and everything seems to be the same as I remembered.I started off with a Thai Iced Tea and the Combination Spring Rolls (Regular and Spicy) to share. I probably should've told them less sweet, but this was just as overly sweet as I remembered from last time (Okay, I really should've been smarter). I got the Red Curry with Chicken and a side of Brown Rice while my friend got the Pad See Ew. My Red Curry: The flavors were all there, but I didn't like how the texture of the curry was gritty. It seemed like they keep it boiling for so long that some vegetables or meat were disintegrating and creating that dissolved texture. I'm not mad about it, but I didn't enjoy it as much because of the texture. The flavors were perfect though and the medium spice level was that nice amount of spice for me! The Pad See Ew: Now, my friend is a huge fan of Kin'd because Kin'd tends to be more heavy handed with their flavors, aka saltier. I quote my friend when I say, "The Pad See Ew is more mild than the one at Kin'd". I don't think this necessarily is a bad sign, but I don't think my friend would come back as he prefers the flavors at Kin'd. I did taste that SriPraPhai's Pad See Ew was less flavorful than Kin'd, but I normally eat less salty so I thought it was okay. Service: The waitress that served us was super nice though! We asked to move outside and she warned us beforehand about bugs and caterpillars if we moved. Loved that she always had a smile on her face. Very sweet! Overall, both experiences were nothing spectacular and I wouldn't choose to venture out to Woodside just to eat here. If I'm in the area, I'll consider going here (also why I decided to try this place or a second time).

Upon exiting we decided we'd not go to another Thai restaurant from here on out. Why bother when we've found the best one in queens? Maybe in all the boroughs.SPP is a large restaurant (seating 200+) and runs like a well oiled machine with a bar, to-go apps and snacks and a separate dining room next to the main and a splendid garden area. It seemed that everyone and their neighbor knows this spot that's boasts over 2000 yelp reviews with 4 stars that's situated off Roosevelt on a decidedly quieter block on 39th ave. Would've thwarted any trendy restaurant but not SPP- not when your food is so good and management this tight.We happily ordered duck salad, shrimp paste fried rice and fried trout with lemongrass sauce. The menu is 3 pages of interesting salads alone and get this- $4.50 beer. Not your run-of-the-mill Thai offerings with a bullseye lock on what diners feel are uber competitive rates. We were blown away by the delicious duck salad with generous thick slices of duck breast doused in sliced cherry tomatoes, red onions, papaya, cucumber, cilantro, peanuts, lime and fish sauce. Sweet, salty, spicy, tangy check. Only thing that could've improved was a bigger portion and white rice to sop up all the flavors. The fried rice was like another salad platter neatly plated with quadrants of julienned papaya, minced string beans, soy marinaded chicken, onions, egg, and dried shrimp. Definitely more subtle in flavor with all the fresh ingredients- it was a veritable poke rice bowl. The fish- oh my. We opted for the small and was explained it would be a filet of trout but what was served pretty much resembled a whole fish. Fluffy not unlike cod and dressed with an emulsified bevy of peppers, lemongrass and ginger. Sweet and tangy over a perfectly cooked fish that was tender and juicy. So darn good, I'd like to eat it twice and in fact requested extra rice with our leftovers. SPP exceeded all my expectations. The only regret i have is that my curiosity of the hard to pronounce namesake that presents like an Americanized Thai chain spot is anything but was not strong enough to compel me to visit sooner. I could've been having SPP all of 2018! Don't let that be you. (You're welcome)

We have been to this place many times in both woodside and long island location. We tried out most of their menu. Today, their bbq pork - a22 has too much black pepper. It is usually my fave pick but not today. The salted beef fried rice is always on point - highly recommended if you like fried rice. Their green curry is good - we ordered the one with bamboo shoot instead of thai egg plant. It is way yummier. Their morning glory is good as well. This place is cash only so bring some cash in. Their service was so so. The waiter has to be called to fill in glass of water

Came here with my family on Veterans day. We made a reservation, came early, but were still seated right away!We ordered a whole bunch of dishes to celebrate a special occasion. We ordered the following:-Papaya Salad: Really good, on the top 5 best I've ever had. It was very citrusy, and was seasoned really well. Be careful of the chili peppers, I downed 3 glasses of water. -Fried Calamari: Basic calamari, simple and tasty. Sauce was good. -Chicken Satay: Chicken was very juicy and tender. Sauces were very good.-Crab Fried Rice: Very simple yet delicious, the way fried rice should be. Had huge chunks of crab!-Stir fried Chinese Watercress: Basic veggies, added to our order so we feel better about eating everything else. -Vegan Pad Thai: Special request for my grandma, and she loved it (she's a picky eater) Flavors were amazing, and they added various veggies for her to enjoy. -Stir Fried Seafood Trio: There was shrimp, fish, and squid. It was good, but nothing special that stood out. Portion was good though, just wish there was more flavor. -Shrimp Pad Thai: I had this to-go the next day, and it was still good. I love the different textures that are in the dish. Its not just noodles and shrimp. There were other lovely bits like tofu or some type of veggie. I can't have pad thai anywhere else now. -Steamed Fish in Banana Leaf: my grandma is an adventurous eater, and she likes fish. This dish is more of a traditional dish. There was a lot of strong flavors, so if you are not familiar with kaffir lime leaves or fish sauce, this might not be for you. Fish was cooked nicely, and coconut cream on top was a nice touch.Overall, this is one of the best Thai restaurants I have ever visited. There is a lot of options, and you can customize the dishes to your liking. They also have a huge vegetarian/vegan menu, so theres a lot of options for everyone. Not only was the food good, but the customer service was amazing. We had some food restrictions, and they had no problem running back and forth to check on the ingredients for us. Everyone was so nice, and accommodating. Highly recommend this place!

There are so many Thai restaurants in New York, it's hard to say which is "authentic". I worked in a Brooklyn restaurant whose chef was Thai. She brought me food a few times that she had prepared at home. I suppose that was the most authentic. All I know is that the food in Sri PraPhai is delicious. My daughter and I go there and always order one dish we have never had because it's so hard not to just order our 4 or so favorites. So yes, we have a lot of food to take home and enjoy in the days following our visit.

A couple of friends and I enjoyed a scrumptious dinner at SriPraPhai recently.  We split a noodle, meat, and veggie dish - more specifically the pad see-ew with beef, the roasted duck, and greens.  All were delicious; although, the noodles were my favorite.  Warning: They are cash only so come prepared.

Love their thai food very much! Sadly there isn't much good thai restaurants in brooklyn. But it is worth traveling to Woodside for decent thai food. I love their drunken noodle, massaman w/ coconut rice, satay, thai ice tea and sticky rice w/ mango dessert. Super delicious and not too expensive! Staff was nice and friendly, and the decor is mod. Cash only!

Hey allWas visitings queens and thought to check out the place once again. Usually i visit this spot during lunch time and its been good but this time it was for dinner and things got a little weird. Atmosphere:- its always cool to see people from all walks of life. Families, loved ones or dates. All in one spot. Pretty cool.Food:- the foods been awesome during day time specially duck soup & noodles. Everything is good.Pad thai too and some funky salads specially the larb one's.Service :- day time was 3 stars but night time is just terrible i am mean terrible. The dude is telling me i ordered the same dish 2 twice. now why would i do that since i am with friends and they all know what they ordered! Hilarious. He took it back since it did not make sense to even his own people. On purpose the food was bland. Terrible service i swear.Long story short :- the food is good and atmosphere is cool too. The service from last night really shocked me. The dude literally told me we are closing in 10 mins and the time was 9:00. Basically eat up and get out. I mean i crave good food and can stand in lines for one but this was a bit to far.Good environment Food was nice ( depends on servers mood or kitchens )Terrible service Its just my opinion based on my experience.

This was excellent. I was pretty stuck between 4 and 5, but went with 4 because there are other Thai places I definitely prefer (eg Ugly Baby, Uncle Boons). Those felt more destination-worthy to me, whereas this felt like more of an outstanding neighborhood place.First visit, we started with the papaya salad (medium spice) and spring rolls, and then followed those with the penang curry (mild, for my wife) and the roasted duck green curry (extra spicy, for me). The spring rolls were good, but I'd be fine skipping those next time. The papaya salad was excellent, and basically a perfect summer dish. We really liked both curries as well -- I think I'd prefer the penang, if it had been the one with more spice, but both were great.Overall, a great spot that is well worth the trip.

Nice backyard. Clean restaurant. Value lunch special. Vegetarian soup lacked flavor. Pad Thai with shrimp was very mushy. Pineapple fried rice lacked flavor. Thai iced coffee was very sweet but tasted good.

I've had this place bookmarked for years, but everyone keeps telling me that it's no longer good. It's hard for me to judge because I've only gone in recent years and I don't know what it used to be like. That said, I thought the savory food ranged from mediocre to pretty good, and the mango coconut sticky rice was a clear 5 stars. So I guess it averages out to 4 stars! I don't remember what I've gotten here besides the drunken noodles and an eggplant dish; I've eaten in and I've done take out. Do be careful with the spice level because they are not diluting the heat; I could barely enjoy my drunken noodles because they were so spicy. There was one time that a take out noodle dish came home ultra overcooked, but there have also been good meals. The prices aren't bad and I've never encountered a wait so I can't complain, but I don't think it deserves the cult following that I've heard about.That said, I've never had better mango sticky rice anywhere else; it's the real deal - sweet and salty with crunchy bits and a decadent coconut sauce. I can't not get it every time I come, and I haven't been anywhere else that serves such a comparable mango sticky rice. (If you have, please lmk!) And for that, I will always come back.

These curry puffs are to die for, I've always enjoyed their food. They were quite unorganized and unable to handle takeout/delivery during corona. I ordered ahead and was told to arrive an hour after my order. I did but I ended up waiting two hours in the restaurant while they made my order. The restaurant started with around 20 people waiting for orders and I sat 6 feet away as I watched people without masks walking in out and to get their orders. I was one of the last people served. Super sad I had to wait 3 hours for 3 dishes but again, the curry puffs are dope.

Come here for all of your Thai dessert cravings!! As soon as you walk into the store, there are two refrigerators on the right where you can satisfy your sweet tooth or even your savory taste buds.They have everything from sago and coconut milk, woon, foy thong, thong yip, kao niao sang kaya ... basically almost everything you could also find on the streets of Thailand. The variety is amazing and don't miss the khanom shan sitting by the register. It's also a sit down restaurant but I was just craving something sweet. Do bring cash though! Luckily, they're all super affordable ($3.50/dessert container)

THE BEST Thai resto I've ever eaten at in America. And I'm 100% Thai, been to Thailand many times, eaten in the Thai town in LA as well, etc. The food is authentic and while there are some Americanized dishes (e.g. drunken noodles), everything else is bleeding Thai. Definitely order the chicken and rice (Khao mun gai), and the stir fried Thai veggies - IDK what the English translation is just the Thai words - pak boong pat. Laarb was very good too. My favorite part is grabbing the ka-nom (desserts) to go in the fridge by the cashier. I find it strange there are 3-4 star reviews for this place...you guys must've never had real Thai food from Thailand...

Location: this place is right in the woodside neighborhood. I took the 7 train and got off at 66 street. Place is really hard to find even in a sunny day. Why? I guess it's because there're so many neons there that I just started to lose all my patience. Please do not be me...Food: had their pad thai and tom yum soup. It's what you have expected - but not the best. Pad thai is sweet whereas tom yum soup is not that good. I mean, I've eaten better Thai food in manhattan and expected to try some legit Thai food here. But everything seems to be neutralized to American taste where I got little surprises. UGH, maybe without eating too many thai food, I can rate a 4 star here but ... sorry for being picky.Price: but the price is very legit. I meant, the price is very cheap and nice. I highly recommend you to come here eat alone lol. Service: they are thai, they know english so dont hesitate to visit here and try stuffThey are nice and welcomingoverall: 3.5  - average food, cheap price

Excellent excellent excellent! What more can I say? DEFINITELY lived up to the hype. The food was super authentic and the flavors of each dish were so different. They were definitely not afraid to prepare the dishes the way they should be (SPICY! So be careful ) and did not hold back on the fish sauce and seasoning to accommodate people who are expecting Americanized Thai food. We got the seafood papaya salad, chicken larb, pad Thai, the red curry, and the sour curry with egg omelette. Everything was insanely good! The larb and egg omelette really stood out. For ground chicken, it was very moist and fresh. The sour curry was the perfect combination of sweet, spicy, and tangy (I believe tamarind-based), and the cubes of egg omelette were nice and fluffy, super effective in soaking up the perfect amount of curry! The 5 dishes with rice were the perfect amount of food for 3 people. We wiped the plates clean and we were incredibly full and satisfied at the end of the meal. Highly highly recommend!!

My boyfriend and I came for lunch on a Saturday afternoon and had no trouble getting a table. I had a Thai iced tea, and we shared the papaya salad, chicken pad Thai, eggplant and a side of coconut rice. My favorites were the pad Thai and the rice, but everything was delicious. Iced tea was perfect, too. Without a doubt some of the best Thai food I've had in my life. Cash only!
Some of the best Penang curry I've ever tasted. A dish to come back for. The Chinese watercress salad was also delicious but the curry was just phenomenal
Authentic Thai...great lunch special. Cash only. Very spicy...papaya salad and drunken noodles are delicious

SriPraPhai Thai is an excellent Thai restaurant. The food was top notch, the ambience is casual and the service is good.They are famous for excellent Thai food. Their menu is a like a mini book, with multiple soups, stews, apps, entrees and desserts. Despite looking over the menu and recommendations beforehand, I had to spend 10 minutes deciding on what I really wanted to order.I was a bit apprehensive to try them because so many foodie friends have recommended SriPraphai and I was afraid they wouldn't measure up to my expectations. Thank goodness my fear was unfounded!K and I went here for dinner. The front dining room was full of large parties and children. The second room (where we were seated) was filled with smaller groups and couples on dates. We ordered Larb salad (ground beef, fresh mint, chili and lime juice), Kao Soy (curry egg noodles with chicken), and Crabmeat fried rice. SriPraPhai Thai food is Thai food on another level! The Larb was bright, refreshing and spicy. It was delicious! The beef was springy and had so many flavors: funk from the fish sauce, brightness from the lime and cooling taste from the mint. It was very addictive. The Khao soy was aromatic and rich from coconut cream. It was slightly sweet. The curry noodles helped calm the heat from the larb. I liked the little plate of mustard greens, red onions and extra egg noodles to add to the curry. The crab meat fried rice was moist, filled with crab and had a generous helping of fish sauce. It was wonderful. You could see the meaty crab legs and taste the occasional shell from the crab. Service was good. They were quick to refill our orders, bring out the food and didn't rush us to leave. I can't wait to return and try more of the menu!instagram.com/snackchatn…

They used to be a lot better. I haven't been for a very long time, went back with my husband and kids a few days ago. Ordered a few dishes I used to like, but it doesn't taste the  same anymore.  The green curry duck, it use to be a lot more creamy and tasty. The pad thai was very oily. The chicken over rice, the chicken was very dry.

I asked my Thai friend what the best time restaurant was in New York and she, without hesitation, said this place. When I finally made the journey to Queens to try this place, I was very excited to see how it would hold up. The restaurant itself is pretty unassuming, I went for lunch on a weekend and it wasn't crowded. We had the papaya salad, pad see ew, and a dish with pigs feet. The papaya salad was so fresh and flavorful, the portion was really generous, and it was the perfect dish to  have on a summer day. Pad see ew was so flavorful and the noodles and the meat were great. The dish with the pigs feet, was definitely the starter. The meet was fall off the bone, and the sauce was delicious. The dish with the pigs feet was definitely the star. The meet was fall off the bone, and the sauce was delicious. We had it with a side of coconut rice, which, to my surprise, wasn't sweet. There was just a hint of coconut in the rice and it was really delicious. We finished the meal with a coconut dessert made from some sort of root vegetable and it was subtly sweet and absolutely amazing. Don't go there expecting nice service, but the food speaks for itself.

This is my favorite Thai restaurant and it makes top 5 in top Thai restaurant in NYC lists every year. I have been to Thailand and also grew up eating Thai food pretty often. Everyone I have ever brought here has enjoyed their meals.  They can make spicy dishes mild upon request, but if, like me, you crave authentic Thai spice and flavors, definitely dine here. And also ask for the side of Thai hot sauces/chili powder!Note that this location is still CASH ONLY. They also have a LI location that takes credit cards (and has easier parking) but there's something extra special about the food at this original location. I was just here for the first time in years (I had been going to the LI location in recent years) and my first time since it expanded to a larger size.  It used to be much smaller and almost always a crowd outside waiting for a table. This time, in the new location, 2 of us were able to walk in on a Friday night and be seated almost immediately. We wished we were a larger party so that we could sample and share more dishes. We decided to go with a few apps and 2 entrees, and had a lot of leftovers. And of course we also each had a Thai iced tea with our meal :)For appetizers we went with the squid salad (legit Thai spicy! SO GOOD!), the fish cakes (one if my all time go-to things to order at a Thai restaurant), and the spring rolls. As much as I hate to say this, I would skip the spring rolls next time, because although they are good they aren't as mind-blowing as the other appetizers. I didn't order it this visit but I also love their curry puffs and would order them next time instead. We had a classic shrimp pad Thai and massaman curry with a side of coconut rice for our entrees.  Both were amazingly delicious and neither of them are spicy, in case anyone is concerned with spice.Whether here or another one of their locations, I always highly recommend Sripraphai restaurant for authentic and reasonably priced Thai food.

This is definitely the best Thai restaurant I've been to in NYC.Each time I come, their quality is consistently excellent.We ordered the papaya salad with ground catfish, the pork noodle soup, and the stir fried Chinese broccoli with crispy pork belly.The papaya salad with ground catfish is the perfect starter. The dressing is packed with intense flavor and the papaya shreds are crunchy and refreshing. You want to mix it all together with the crispy ground catfish which is a light, crunchy, and salty cluster of light brown matter placed next to the salad. I have no idea who thought grounding up catfish meat and deep frying it would make a good topping, but that man deserves to have his name remembered. The catfish gives a very nice textural contrast to the salad.The pork noodle soup was huge and delicious as always. It's packed full of pork of all kinds, sliced, balled, etc. The noodles can be had either wide or thin. We ordered wide. The broth is tangy and savory. Definitely big enough for 2 people.The Chinese broccoli with pork belly was nicely executed. The broccoli isn't overcooked and is appropriately seasoned. The pork belly is extremely crispy and offers a nice contrast to the slight bitterness of the broccoli.We also ordered Thai iced teas and coffees which you can never go wrong with.I don't give a lot of 5 star reviews but the consistency and quality of this place really does call for that 5th star.The service is good and prompt. The decor is clean and utilitarian. They only accept cash but have an ATM here that only charges a $1 fee.Get yourself over here now if you want the best Thai food in the city.

SO.EFFING.BOMB.Just like going back to Thailand without the long flight.DAS IT.Pad thai was my fav Thai dish growing up. But I realize that it's a hard dish to perfect because it's just OK every time I order it. This is the only place that has it down 100%.

Delicious!  I went in today for lunch and we were seated right away. The restaurant isn't anything fancy or fabulous looking. They are known for delicious food and they deliver on that. There are lunch specials until 3 Pm for about $15. That includes an appetizer, entree and dessert. I decided to just order a separate entree and went with a favorite of mine: pad see ew with crispy pork. It was a generous serving and also very tasty. The Thai iced tea was very sweet but delicious over ice. The suggested dessert was a mango and coconut type of thick jelly. I didn't care for it but we tried something new. Overall, if you want good Thai, this is a great place to check or. Cash only.

My fiancé and I came here for dinner tonight. We ordered the chicken satay, chicken and shrimp dumplings, and two orders of drunken noodles. I asked for the drunken noodles to be as mild as possible and they were still a bit on the spicier side (my fiancé asked for his order to be medium and it was the same level of spiciness as mine). However, the service was really great and our glasses of water were constantly refilled as soon as they were coming close to being empty, so I looked past the spiciness and still enjoyed my meal.We enjoyed our food and this will definitely be our go-to spot for thai food in Queens now.I was actually surprised at how great the chicken satay was, as I usually am not a great fan of it (from previous experiences at other places).It is cash only. There is a big sign on the door. There is an ATM machine inside.We did also notice that on the front page of the menu it states that you can bring in your own liquor for a fee (don't know what that fee is though).

I have to give them credit.  The good was good and priced well considering what Manhattan would charge.  I am not happy they only accept cash but am not experiencing the same issues I had in the past.  Further, we were not rushed.

Came back a second time to try just the vegetarian menu. Fried Shredded Taro and Peanut - interesting to have but probably would not order again. Fried Curry Puff - not bad but not spicy. Green Curry - this was actually spicy, probably more than I can handle. Kao Soy - not bad, maybe a little too sweet for me. Sauteed Mock Duck - was actually the highlight of the meal, although it doesn't taste like duck, just a really nice tofu. Pad-See-Ew or Soy sauce noodles, as it says on the bill - pretty good version of this dish.

One of the best Thai spots in the city at a reasonable price. Some dishes were reminiscent of some Thai-Chinese I grew up with. I would definitely go back. Try the green curry, curry puffs, chicken satay skewers, and mango sticky rice

I have been hearing about SriPraPhai since I moved to New York City. After a friend's birthday party in Jackson Heights, we seized our chance to come here for a late Saturday lunch. IT IS CASH ONLY. The menu is full of goodies. We had a feast of tom yum, papaya salad, beef larb, pad thai with shrimp, the roasted duck curry, and drunken noodles. (What more could one want in life?)The service was a bit slow in the slump of the afternoon. It took a while for someone to come over and take care of our order, but once we ordered everything came out in lightning fast time. Fair warning, they do put hot spicy pepper in the papaya salad so watch out for that burn!The tom yum is sweet and spicy. Sweeter than most tom yum, so be prepared for that. I loved that there were so many mushrooms floating around, and the to-share portion split amongst three was a good serving. The beef larb was flavorful and warm. I think it was my favorite protein dish, though the duck in the green curry was tender and delicious as well. The green curry was spicy and tasted rich with coconut milk. Just the right amount of spice, and the white rice soaked it up perfectly. We all loved the texture of the flat rice noodles in the drunken noodle dish, but preferred the flavor of the pad thai. Getting chicken in the drunken noodle was the only disappointing thing; I'd suggest getting a different meat. Overall, everything tasted authentic and delicious. The portions were larger than we thought, and we had plenty of extra food. I'd definitely come back! I'd even order take out and eat it at home if I could.
Normally their food is delicious but I bought one of their corn / coconut desserts and it was clearly rotten.  Tasted like expired cheese, had to puke it out.

Papaya salad - Very tasty with a slight sweet taste to it.Pineapple fried rice - Stingy with the pineapples and meat. The dish lacks flavor. I would not recommend it unless you like eating a lot of rice.Whole Fried Red Snapper with sweet chili sauce - Very generous portion. The fish was crispy and the sweet chili sauce was tasty. The whole dish was a bit too salty.Jelly desserts - Tasted ok but I would not recommend unless you are the type that likes to eat very firm jelly.Durian Ice Cream - Ice cream comes with peanuts and jelly on top. The ice cream was not very creamy and has a mild taste of durian. For $5, you get a very generous portion of ice cream.

Yum. Come for authentic Thai and have good service at the same time. It's also quite nice in there and not a hole in the wall. Larb - SOOO spicy but I cant handle spicy so just be forewarned. It's good but if you normally can't, stay away. Curry puffs - good fried dough and fillingTofu puffs - tasty enoughRad na - great, tasty gravy fat noodle. It tastes more similar to a Chinese noodle.Curry fish fillet - soo tasty. Red sauce that isn't a harsh spice. Tender fish fillets that are easy to eat. Big space that can accommodate big groups but I'm sure at peak times they get crowded!
Wow. Wow. Wow. Best Thai in all of queens hands down no competition. Don't even doubt. Get it done and eat your heart out
Green curry with roast duck is delicious . Must try the fried water crest salad with squid chicken and shrimp.

My friends and I walked in on a Saturday lunch and we were seated right away outside in the back garden. The atmosphere is lovely with a lot of plants and flowers around and a small fountain. We ordered a BBQ Beef Salad for appetizer. So it's not really a typical salad with veggies but more like grilled beef seasoned with lime juice and stuff. It's really good trust me. I ordered the Chicken with ginger sauce over rice. The chicken wasn't too dried and I love the sauce! It also came with a bowl of chicken broth. All of the dishes we ordered were a big portion so keep that in mind. They have pages of dessert which is everyone's dream. I had the Lod Chong with ice and it was very refreshing and authentic. Price is reasonable and service is so-so. Definitely gonna come back to try more!

This is one of my favorite thai restaurants in Queens, NY. I love the Mango salad and the papaya salad, the red snapper, the ground beef with white rice and alot of other dishes. They make good cocktails too! I went there so many times!Only down side is that they take cash only, but love the food!

I've been going to SriPraPhai for couple years now with my family and my friends and the food has been consistently good. Location is a bit removed so I can't go often, but it is definitely worth a trip at least once or twice a month. It's a must-go place if you are looking for a good Thai restaurant for a more affordable price. Atmosphere is casual and it is cash only! There is plenty of seating for a group, although it can get quite packed during peak hours. The menu is huge so I recommend: Fried Fish topped w. chili, garlic and basil sauce and Sauteed Chinese Watercress.
Absolutely delicious food!!!   My favorite Thai restaurant! I've never had an issue with this spot! Beautiful garden area when able to eat outdoors.

What happened to this place? I used to crave SriPraPhai but this last visit things were meh at best. Everything skewed soooo sweet. The tum yum soup was practically sugar in hot water, the morning glory was fine, but both the pad thai and red curry was not what I used to love of this place. The taste palette is broad in strokes and geared for people who don't want delicate flavorings that Thai food has. Perhaps the immense amount of solid Thai in the area has made these guys rest on their laurels, but damn this is a fall from grace.

I think this is as authentic as Thai food gets in NYC. Food here isn't westernized at all, and all the fragrances of lemongrass, ginger, fish sauce, and all the great spices and ingredients are pronounced as any good Thai cuisine should.  The variety of available dishes is staggering, and some of the less known northern Thai cuisine are available here as well. Service is friendly, the atmosphere is casual and loud.Only thing I would caution is that this location is cash only, but they do have an ATM on premises.
Best Thai food in NYC! The only thing better would involve a 16 hour flight and even then I still pick this place. You can't go wrong here, EVERYTHING is delicious!

Solid Thai food. Cash only.  It's def a better option to stop by here with larger number of people so you can order and try more foods since the food here is delicious. We were a table of 5 plus a baby and we waited around 15 minutes for outdoor seating on a Sunday night around 7pm. The restaurant was busy throughout our dinner but service was pretty fast and efficient. To start we got the watercress salad, roasted duck salad, and chicken larb. My favorite is always the watercress salad. The fried crunch goes so well with the salty squid sauce that comes on the side. The larb had a good kick to it which I enjoyed but can be too much of other people who can't tolerate spicy foods. My friend ordered for us so I can't really say what was delicious but the green curry was fantastic with the coconut rice. The pineapple fried rice was ok. I preferred eating the coconut rice with the different meat dishes rather than just fried rice. Will def be back here when craving Thai food.
Horrible This place was it - so many years ago - a good memory Flavorless horror food nowComplained - pointless

A New York friend always recommended this spot for us! And today we have an opportunity to stop by this area and then try this restaurant. Homely, food were delicious but a little sweet for me. That's fine. So 5 stars for it!
Really great Thai place to check out in NYC! Staff is hard working and kind and food is fast and yummy!

This is not my first review. I come here often. It used to be perfect in a sense but recently they have off days. Green curry a bit off. May be better without pork. Laab moo is not good. Would not get again.  Duck salad too salty and without the flavor it usually has. Mango salad is excellent.

I luckily walked by this place on my way to work tonight, the wonderful smells lured me in so I stopped for a quick bite and am so very glad I did. I was in a bit of a hurry and got seated and placed my order right away during a busy weeknight...customer service was impeccable but the food was the shining star--papaya salad was among the top 3 I've ever had, Tom kha soup was wonderful and I'm already planning to come back tomorrow with my husband to try more of the menu!!

We came here this past weekend to celebrate my son's birthday. I tried to call a few days in advance to make a reservation since we were a party of six but they don't take reservations. The lady on the phone asked what time we would be arriving and when I told her she assured me that there would be availability so we took a chance.When we arrived, parking was scarce so I would suggest parking on a side residential street. The restaurant seemed pretty packed upon entering but we only waited for a few minutes before being shown a table. I think we lucked out because a large table got up right before we came in.The staff was very nice. I ordered a bunch of appetizers for the table to share and we all ordered our own entrées. Every beverage has added sugar which was unfortunate because I would have liked an unsweetened iced tea but the black tea I ordered was pretty sweet. In the beginning they were very attentive with refilling the water but nearing the end of the meal, we were hard-pressed to get our glasses topped off.The Grub Rundown:Fried Chicken & Shrimp Dumplings - These were so good and there's a nice amount per order so it's perfect for sharingFried Chicken Wings - These were tasty, served with sweet chili sauce. Nothing special about them but good for sharingFried Whole Shrimp - These were standard, tasty and good for sharing Fried Chive Vegetable Dumplings - These were very tasty! There are only four per order but they're pretty big so we cut them in half for sharingPad Thai - You can't really go wrong with this dish. It's a go-to staple in most every Thai restaurant I've eatenPineapple Fried Rice - Again, a pretty standard dish of chicken, rice and sweet pineapple chunksChu-Chee Shrimp - Very spicy curry dish with nice sized shrimp and mushroomsGreen Curry Shrimp - Medium-spiced Curry with eggplant and coconut milk. Loved this!Crab Meat Fried Rice - I was very surprised by this dish. I liked it a lot. The only thing that could have made it better would be if they used lump crab meat but that would increase the price, significantlyIce Cream: served with fruits on top and enough of a portion to share Lychee - slightly sweet and refreshingGreen Tea - standardThe food was good, service was pretty decent and our bill was only $160 for the six of us. I would definitely visit again if in the area.

My bf really hyped this up as super good and cheap Thai food. Prices were comparable to Manhattan, not what I'd consider cheap. Food WAS tasty. But service was a bit rushed. Don't take my Singha away from me before I'm finished

This is one of my favorite thai cuisines. I been there over the past few years which haven't been disappointed for their taste. The huge selection from appetizer, entree, dessert and varieties of ice cream flavors The service perhaps not that good as the food

we came by for lunch, i've been meaning to for a few years now! Luckily found a parking spot around the corner and to my surprise saw a warning on the door that said lock your cars? the menu is huge! i was hungry so we had chicken curry puffs - this id probably the best one i have had, the relish could improve a bit but the chicken puff was full of flavor and actual bits of chicken! i ordered the pad see ew, although i have had better it was solid. we also had thai iced tea which is EXTREMELY sweet. and this is coming from someone who loves sugary sweet drinks. we also tried the pork knuckle/leg over rice - this was delicious. i think more of a chinese dish but they have just the right amount of seasoning / flavor. took off a star as there wasnt too much hospitality, and the thai milk tea was just that sweet, and the pad see ew.

I was here on a Thursday night for dinner around 7 PM, it was crowded, but there was plenty of seating available, the restaurant is big. They do not take reservations and it's cash only so come prepared! They have a full bar and a gigantic menu, which can be a bit overwhelming since there is just so much food to choose from. There were four people in my party so we ordered a few appetizers and a few dishes for dinner. Apps: large tom yum soup, medium spicy papaya salad, and chicken satay. The tom yum soup is delish it is one of my all-time favorite soups, I think it was the best I've had so far, the spice level was perfect it had a bunch of mushrooms and some shrimp, I wish there were shrimp though. The papaya salad was ok, it didn't taste fresh and it was a bit soggy, I found it had an overpowering fish taste. The spice level was enough. I didn't have the chicken, I was chugging tom yum soup, but the group said it was good.Dinner: Drunken noodles, chicken pad see ew, beef basil fried rice, fried chicken with nuts and pineapples. Everything mentioned was great, but the beef basil fried rice took the cake, the beef was sliced thinly, cooked well, complementing the fluffy fried rice! The drunken noodles were also very good, the noodles were wide, but thinner than usual, which I liked. The chicken with nuts and pineapples is your classic sweet and savory combo, a slightly too sweet for me, but still tasty. I didn't try the pad see ew because I was busy with everything else, but it got rave reviews. We ended the dinner with my fav, green tea ice cream, it was good, not the best, I enjoyed it, unlike the others who couldn't understand the taste.
