Overall dinner was great, the price was decent, parking was tough, and the service was average. I'd like to go back to try the pad thai until we meet again SriPraPhai!

After seeing all these awesome reviews of this place I was really excited to try it but I was disappointed to say the least. Their lunch specials consist of an appetizer, soup, main dish and a drink. We ordered the chives pancake, chicken wings, Tom yum and Tom kha soup, pad Thai, cashew nut chicken and for drinks the Thai iced tea and Thai iced coffee. The wings were very salty, soups was meh, and pad Thai was bland. Idk if they were having an off day but there was nothing memorable about the meal. Huge disappointment!

OK so my favorite nyc restaurant EVER was closed today (what a bummer), so I decided to venture out of my comfort zone (without my safe word) and skedadle over here. Good thing it was only a 6 minute walk down the street otherwise my bald head wouldn't be able to handle it.The pros:+ a huge dining area. 3x the size of playground.+ huge menu! Seriously how are they able to make all this shit?+ Thai iced tea tastes like Thailand. And by that I mean good.+ place is packed! Don't know. If that's because this place is good or because Playground Thai is closed. Let's give them the benefit of the doubt (because they're Asian) and say it's the former.+ clean and nice layout. Love the solid dark wood tables.+crispy pork belly dish is amazing. So many Asian flavors in my mouth it's like I ventured into Vietnam's red light district +food came fast (almost as fast as I do). Makes me wonder if they have a super team of chefs in the back. + portions are just right (goldilocks would approve) Cons- seafood papaya salad is good, but the squid in it isn't. It's soft and delicious, but doesn't soak up the flavor of the papaya. Seems odd when combined with the salad.- spice level here too mild. Even the extra pepper on the side seems too mild. Probably caters more to the American crowd.- drunken noodles good, but playground Thai does it much better. -waiter didn't come to check on us or refill water throughout the whole meal. Overall this place is awesome, but in some ways Playground Thai does it better. It just goes to show that no matter how good you are, there's always an Asian that does it better.

Really good drunken noodles. I asked for extra spicy and indeed it was spicy. Papaya salad was pretty salty but flavorful. However, I dont think I will bring back home leftovers- my noodles were stuck together and was hard.

The place was quite busy when we walked in and the restaurant was surprisingly clean and spacious. However, the food didn't feel very authentic. Maybe we ordered all the wrong things. Although the staff was friendly, the service was mediocre at best, they were not attentive at all. We had to ask for our water glasses to be refilled. We ordered a pineapple fried rice and a shrimp pad Thai, I felt like I was eating the same dish. Although the ingredients were different, Ihad the same flavor profile, there was no punch to the food. It wasn't bland per se, it just had no personality.
Good is good but the staffs are extremely rude! It's a cash only place which is again a bummer and while tipping they don't want to return the change!
Amazing and authentic Thai food. Tastes is fresh and the portions are huge. Menu is so big so I always try different things and they never disappoint. Chicken panang with coconut rice is my fav!

TLDR: Great Thai food if you're in the area. I wouldn't come out of my way to go here though. CASH ONLY! Overall rating: A-Drunken Noodles (sautéed noodles with choice of minced or sliced meat, chili and brasil leaves) $11.00: I got it with sliced beef. It was very good. A-Fried Marinated Pork Strips Combo (served with sticky rice and papaya salad with dry shrimp and crushed peanuts) $11.00: I tried a little of my friend's pork and it was also very good. A  -Lychee ice cream: Served with lychees on top. Creamy and not too sweet. Yummy! AMy friend and I had a good time catching up and enjoying the food. They didn't rush us out. Their 2 single occupancy bathrooms could use more cleaning though. I'd come here again if I was in the area. Just wish this wasn't so far from home!

A fairly large restaurant with extensive menu, but cash only in this modern age. Very inconvenient carrying all these coins. Message to the owner: Please get with the cashless day and age . The soft shell crab with mango salad had a good portion of deep fried crabs with a small plate of mango salad. The crab was good. The mango salad was drenched in very salty fish sauce which ruined the good tasting crab. The beef noodle was mediocre, tasted nothing like one from a good street cart in Bangkok. The black broth was way too sweet.Service was mediocre.

I am a strong believer in tossing out historical baggage when it comes to restaurants.  Some places have a certain fame based on past histories.  Take, for instance, DiFara's  - if you are from Indiana, someone dragged you to Midwood and thrust their slices upon you, sure, that's a good slice compared to your usual, and it's on all the NYC guidebooks as "the" place for pizza in town, so you got some sense of consensus reinforcement. However, when you are a New Yorker with pizza mileage under your belt (Arturo's, Totonno's, etc), you basically feel that the media hype is based on out-of-towners or lazy complacent people who kept deluding themselves into thinking that there is something special about that place.   The same issue hits SriPraPhai.  Sure, it's the first authentic Thai place in Queens 15 years ago. NYT/NY Mag/New Yorker/The Village Voice used to rain rants and raves upon it, usually about how its original dinky storefront had some serious culinary magic.  I am sure there are plenty of people who only goes there because of its past fame, or the fact that it's relatively swanky with an outdoor fountain (which is irrelevant when you are dining during the colder months).  That being said, a lot happened in local Thai within the past 15 years - there's Ayada, Arunee, Zab Elee (late and lamented, but great for midnight Esan), the 2 Chao Thais, 8 Paet Rio, Playground and Boon Chu.  Each of them are great in their own ways.  But what I can tell you is what SriPraPhai isn't good for - making Thai standards.  Well, let's see - let's compare 3 dishes.  N1 Shrimp Pad Thai This is pretty much the standard to how I judge Thai restaurants.  SriPraPhai's version was sticky, overly sweet and lacks any firepower (the Cantonese term wok-hay, or the certain toastiness that you get in a stir-fry when it was done on a hot wok in canola or peanut oil), and it lacks any serious flavor.  It tasted like something someone could make in their apartment kitchen using a standard stove.  I personally measure any Pad Thai with the version from Boon Chu, which is hot from the wok and features crisp strands of egg, tofu strips and mung bean sprouts along with shrimp that has the smoky finish of a well made stir-fry, well balanced with fish sauce, tamarind, peanuts and soy.  This was not it, and it's not good at all.O12 Gai Yang Combo - Barbecue chicken combo with coconut fried rice and papaya salad This is similar to the barbecue chicken that I had at Zabb Elee (their village location still exist).  On the SriPraPhai version the Papaya salad isn't bad, in fact, it was quite spicy with crisp textures and fruity notes, and the coconut rice was coco-nutty and that coconut cream unctuousness without being mushy.  However, the chicken was moist but flavorless.  It didn't taste barbecued (not smoky) as much as it was griddled without much marinate.  In the Zabb Elee version the chicken was smoky, spicy and a bit dry, which is actually the style that I was looking for - great with sticky rice and whatever salad you have on hand.  So that one is a bit of a fail. C14 Pad Gra-Prow - Ground meat with basil, garlic and chilesWell, this was by far my biggest disappointment with SriPraPhai - a good Pad Gra-Prow is supposed to be loud - salty, garlicky, fresh basils, packed with spices and some heat from the chiles.  It's meant to be the thing that drives you to eat more rice.  In the Sripraphai version it was much more subdued.  I asked the server to knock the heat down a little (stomach issues), but what I ended up with was an across-the-board lowering of volume, like someone took the food and turned it down to 2 (instead of up-to-11) - it was bland.  I mean, wow, what happened there?  Man, compared to the version at Ayada where they get flavor down without the heat, this one doesn't make the grade.To be honest, it was not a bad place - the interior looks great and the service was decent.  If I didn't get sticker price shock from them ($50 for 2 people including tips, which is about 20% more than the usual), I would go there if I am in Woodside and looking for okay food.  The problem is that I am not looking for "okay" Thai.  If I want okay Thai I know a ton of places...I want great Thai, and despite the hype, this is not great.

Mediocre Thai food at best hidden behind the excuse of authenticity. While a clean, family friendly restaurant, the main attraction is found wanting. SriPraPhai decides to throw away any notion of flavor in favor of authentic stubborn stagnation. Evolution, change and elevation of a dish is integral to great food, this is anything but above average and not deserving of the accolades it currently holds. Before the advent of mass produced soap, one could say it was authentic to serve food in a place where the staff did not wash their hands. I ask please SriPraPhai, please wash your hands(figuratively of course).
Really good Thai food in Woodside.  Spicy level on point.  Friendly staff.  Cash only.

The great thing here is that they have dishes that appeal to the adventurous or non-adventurous who like standard stuff (Pad Thai, Tom Kha Gai, Drunken Noodles, etc.) that can be boring at most other barely-Thai restaurants. The laabs are outstanding, also fish balls/caked, the curries, ground catfish and mango salad, sausage salads, watercress salad, tom yum pork leg are all worthwhile. Very efficient and friendly staff and teh garden is nice if weather permits.

Very thankful that they were able to host my party of 19 people during lunch on NYE. They don't take reservations so they told me to just call 30 minutes beforehand. I commend the staff for giving us such impeccable service especially when the orders can get confusing with so many people. The only "mistake" they made during our whole meal was one person's order got really delayed. It came out when everyone was almost done eating. But I don't blame the restaurant for it. I think they did the best that they could already which is why I'm giving them five stars. They also had an extensive menu and decent food. I got to try the seafood fried rice, fried calamari, pad see ew, and crab and chicken wontons. The seafood fried rice was very addicting. Tasted very light and the seafood bits were a nice addition. Fried calamari was good, nothing special. I've had better pad see ew at another place that closed down but SriPraPhai's version is not bad either. However, I definitely don't recommend the crab and chicken wontons. Didn't look appetizing and didn't taste good either. Some people got desserts but their mango sticky rice was not an option because mangos weren't in season. All four cars managed to find parking around the block.

Love. Love. LOVE this place. It's my favorite Thai spot and the Green Curry is soooo delicious! I've not had a bad meal here yet.Service is great, food is outta this world AND they have a nice outdoor garden to dine in during the summer. Highly recommend!!

The only reason I come here is for the pork neck bbq meat, since it is the only place I know that it has pork neck dish in NY. But the pork is not even that fresh but it tastes like it so I'm fine about that( the second pic). The Thai ice tea is not cold enough bcos the condensed milk they used is not cold and the condensed milk tastes too strong is not mixed with the Thai tea well which is disappointed. The lady there told me that that's what real Thai ice tea should be but sadly I prefer the one with real milk.And the last thing and is the most horrible Hanna Hoom Crop I ever had in Thai restaurant. Look at the first picture, the pork belly is dark which means it is put in the fridge for too long and tastes like trash. The Chinese broccoli is too soft like a boiled one but not the fried one.

Very disappointed. Been to SriPraThai Woodside for many years. This is probably the last time I am going there. I give a star to the staff/servers and a star for the freshness of the shrimps they used. That's about it. I almost feel bad for giving it two stars but it does not deserve more. The food was no good and the price has gone way up. I honestly can get better authentic Thai food elsewhere in the neighborhood at a much more pocket book friendly place. So what's wrong? You know while your neighbors are making Thai food from scratch, with real ingredients like lemon grass, gingers, curry spices, and real chilly peppers. Your customers can probably taste the instant spice mix you are using as a short cut?! The Tom Yum Soup I ordered was very sour. I finished it anyways because I came on a chilly day. I was freezing. But honestly I can make Tom Yum Soup at home just like yours with a jar of Tom Yum paste I get from an Asian supermarket. The green mango salad with seafood has more seafood than mango. Fine. It's 12.50 you need to justify it. I get it. But the flavor profile of the salad was weak. The mango was very sweet and very finely shredded. I want more mango that's why I ordered this!! I've had better mango salad from a no name Thai restaurant than here! Seriously! What made me really upset was the so called drunk man noodles! From the first time I had it here, this very location in 2008, this is the worst one I've had! There is no way I was at SriPhraThai! This five ingredient Dumrunkman noodles: noodles, tomato, a few sad piece of bell pepper and basil, and the boiled mock duck -- was soggy and sad. Instead of stir frying the noodles and other ingredients to give it a nice char. This was like mixing all the boiled wet ingredients together. I doubt they used a wok to cook this. Really??!?!! I would never expected a drunk man noodles of this quality from here. Were you using a tempt-cook tonight? I couldn't finish it. I had five bites, the max. The Khao Soy with Chicken was really meh. It was like mixing a bag of instant ramen mix with coconut milk. Have you tried Mama's instant noodles curry flavor? Look for it in an Asian supermarket. It costs $1.5 a bag the most. This Khao Soy tasted just like that. Not sure we could find any real spices used in the dish; everything tasted very artificial. Sigh... This restaurant needs a little more love for food. This is not the same place I used to go and look forward to my next visit. No more! No thank you! I reviewed its Hillside Ave location a few months ago, referencing how the food was better here in Woodside. I am taking it back. Sorry.

RECOMMENDEDThe legendary and iconic SriPraPhai (impossible to pronounce!) was once referred to as one of the best Thai restaurants in the US in the last decade. I dined there with three others on Thursday, 8/10. Although this is a good restaurant worth returning to, it is not entitled to the aforementioned praise.The restaurant is convenient to mass transit, one nearby subway train being the 7, as well as the Woodside LIRR station. It is in easy walking distance from both. Forget about parking which, in Queens, is as relevant as the tooth fairy. The casual storefront space is much larger than it seems and acoustics are not bad so conversation is possible. I ordered a large Saki to put a glow in this meal.The servers were pleasant and efficient and our dishes arrived much sooner than one would expect. The  Tom Yum Soup was savory and delicious with a nice coconut flavor. Duck Salad  was "on point" (I hate that phrase!!). The two Sausage Salads we ordered were appropriately fatty and nicely seasoned. The Fish Cakes were yummy with a nice soft texture.Onto the entrees. The Chicken with Glass Noodles was superb. The chicken was tender and the noodles had fabulous texture.We ordered three curries and I was a little disappointed by each. The curry dishes were Penang Beef Curry, Massaman Shrimp Curry and Shrimp Green Curry. We asked for a medium spice level but the curries were each EXTREMELY mild with no evident heat. The curries were "dumbed down". What a shame because each of the curries had wonderfully complex flavor. If you go here, INSIST upon the level of heat you desire.The last dish I tried was the Fried Catfish. I do not recommend this dish since it was all breading with little visible evidence of fish.BOTTOM LINE: SriPraPhai Thai is a good, not great, restaurant. I would not hesitate to dine here again, however.

Great Thai restaurant and feels really authentic. One of my favorite curries, but the noodles (Pad See Ew?) are a bit too sticky for my taste. They have great dessert options!  Next time I want to order a full fish,, which I've never had here but it looks great!

Finally came to try SriPraPhai after almost everyone recommended this place to me!To start off, I had the curry puffs and the papaya salad. I normally order the papaya salad at Thai restaurants but I've never had one that was spicy! I love spicy and thought that this was the best papaya salad I've ever had. My bf had to look for papaya for me because I could not stop eating it! It made my tongue hurt but it was worth it.The curry puffs were pretty good. It was my first time having them so I can't really compare them to another previous occasion. But I'd much rather stick with the papaya salad.I ordered the Chicken Pad Thai and I would have to say it was pretty similar to other pad Thai I've had. It didn't stand out much but they did give a huge serving that I ended up taking the rest to-go. My bf ordered the Drunken Noodles which were just as good. They had a spicy kick to it and there was a good amount of basil incorporated in the dish.Overall, SriPraPhai did not disappoint. The main dish that stood out to me was the papaya salad and I would travel out to Woodside for this. The other dishes, I can probably find a Thai restaurant near me that can satisfy my cravings. Also, Cash only. And tip: if you go around 7PM, you are almost guaranteed to find parking in less than 10 minutes.

There's not a lot of legit Thai restaurants in NYC- surrounded by the ever rising genre of Asian fusion and restaurants that enjoy incorporating Asian elements. Sri Pra Phai if woodside is the antithesis of this- going back to its pure roots- serving authentic style Thai dishes. This restaurant is a favorite of mine- the food made with the same passion and joy that is found by chefs cooking for a hungry family member. From the tum yum soup to the beef rendang- there are few restaurants on yelp that is able to match the quality of food with the yelp rating and STILL remain consistent through time. This restaurant is LEGIT.Recommended? Hell yeaBathroom- yes and cleanParking- street parking Pricing- $10-25/ personLove it or dump it- absolutely love it- I'm a returning customer!
This place use to be real good, now with so many other choices, not so much!  Still cash ONLY with a surcharge for rice and no lunch specials!?  Over rated and over priced for a average Thai lunch!
So yummy. Get the curry rice noodles! If you've ever had to decide between pad thai and curry, then this is the dish for you. It's the best of both worlds. And fair prices.

I finally came here after many years of it being on my list of places to try. I met a friend here during lunch, when we practically had the place all to ourselves, and we enjoyed all we ate. It was just as I expected. I was thinking of who I could bring to the restaurant with me for repeat visits, because it's in my neighborhood. But, I noticed odd lack of hospitality and passive-aggressive behavior. Our water refills stopped before and after the check came. Admittedly we were caught up in conversation so we waited a while to pay. We even entertained the idea of ordering desert. After we paid and tipped 20%, we were ignored. So, we changed our minds about desert and asked a waiter, who had recently started their shift, for some water. The waiter, hesitant, came over, refilled our glasses, but not without emphasizing that we'd been there a "VERY long time." Yes, we had, but that comment was uncalled for. It was obvious that the other staff told that waiter about our being there a while after paying. There were not many other customers there the whole time we spent there either. To add, it was also very obvious that they were talking about us in front of us. Finally, before we even left the table, with our bags on the table still, that same waiter rushed to clean it. There were literally SO MANY empty tables in the place. That was so off-putting. Perhaps that's why so many tables were empty. With so many other options for authentic Thai in NYC, that offer quality service AND a great ambiance, I'm fine with having tried the food here just once.

It took me a while to think of exactly what rating I wanted to give this place. I loved their pad thai, drunken noodles, pad see ew, thai tea, tom yum... the list goes on (I've been here way too many times).The food is excellent, but the reason 1 star is taken away is because of the inconsistent service I have received eating here over time. I know service can be touchy and sometimes objective in terms of perspective - it also varies from time to time due to staffing. Would I come back to this place? Absolutely. Would I bring a friend here? Yes. Go on a date here? 100%CASH ONLY!
Best Thai Food in Queens. Great seafood and noodle dishes. Excellent Thai iced tea.

Out of all of the Thai restaurants that my family goes to, we consider this the most authentic, best tasting Thai restaurant in Queens.  We always have a large party (10 or more) and everyone is consistently happy with the quality of the food here.  I wished we lived closer as we would frequent this place more often!

Ayada has been my longtime favorite Thai spot but I think I found a new place to obsess over. Me and my friend head over because I read that they have one of the best noodle dishes in NYC, which is plenty of a reason to check this place out. While I was going to order the noodle dish, I couldn't help but notice that lunch is till 4 pm?!?!? You get 3 dishes plus your choice of drink for $14.50. Wut? WUUUUUUT? That got me really excited so the noodle dish would have to wait. I got dumplings, Tom Yum with shrimp, and I believe basil chicken with rice. Let me explain to you about their hot sauce. Every thai restaurant has their staple of hot sauce. Some places have a variety while, every place has the standard red hot sauce with the bits of the seeds. So per usual, I ask for hot sauce and I got 3 different types. Standard. The pickled concentrated version and one that I haven't seen before. I try the new one and I gradually begin to notice that it's hot. Not the usual spiciness but the kind where you finish your iced coffee and have to order a second in order to not start crying. So when the lady comes to clear the table and give us our bill, I ask her what's in the hot sauce. People. THIS. IS. NOT. ORDINARY. HOT. SAUCE. This is Thai chillies in which they would dry on rooftops back in Thailand.  But here they just dry out the peppers in the oven. If you're familiar with Indian cuisine you know the dried peppers packs a much stronger heat that the ordinary ones. I wasn't dealing with ordinary spices but thai level spices AND DIDNT DIE. Definitely an accomplishment. The food was definitely delicious. Portions were massive. Staff was very sweet and engaging in conversation. They have the beautiful fountain in the back. I can't wait to come back. The only drawback would be cash only. But that really is a small setback to the wonderful dishes you are about to experience.
We love this place. Best Thai food around, and when its's nice out, the garden is just beautiful. And their mango sticky rice is to die for. Wish it was available more often though!

I've been coming here since the '90s. Not much else or much different to say. The food is definitely worth all the praise even with all the newer Thai restaurants that have popped up. SriPraPhai was the first to make the outer boroughs, specifically Queens, a destination for Thai food. I love getting the catfish salad and the grilled pork neck. Also when I'm in the mood for fried foods I'll get the crispy watercress salad. I also love the panang curry here. On a recent visit I got the broiled chicken over chicken stock rice, the chicken satay, and fried taro. I got the ground chicken with basil as well and sigh forgot to request the fried egg but still a delicious and flavorful dish. I've never had a bad meal here. I always leave full and satisfied, happy for the treat and for not breaking bank. Great selection of desserts in the fridge too if you want to take it to go.

Had high expectations, but restaurant sadly did not meet it. The restaurant was packed at 8pm, but there's plenty of seating for large groups. We sat outdoors in the backyard patio (think: outdoor chairs, umbrellas, string lights, garden).I ordered a Chicken Pad Thai and actually didn't like it. Did not taste authentic and wasn't made very well. It was bland and didn't have a wok heat flavor. The Chicken pieces also was very dry. The Pork Tender Jaew dish on the other hand wasn't bad. But overall my pad thai was so disappointing it affected my judgement of all the other dishes.Also the menu is huge... like thick stack booklet huge. It was hard to look through the menu. Ambiance was pretty chill. Service was attentive.

First off, they have a back yard garden area for dining which felt good after this long winter. Plus NYC isn't famous for space so it's refreshing they manage to acquire that much of it. For a group of 4 including drinks and appetizers the final amount was $110 (excellent). I had the duck drunk noodles which was good when it comes to the noodles consistency and the overall flavor of the dish. It was not greasy and the duck added even more flavor but their mild spicy is more hot spicy, they need to bring that down a notch. We also got their bbq pork (not sweet like typical American bbq) with papaya salad (very good salad mix) and coconut rice (hardly noticed the difference from regular rice). We also got a green curry and a red curry. The red curry was a bit too greasy on top, almost swimming in oil but the flavor was good. I preferred the green curry here compared to other places where I preferred the red curry. Their Thai ice tea was strong but it came with a lot of milk, yummy. Their lychee ice tea has lychee in it but doesn't have much flavor. And we had the crab and chicken puffs which was good. I will go here again to retry everything to confirm if there's consistency and with prices like that, I probably visit often.

The reviews on this restaurant speak for themselves! I tried SriPraPhai for the first time today and actually think it has become my favorite Thai restaurant in New York. The food was amazing! My hubby and I ordered Papaya Salad, a small Tom Yum Soup, Pork Leg Over Rice, and two glasses of Pinot Noir. Everything was great. Top-notch Thai food for a great price. The Papaya salad was on point, portion, taste, and price-wise. The Tom Yum soup was a little on the sweet side, and I like it to be more on the sour side, but still better than quite a few Thai restaurants, and everything in it was delicious. A little smaller than I expected though. Pork Leg Over Rice is usually always a good option. It is a star-anise based dish. Very flavorful. Pinot noir was pretty standard. Everything comes out pretty quick and tasting great. They have a whole vegetarian menu too!Service was pretty good. And their bathroom (well, I only saw the ladies room) is pretty clean. I don't normally mention bathrooms in my reviews but I just felt so comfortable here. Indoor space is dimly lit and can be great for romantic dinners OR eating out with friends. I didn't get photos of the inside of the restaurant because we chose to dine in their outdoor/backyard garden, but the whole place was spacious. I did get a video of the outdoor area though, which was very lovely (Cannot add it to this post, so I'll upload it separately). Oh, this place is also CASH ONLY. Definitely will be going back!!!
I am from Atlanta and love Thai food so much but sorry to say that this restaurant doesn't come close to being an authentic Thai food and it's tasteless. I have 3 stars for the ambiance only!

This is my absolute FAVORITE spot in all the boroughs. I frequent about once a month and the food is always consistent, always fresh. The restaurant gets jam packed during weekends. They don't take reservations but you don't usually wait more than 30 minutes. The menu is hard to parse through as there are tons of options and pages -- I usually hate too many options at a restaurant but don't totally mind it here.The soft shell crab appetizer is an excellent starter. All three options you can get with the soft shell crab are excellent. The green curry, red curry, pad see ew, drunken noodles, pad Thai, and Cal Soy are wonderful. It's filling, it's fresh, it's beautiful!!! One thing to note is that their spice level is very extreme - their spicy will make you chug water like crazy. So, be cautious. For dessert, their mango with sticky rice is good, but they have a lovely section in the fridge of Thai desserts than range from 3-5 dollars. They're delicious. All are a must try.
Excellent food qualities and lots of choices. Very authentic taste of real Thai food. Love their pork salad and curry. Been here many times, only CASH payment accepted

This is a disappointing experience for me.It was noon and they start to getting busy in lunch. I din in for 1 and get ignored by the host and server after seated. They only take care of big party, not for small group. I order the jumbo noodle with mixed pork. I wait for long time and finally get my order. The soup lack of favor and the fat noodle is too sticky. I find the other Thai restaurant ( chao Thai ) makes better than them. I think is place is overrated by people. I don't get it. The Whole meal, the server not even come to ask and follow up. Forget about this spot if u want to enjoy your thai food. Never come back.

AMAZING THAI FOOD. I thought Thai food was all about the pad Thai and pad see ew but I was so wrong.I got to come here with a big group which means I was able to try a lot of things on their menu.I'm not sure what this dish was called but it was this fried fish with a spicy mango salad. that was honestly the best dish there. Also, their soft shell crab is so damn good. If you like spicy, their curries will set a fire in your mouth straight down to your stomach. Honestly, it seems pointless to try to describe my experience here because you just have to go and try their food. I doubt anything on their menu will taste bad. Just stop reading the reviews here, jot the address down, and come here for a delicious meal.
Came here for lunch, food was on point! Ordered tumyum, panang curry, pad Thai, and skewers. I would come back. Own and operated by Thai. Cash only

TL;DR: Can't beat this place for the price, taste and service.We arrived on around noon on a Saturday. It was pretty packed but we were able to get a table. The wait staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The constantly kept our waters full which helped with the spicy food.We started with the Shredded Mango Salad and curry puffs. The Shredded Mango Salad was really refreshing with the mango, cilantro and seafood. It had a little bit of heat with some sweetness. The curry puffs were nice and hot! The insides were delicious.For our entrees we got Green Curry, a side of Coconut Rice and Drunken Noodles. The Green Curry was pretty good with lots of coconut milk mixed in. It didn't come with rice so we had to order our own but the Coconut Rice was perfect with it. The Drunken Noodles had a nice stir-fry flavor and a good amount of heat to it.
Nothing you probably haven't already figured out from the 2000+ solid reviews. Amazing well priced food in a no frills setting. I'm hungry again after writing this review.

I started coming here when they had a very small place maybe five tables .. before the expansion... I stopped coming after the expansion because the few times I was there I felt like the service and food were both lacking .. perhaps growing pains. Went there two weeks ago and well... can't stop thinking about eating there.  The food took me back to Thailand ... my waiter was the same little boy who used to help his parents back in the day.. now he's a grown man and so kind and humble.  Going to Sri is like going home ...
Excellent food, good service.. mixed drink was not good but otherwise excellent. Tom Yum Soup was amazing.

I heard a lot about this spot and it's good reviews so I finally got to try it. I thought the food was good but not as good as it was hyped up to be. The service was very accommodating. The staff was friendly and made sure everyone was well attended to. They were nice to provide a separate kid friendly setting for a toddler.

Been there twice. Both times had poor service and food was only so so.  Think there are better places to have authentic Thai where the experience will be far more pleasant.  This place is basically a cafeteria with so so food.  Try somewhere else.

Rarely do I give 3 stars but here it is. This our first time at the restaurant.Negative:-sign on inner door as you come in "do not leave valuables in car" or something to that effect. Wish I took a picture. -you are charged $10 if you bring your own alcohol/cake, it's literally printed on the menu. If they posted this on their door I would of reconsidered going in. We brought birthday cake. -fried catfish dish, waitress tells us "little fish". Saw pics on yelp decided to try it. Where's the fish? We tasted the essence of fish but it's like a mouthful of shredded panco. -tom yum soup was not good at all. No one in the party was able to finish it. It was very sour.Positive:-Pad Thai was yummy-mango salad was refreshing-nice! That they put WiFi passcode on menu They have a fridge up front where they have a large selection for the take out crowd. Desserts and what not. Wish we tried some of that. BUT we were so put off by the $10 charge for birthday cake I don't know if we'll come back.

I came back today (Saturday) and wasn't wowed. At least I didn't have to wait: at 5:15pm there were plenty of tables. The food was plenty, but the quality was just ok. Papaya seafood salad: big portion, but boring taste; the seafood was clearly pre-frozen, and had no taste. Larb with ground pork: just ok; the minced pork had a lot of tougher cartilaginous pieces that I couldn't chew. Drunken noodles with sliced pork, although the meat was dry and tough, the noodles were good. Sautéed crispy pork belly with chili, garlic and basil leaves: although the flavor of the pork belly was good, you could tell that it had been cooked earlier, and waited for a while. Ripe mango with sticky rice: delicious. Their house red wine (1/2 liter for $9) is pretty good, and a true bargain. Overall, I'm not sure it's worth to come here anymore. Even though they give you a lot of food and have a lot of choices, they have so many dishes that it's impossible for them to cook them expressly for you... and it tastes accordingly. I have a personal attachment to this place, and will probably end up coming back (but not for a while). However, I wouldn't wait to eat here. It's just average quality Thai "comfort" food, way too popular than it should.

I love this place. One of the best thai place in ny and I've tried a lot of them. Branch out and order something other than a pad thai and you'll be rewarded. With that said, my go to order includes crispy pork belly with chinese broccoli, sauteed water spinch aka best veggie dish in the universe. Last time we tried the jungle curry which includes a very spicy but addicting curry sauce, your meat of choice, and veggies such as thai baby eggplant, bamboo shoots. Despite the waiter's repeated warning that it would be extremely spicy, we went with it and it was definitely spicier than most things but not too the point of me drenching myself in water after each bite. That said, know your spice tolerance and enjoy a super extensive menu of delish things. Be adventurous!!
Very popular place. Something about the dishes that didn't taste 100% Fried rice was a bit too saucy and the Thai ice tea was too sweet. The lunch menu was a great deal though.

SriPraPhai has amazed me enough that I would make almost monthly trips to Woodside just to dine there. I cannot speak for its authenticity, however I can say that the menu has dishes that one would not commonly find in a generic Thai restaurant. Seriously, if a Thai restaurant just has curries and permutations of meat, it could do better. When a Thai restaurant starts to have dishes like the roast pork and crispy pork and sausage over rice with the egg, that starts sounding legitimate. Or maybe the larb salads? How about the Esan sausage? SriPraPhai has all of those. And with a crowd every time I go there, I can say this is a restaurant I can trust.I'd be honest, I wouldn't go here for dishes I could go elsewhere. This is not a comment to quality. My premise is, the curries can be found everywhere else but that these other Thai dishes not usually found should be tried. That said, I'm a sucker for the Northern Thai sausage or Esan sausage and I almost always get that roast pork/crispy pork over rice. They also have a pork leg over rice as well as combos that feature roasted chicken or grilled pork meat with sticky rice. With respect to the roasted pig combo, the roast pork is always a little sweet especially after I dipped it into that sweet bean sauce. The crispy pork always maintains that crunch. The sausage dish is always good too. They usually serve them sliced with some peanuts and the lettuce. Ideally, they should be wrapped with the lettuce to eat. I just use a fork. One of them, the Esan or the Northern, was spicy. And I recall the Northern sausage resembled like meatballs. Nonetheless, I usually get these on my visits. But even if I got the same thing every time, somehow I fell in love with the food here. The waitstaff are generally friendly, but because of how busy the place is they're probably too stressed to make extra talk. The ladies up front may appear a little surly especially on weekend evenings.

The shredded mango salad is the best thing I've ever eaten.  My immediate and instinctual thought was to get enough to go orders to fill a trash bag with and paying 70 dollars to check it on my way back to Detroit. It was a legit symphony of flavor - mint would pop out of nowhere then beautifully subside into basil all with perfectly tangy undertones... I honestly can't even describe how much I liked it.  Everything else we ordered tasted like garbage in comparison, but I hear it was all pretty good hahaThere was a book of a menu too and you could order every combination of foods I can think of so the options are limitless.The dessert case was beautiful too.

Came here for lunch on labor day and it was poppin. This restaurant definitely looks like a place where families like to frequent, and I liked the vibe. We got the curry chicken puffs which were really good. The inside was like a mash of potatoes and chicken. It came with some pickled onions and cucumbers in a fish sauce (I think) and it was delicious. We also ordered drunken noodles with chicken which was just mediocre and had a very, very strong basil taste. My boyfriend got the gai yang combo which was okay - a bbq chicken dish with coconut rice and papaya salad. We asked for these two dishes to be "a little bit spicy" and we got mild which was not spicy at all. Overall, the dishes were alright - not insanely good, but I'd come back. This place is cash only, and the prices seemed to be standard thai prices.

This place does a lot of things right, so it may be easier to start with the bad. First, this place only accepts cash, something I carry very little of. Even small snack stands accepts credit cards these days. Second, the waiter was not very attentive. We never got our waters filled and he never came to check on us during the meal to see how we were doing.Other than that, the main courses were amazing. We ordered some appetizers to start, which were okay, not fantastic. The Thai wings were salty with a hint of sour. They were fried really well, with a crispy skin. The calamari was okay. The sweet and sour sauce was good, but the calamari itself wasn't the best. The papaya salad was really good. The papaya was fresh and crispy. The flavor was fantastic. For the main courses, we got the drunken noodle, pad Thai, pineapple fried rice, sautéed chicken, and Penang curry. There were five of us, and this was way too much food. We were only able to finish the sautéed chicken. The other main courses were only half eaten. In short, all the dishes were delish. Bill came out to about $105. Defiantly one of my favorite Thai restaurants in NYC.

I know this place is an institution, but honestly, I really do like Ayada more. SPP definitely has the larger menu and can absolutely slam it out of the park when they do things right, but in the half dozen times I've been here in the past few years, I feel like the quality of the food greatly varies from day to day, which I don't want to contend with whenever I go somewhere. Also, I'm not sure if it's still the same, but having to pay in cash only is quite a nuisance.Yes, the lunch special can be an absolutely great deal, but the few times I've ordered a lunch special menu item, I've been let down. If you happen to be dining in for lunch, I would absolutely urge you to order off their regular menu instead.However, I would still say that yes, this place is worth checking out for fairly authentic Thai fare. It's been around for over 2 decades for a reason. 3.5 stars really, but rounded down because of that annoying cash only clause.
Love their soft shell crab or whole fish top with fresh mango sauce.  Soft tofu soup with ground pork is yummy.  Ate here many times and enjoyed it every time

Have to say this place isn't what it used to be. The Tom yum soup was totally off- super salty and tasted like ketchup/vinegar (no flavor of lemongrass and lime leaves), not at all comparable to what is used to taste like here before, and way off from authentic tom yum flavor.

Spacious place, with many options and good pricing! We got 2 of the lunch special combos that came with an appetizer, soup, drink and entree for only $15.50. The soups were both interesting! Got the chicken coconut and the spicy shrimp one. The appetizers were both great and the entrees were good. Got the drunken noodles (it was alright) and the sautéed chicken with rice. The food came out really quickly and the service was great.The thai iced tea with milk was also amazing!

I came here recently and there was about a 15-20 minute wait. We were seated in about 10 minutes. This place is pretty big and seats a lot of people. It is very busy and crowded, so that's a good sign!Thai iced tea - VERY sweet and milky. I honestly don't know if they could really call it tea. It was almost like a milkshake. It was very tasty, but I wish it wasn't so sweet/thick.Pad Thai - decent. I have had pad thai so many places; some stand out and some do not. Although the pad thai was good, I have had better. It was a big portion, so I got 2 meals out of it.I also tried the crab fried rice and the sliced basil beef - both were really good. The menu is extremely overwhelming...which is why I just went with pad thai. Too many options! Pages and pages and pages long. I would recommend looking at it online before coming. Service/staff was fine. I would come back.Cash only.

I ordered the clear soup with mixed veggies and seafood but I got was like just plain water. So disappointed. Not worth my hype. And the old lady with short hair was kinda rude to me and my friends. I remembered that we used very polite way of talking because we use the same language as them. By the time we were paying the order, the register called over our head to the customers who just came in. I think this manner considered rude in Thai society. Anyhow, what I can give them for the compliment is cleanliness.

Note: it's cash only! Easily some of the best Thai food I've had in NYC. Lots of vegetarian options, lots of seating, and attentive wait staff. The mango salad appetizer was delicious and refreshing especially for this warm weather! I  ordered a crispy noodle vegetarian dish and it was yum! Also for fellow lightweights, their Siam sangria is sweet and fruity and hardly alcoholic haha.

SriPraPhai is an old Thai restaurant establishment going back in the 80s. Not sure how old this place really is, but my parents always came here back in the day. If you're in the Woodside area, it surely is a must! Although this place is no longer the "hidden gem" of Woodside, Queens, the food and ambience is still good. Prices are decent but not entirely cheap. They have an extensive menu beyond Pad Thai and Thai iced tea so make sure to explore as much while you're here. My favorite noodle dish here is the Gai Kua, a flat noodle dish with peanuts, chicken, squid, and cilantro. The apps are a great addition as the entree may not entirely be filling if you haven't eaten much. Try their curry puff and spring rolls. If you aren't full, dessert is a must! Sticky rice, sweet soup, and ice cream dishes can be ordered here. There's also a sweets section to-go at the cash register. In warm days, they have outdoor seating which may get a little itchy if mosquitos are out. It does feel very homey outside as it's a backyard setting. Service is fast and friendly. Cash only!

I went on a Sunday afternoon and surprisingly I was seated right away. Parking was easy to find also which was great. Their menu is like a maze. They have so many items on the menu; we spent good 10 mins going through each items. Crispy chicken, duck entree, dumpling, Tom soup, shrimp fried rice, papaya salad, beef skewers and the drinks. The bill came out to be about $80 for the two of us. The food was delicious and service was very efficient. One thing I didn't like was at the end, it started getting busy so the waiters started to rush things. I wasn't even done eating but the server took my food to pack it for Togo. Rude. Whatever.
This place is by far the best Thai food I have had in NYC. I had the soft shell crab appetizer which was just amazing.

This place was a little crazy when my fam and I came around 2pm for lunch on a Sunday. Come early or a little later pass 2pm during lunch/brunch if you don't want to wait for a table.We did family style because we wanted to try diff types of dishes. Keep in mind that their portions are pretty small. Slightly disappointed tho.Duck noodle soup: 4/5 the broth was just PERRRFECCT! It wasn't too sweet or too meaty (if you know what I mean lol) or too bland. Generous amount of shredded duck meats. Papaya salad: 3.5/5 who comes to Thai resto and not order papaya salad? It was def spicy even tho we asked for mild spicy. I felt like the sauce was lacking, it was missing something. slightly disappointed. Pad thai with shrimp: 4/5 you know this pad thai was good when my father who doesn't like Thai food finished this dish lol! It wasn't too sweet or bland because you know some Thai restaurant either make it too sweet or too bland, but here the flavor was HITTTING IT. Basil minced chicken with rice: 4/5 first time ordering this dish and comes to my surprise it was pretty good! I think this dish might become one of my fav thanks to SriPraPhai. Raw shrimp salad: 3/5 THIS IS SO SPICY EVEN THO WE ASKED FOR MILD SPICY -- because there's chili pepper. slightly disappointed with this salad because the flavor was just not there, it is missing a kick. I guess one of the reasons I gave this place a low rating because of the service. 1) we barely even sat down or looked at the menu and the server/runner kept asking if we wanted anything to drink from the menu 5X. like for real we literally just got here and didn't even have the chance to look at the menu. 2) when we were looking at the menu deciding what to order the server repeatedly asked us if we were ready to order. 3) they collected our plates, utensils, and bowls when we weren't done eating. like yes, I got it, we only had one dish that is about to be finish but like can you wait until that dish was finished first and then collect our plates, utensils and bowls. 4) we were still hungry so we asked for a menu and they repeatedly kept asking if we are ready to order dessert, like no -- in the end, we decided to order a dessert because there wasn't anything we were particularly interested or wanted. we wanted to try the mango with sticky rice but the server told us that mango is not in season so they don't have anything with mango. then why didn't you say so from the beginning that there are no mango desserts?? IDK if this is considered a Thai style service but like I just don't like the feeling of being rushed from the moment we came in to the moment we are leaving. I get it when it is busy or during rush hours but it wasn't like crazy busy esp after we finished our meal. Would I come back? Prob just because the food was pretty good. Just prepare to be rush throughout your stay if you do come during busy hours. OH BRING CASH W YOU!

You know when you first go to a restaurant and you're like "Wow, this place is awesome!," but then you go back and you keep going back and you're like "I can see how this place is not perfect..." Well, that's exactly what happened to me and this restaurant. I probably ate here with 3 different groups of friends and all ordered different menu items so I would like to think I got a good sense of the menu, while it is enormous in its own right. Think of this review as a crowdsourced review, because it is.The curries here need some work and maybe this is due to some Thai restaurants taking it easy on the spicy for particular customers, but I really felt like the curries were missing a few elements. Friends ordered the green curry and the massaman. As for the noodles, I didn't think the Pad Thai was super memorable. My friends ordered other noodles - one got the Drunken noodles, which was way too spicy and the other got the Pad see ew, which was too sweet. Vegan dishes are apparently very good according to my other friend. The Kao Soy and dessert dishes are very good according to myself.

Food is average at best. The service is dissapponting and waiters were very rude. The pad thai noodles were too soft. I ordered fried fish with curry sauce and the curry sauce was so overpowered with ginger i couldnt taste the fish. Pork belly was overcooked and their chili sauce is watered down. Very disappointing! If you want authentic Thai food - go to Ayada.

My absolute favourite thai restaurant in Queens.  I am very fussy about Thai food as there is a lot of subpar, americanized food in this city.  This is extremely authentic, and their back garden is very cute.  I try other places in Queens and they are good, but this place is hands down my favorite.  The red curry and the panyang curry can't be beat.

Very nice local Thai spot. Love the choices for fresh soups. The vegetable soup was really good.  Combination platter was tasty finger food and the dumplings were good as well. Was not so crazy about the duck salad. Too much going on. I did not enjoy the combination of flavors for that particular dish.I also feel that the menu is way too big. It's a never ending notebook binder. Makes it too hard to make a decision. Service was decent and the prices are nice. I enjoyed the food for the most part. The soup once again was great. I would come back to eat again

Loved everything here: food, ambience, variety, service!  Thumbs up!!!  Will be back We had one appetizer (fried tofu is my least fav), one seafood salad, 2 noodles: one dried and one soup.  Very authentic!!

It is the best Thai food restaurant in New York ever.I wanted an authentic Thai restaurant so bad for the last 18 years but never found it.Until I visit SriPraPhai, I hit the jackpot.The Tom Yum soup is so rich in flavor. Fired rice mixed with chestnut and pineapple makes it so attractive. I went there for lunch. The lunch special comes with one appetizer, soup, drink and one main course only costs $15. This is the best deal ever. I highly recommend you visit yourself.

One of my friend wanted to check this place out since some friends recommended it to them so I tagged along. We made the trek out to Woodside for this Thai restaurant for lunch. Their lunch special is a really good deal - $15.50 for an appetizer, soup, main, and drink. I got the Thai iced tea - it was already premixed when I got the drink so that's a bad sign. Taste like it was out of a can. Too sweet and not enough of the tea flavor. The tom yum soup was flavorful so that was a good start. Even though I asked for the papaya salad to be spicy, it wasn't that spicy and more sweet. The drunken noodle with ground pork was solid but nothing spectacular. Space is pretty big so you can definitely bring a stroller here. Service was good - they refilled our water a couple of times.Overall, great lunch special but probably not enough for me to make the trek out to Woodside for this Thai food.

Great yelp choice . I ordered the Fried marinated pork strips ( O-15) which came with sticky rice and a seperate papaya salad with dry shrimp and crushed peanuts . Excellent ! My companion had a cold shrimp and mango salad . Refreshing as the temperature was close to 100 F . We ordered a couple of  Brooklyn Lager beers . Excellent meal with friendly service .

I came here on a whim with my family while we were visiting relatives. I saw the good review on Yelp and decided to give it a try. Overall, the food was authentic and good but my pad see ew was lacking in flavor. The salad was acceptable and so was the dumplings, I just wished the dumplings were either chicken or shrimp not chicken and shrimp mixed together.

This is one of my favorite restaurants currently.  Their menu is quite extensive and they include a picture next to every dish which I totally appreciate. Everytime I go I find a dish that I haven't tried yet. Some of my favorites are the fried soft shell crab and the pork belly with spinach. The restaurant is pretty roomy and there's the garden area in the back that's really nice. The staff here are very friendly and they are great with kids. I always see lots of families eating here. The only complaint I have about this place is that they are cash only.  I don't know why they don't change that and start accepting credit cards. They would make so much more money.

Given the delicious quality of their food and robust menu, it's no wonder this Thai restaurant has been apart of the Woodside community for so many years.  Even though the service is fast paced, the quality of food is not comprised.  The place is definitely worth the visit.  Authentic and fusion options available.  Limitations: Cash only, very busy some nights and weekends and finding convienentent street parking can be a challenge

I gave this place two chances and I am not as impressed as I was by other Thai restaurants in the area.  I tried their chicken drunken noodles on my first visit and one of their curries on my second. Both meals were less than memorable and in my opinion, overpriced.  The drunken noodles were surprisingly too spicy although I had ordered a mild,  and the curries were boring and lacking in any real flavor.  Service was not very friendly, establishment is cash only and these are the additional factors which contribute to a low two star review.  If they lowered their prices and stepped up their service, it would have potential be a 3.5 star restaurant.

Most probably one of the best and authentic Thai place around NY. Came here 3 times and ordered different foods. Everytime they pleased me. Tried mango salad, green curry, spring roll, bar b q chicken and mango sticky rice. All are right to the point. Food is fast. Parking could be tricky. They dont take card, but they have an ATM inside. Definitely coming again.
Best Thailand cuisine in New York City!Beautiful outdoor seating with garden and water fountain Authentic food, great service and lively atmosphere.

Coconut rice + soft shelled crab = winning combo.The rice was sweet and works great with the curry served with the crab. Crab is so much better when you don't have to work to get it out of the shell.Thai iced tea was way too sweet, probably will opt for something alcoholic next time.

The menu was large and had a good portion for vegetarians,  which I appreciated.  It was nice to enjoy a meal wo the worry of Fish sauce,  which I'm allergic to. I ordered the vegetarian combo which include coconut rice,  green curry with eggplant &  bamboo shoots and a papaya salad -  all vegetarian for $11!!!!The food tasted fresh and was really delicious

This is supposed to be one of the best Thai restaurants in New York City, but my experience was disappointing.All 3 of us got the lunch special. The food came out super quickly, which made me wonder how fresh it was. My vegetarian friend loved the Tom yum soup, and the Thai iced tea with milk was delicious. However, the chicken coconut soup was too sweet and too bland, the papaya salad was too sour, and everything else was just ok. I ordered medium spicy, but the food wasn't spicy at all. I've had better Thai food elsewhere. But maybe the food is better if you don't order the lunch special. I appreciated that they had a sign saying that the single stall restrooms were gender neutral. Also, there were quite a few empty bike racks outside during lunch if you are the type that needs bike parking.

Authentic Thai dishes galore. Like a 20 page menu with all kinds of dishes and 4 pages just for dessert. We shared several different dishes with our friends. All of the food was tasty. I enjoyed the red snapper, larb, and Pad See Ew the most. Most dishes have an option to add chicken, shrimp, or beef.  For dessert, I had the mango sticky rice. It was ok, I expected a little better. The place is CASH ONLY and they have a big selection of dessert items you can buy and take home. See the fridge by the entrance.

Been here many many times. It rarely disappoints but it probably won't wow you. There are definitely some better options, however, for the price and service and the fact they they have a huge menu that most items are good on, I recommend it. This is a great place especially to go for lunch and to get their Thai iced tea, appetizer, and main course special. If your threshold for spice is on the low side, you may be surprised at how spicy some of dishes are even if you ask for a more mild version. Sometimes they get it right and sometimes they don't. I would recommend getting the dishes the normal way they make them (especially if you have a high spice tolerance) because you couldn't expect them to taste the same if spice level is heavily modified.

Quite dissapoint, was order Sa Tor  with Shrimp and Tod Mun shrimp, tod mun is fine. But Sator is very sweet and non flavor at all. I could even finish. I had Sator before and it was very good. Not sure what happen in the kitchen on that day. I just need to leave this review for the owner to check more quality of the the food. Thx

Best thai spot in Queens in my opinion. It is a cash only place, so make sure you have enough cash on hand. If not, they do have an ATM there but why pay an unnecessary atm fee? The drunken noodles here are great, as is their thai iced tea and their chicken pad thai. If you like thai food and want to try the best thai food in Queens (based on the opinion of a dude whose not thai), try it out.
We order thai soup and red cuffy with beef.Food is not good not fresh.We cannot  eat at all.

The food is A-OK. The menu consists of over 30 pages of items and the restaurant is large - I think that's why the quality is not quite there. It's edible but nothing special. The BBQ Pork appetizer was very good, it came in a nice portion and the meat was juicy and marinated. The Thai ice tea was a little too sweet. The pad see ew was bland and boring! I don't know where the flavors were but at least it wasn't oily. The red curry was also a disappointment, asked for spicy and it was not spicy at all and they put too much basil in there; makes me wonder how can the curry be so bad in a Thai restaurant... If you want rice, you have to pay extra! $2 for the coconut rice. Just meh.

I ll keep it simple with this place, I have been coming here for years and I have to say, this is the best Thai restaurant . Drunken noodles and pad thai are my favorites, Everything in this place is fresh and tasteful.

We had the papaya salad and green curry with Thai iced tea. They were both really good! I recommend if you like spicy asking them to make the salad spicier than mild; mild is very very mild. The green curry has a perfect amount of kick. The Thai iced tea was delicious. Make sure to check out the garden in the back. There is seating both in the sun and covered.

I came here after hearing all the reviews and rave about extraordinary Thai food. The flavors here are on point, i ordered the drunken noodles and my girlfriend tried the pad Thai. Both were plate licking good. Unfortunately we didn't get to try the famous green curry, which I would recommend, the other tables seemed to have a better time slurping their curry.  The only one thing I can find unsatisfactory about my food was the noodles felt a little overdone. It kept falling apart when I tried to pick it up.

This place is good, but over rated. When we see a place with thousands of good reviews, we go in with higher expectations, but we were not impressed as we hoped we would be. We agree that this place is better compared to many many many Thai restaurants in New York. However, we've been to a better one and that's why we were not as satisfied. We are giving the three star rating compared to Ayada Thai restaurant. We feel that if we give five star for Ayada for their service and food, then this restaurant should be a three star. The Thai ice tea was just okay, slightly too sweet for my taste. There is too much on the menu to choose from and it makes it hard to choose every time. We've had the pad seew, pad Thai, roasted duck green curry, red curry, and other dishes. The flavor of the dishes overall is just average, the spices are a bit lacking. We've had a few family dinners there and gave them enough chances. We don't think we will be going back.
The best pad thai ive tasted in nyc. I always go there when i want some pad thai in Queens area. Very authentic and worth the eat.

Fantastic Thai food. Ordered around 7-8 entrees and 7-8 appetizers. No complaints, would order almost everything again except the Tom Yum. For some reason... it tastes like old pepper to me (?). Still giving it 5 stars because you really can't not enjoy the food here.  The raw shrimp appetizer was probably my favorite! We ordered the red curry and the yellow curry - I would recommend the red over the yellow. The catfish papaya salad was weird to me because I thought there would be fish but it's like catfish crispy crumbs? Seemed like just breading but I may just be unfamiliar with this type of food.

Terrible.. the Yelp reviews encouraged us to go and we didnt enjoy it at all. The drunken noodles were so spicy that it hid the taste of it completely.  The pad thai was bad. The soup was bad.. the thai tea was so small. Not going back.

3.5 starsI got the Drunken Noodles with chicken. The waiter asked me if "mild" heat was fine and I said "Yes!" instantly. Little did I know, "mild" really meant "dripping sweat" kind of hot. I love spicy food, and I thought I could've handled SriPraPhai's "mild" noodles, but I was wrong. The first few bites were manageable; but after about 1/4 of the way into the dish, the chilies kicked in.  Other than being spicy, there really wasn't anything special or memorable about the Drunken Noodles. It was also too salty. I was more bothered with the level of saltiness than anything else. However, I would come back and try something else off of their extensive menu.

This is an impressively popular Thai restaurant! I've dined here more than 5 times and have always been satisfied with the food. Dishes come out rather quickly and I'm always happy with the portion sizes. Other Thai restaurants I've been to have not been so generous. Friendliness of the staff is hit or miss, but it doesn't matter too much as long as I get my food. Relatively fast seating and fair prices.

I found this place on yelp and decided to check it out due to their high ratings. Really close to the woodside lirr station and 7 train stop. I got my usual go-to thai food, the drunken noodle in the vegetarian option. The food was really good. The perfect amount of spice and the flavors were bursting in my mouth. As soon as we arrived we were seated right away. The restaurant was packed. Where we were seated was so tight so i legit had no room to move which was uncomfortable. After we ordered our food, the food came out in legit less than 10 minutes which was a major plus!! The portion size is decent. You leave not too stuffed or hungry and the prices for the entrees ranges starting at $10.00I will highly recommend and will defiantly be returning!

I really like this place. So, I drove from city to get some food to go, they gave me new menu. And took food to home,  there was no spoon or chopsticks and I order green curry and pot tai and rum yam soup.  Pot tai was horrible.i don't know if owner changed but food changed.  I was so disappointed
I loved the yellow curry and Coconut juice  sooo good . My husband didn't like his food because we are not used to that type of noodles in our country .Summary: highly recommended  . I'll be back .

Cash Only! Highly recommended. Wasn't packed so we got seated right away, food came out fairly quick and we were starving! Ordered Spring Rolls, Thai Ice tea and Chicken Pad Thai. My friends got drunken noodles but said they liked my Pad Thai more after they got a bite from it. I would highly recommend this place and chill vibe.

***CASH ONLY - they have an ATM & it charges $1.00 fee****Vegetarian review - be forewarned. Although there is some decent insight *I've been eyeing this place for a long time and never went until recently. A friend who lives in Long Island wanted to catch up over dinner. We needed a place close to the Woodside LIRR station so we picked this spot. As a vegetarian, I was happy that this place was vegetarian friendly. There is a yellow section of the menu that is specific to vegetarians - its a few pages - which is great. We ordered very light. I got the chive vegetable fried dumplings, Tom yum vegetarian soup and we shared a sticky coconut rice and mango dessert. The chive vegetable dumplings (About $4) are only filled with chive. Which was a let down as chive is a great addition to veggie dumplings (shout to Brooklyn Wok Shop!). It was way to "doughy" tasting. My fellow Vegetarians: Skip this appetizer! So this was my 1st time having Tom Yum soup. Turns out - It wasn't really my thing. But it wasn't bad @ all. It tasted sweet & spicy. It had flavor It's just, I didn't  know that I wasn't gonna become a fan of lemongrass. All in all, it was great to have a veggie version of a popular meat dish. It was also full of mushrooms, snow peas and other veggies. So it was definitely hearty. (Sm; about $4.50) i just only drank the broth tho so The dessert was delicious and unexpected. We weren't expecting sticky coconut rice w 2 big halves of mango and then the mango was on top of coconut milk that was dripping off of the sticky rice. It was a great combo! (Dessert; about $7) I also ordered a chardonnay ($5). It wasn't the best but what do you expect? It did the job. They don't have a happy hour but the drinks are cheap $4-10. Just don't ask the waiter - he has no idea what "happy hour" is. Kinda embarrassing on my part! Lol5 stars because of good service, ambience and the space is quite clean. Very well taken care of!Possible Dinner Party Location?I noticed that the place is not only well taken care of but it also has an extensive amount of space. Which lets me know that this restaurant would be a great party location. They were only using 1 dining room but had 2 available. This includes a beautifully maintained backyard dining area. They did a little "landscaping" and it looks really nice. I think there's even a fountain! I mean, you wouldn't even know they had a backyard from the outside. This place has big windows that let in a lot of light. Anyways, point is - if you're interested in having a dinner party - this is a cute spot. Last word: great romantic date night spot for under $35 for 2. That included tip!

This is my go to Thai restaurant whenever I am in queens. The food is so fresh and really authentic. Their drinks are also on point. I always get the same thing when I come here. Lots of options to choose from. Our waitress was poom and she was sweet and very attentive. Prices are great here as well. We usually pig out when we come here this time we took it easy. Vanilla Thai tea with stioli and a mango mojito hit the spot.  Bbq beef salad and crab and chicken rolls were also unreal. Honestly everything here tastes good lol. Go here. Won't be disappointed.

I've had Thai on 3 continents and my friend that joined me was from Asia and agreed . This place is incredible I would highly recommend not coming at rush . Had to take one star away for the wait. However I will def be back .

This is the best Thai restaurant I have ever encountered compare to all others. Their food portions are family sharing sizes, tasty menu, and they have the best Thai iced tea. You can order the Thai Iced Tea with bubble or without bubble (Tapioca)I have tried their watercress dishSatays (chicken and pork)chicken with cashew and pineapple flat wide noodle crispy pork with watercress Soft Shell crabsMango SaladsTom Yam Soup Tom Ka kai Soup Overall, I loved everything I have tried there. I usually eat them with rice.  Should give a try. There are notes on the menu for gluten, soy, etc in the dishesThis is CASH ONLY place.

We came to this place on a Sunday afternoon with a friend who had recommended it highly. First off, parking is a bit of a nightmare. You have to drive up and down the surrounding blocks hoping to get lucky and find something. After about 10 minutes we found a spot about 3 blocks away.The restaurant itself is small but set up nicely on the inside. It was packed, but we were seated in about 10 minutes. Be prepared for the menu! It is extensive and a little intimidating, but there are pictures and descriptions of everything and the wait staff give you plenty of time to look it over without rushing you. Once we ordered, the food came out surprisingly quick, which pleased me because I was starving and we had a toddler with us.We ordered the fried watercress salad (which is bomb, a must try), drunken noodles with sliced beef ( also excellent), fried tofu (yum) and fried pork belly (yum yum). Honestly I didn't try anything I didn't like.
Would give a 0 star if possible. Bad service from the old lady. Very rude while rushing us to order while we didn't even get the menu yet. The food wasn't even that good.

I thought about reviewing this eatery for a week and then decided a few well chosen words might save a few unlucky diners from choosing this Thai restaurant. My wife and I hadn't had Thai food for many years and decided to celebrate an event by dining at a "5" star restaurant. We ordered an appetizer each and then decided upon our entree's. If one appetizer was inedible I would not be writing this now , but both appetizers were bland, tasteless and just , be gentle now, garbage. My wife's ordered a noodle entree and decided it was tasteless and requested that it be replaced with one that might have some flavor. Our "waitress " acquiesced and grudgingly put in my wife's new choice of entree.. unfortunately this too was inedible, as was mine ... we then decided that leaving our best option and we did have food at home.. upon receiving the check our waitress brought back the original entree in a bag and we were charged for three entrees , although we hadn't taken more than one fork full of each .. we mentioned that we should not be charged for the first entree and our waitress was adamant about leaving it on the bill. So in summation, if you have a free night and want bad food and snippy service.. you have found your nirvana. I have no idea what so ever how this eatery survives.. but don't buy the "5" star reviews.. fini!

Phenomenal! As a person that absolutely does not like Thai, this restaurant is awesome! Came here on the recommendation of a couple of friends and could not be happier we did.SriPraPhai Thai sits in perhaps the most unassuming corner of Woodside. You have your local barber shop, a few bodegas, an urban park, some bbq's and domino games, then--BAM amazing Thai restaurant!When you get to the restaurant, you'll likely have to wait so grab a number. They've got a DMV type system so you'll see your number on a large lotto like board in the windows. Efficiency here is high, you probably won't be waiting long and the place is also pretty big.SriPraPhai has an inside section and an outside section. Now that the weather is nice, I'd def recommend sitting outside. You'll walk through the inside and smell a bit of heaven. Walking through the threshold, you'll notice a wonderful water fountain. There's a fair amount of seating outside and each table has it's own (LED) overhead light above the table for when it gets dark.The menu--it's like a Thai bible. It's has enough pages to make Game of Thrones jealous. There are plenty of house drinks and beer as well as bountiful food options.Our table went with a number of dishes including: watercress salad, fried pork belly, drunken noodles, and a few soup dishes. They were all winners. Watercress salad is a must have. Full of flavor, it's crispy and delicious. The fried pork belly was my favorite of the selections. The drunken noodles were great and had the perfect amount of heat to them. I honestly wish I could describe the food in greater detail, but again, I don't like Thai food so this was all really a revelation.The service was fantastic. Our server was friendly, helpful and informative about the menu, and very eager to make sure we were enjoying the food and having a good experience.At the end of the meal, I expect--like us--you'll be blown away by how good this place is. It's not often I can give a place 5 stars, but here it is. More than worth going out of the way for.

Ummmmm wow okay this is now my fav Thai restaurant. Huge portions, really delicious food, fresh and just super yummy. This place has THE best soft shell crabs I have ever had. They give SO MANY too. Ugh I love this place.

I love thai food & I've been to a few restaurants that I know which one is okay, good or the best. I bookmarked this place since its close to where I live. I got a chance to check it out yesterday. The place is big & lots of seating that when we get there we got seated right away. We got our water & for drink, my bf got the iced coffee & I got the thai iced tea. It was too sweet & taste okay. For appetizer I got the papaya salad- the waiter suggested medium spicy so I agree. Its very sweet so I didn't really like that too much sweetness taste & its not spicy so I ask for a side of chili. My bf got calamari- so tiny but it taste good. For our dish I got the ground pork with chili & garlic over rice- the flavors & spiciness of the food is perfect! Very flavorful. My bf got pad thai- I tried it & it was dissapointing. Its very sweet & It doesn't really taste like pad thai. So he didn't really end up eating it. Overall, service is good! They're attentive. About the food I was not impressed. Whenever you think about thai restaurant you surely think about pad thai. How can that specific dish doesn't taste good. I don't think I'm returning.
SO GOOD! Fresh food, and quick service - been wanting to try this place for years and finally did and it was absolutely worth the wait!

Awesome Thai food!  CASH ONLY!Go early otherwise you'll have to wait with the hordes of people trying to get in - they provide a deli counter paper number system with an outdoor screen for you to wait and watch.  They have an adorable backyard that's manicured very nicely and has umbrellas to offer some relief from the afternoon sun.  I've never had a bad dish here, the staff is friendly and attentive.  If you're looking for spice to knock your socks off - just tell them Thai spicy and they will not disappoint.  Try the jungle curry if you're up for a spice challenge.

Loved their service, and I really liked their food. I ordered the drunken noodles (spicy basil noodles) and I thought the food itself was great and the portions were pretty big. I got the minced chicken as the option, but I wouldn't really recommend it unless you like the meat in your entree's grounded up

This is the most amazing Thai restaurant with consistent 5 Star food quality. I don't question why there are long lines anymore, the food speaks for itself. We come twice a month here, birthday anniversary, just because it's Wednesday, it doesn't matter. Man their selection of deserts is mouthwatering.Don't believe my review, GO AND THANK ME LATER!

One of my favorite Thai restaurants!!It appears their menu grew since the last time I came, but the options are endless and so hard to choose from cause I want to eat everything. We ordered the shrimp pad thai, tom yum soup- shrimp, and the chicken rice which were all delicious! They're very authentic as well. For dessert, I definitely could not forget to order the water chestnut in coconut milk. That's a dessert I absolutely love and find it surprising a lot of Thai restaurants I've been to don't have this. Overall, highly recommended!!

hands down the best vegetarian thai food I have ever had and this is even after going to Thailand! Love love love this place! We ordered: Appetizers - Papaya Salad, fried tofu, and tom yum soupEntrees - Drunken Noodles, Panang curry, and Basil fried rice The appetizers vanished minutes after being served.  Everyone loved their papaya salad which was a great vegetarian find considering most papaya salads have shrimp or fish in it.  Than came the entrees, and I have never seen plates empty so fast! Their drunken noodles were my fav, but the othed entrees were very close to being that yummy! Their food we ordered was medium spicy, though it was a little spicy for my palette, my parents and hubby enjoyed every bite of it.  Told my family that we needed to go here 1 more time before heading home!

This restaurant is a pleasant surprise located in woodside. The food and service was excellent. We ordered a red curry with beef and my son ordered a fish dish( I forgot to take pictures).
