And a bowl of coconut rice. The rice was sweet but not too sweet. The red curry was rich and flavorful. The fish was fresh and tasty. The prices were inexpensive. Not a dive or fancy decor. Great tasty food plus great service plus great prices equal I will be back again .
We had crispy egg noodles with shrimp, Pad see-ew, shrimp fried rice and beef fried rice. It was fantastic! Worth the 1.5 hour drive.

I don't hate or love this spot.  They have some amazing Pad Thai and noodles.  I've gone here 3/4 times and will continue to enjoy this spot.  Only reason I gave this spot an A-OK is because I wish they would inform this is cash only when ordering on the phone.  Also for some weird reason my husband and I did not enjoy the pineapple fried rice something was very off with the plate not sure what is was but wasn't my favorite but overall still a great spot!

Came here to celebrate my sister-in-law's birthday. We wanted to go to the best Thai restaurant in Queens because we were going to go laser tag afterward.Did not disappoint; food + service is AMAZING! They had speciality desserts and food that we never seen is other Thai restaurants.

I really don't understand why people go here. The food is not that good. And the service is horrendous. Not to mention how expensive it is. There are so many better thai restaurants in the area. The meals don't come with rice. So you have to pay another 2.00 just for rice. The fish cakes are 11.00 for store bought!

Great place to go if you are hanging out with a friend in the area. The setup in the restaurant gave you enough space to enjoy food and chat. We went there during the lunch hour, so we ordered their lunch special, which includes dessert, soup, over rice dish and drink, all for just $15.50. I've been to Thailand before, I can say this is an authentic thai food place. Highly recommend.

I've been hearing about this place since HS. My teacher recommended it to us but I never got around to trying it until 5 or 6 years later. My coworker also recommended it and since he was a foodie too, I trust that it had to be good. He gave me a list of recommendations to try out. I only managed to try a couple items because we weren't very hungry but they were all delicious. We had tried the Papaya Salad, which was spicy and tangy. It was also very refreshing to eat something light and tangy to rev up our appetites. We then ordered the Beef Tendon Soup Light, along with a couple bowls of coconut rice, because why go for regular when you can have coconut! The soup very flavor flavorful from the broth and the added cilantro for an extra punch in flavor. The beef tendon were also super tender that you barely even have to bite them! Even though this soup is so simple and light, it has a very homey feel to it, as if my mom made it for me. I could just eat this for days! I usually don't like soups when it comes to food outside because of the greasiness, but the soup here doesn't feel heavy at all (or at least this one doesn't). I'm not sure how the Dark version tastes like, but I am thinking it would have a more rich flavor in broth. The coconut rice was also really nice because it wasn't overly soft like some places. The coconut rice is also not as heavy as some, so if you like a lot of coconut milk in yours, this may not be for you. But even without being very heavy, it has nice fragrant coconut flavor to it.We also tried the BBQ Chicken which was less exciting because it was more like grilled chicken with two types of sauces, one which was more on the savory, while the other was sweet. The chicken was very moist, but flavor wise, it wasn't as exciting. I would definitely recommend this place if you want a larger range of choices when it comes to Thai food. If you want more than Pad Thai and Pad See Ew, this is definitely a place to go because their menu is quite large. If you do want the usual though, they definitely have Pad Thai and other noodle dishes that you see at a lot in other Thai restaurants. If you haven't tried SriPraPhai, just give it a try! I definitely want to go back and try out the dishes my coworker recommended. (Some dishes he recommended: papaya salad with dried shrimp, mango salad, thai buffalo wings, fried fish cake, beef noodle soup light, sour and spicy noodle soup, tom yum pork leg, stewed beef tendon, tom zap beef offal soup, soft shell crab, chicken over rice, pork tender, steam fish and sauteed crispy pork belly.)

One of my absolute favorite restaurants of all time! There isn't another Thai place that meet SriPraPhai's level. The prices are "cheap" and affordable compared to other Thai restaurants out there. Polite and great service. Authentic food. Every dish remains consistent every time I come to dine. Never fails to impress me! If you are around this area and you've never tried this restaurant, you're missing out!

I went here to figure out if it lived up to all the hype. We ordered the red curry, somtum, Pad see ew, spice basil fried rice and some drinks. It does feel more authentic and the most similar to the thai food in Thailand. It's not as sweet which is good because thai American food is toned down a bit to meet the palate of Americans which done in a lot of thai restaurants in the city. However here not so much, which ends up being its plus point. Also, explains why it's very popular among Thai families! Will definitely be back here if I'm in the neighborhood!

I came to this restaurant before. Back in the day the food was great and the service is good. Yesterday i went there with my husband, ordered pai thai, roasted pork over rice, chicken puff, Tom Yum Soup, and the dessert is sticky taro ball. First of all, Pai Thai is horrible there is no taste and the noodle is over cooked. All the noodle were stick together and soggy. Chicken puff is over fried, too tough and chewy to eat. Tom Yum soup is way over salted. And finally the dessert is the nightmare, it tastes sweet and salty at the same time. I asked our waiter right away why our dessert taste salty and sweet. The waiter replied "i don't know". Well, i asked if he can ask his other coworker or chef. And he kept on replied "i don't know" and just walk away. I look at him and i am liked seriously? However, few minutes later he came over and hand us the check. Btw, our waiter barely speak any english, sigh. I would not recommend anyone to try there food despite the high yelp review. Poor service, bad food, CASH Only.

Pad Thai tastes just like the one I waited an hour in line at Bangkok's famous pad Thai restaurant- a bit sweet, hint of sour, and even bigger portion and a choice of protein! Arrived on a summer Tuesday afternoon during their non-peak hours. My date and I wanted to go out to the garden to enjoy the surrounding flower but the server who greeted me warned that there will be lots of insects. Since it was really hot, we decided to stay inside. Interior is still spacious and can host parties of 20 or more. We ordered the duck salad (plenty of duck pieces but duck skin could be more crispier) which was refreshingly seasoned with lime and fish sauce.  They gave a generous amount of chicken pieces in my chicken pad Thai. The beef drunken noodle had a hint of sweetness and smokiness. My date said it taste as good as the one at Klong's (St. Marks, Manhattan). I was not fond of the coconut juice because it was overly sweet. Do they use real coconut juice? I am not sure. Menu is extensive. Servers are friendly and approachable. I will most likely come back to try more dishes. Hands down best Thai restaurant in NYC.
It is a nice restaurant to hang out with friends or fam.  every food i order is thai legit.  The Thai Noodle, comes in green curry and chicken, is al dente.

CASH ONLY. Be prepped. You'll only find shady ATM's around here so if you know you're coming, come with some green. Luckily the prices are dirt cheap here. We ordered an appetizer and three entrees and split them up between four people. The bill I'll came out to about 47 bucks.  The outdoor seating area was beautiful but we chose to stay inside on a hit and humid Sunday. Can't comment on the drinks since we didn't order any but they do have a few on the menu. Only reason why I'm dinging a star is because their idea of Thai spicy is way below standard. The pad Thai was way on the sweet side too.

In Queens?  Hungry for Thai food? SriPraPhai is the go to place.  Group of 15, np.  They were able to accommodate us during a busy lunch hour.Food?  Delicious.  Whether it's the Tom-Yum Shrimp soup, the Pad Thai, or the Sautéed Roasted Duck in Curry Sauce, the food here is full of flavour.Service? Excellent.  The staff's always ready to help you out with any questions you might have at a moments notice.this place is cash-only.

The server was very nice, and that's about the extent of why I'm giving 3 stars. We ordered the pad thai and papaya salad - there are different variants; I got the type with "raw crabs" and other add'tl ingredients. Or so I thought. 20 minutes passes by before I get the (non-cooked) salad, and it turns out to be the wrong one.  I decided to just go anyways with it since the regular version seems popular from reviews, but it's $10 for some slices of papaya, crushed peanuts, and a few small green beans. Another ten minutes passes by before the pad thai  comes - and this is all after we already had to wait a fairly long time to have our orders taken, despite being there only being two other tables.We didn't finish the pad thai and said we didn't want it packaged to go when asked - and of course, they packaged it for us to take to go. Which is fine, but it was pretty frustrating after also getting the wrong order.We also ordered dessert but it turns out they didn't have it, which is fine but just made the visit all the more underwhelming.Given the other reviews I'm really hoping my visit was an odd one out but aside from the friendly server, the mediocre food, high price point, and slow/poor service made for a fairly negative experience. I originally took my friend here to show off the food scene in the Jackson heights area, but ended up pretty embarrassed and regretting that I didn't go somewhere else.

Their food is great. The crispy pork with Chinese broccoli is to die for. Our food was served fast and piping hot. The reason I am giving this place 3 stars is because I felt rushed to leave. The moment we asked for our bill the bus lady decided to have us pass the plates to the front so she can collect them. I wasn't even done eating and she grabbed my plate. Didn't even ask if I was done. She grabbed my beer bottle by the spout and when I said I was not done, she said, "I was just checking."  really? granting the place is busy, learn how to ask if people are done with their plates and drinks before you collect them.

I came here with a group of friends on a Friday night and there was no wait. They don't take credit card. I ordered the coconut soup and the sautéed seafood. Both of the portions were very small so I did not feel full after. The fish in the seafood did not taste good. One of the girls in the group ordered the salmon soup which she did not like either and someone else in the group ordered the BBQ pork which he said was mediocre. The service was very good and our drink (the valley girl) was amazing! Maybe we ordered the wrong things but I felt like the food was ok, not amazing.

Off the beaten path but a great spot for good affordable Thai.  What I love is that they have dishes that many restaurants don't have.  Good selection of soup and the great stand by pad thai.  I always want their mango soft shell crab.  Back in the day, they were tiny but now they also have a beautiful garden patio.  The service has gone down but the food is still reliable.

I hadn't been here in almost 10 years  but my memory served me correct. This place has awesome food especially the noodle dishes. Pad Thai and drunken noodles were and are the best I've had anywhere. The spicy dishes are legitimately spicy. Flavor was great for both noodle dishes and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The meat in the noodles was good - tender and tasty. This is a failing of many of the mc-thai restaurants popping up in many suburban towns where the meat in the noodle dishes is rough and flavorless. Appetizers were not as good as the entrees. The papaya salad was very flavorful but way too salty. I had to be "that jerk" to ask them to take it back to the kitchen and make it less salty (and spit in). It came back just as salty. The mushroom shrimp soup was overly salty too and not worth the price tag imo based on the simple taste and the modest portion. Just try out another delicious entree instead for a few bucks more.

Best   Thai food.   The service --- is there an excuse for stupid/ignorant/slow-------  with apology    that  is insincere  ?Ordered for  -2-  drinks,appetizer, main course . EVERYTHING  came at  VERY very very   different times for the  2 of us .  Food  is excellent.  I cannot believe that people  put up with this.  We have eaten many times here. The service---   Appetizers  came when the servers  brought them, same with the  drinks . When  my entree came just after finishing the very late appetizer for my spouse, and drink  for my spouse .     I had   ENOUGH !    Apologies from here and there from staff that were empty words,  but does that really excuse  stupid,ignorant,slow  when one is paying  [ ONLY  in CASH  hmmm    NYS ATTORNEY GENERAL investigation... ]    to have an enjoyable experience?     We came  out to this place for an enjoyable  experience, the food   EXCELLENT,  but  IF  you don't mind  the stupid/ignorant/slow  service....Oh yes we  arrived there at  6:30  on a Saturday night. There are  tooooooo many excellent  Thai restaurants  in Manhattan  that have  excellent food without the bullshit crap we had to deal with at this place for the last time.      I am a chef that has worked in very  high end places, and some  VERY - low Internationally, and very local, now privately for  many VERY very  high end employers . The kitchen staff,chef/cooks/ dishwashers/porters are the  BEST  they put out  THE  VERY BEST FOOD, and JOBS  I, and friends have eaten.PLEASE  do something with those  stupid/ignorant/slow  front of the house peoples .  The front of house  gets  'glamour'   trust me  these   'front'  house people  need  to  realize   it is  the   'back'  of house  that helps   you  front  peoples  have the  ''GLAMOUR''   that you spend  waay too much money trying to achieve .    Its  all  INSIDE of you .   Not  up front  or   outside ........   Get  real,  stop  the    ''SORRY''  just  ......

The food is still great here.  Authentic Thai food, almost feels like im back on vacation in Thailand.  The staff is all Thai ethnicity from what I can see.  Brought my friends last night as part of the Queens Welcome package I promised when they moved to Queens. In ranking order from best to least favorite last night would be pad thai, softshell crab (expensive : $19), pappaya salad, pork larb, mango sticky rice, fried fish, chicken curry. The mango sticky rice couldnt hold its sticky form too well, and the mango wasn't as ripe as it should be for the dish.  And the curry was a little watery and not as flavorful as I expected it to be. Overall good experience with lots of seating and friendly staff.  They are still cash only so leave the plastic at home.

Food is great but disregard the posted hours of operation. I arrived with a party of four at 9:15pm on a Sunday evening, they say their open till 9:30. We were outright told they were going to rush us and actually came to the table to give us a five minute warning for drinks from the bar. If your hours say you're open till 9:30 and customers arrive before then there should be no problems with serving them properly

One of my favorite restaurants to go to as a kid growing up. It was also a spot my family loved going to and probably the first time I ever tried Soft Shell crab was here! So clearly that's a must get item here!

It's ok. Don't see what the hype is about. Just like most east coast Thai restaurants the food is too sweet. They do this for Farang. Also the availability of proper agriculture in this region of the USA shows. In California we have Thai farms. If the food wasn't so sweet it would be much better. Definitely overrated.

I will say this place reminds me of the touristy spots in Thailand, pictures of all the items on the menu. I've been here a few times, and I will say the fish entrees are the best things on this menu. This time around I opted for crispy noodles, curry puffs, Tom yum soup. The noodles were how I expected, not in your face with flavor but not bland where I would drop fish sauce and whatever condiments that will make it salty. The curry puffs were on the sweet side for me, which is something I noticed when I was over there (things are sweeter in the motherland). Tom yum is Tom yum.What is my take away this time around? Get fish!

Came here for a lunch special one afternoon. The lunch special is huge! You get apps, soup, an entree and a drink for around $15. There are limitations on the entree though but there are some good options. I thought the food was really good, but honestly not that much better than the nearby Thai restaurants. I got a panang curry and the flavors really hit the spot. Going back though, I did wish I ordered just the khao soi (which wasn't a lunch special) but I enjoyed my meal overall so it wasn't a big deal. They are cash only which is kind of annoying so come in with bills !

I love this Thai spot when I go to NY. It's always busy but it's worth it. Everything is so good. Me and my friends usually get a lot of food and just share. I love the pad Thai, fried rice and spring rolls. YUMMY!!!! I can't wait to go back there again.

The best Thai food I've ever had and they really deliver consistently. Worth the long trek out here. Pad see ew, green curry, massaman curry, fried pork, EVERYTHING! So freaking good....just so freaking good. The hype is real! Service is always friendly and the decor is of a typical Asian restaurant with a nice back outdoors area.

I understand why this place is raved about. They have a HUGE menu, and prices are cheap ($10-12)! Please note that they are cash only.Food:For me, they are a hit and miss. I ordered chicken satay and pad thai to go a few months ago, and I was underwhelmed. They were okay. This time, we ordered..- Masamman curry:   I'm not sure if this is what it's called. But it was a peanut curry, so. This dish is actually pretty good! The sauce was peanuty and packed with flavor. - Shrimp drunken noodles:   Shrimp was perfectly cooked. Noodles were nice and a bit bouncy. The flavor though. . It's missing something. Flavor was flat. I've had better. - Thai iced tea:   Two thumbs up! Highly recommended! Service:Standard Asian restaurant service. It's pretty easy to ask for whatever you want. And it was nice that the lady asked if we wanted chopsticks when she set down silverware. The good:- Wide selection, good prices.The not-so-good:- The bf ordered chicken curry, but he got pork pieces as well. It would've been a big deal if he had a thing against pork.- Hit and miss menu. At least, for me.

Still on my apartment hunt, I ended up in Woodside to seem some places.  The apartment I was seeing happened to basically be next door to SriPraPhai Thai, which my fiance had previously raved about as her favorite Thai restaurant in New York.The first thing you need to know is that it is cash only.  Don't forget it!  The next thing is that when they say food is spicy, they mean it.The decor of SriPraPhai is very simple and basic.  You can tell they are going for a more comfort, homelike atmosphere.  It was cozy, but not somewhere I would go on a first date when you are out to impress with great vibes.  But on that fifth or so date, definitely come for great food.My fiance ordered the pad thai, as she does at all Thai restaurants.  She had told me before the pad thai at SriPraPhai was her favorite, and I have to agree.  I tasted it and the flavor and quality was on another level compared to other New York Thai restaurants.I ordered the Jungle Ground Fish Curry Sauce, something I had never heard of or tried before; I was feeling adventurous.  The waiter asked me if I was ok with spicy food, to which I replied "of course!"  I have been thoroughly trained in eating spicy Korean food and felt prepared.  But after my experience, the warning was justified as I sincerely believe most westerners could not handle the spiciness of this dish.  The dish came with a bowl of the curry and noodles on the side.  I mixed them all together and dug in.  I loved the flavor and it was definitely spicy.  By the end of the meal I was sweating, but it was worth it.  At one point I accidentally inhaled the curry and started involuntarily crying while laughing at the same time; they are truly not lying when they say it is spicy.  For those of you who aren't familiar with jungle curry, it has no coconut milk in it like other Thai curries, which usually helps cut the spiciness a bit.  Jungle curry is just raw flavor and spice and if you can handle it, it is great.SriPraPhai is worth the trip to Woodside.  Usually I don't eat at restaurants that are out of the way unless I have something else going on there, but SriPraPhai is one of those restaurants where I would make the trip just for the restaurant.  It is great value, great flavor, and great food.

Three words. Don't Get Spicy!I came here on a Saturday night, I was warned prior to going here of the crowd so the overwhelming group of people did not alarm me while walking into the restaurant. Even though the restaurant was packed, my party of 4 did not wait more than 10 minutes to be seated. The server suggested that we order as soon as possible so that we wouldn't have to wait too long for our food. The menu is HUGE! So many choices, I was honestly overwhelmed.Appetizers: Calamari- They were flavorful and crunchy.Vegetarian Curry Puffs- These were also good but there was too much corn in each.Entrees:Drunken Noodles- This was so spicy, my dad (a man who eats raw peppers) couldn't finish it. However, I ate it the day after and the spiciness did calm down. If you get this, don't say you want it "thai" spicy.Fried Rice with Chili Sauce- If you enjoy a sweet dish, this is the one for you. The green beans on the side were lightly steamed which, i did not enjoy.Roasted duck over rice- My mom enjoyed this, she said the duck wasn't as chunky as it should be but it was good.There's also a vegetarian menu, my sister got the fried tofu- she said this was spicy but very flavorful! Overall, the food is unlike any thai food i've had before, the flavors and taste are distinctly different. The service was great!

I'd give a 3.5 if I could. I've been here twice and it's great but definitely not the best Thai food I ever had and it's on the pricey side. I got the papaya salad because I remember this from last time. It was unfortunately too salty this time and portion seems to have shrunken.My husband got the beef curry soup, which was not bad but still a tiny portion. And they charge rice separately!It's cash only here and the good news is they have ATM machine. Bad news is that the machine charges you $1 when you withdraw.

This place is amazing. I have been going here for 10 years and it's the best Thai food outside of Thailand in my opinion. The spice is real (or mild if you'd like), the food is always fresh and delicious. They have outdoor seating with plenty of cover from the sun. This would be a 5-star restaurant but they only take cash so I would make it a 4.5-star if I could. Long wait on Friday and Saturday nights so come prepared, especially with a larger party. If you like Thai, this is the place!

To be honest, I thought this place was Meh! I've been meaning to come here forever because I heard this is one of the best thai foods in town. We came on a Thursday night and it was not that busy. The best dish of the night was actually the fried watercress. The sauce that it came with was phenomenal and it came with many plump shrimps. However, there were more cons than pros based on my experience. Strike 1: I was really disappointed when we couldn't get outdoor seating (which is gorgeous..opt for it if you can get a chance). Strike 2: The Masaman curry was pathetic. It came with 2 small pieces of chicken and the rest was just potatoes. Strike 3: The drunken noodles were not flavorful at all and it tasted more like chinese take out chow fun. It lacked a lot of the thai spice. Strike 4: The soft shell crabs (which was the main dish I wanted to try here) was EXTREMELY SALTY and the fish sauce overpowered the dish. Strike 5: The coconut ice cream looked 100x better than it tasted. I wasn't a fan of the peanuts on top.

I don't have much experience with Thai food, but I really like this restaurant and I am always satisfied with my meal afterwards.To start, the the pork jaew (pork neck) is AMAZING (I WOULD KILL FOR THIS). The meat itself is so tender, but the outside is nice and crispy, and the contrast is so nice. The spicy and sour dipping sauce is so good also, I love love love this dish so much, a must try.I really like the beef tendon soup also. They are super generous with the tendon - it's perfectly cooked with an amazing bite to it, and the soup is nice also. I always get the regular one (never tried the dark).The crabmeat fried rice was a little disappointing. Again, they are VERY generous with the crab meat, but I wish the rice was a bit crispier. The soft rice and crab have almost the same texture so it didn't really have that nice mouth feel you would get at a good Chinese restaurant fried rice. I also think they could be a little more aggressive with the seasoning- they probably don't want to overpower the sweetness of the crab but it was a tad bit bland.The pad Thai is usually quite good, but today it was a bit on the sweet side for me. Generous with the shrimp also, and the peanuts and lime are a nice touch. We also tried the BBQ chicken with coconut rice set, and it also comes with some papaya salad. The papaya salad here is pretty good- it's nice and sweet, sour, and tangy. The BBQ chicken was nothing special really, but at least it was well cooked. Interestingly the coconut rice here is sweet! My first time having coconut rice ever I expected it to be sweet, but it seems that in Malaysian cuisine the coconut rice is more savory, and the coconut is more for the aroma. However, the coconut takes the driver seat, and it was pleasantly sweet. The rice was nice and fluffy, but they provided a sweet dipping sauce for the chicken, so I'm not really sure how I feel about the sweet on sweet.The appetizer plate is just alright. The chicken wings aren't bad but the tofu is pretty boring. The brocolli with pork belly is so good (and I don't even like vegetables lol). The sauce is great, and I love the fact there's crispy pork belly in the vegetables. I am not a fan of the Thai iced tea here. It's way too sweet for my liking and there isn't much of a tea flavor because of the overwhelming sweetness. I've tried a few of the desserts in the past but I was not particularly impressed.Service here is pretty prompt and the food doesn't take too long to come out. The restaurant gets pretty packed on Fridays and weekends so there might be a bit of a wait. The menu is gigantic and a bit overwhelming. But overall awesome and authentic Thai food. Super cool toilets also :)

Overrated, overpriced, tasteless food. Ordered the fried platter..tofu was so rough and dry, spring rolls meh, the chicken wing was really sour...not sure if it was suppose to taste like that but just didn't taste right to me, everything else was just fried and tasteless. Chicken pad thai didn't have much taste to it and we ordered another flat noodle which also was tasteless. Only thing I liked was the thai iced tea. Oh and, the coconut mango jello was hard and looked better than it tasted. I did like that this place was spacious but definately not worth the drive here all the way from Brooklyn. Expected it to be really good, disappointed.

Red curry and pineapple fried rice are amazing here. menu is huge and lots of seating. It is cash only so make sure u have cash! The food even if ordered mild is spicy but its so good!Fish sauce smell here can be overwhelming and parking is hard to take a lyft.The mango and rice also looked amazinggggg
Wrong food. Disgusting. Very disappointed. I ordered red curry beef extra spicy and came horrible curry beef. I won't order from this place anymore.

We ordered several popular appetizers, watercress Salad, chicken curry puff, chicken dumplings, Tom yum soup and three main dishes, beef drunken noodles , chicken pad Thai , and soft shell crab. Overall good food and value. My favorites are beef drunken noodle and chicken curry puff. I feel pad Thai is too saucy.

Thai spice hotline. I have not been to this place in 15 years. It is certainly a lot fancier then I remember. I came here last night for date night with the wife. We had three healthy sized apps, the green papaya salad. It was just as it should be. A  hot / cooling sensation running thru my mouth full speed. First dark lao down and wife's lychee martini. Then came the fried watercress salad. I was apprehensive on ordering this one knowing my wifes love for fried anything, not! This dish was devilishly good. The larb was larb a awesome dish of heat,meat and lime. Third lao and second lychee down. Wife returns to the watercress to keep the heat at bay. Now I did ask for thai hot and it was. I wish I sat with a party of 50 so I could have tasted everything. I guess I will have to just go back. Worth the trip ManhattanitesEat, drink enjoy

Solid, well-maintained neighborhood Thai establishment that offers all the Thai dishes that you would expect (in fact, the menu is positively encyclopedic!), with an added bonus being a nice backyard with a fountain.The drunken noodles and pad see ew were all solid, enjoyable, and shareable, plus there were sufficient vegetarian options. Some items felt slightly on the spendy side but the quality of the ingredients and preparation, as well as the taste, were evident. Service was also fast and courteous. Overall, a nice option to have in Woodside.

Given what I'd read I was expecting more; while the food was all really good, it would be hard to distinguish it from any number of the places I go in Miami, which I don't think shares Queens' reputation for great Thai food.  So either Miami has seriously underrated Thai food (check out Panya, Oishi and even Eddie Hills - all in North Miami), or this place just wasn't as impressive as its press coverage would suggest. The soups were quite impressive, and the lunch deal was appropriately priced ($14 - you may need to request the menu).  I wouldn't cross town to visit again, though I'd stop in locally for sure.

1/3/17 after a long hiatus, I visited last night and was disappointed at my spice level. I think it is time Sri's gets called out for false advertising. You cannot have a dish listed as spicy and then serve some "Americanized" bland version. This is a disgrace to anyone who knows Thai food well.No self respecting Thai food lover would approve the crispy Trout Fillet in Spicy Curry Sauce that was served to me last night. It was not spicy at all and I had to request for the spices on the side to give it a kick. This used to be my favorite Thai restaurant but the inconsistency showed in getting the spice level right is just too much.Coupled with the fact that my favorite server and the only one I trusted to get my order right - the one known as "Bella" is no longer there. I might continue going to Glen Cove to get my Thai fix.Still, despite all of that, I did enjoy my Tum Yum soup last night. Seriously, folks please get it together or else you are going to keep losing your regulars.

I've always been a fan of Thai food. This place reinforced my love for it. SPP serves great tasting Thai food. The service is quick. It offers an extensive menu. Divided up by meats in the front part and vegetarian in the last part. The place looks very down to earth. The uses of the brown color gives the place a natural look. Since the weather agreed with us, we decided to sit outdoors. The staff opened the sun umbrellas. That made it feel more comfortable. For the appetizers, we ordered the fried wheat seitan. I ordered the Drunken Noodle with vegetables. Delicious. Before you go into the restaurant, you see signs that says 'Cash only.' I would say that is the only drawback about this place.I recommend this place!
Wow. Very amazed at this little gem. Good authentic Thai. Decent prices and tons of options

This was the best Thai food I've ever had. Ever. My parents agree. Thank you to Fazeela S. for the recommendation.We came on a rainy, windy, cold Thursday night and SriPraPhai still had a full house! Impressive.I was thoroughly pleased with everything I tried. The coconut chicken soup was so delicious and so flavorful. I'm still amazed. Chicken curry puffs - this standard Thai appetizer was so good, fresh, and piping hot. The red curry (we requested no fish sauce because of my allergies) was spicy but good! I can't handle spice too well but my parents really enjoyed this. We also had an order of the roasted duck and pad see-ew with pork. Everything was unbelievable.The menu is huge and very overwhelming. If you have trouble making decisions or aren't familiar with Thai food, you might have some trouble figuring out what to order. Regardless, they have everything!ALSO, they are very accommodating for customers with food allergies and there is a separate vegetarian menu. These people thought of everything!Service was kind of slow but not for lack of trying. They were just very, very busy. Those servers were always on the move. Very polite, accommodating, and we had an overall great time.SriPraPhai is also relatively inexpensive (as most Thai restaurants are) compared to others that serve food of this quality. We ordered 1 appetizer, 2 soups, 3 entrees, 2 sides of rice, 3 cocktails, and 2 desserts and the bill was ~$95 (and we had leftovers to bring home).Drawbacks: cash only and they do not take reservations. But the food is beyond worth the small hassle.Thai is not my cuisine of choice. That being said, this is the ONLY Thai restaurant that I will happily go to or even suggest knowing I will enjoy the food. Do it!

Environment : noisy, outdoor seating is nice Waiting : no wait for seating, 15-20 min for foodFood : - Crispy watercress salad : order every time, crispy, sweet, sour mixed w seafood and nuts - pork belly : not very crispy- drunken noodle : delicious, more than average taste- papaya salad : average - crispy ground catfish : delicious - satay : worth for a try Service : regular Price : a little pricy for Thai food Overall : a good place to treat visitor who want Thai food in a fancy environment. If you don't mind about that, Should try chao Thai, Zabb elee and Ayada Thai Tip : cash only, parking situation is not bad

We have been going to this place since it was booth tables with mirrored walls.  The food has not changed.  Been to Thailand a few times and every time you walk in to SriPraPhai it is like we are back in Thailand.  Crispy watercress salad, bbq pork with honey, drunken noodles, red curry with duck and eggplant, greens with crispy pork, crab fried rice are our regular's.  Tried so many of their other dishes.  Their curries are spot on no matter the color or protein.  Don't bother with all the trendy Thai spots. Just stick to this place.

Really good Thai food! My friend and I went there on A Sunday night. The average wait time is about 20 minutes. It shows how popular it is.Appetizer: We ordered papaya salad which was very delicious! It comes with peanuts, so please let them know if you have any allergy.Food: Soft shell crab is a must try! It is a little bit spicy but very delicious! We also got panang curry with chicken, and it was good as well.Drink: They have the best Mango Mojito! We love it!I got two snacks from their fridge, but snacks are not as good as their food. I don't really recommend their snacks though.So far, it's the best Thai food I have ever tried in Queens!

Everyone knows this is the best Thai spot in Queens and it's the best for a reason. The food is spot on. So many amazing yummy options from the meat lover to the vegetarian they got you covered. This place is always packed even on a Thursday night be prepared to wait. Even though they have two dinning halls you'll still wait at least 30mins for a party of two, more than two people I can't imagine but I wouldn't know I've only come here with one other person each time. The portion sizes are standard you won't leave hungry. The service can be a little slow due to the high demand of people coming and going. No biggie The food was very tasty and spicy had some hot lips afterwards but I was content. All in all great place for a date night.

Excellent Thai food! We had Tom yum soup, satay chicken, pineapple fried rice and green curry. Everything was spot on! Food is really tasty and fresh. Friendly service and great ambiance. Will come back again soon.
Great place to come for thai food. Ordered drunken noodles, curry chicken, beef soup, chicken skewers, and others. They were all delish and fresh. This place is def. worth it!

Food wasn't bad but service wasn't great at all. Waited for a while for our check. Worst thing we wanted to pack our fish cake with our chicken satay and the waiter grab the fish cake with his hand after touching money.

Food is so good here, but the service and poor attitude stops me from rating 4 or 5 stars. Still one star improvement from last time! Papaya salad -  4 starsCrispy watercress with shrimp and squid - 5 starsIsaan sausage - 5 starsSweet sausage salad 4 stars.Crispy pork with basil 4 starsDrunken noodles 4.5 starsPad kha prao - 5 starsLarb gai 4.5 starsOn the whole food is fabulous, but as mentioned service with a scowl!

Was recommended by a friend months ago, finally got the opportunity to make it there for my bday weekend and I have to say...it was worth it in the crappy weather. Food was amazing and the service was excellent. The wait for our appetizers and main course was so so short. My only problem was the fact that they don't accept credit cards, "Cash Only"...there's a dollar ATM thoI had the Lychee martini and my b had the Mango mojito...omg! Heaven...everything was greatI had the Drunken noodle shrimp and my bf had the chicken Drunken noodles, wings and shrimp raring rolls...was awesome. Will definitely head back soon

Had dinner here for the first time today and I was excited because I had heard great things. I have dined in the Long Island location and the flavors were not as strong. We ordered tom yum soup, papaya salad, basil eggplant, chinese broccoli and crispy pork, and taro custard. The food tasted fine, but it was loaded with MSG. Oh wait, it gets worse...both my cousin and I got food poisoning from our meal. My guess is the pre-made crispy pork was not re-heated at the right temperature. Unfortunately, this experience will deter me from ever returning.

A really cute place for a date. Try to eat in the backyard if you can and if it's not too cold. Honestly, it's a hidden gem. The food was good and the prices were average. Really good spot for a date with your SO or with friends!
This is in my top 3 Thai restaurants and definitely the best Thai I've had in NY. It is authentic and even had a dish my boyfriend hadn't seen since he was in Thailand.

My favorite Thai restaurant in the NY area, and the coconut rice here is the bomb.com. This place does not take reservations, but if you have a large party, come early so you don't have to wait around prime meal times. The papaya salad here is fresh and pretty much the only papaya salad I've ever liked. These people here do not play with spice levels so from whatever you normally get, order down a notch so you're not chugging water throughout your meal, and can actually enjoy your food.

My favorite Thai restaurant. I know you've heard the whispers about how they've fallen off, sold out, etc... don't believe it. They might not be the best at any one dish, but they're great at most. CRISPY WATERCRESS SALAD (the best salad of all salads) and whole fish filleted, and not a shred of regret during or after.

3 1/2 stars. This place can serve pretty authentic Thai food but you really have to know what to order. Not everything is a win in this place. I came with Marco and we ordered the raw shrimp, the roasted duck on rice, the crispy ground catfish and the thai sausage. The raw shrimp hands down was the best thing. Amazing. I'd go back to this place just to order this. It's really outstanding. The roasted duck isn't bad but not great. The ground catfish is a waste. I've never had ground catfish so wasn't sure what to expect. It's like a hard powder that really has no taste. The sausage was solid though, would order this again. Next to the raw shrimp was a small order of mango salad which was really good also. So overall, I'd come back to try other things but I really think you have to order the right things off the menu.

Sripraphai has been for me THE go to Thai place for many years. Whenever we wanted *real* Thai, and had time to make a hike to Queens, we never hesitated to spend the time. I always recommended it to everyone as the best thai in NYC . It was always sooo good. But something has changed. Over the last year, visited the place twice and both of the times were very mediocre experiences. Just this weekend, we went back and had 4 dishes. Only one of them came out decent, as in approaching to what it USED to be. The rest was just bleeeh . Wheres before each dish would be a revelation, now i can't stop and think that I could do better at any takeout. I asked that has been there for many years if something has changed? No, she assured me, the chef is  still the same. I don't buy it. Also, i couldn't help but notice that the restaurant is having hard time filling seats. So i think lots of  people have noticed the deterioration of quality. On Saturday night the restaurant was half empty. The adjacent sessions - which they built in the last year or so was completely empty.  In the past, there used to be a line out of the door with half an hour wait.

An absolute gem of a place in Woodside!If the weather is nice, definitely sit in the back outdoor garden area. Highlights included the red snapper, fried soft shell crab, and (sorry to be basic) amazing pad Thai. Do not skip the mango sticky rice!Probably the best Thai food I've had in New York and a beautiful place to eat with friends. Don't forget it's cash only.

I am so happy to have found this awesome place for Thai!! You will not leave Unsatisfied. We got the Penang chicken curry which was a delightful touch of spicy awesomeness & the beef drunken noodles which is on the sweeter side! We also got the pomegranate Martini & mojito which was on the lighter side of alcohol but refreshing!! Overall this place was delicious and can't wait to try more dishes!! Last thing their entire menu had photos of what the meal looks like!!

Being a huge fan of Thai food I'm sort of ashamed that I didn't try this legendary place this many years living in the NY area. Finally by chance on a beautiful Saturday morning I was nearby for a test drive earlier that I've finally get a chance to try this place for some takeouts before heading home. Although I didn't dine in, looking at the interior it did seem quite modern and more updated than I would expect from a traditional Thai place, the place has been doing very well with the help of these glowing yelp reviews no doubt. I arrived shortly after 12pm where it wasn't as quite packed yet, but after about 10-15 minute of walking around the neighborhood while waiting for my order when I stepped in it was a totally different situation where I didn't see one single table empty. Like anything popular in NYC the earlier you go the less you have to wait.Anyway onto the food, I've tried Ka Soy and as well as Massaman Curry a dish that I almost always get at a new Thai restaurant. Ka Soy was a first for me especially since they packed it separately I thought the broth is more of a dipping sauce than soup haha. But while the broth was really creamy and flavor I think was really salty if I drink it straight as soup. Definitely a very enjoyable dish. The Massaman Curry is really one of the best I've had and that's after it was sitting in my car for almost an hour for my trip back home. The chicken was really tender and large cut while the sauce is very creamy. I've no doubt its probably filled with oil and salt but man it was very delicious. A little disappointed that rice wasn't included by default but glad I had backup rice already made at home.Their desserts are amazing as well. I tried both the Taro Custard Cake and their deep fried taro bread and both were phenomenal. I would certainly go with the fried taro as that was freshly done and the breading was very crunchy and filled with sesame seeds.I think the price was a really good selling point for this restaurant as well. Although its cash only but at $10 a dish it's certainly cheaper than many of other Thai restaurants with similar offering. Definitely a 5 star place for the food and price alone being I didn't have to wait and didn't really have to experience their dine in service. It doesn't really need another glowing 5 star review but honestly this is one of the times that something so well reviewed lived up to the expectations.
Some of the best fried rice I've ever had. The Chinese broccoli was fantastic as well. Spicy spring rolls were really good too. Service is attentive, and the food came out fast and hot.

I ordered green curry, papaya salad, pad thai and fried pineapple rice. They all tasted pretty good and especially the pad thai was the best in NY !!! It's a popular place with cozy and nice atmosphere. Go and try their pad thai !!! So so good!

A very middling experience at this quiet thai restaurant. I was expecting a bit more effort put into the ambiance, food presentation, taste, or dining service to justify the slightly higher prices, but all you really get is a bit more square footage, back patio, and bathrooms that don't double as mop storage. Ordered drunken noodles "spicy" and they might have a bit of a kick but I was certainly not sweating or hurting. They have a "very spicy" which may have acually been what I expected. Nice cooler full of prepackaged takeaway desserts. Probably a good bet for a first date because it's near the subway and there's nothing really remarkable to distract from getting to know each other. Cash only.

I love Thai food, I eat it at least 6 times a month and with that, this is one of my top 3 places for Thai food. They have a huge variety of Thai dishes, so many noodles and entrees. Not one of those places with just pad Thai. The menu seemed pretty authentic. They have a very large outdoor back patio that got very busy for Saturday lunch. From the front it's very misleading about how many people they could serve. They were also selling premade dishes from a fridge when you walk in; I didn't get, but good to know for those late night cravings/lazy nights.

Oh. My. God.  I'm going to zoom right past the food and just say yes it is good.  But the mango sticky rice.  The five stars are based solely on the sticky rice (service was meh and food was just good). If you order nothing else, order the mango sticky rice. It is sweet and savory and melts in your mouth. It is so well balanced. It has this surprising little salty element that really puts it over the top. I could not stop going back for more.  Had this not been a cash only establishment, I would have taken an order (or two, tbh) to go. I have never had sticky rice this good.  In fact, I've never even cared about it until now. Get you some.

Expensive rip-off with stingy portions.  Not returning.  I've been a loyal customer for 20 years since they had the original single storefront.  The quality has been in gradual decline since they expanded.  I took my boyfriend who was visiting from Wisconsin.  On behalf of New York City I was embarrassed that this is supposed to be one of our best Thai restaurants.  It was expensive for the tiny little bit we ate and it didn't taste good either or have any degree of spice.  The chicken red curry BARELY had any chicken in it.  Come on, Sripraphai!  It's not like chicken costs that much, especially with the volume you're buying.  Don't be so cheap.  We had:Spring Rolls Combo - What were these toothpick-sized excuses?!Chicken Red CurrySauteed Mixed VeggiesChicken Stock RiceWith a 20% tip, it came to $42.  We could have barbecued at home and eaten like kings for that amount of cash.  We've had MUCH better Thai food in Wisconsin.  If you're ever in Milwaukee, go to Thai Kitchen at 2831 N Oakland Avenue.In Queens I guess I'll just go to Ayada.

I came here for dinner tonight with 4 friends. 2 of them live close by and have been here many times. Within seconds of walking in, I noticed a terrible smell that reminded me of a mix of bad breath and sweaty socks. I was hoping that the smell was coming from a person but when I took a walk to the back of the restaurant, the smell lingered throughout. 1 of us got a beef dish and 4 us got pad Thai. 2 chicken, 1 shrimp and I got beef. We got some appetizers for the table including a spicy beef dish, fried crab ball, veg roll, soup and chicken wings. 2 people ordered drinks. The pad Thai had some kind of strange flavor that I couldn't put my finger on but I didn't really like it. The spicy beef smelled like feet and (even though we ate it) we had to throw a napkin over it and push it aside. I didn't try the rest of the stuff but my friends said they enjoyed their meal. The best part about the meal was the price and portion size. We spent $150 for 5 people and 2 of us took food home. I've heard a lot of good things about this place so I would try it again. Hopefully next time the smell will be gone.

Love the coconut rice - $2 for a big bowl of it. Sweet and coconutty Always get the soft shell crab in the appetizers section with mango slaw, one of the best soft shell crab I've had $19 for about 6 piecesSautéed Chinese watercress has nice flavor Green curry is spicy and not a lot of restaurants have this kind.Will definitely come back.

Honestly the best Thai restaurant I have ever been to.  The green curry, Panang curry, Duck and basil over rice, papaya salad, and pineapple fried rice were all phenomenal.  Most Thai restaurants I have been to in New York have been not as authentic, but SriPraPhai is very authentic.  Not only is the taste amazing, but the ingredients are also very fresh.  Will definitely go back.

Wonderful restaurant. The restaurant is also busy, especially on the weekend. If the weather is nice  we can sit in the garden in the back of the restaurant which is a plus. Varieties of food to pick from. Very authentic. You can adjust the level of spicy by simply telling the servers. Thai Ice Tea with bubble is great. Every servers are very friendly and helpful.  But this restaurant did not accept credit card and closed on Wednesday.

We came here years ago and haven't gone back for a sit down meal ever since. My family is very picky when it comes to Thai food since my husband's family used to own a Thai restaurant and we frequently had trips to Bangkok. Authenticity-wise, their food doesn't do justice and it's more of a toned down version of Thai food lacking the flavors that my family are used to.The real gem in this establishment is their packed food-to-go right beside the cashier near the entrance. We frequently drop by just to buy a few packs of their deep-fried chicken skin which we also bring for pot luck at parties.

Today I ordered a vegetarian pad thai to go from the Williston restaurant, I would say that was the worst veggie pad thai I ever had!  It was dry, noodles all stuck together, the tofu was hard & over cooked, un-chewable, and the order seemed smaller than usual, but cost $12, totally not worth it.  I don't think I'll ever order from them again!
The food was great, without being otherworldly. The appetizers seemed a bit on the price side, while the entrees seemed more reasonable.They have  outdoor seating which was nice.
The place used to be very good but now more commercial and the food taste is not like before. The fried rice we ordered was not at all tasty.very disappointed

Solid 4 star Thai joint in Queens. We got there probably 15 minutes before close and it was packed. People were still coming in and they were still seating until 9:30pm when they closed. Even though they were about to close, they never once made us feel rushed. They went about cleaning the other tables as patrons got up to leave without making us feel as though they wanted us out. They sat us at a table and were told to order cause the kitchen was about to close - but they gave me plenty of time to pick some pretty good dishes and get recommendations from the server. Plenty of servers on hand to take care of water glasses and napkin requests. The food was just as good as I have had at other Thai restaurants. Pretty authentic with the heat so be mindful of those in your party, when you tell them you want original Thai spice. Oops! I loved it though! :PI could have eaten the entire plate of the Basil Fried Rice with beef. Wasn't in love with the Northern Thai sausage but it had a really nice heat to it. The Thai Iced tea was also too sweet for me. But I don't think you can go wrong with most of the dishes here. I appreciated their ability to serve us and at the same time let us know that it was closing. We didn't overstay our welcome and ate and left when we were done but it was still a relaxing and great meal.

It is so delicious here!  We always start with the combo spring rolls. I always get the drunken noodle (chicken and you can choose your spicy level) $10.50 or pad see ew (beef). Will have to try the curry one day but I do not doubt it'll be as delish. Portions are big here!Don't forget to get the Thai ice tea too $3. Was just there last night and had they a.c. pumping. It was great. Ps-they have outdoor seating too.

It's really bad they only accept cash. I didn't find the shrimp on my soup but the soup of my husband was good. I'm not sure but I didn't find the scallops on my plate either, I know seafood is expensive but I'm paying for it, so I should have what I paid. The flavored of the meal was ok.
I like the food here. i like the service here tooi had green curry seafood, the first soup on menu, and coconut rice.coconut rice is soft tender, taste like coconut. very good

This is the most authentic thai place around. Everything on the huge menu is very tasty. They have loads of dessert too. And many vegetarian options. The staff is always nice and helpful. The atmosphere is great, they have outside seating in the summer. The only down fall here is that it is cash only. I would have only given it 4 stars for this but the food is that good.

Still a notch above most other Thai restaurants. I usually try something unusual, but this time it was old standards like Tom Yum soup, Chicken in Red curry and Pad Thai. A solid Pad, and the best and most complex Tom Yum and red curry I've ever had. PS. They've got an insane luncheon special: appetizer, soup and entree for$15. Hard to beat that.

I love Thai food. After finally having authentic Thai from Somtum Der and Sripraphai, Thai food has definitely risen to the ranks of one of my favorite cuisines. We went on a Saturday around 7:30pm and there was no wait to be seated in the inside and only a 20 minute wait to be seated outside in the back garden. I enjoyed the garden area on a beautiful August day, where it wasn't too hot or humid. The servers were extremely friendly, very attentive (never an empty water glass), and helpful when recommending what to order. Here's what we ordered:- Fried Softshell Crab with Green Curry ($19) - My favorite of the night! A little pricey for two softshell crabs, but they're expensive everywhere. The crabs were fried perfectly, thin layer of batter, crispy crunch, piping hot when it arrived at the table. Devoured immediately. Pull it apart and dunk it in the green curry, the crab stays crisp but has a great added flavor with the curry. Buy some coconut rice to go with the rest of the curry or just eat it by the spoonful like we did! - Pad Thai with Shrimp ($10) - I don't care if pad thai isn't authentic. The flavor combinations work perfectly well together. Sour from the tamarind paste, sweet from the palm sugar, salty from the fish sauce, with a touch of brightness from a squeeze of lime! I love it. It's delicious. The noodles made here are still springy even while the sauce clings to it. You only get 6 shrimps... but it's more than what other places give you so I'm not complaining. - Mango Salad with Seafood ($11.50) - I really liked this. I opted for this instead of the papaya salad and I'm glad I did. The mango julienne strips held up well with the marinade, a little spicy, a little sour, all over tasty. Lots of seafood too. A little odd with the added chicken pieces but didn't take anything away from the overall dish.I can't wait to come back! Looking forward to trying the fried pork belly with chilis and basil and the fried whole snapper!! I saw the snapper on other people's tables and my mouth was drooling.
This is my most favorite Thai restaurant in Queens. They got a lot of food choices. I recommend the soft shell crab with chili if you like seafood. All in all food is amazing.

Sripraphai is the really first restaurant that I tried in NYC. The ladies were really good in customer service!! The foods are great, but they need more thai style tastes like in LA. They have many varieties of desserts!!! My favorite one is "Lychee Icecream" !!! Overall, the place is nice and clean with great customer service!!
Outrageous food.  The menu is huge, lots of choices.  We have eaten here at least 20 times. Each time, food is fresh and delicious.

Wow, such a good Thai restaraunt! I literally loved everything that we ordered. It was also packed, so you know it's good. Luckily the wait time was actually pretty short!I can't necessarily remember what we got, but we got duck drunken noodles, curry with rice, chinese broccoli, soft boiled crab, and a few other things. The duck drunken noodles were so amazing, I normally can't get duck in other Thai places! The service was quick and the refills were plenty. If I lived in NY I would definitely be going here!
Ordered to go1. Award winning chefs picks-Drunken noodle w/ shrimp2. Padthai w/tofu, beg & egg$24.50

This place is REALLY big and packed. I didn't expect that. We waited about 5 mins for a table of 2. Staff was friendly and attentive. It's very clean design is a bit bland. So I got the Chicken Pad Thai. It was good had taste, big portion but might have been rushed when cooking. Also got the beef massaman curry. This was really good the beef melted in your mouth and was slightly spicy. The only thing was that it had to much meat and not enough sauce. That could be good for some people though.

I got the chance to try this popular Thai spot on a Monday for lunch. We got to try out the lunch special where you choose from 3 different categories: appetizer, soup, entree, and  beverage for a set price of $14.95. We started off with the chicken & shrimp dumpling and the papaya salad. The dumplings were a little below average. It had a funny texture to it. The papaya salad was pretty refreshing but got a little too spicy for my taste. For the soup, I got to try the cocounut chicken soup & the Tom Yum shrimp soup. Both were amazing. You could really taste the coconut and the curry in the soup. It blended pretty well together. The tom yum soup was also very good. The soup came with two shrimps in it. Our main entree was the Red Curry with Rice & the drunken noodle with chicken. Both were excellent and very tasty. The noodles were cooked pretty well, which could make it or break with this dish. The red curry was delicious, especially with the bamboo and the chicken in it.Overall, fast service, great food, and excellent price for lunch. Highly recommended spot.

For those that have known me for a long time, know that I have been trying to get to this place for about....6-7 years.  No, I am truly serious.  Yes, I know where Queens is.  Yes, I have multiple forms of transportation to get here.  I guess the first tip off I got was when we got parking literally right in front of the place.  You know when they say if it's too good to be true, it probably is?  Yeah - my feelings exactly.We walked in, and the place was a lot larger than I thought.  Lots of parties and big tables were arranged, and people from all walks of life were enjoying themselves.  We were quick to be seated, and they were quick to take our order.My husband got the Massaman curry and I got my staple of drunken noodles with shrimp.  The Massaman curry was so spicy, it was even too spicy for me, and I love spice!  He got the most lowest amount of spice one could ask for, and it was just too overpowering.  My drunken noodles were pretty basic - I wasn't wowed in any way, and no, this wasn't my favorite either.  The spices and the overall presentation fell really flat from my expectations.   From what Brooklyn has to offer, there was no need for me to leave my borough for here.  Sorry SriPraPhai - you might be a fan favorite, but I'm not getting on this band wagon.

My second attempt at eating at SriPraPhai (the first time, it was closed on a Wednesday) and my girl friend and I got in with no wait at 7pm on a Saturday evening. I was a bit surprised of the lack of wait, given the hype this place has.We over-ordered and went with the following:Basic papaya salad - mmm, this was good.  The papaya had the perfect crunch to it and it was well marinated and very flavorful.  Love the dried shrimp - most "un-authentic" Thai places forget to put in the dried shrimp, and that stuff is critical.Shrimp tom yum soup (large) - not really that large, to be honest.  It was a bit too tangy and sweet and tasted somewhat artificial.  Not sure how to explain it, but I've had better tom yum soup back home in the suburbs of Atlanta.  Shrimp was tender and the mushrooms were good, but did not like the soup base very much.Calamari pad gra prow (basil sauce) - extra $1.50 for squid.  Came with plenty of squid, lots of basil, and plenty of red bell peppers.  Flavor was alright, but as I've said, nothing really different or better than any Thai place I've had in the city.Drunken noodles (sliced beef) - you have the option of ground or sliced.  The sliced beef was tender and juicy, but there wasn't much of it.  Noodles were yum as usual, but not much to it for this dish.  Comparable to other places.Rice is an additional $1 a bowl.Not sure if SriPraPhai is SO good that I would make my way out to Woodside from the city again, but it was a decently satisfying meal.  I think I still prefer Pure Thai Cookhouse in the city.

A very good experience in Woodside. It's a bit of a trek, but was worth it on a lazy overcast Memorial Day with nothing planned. We ordered the watercress salad on a whim and it was delicious! It's the only photo I took. Deep fried pieces of watercress with a side of shrimp, chicken, and squid in a fish sauce vinaigrette. Definitely worth it if you need to order only one dish.Other items: shrimp salad (standard), beef penang curry (very tender), chicken stock ride (must have), and sticky rice.I'd forego ordering Thai iced tea since the glass they serve it in is small for the price you pay.

I have been at this restaurant few times and I always enjoy having dinner there, I highly recommend the green mango salad with shrimp, the fried soft shell crab and their curry dishes. Great Thai Food Restaurant

SriPraPhai is where I find it surprising that the restaurant is much more lively than the street outside! With good reason too! Thai food here is authentic and superb! Any curry dishes here are great choices. They are full of spice and flavor.  Vegetable ingredients in the curry are very fresh and not overcooked, still has that crunchy taste! Pad Thai, Pad See Ew, and other noodle dishes are delicious. The perfectly charred noodles really makes the difference here! Meats are very well marinated with Thai spices and sauces. Delicious!Overall, a very solid Thai spot and it is no wonder it is so popular!
Big menu great atmosphere excellent food first time and been in this neighborhood and never noticed the place great service and awesome drinks

A bit of background, I'm from Toronto which is super multicultural so I've had pretty good Thai food. I've also been to Thailand and had the authentic food there. The food here is merely just mediocre. I got the spicy level on all the items ordered - it really wasn't that spicy, mild to medium at most. I ordered the beef tendon soup (3.5/5), beef red curry (2.5/5 in taste, but also side note that you have to order rice separately...) and shrimp drunken noodles (4/5). The drunken noodles were definitely the best item ordered - I'd recommend. However this isn't a place I'd rave about and probably won't be coming back again.

Lots of options and quite authentic the only thing is that the ingredients aren't the best or freshest. Service is nice but quite slow and downtime unaware but never rude. Reasonable price and tastes quite nice! Walking distance to bus stops and subway station.

The food didn't wow me but the attentive staff and decor definitely did. There's plenty of tables inside but the back yard seating is cozy and would probably be perfect on a breezy sunny day. I came on a Saturday afternoon and it wasn't too packed. However, there was a larger party behind so I guess they cater to large groups as well.  Their menu is organized and offers a wide selection to choose from. And my favorite was actually the large vegetarian section. Pricing is decent and parking may be difficult at certain times but service is great.

Don't give into the hype. Sripraphai has been a part of my family since I was a kid. I mean, my auntie used to work in the kitchen for the owner, Mae Sri (who has now "retired" to cashier). The food back then was top notch. Since it's expanded (and consumed the surrounding two spaces) it has become a Thai "mecca" serving mass produced food. Of course, those who are just familiar with the basics (pad thai, som tum, etc) may be satisfied, but they didn't even get that right for me the last time I was here. The pad see ew I ordered (in Thai, etc.) came so sweet and dry that it was just irreparable - even with all the side condiments (that came in to-go jars?). WTF happened?? Where did the authenticity go? It certainly didn't go to Northern Boulevard. It's as if the chef either didn't taste the food going out. Or, the chef doesn't know how it's supposed to taste. Or, perhaps, the authenticity here is no more and those searching for it have to go elsewhere.Get it together SPP.

I came here with a large group of people and thus had the chance to try many dishes. We had the papaya salad, both with the dried shrimp, and the vegetarian options, drunken noodles, again, pork and the vegetarian option, coconut rice, and chicken saute, as well as some currys. My favorite curry was the duck one, with chuncks of pineapple, and I believe potatoes. The noodles were great, especially as a late night option, and the papaya salad,with it's crunch and strong flavors, was one my favorites, and I am far from a salad crunching gal. The chicken saté was perfection with the peanut sauce, and I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that one vegetarian guy in the group *cough* *Charles* ate the chicken and didn't know it was chicken! Naturally that merited one hell of a roasting. There wasn't a single thing I tried that I didn't like, everything had texture and flavor and at a great  price! Now I just need to go back and try all their drinks.

Food is okay but portions are really small so you have to order sides to fill up. I got the sautéed steak and it didn't even come with rice. As far as service, it took a while for them to come get our order and then even longer to get the food so make sure you have time and are patient. Don't bother ordering an alcoholic drink because it's basically all juice and no alcohol :(

Shrimp wrap was ok but not their good sweet chilli sauce, Chicken and Crabmeat roll had a weird taste and they gave that same terrible sweet chili sauce again. I wish I could reach into my fridge right then to get my Sweet Chilli sauce instead of this horrible one they gave. Shrimp pad Thai was way over cooked in water and was too soft. Green curry soft shell crab tasted like popcorn chicken from Popeyes'.  Way too much breading which overtook the Crabmeat and it was lost in.  The curry sauce was good for my rice though. Roasted duck in curry sauce (with bamboo shoots and eggplant) was disgusting. It was very salty and the sauce was beyond horrible.   I wish I sent this back to the kitchen cause how can they serve this?  What a waste of duck when duck is such a delicious meat. We were in shock the place was so busy even the food was so bad.  We've been eating Thai food for over 20 years (most of them in Manhattan) and this place is not recommended.

I wanted to go to this place because of the reviews and some of the menu items. Getting out of the way to make it there while on vacation was so worth it!!!! The food was amazing and the ambiance was very nice. We sat outdoor and truly enjoyed every bit of everything. We were a little concerned with the look of the front of the restaurant, but I'm so glad we stayed.

Ordered some delivery the other day. During the lockdown it looks like they're walking it. Worth the wait, food was great. Fresh and flavorful. Had the shredded flank steak, flounder w garlic sauce and some breaded chicken. All good :)
best cuban hands down !ox tail #1!!!!!!!!ropa vieja garlic yucca tres leches cake ... brooooooooobirthdays are the best here, they are amazing !service is always great. thanks guys!!!

This place has consistently gone down hill slowly, the food used to be really amazing, now it's just okay. Black beans, have lost the flavor, the steak with onions had barely any onions, and very little flavor as well. The owner(s) of this place should really stop being so cheap, and fix the place up , it looks like a dump. The tables and chairs look like they are there from day one, the faded yellowing plastic table covers have to go. This place looks like they've had the same furniture, and utensils since 1950.

Located in a bustling area between junction Blvd and Roosevelt Avenue is this little gem. Tucked away is this rustic Cuban restaurant serving up delicious food and a cool island vibe with its photos and memorabilia of Cuba on the walls. It is not an upscale place but it is warm and inviting with an atmosphere perfect for a cozy dinner with that special someone or family. I ordered the red sangria and jupina both equally delicious but who doesn't love sangria so I would opt for that next time I visit . We ordered the fried green plantains, rice and beans cooked with bacon, roasted pork and of course their famous Cuban sandwich with a side of drench fries. Let's start off with those rice and beans .... could I have a whole pot of those to go ? So delicious so flavorful .... I couldn't get enough of it and paired with the roasted pork covered in their garlic sauce it was bliss in every bite . The fried green bananas also amazing and super crunchy.their Cuban sandwich really is delicious I truly enjoyed the fact that there was a good bread to filling ratio and that the bread was nicely toasted and super crunchy. My only issue were the fries being a little too oily. Overall an amazing culinary experience and i will definitely be back for more of that rice and beans !

some of the best cuban food you can find in NYC. with it being a family run and owned business they always treat their guest like as if you were a guest at their own house. highly recommend this place, you wont regret it

Me and my coworkers have been dining at this place for years (9), our last two visits were ruined by a woman who said she was the owner. When we dined in she was very snippy and condescending. We then went today for to go and ordered porkchops and asked them to put some type of gravy on the rice from the stewed chicken, oxtails of beef stew and she said  " we don't do that because it would be taking from somewhere else. I've never heard such nonsense. Especially, we always get gravy. In fact, I've never heard any restaurant respond that way. We "Help you survive." The servers and cooks are amazing, but SHE has a poor attitude.  She should let her staff head the front of the restaurant and just sit back! Nasty!!!You just lost customers over gravy??? Poor business decision. A spoonful of gravy? I told her to keep it and canceled my order. We all did. Customers matter!

First time i Order from this place and i'm very disappointed with the prices and food.I paid $74 dollar for rice and been,flank stake and two cuban sandwich .The meet was so salted that i have to run it an hot water to rinse the salt out and the rice very dry.the portions very small in plastic containers like Chinese food.Also all this extra charges for rice and beens that it cost 9 dollars in any other place in Queens. Note ! this a review from 2 people that try the food in the same house.

If you blink, you could miss it. That would be a loss on your part. Situated right next to a bakery with bright fruit colored cakes, RC's signage is a bit faded and incognito.Old school red and white checkered table tops, RC is comfortably dated and well worn, with minute service. By the looks of the clientele this Cuban hotspot was a regulars kind of place. Thumbs up.We had some trouble deciding but their special app of the night sounded wonderful: tostones topped with ropa vieja and ground meat. All the items were in Spanish and English but we found the names to provide little clarity as to what was in each meat dish. The first guy they gave us was confident and cordial but because we were indecisive they gave us Esther who was amazing. We opted for a stuffed cassava starter and grilled skirt steak with onions and oxtail (Rabo encendido). That cassava was burn the roof of your mouth hot and delicious. Think silky smooth mashed potato that's a bit sweet folded into ground beef, shaped into a burrito and deep fried. That crust was something else and you eat this with Tabasco apparently. I can dig that. The skirt steak was juicy and flavorful on its own topped with rings of seared onions. The oxtail was fatty and fall of the bone tenderness in a tomatoey stew. All served with rice and beans and maduros. Proportioned perfectly just like Esther said, we ate every morsel and left nothing to waste.The dishes are not blow my mind flavor bombs, but reminiscent of mom's kitchen. Something someone has cooked a million times to know the right cut, pressure and time to let the ingredient shine by itself. When I asked Esther if the Oxtail sauce is the same as the famed Ropa Vieja, she said no. They are both red but different. The sweet girl even brought over a little sample of their RV for us: rich and brothy with definitely more tang, it was really good and we can see why it's a bestseller. My only gripe is that we didn't have room for dessert but we will be back.

Absolutely love this place! I have been coming to Rincon Criollo since I was a little girl! There's this ambiance of family throughout the whole restaurant. The staff are so unbelievably welcoming, with huge smiles from the moment you walk in! The food is just as good as their customer service. You can tell they place a lot of emphasis in ensuring the food tastes home made! My favorite dish is the Vaca Frita, with white rice and black beans! (Also not on the menu but available upon request, yuca frita and make sure to order it with mojo sauce)

OMG... this food was soo good. Everyone has to try this place!!! I had the chicken with garlic sauce with fries and rice. Being from Chile this dish reminded me of my moms cooking. It was so good and packed with flavor! When you get this dish take the juice from the chicken and pour it on the rice .. it's amazing.. The service was excellent. I couldn't find a problem with this place. I will always come back until they get tired of seeing me

This is authentic Cuban food run by 3rd generation Cuban restaurateurs. They are not only over friendly but they treat me and my guests like family! After eating here 3x I thought it was finally safe to bring a Cubano here for dinner. Even though I felt it was delicious I was still afraid of what this Miami Cuban would say. Well he told me it was the best Cuban food he'd ever had in the tristate area. Furthermore he said he hadn't had Cuban food this good since his his grandmother cooked for him many years ago! PERIOD!!!

Visited here recently with a few friends. Before walking in, I expected the restaurant to be small, however, after opening the door and taking a few steps in, I was surprised at how big it actually is. The decor and ambience of the restaurant is culturally rich, nothing lacking of Cuban culture. The menu is very easy to understand, they have the dishes in Spanish with English translations. Each entree comes with two sides. We had an order of the 1/2 roasted chicken and chicken breasts with green peppers and onions. We had side orders of rice, black beans and tostones. The garlic sauce that came with the tostones wasn't strong or pungent in my opinion, I would've enjoyed it a bit more if it were stronger. Their dishes were delicious, I found the 1/2 chicken to be a bit dry but it fared well with the beans and rice. The dishes are small but enough to share a few bites around the tables. A cup of coffee is the perfect nightcap to you meal. It's strong but perfectly brewed. Might I also mention, the dishes are fairly priced, cheaper than your average Cuban spot. The only downside of my experience is that I was looking forward to a garlic of homemade green sauce to compliment my dish, however the only sort of hot sauce they had was Tabasco, eh. Nonetheless, great experience, I'd visit again.

Food is good however interaction with whoever the heavy bottomed female that works there was less than pleasing. She's extremely condescending. Will not be coming back. No food is worth the disrespect.

My family and I have been coming here for over 30 years. The food is consistently good and the atmosphere is always energetic.The food doesn't take long to come out and the service is always friendly.
They have the best Cuban food ever.  The staff make you feel like family. They are the greatest

Great little hidden Cuban spot with delicious food. We stopped by for a quick lunch and shared a ropa vieja plate. The meat was juicy and tender. The rice and beans were solid. The plantains deliciously fried. Service was quick and I totally loved the whole lunch. I I'll have to come back for dinner when I'm in the area.

I was very disappointed at tonight's dining experience. What's more surprising is that this place has amazing reviews which totally deceived me.
