I can really only speak for the seafood paella since my friend and I shared that as our main dish. 1st of all, it takes an HOUR to make which they tell you ahead of time, so that's fine since we had an appetizer (which was delicious- the only good thing here) and wine. However, when you order an hour long paella at $52 for the dish, you expect AMAZING paella. Not mediocre, not bad, but amazing! Sadly, this was the most tasteless, overcooked paella I have ever had in my life. It had NO flavor. The seafood inside was cooked dry. The lobster meat and shrimp was tough and didn't have flavor. The scallops were soft but almost too soft as if they didn't cook at all. Horrible ! My friend and I added salt, pepper and hot sauce onto it which we typically would never do to a restaurant made dish cuz it's usually always flavorful, if not beyond ! This was crazy ! What's worse is that we mentioned this TWICE to the workers- one who brought it out from the kitchen and one who's our waitress. We mentioned it in the beginning before we even really touched it. the first guy who served it to us just smiled and laughed nervously.  Didn't say or offer anything. The second time, we mentioned it to the waitress and she said "oh no !! Really ?? No one's said that to us before... I'm so sorry" which was MUCH nicer than what the other guy did. However, she didn't offer much at all either except for spices in the back kitchen.... seriously ?! - no refund, no half price, no dessert on the house or ANYTHING to make up for the horrible paella - and mind you, this paella was $52 dollars- RIDICULOUS for something that tastes so bad. Yes, the portion is huge and can feed 4 instead of 2, but I don't ever wanna pay so much money for something that tasted like nothing. I don't mind paying a lot for good food - excellent food I might add, but paying a lot for bad food and horrible customer service? No thanks. Lastly, I'm not sure why this isn't mentioned on yelp enough but this is a CASH BASED restaurants. CASH OR AMEX only. When you charge a single item that's over $50, how can you only accept cash and Amex ?? I've eaten at many cash based restaurants, but they're smaller restaurants and wayyy cheaper meals, so it's understandable that they only accept cash. We almost didn't even have enough but it was enough to cover the check and give them a very low tip - and to be honest, that's all this restaurant really deserved, if any at all.  There are only 2 good things about this restaurant: the wine and this appetizer where they had ropa Veja and ground beef on top. The ropa veja was very good- better than other Cuban restaurants I've been at. And as for the wine, it's $6-8 for a very full glass which is great. But honestly, besides those two things, this was a pretty horrible restaurant and establishment. Truly disappointed and will not be returning
For it being in TV and many people praising it, I was not pleased. The ropa vieja was very salty and the fried garlic chicken I could get at the Chinese spot. Best part of the meal was the soda.

BEST CUBAN RESTAURANT!!!This place is just 100% amazing. I'm so happy I discovered this place back in 2015 ever since then I've been coming here at least 5 times a year. I always get the same thing, although my partner Gets something different all the time, so I get to try his food :) I get the "pollo al Rincon criollo" and one plate comes with two side dishes for free, so I get the black beans and rice. Their plantains are also delicious. But ok so the amount of chicken they give you is a looot, and trust me you get full. Their drinks smoothies and juices are really good as well. NOW customer service---100% amazing. They servers are funny and always attentive, I've never had a complain about this place. Prices are normal, I actually think for the amount of food they give you, it's a cheap place.

Don't ignore this review, COME EAT. Very welcoming, food is good and service is great. Flavorful Cuban food at very reasonable prices except (tres leches at $8 a slice) to much, but is that even a complaint?! It was ok not great wouldn't buy it again. 4 stars for the service and delicious food!

Lives up to the hype for sure. Great authentic Cuban food spot. I've gone here a few times and gotten the Cuban sandwich which hits the spot and the ropa vieja which is some of the best I've had. The best literally melts in your mouth and has so much flavor. They give you a really decent amount so I always end up having left overs that taste just as great the next day. Service is great wait staff is very friendly. I believe they only accept discover cards or cash. Would definitely return when I'm in the area.

Fantastic authentic Cuban cuisine. The waitstaff is prompt and friendly. The menu has a variety of dishes and specials of the day. The portions are filling and were delivered individually. (I combined mine to the single large plate that was also brought to the table). They only take AmEx cards, otherwise you need cash. There is an ATM right next to the front door once inside. Definitely a keeper!

I'm going to give this place 3 stars based only on my customer experience. Food is great and our server was amazing. Our bad experience was with Ester, I don't know if she was a manager or a hostess but damn her attitude was horrible and she was hella condescending. We asked for them to split the bill and our awesome server was about to help us when she abruptly interrupted our conversation, she then proceeded to split our bill in two which uh duh we could've done ourselves. They only take AMEX and cash so bring cash or you'll pay a $3.00 convenience fee to use their ATM machine.  The worst part about this whole situation was when we gave our waiter the money to pay for our bill she took it from his hands. I just hope he gets his tip because he deserves it.  Voy a darle a este lugar 3 estrellas solo en función de mi experiencia como cliente. La comida es excelente y nuestro servidor fue increíble. Nuestra mala experiencia fue con Ester, no sé si era gerente o anfitriona, pero maldita sea, su actitud era horrible y ademas condescendiente. Pedimos  que dividieran  la factura y nuestro increíble servidor estaba a punto de ayudarnos cuando ella interrumpió abruptamente nuestra conversación, luego procedió a dividir nuestra factura en dos, lo cual podríamos haber hecho nosotros mismos.Solo aceptan AMEX y efectivo, así que traiga efectivo o pagará una tarifa de conveniencia de $ 3.00 para usar su cajero automático. La peor parte de toda esta situación fue cuando le dimos a nuestro camarero el dinero para pagar nuestra factura, ella le quitó el dinero de las manos de una manera irrespetuosa. Solo espero que reciba su propina porque se lo merece

The place is lovely. Very Cuban feeling The YuCa Rellena app was crispy and tasty. But the Shrimp in Garlic Sauce needed to have the garlic taste, but the shrimp was cooked perfectly. Presentation of the shrimp dish was nice. Rice and Beans tasted good. My boyfriend said the Sangria was ok. Payment: they accept only American Express or cash. The service was satisfactory.

Definitely worth the trek to Corona for this hearty, flavorful Cuban fare and amazing service! A big group of us came and though they don't take reservations, they allowed us to pre-order a paella for four. Definitely a smart move since it takes about an hour to cook! And it's definitely enough for more than four people... especially if you get some of the other delicious dishes on the menu. I loved the vaca frita (fried shredded beef) and the mariquitas (plantain chips) with that heavenly and pungent garlic sauce on the side. OMG. The service was fun and efficient the whole time. I liked that the manager lady was real with us by telling us we had ordered plenty, even though our hungry asses kept wanting to order more. She was right, mostly because that paella is HUGE! A fun, casual place that really knows what they're doing!

Authentic Cuban food - I usually go with a group of friends before heading to a Mets game and order a bunch of plates we can share. Don't miss the vaca frita, croquettes, bistec encebollado, rice and beans (duh), and the ropa vieja. If you're in a rush and need a quick delicious lunch, then look no further then their Cuban sandwich. ::chefs kiss::
My wife being from Miami and growing up on Cuban Food, this was a delicious treat on our way from LGA to JFK!

Being from South Florida I have found it difficult to find good Cuban food in NYC (I know that is odd). So, I was excited to find Rincon Criollo on Instagram. The pictures of their food looked amazing but the food was even better! I had the Vaca Frita, Yuca in garlic sauce, the rice and beans cooked in ham, and the fried dough. Everything was absolutely amazing! By the time I finished I wanted more so I ordered the steak rolled with ham and cheese and then fried which comes with 2 sides. I have honestly been in a food coma since. The food was just so good! Everything was cooked perfectly and the sizes were plenty. I am so happy to finally have found some good Cuban food. I will definitely be back!

This has been a bookmark for a long time. Nice that I finally got around to it. The amount of good reviews and now I know exactly why. Ordered bacalao fritters and shrimp in Spanish sauce w white rice and red beans. The Bacalao fritters were very tasty and not too greasy but just wish they were a bit thinner. Doesn't take away from the flavor though just the texture. Has so much potential on being crispy. I would order again though because it tasted very good. The shrimp in Spanish sauce... oh boy this was phenomenal. I took that sauce and started putting it on everything. The best combo was the Spanish sauce with the Moro rice. Oh man my taste buds were dancing. The shrimp was so tender as well and huge. This would be my go to fish for sureeee. Service was impeccable. The water glass was always full. Lovely. Their sangria was very good, not too sweet but filled with rich red wine flavor. Yummm
The wait staff was very friendly. I ordered two Cuban sandwiches to go, so I'll let you know what the Cuban tasted like when I get home...
Been coming here for years. Never gets old. If you like Cuban or Hispanic cuisine then make your way here! CASH only.

This place is hidden gem , the wait was very short despite it being so small . The waitress that night was quite personable , funny and knowledgeable about their menu . The food was on point , the sangria could use some work as it was very weak ! The prices are also very inexpensive
Honestly. Incredible. The to ropa vieja to die for. Service was amazing. It's a small hole in the wall but holy shit. Amazing. Oddly they only take cash and AMEX which was weird but nbd. Will return
This is my goto for Cuban food. Staff is wonderful and the food is amazing. I don't eat Cuban food often but when I do, it's always this place. Don't sleep on the ropa vieja!!!

Went here with a Cuban friend from Miami for his birthday. Look the food isn't incredible, but it's good. And it's very reasonably priced. And the staff is really nice and welcoming and they do a hilarious birthday celebration. And let's be real: NY doesn't have a ton of good Cuban restaurants. Highly recommend.

My search for the elusive Cuban dessert, cascos de guayaba (sweetened guava shells) led me to Rincon Criollo. I found out that several of my friends on Yelp, including the revered Mister Dessert himself, had rated this restaurant very highly, so I was ready to be delighted. And delighted I was. Ropa vieja (a classic Cuban dish of shredded beef in a savory sauce) is always my first choice at any Cuban restaurant. The creative name of the dish literally translates to "old clothes" due to its appearance (with intertwined shreds of beef), which somebody with a vivid imagination apparently thought bore a resemblance to rags. Rincon Criollo's version of ropa vieja, cooked in an onion and tomato based sauce, is the best I've ever had (including the ones I've had at Cuban restaurants in Miami and Puerto Rico). The tenderness and flavor of this dish are outstanding. When you go to this restaurant, you can pretend to peruse the menu in detail, feigning an interest in other dishes, and then just order the ropa vieja. OK, if you get the vaca frita (another dish of shredded beef but cooked dry rather than in a sauce) instead of the ropa vieja on one of your visits, I will not judge you too harshly. Cuban desserts tend to be a little too sweet, so you might not be able to finish your cascos de guayaba or dulce de leche cortada (caramelized and curdled milk), but don't let that deter you from trying these fantastic desserts.

Very easy to pass this place, nothing fancy outside or inside decor wise.  However, food and service was excellent.  Staff was very attentive and I thoroughly enjoyed every dish.Had the Codfish fritters as an appetizer. Shared the ropa vieja, and oxtail entrees that came with 2 sides each.  Sides were 2x yellow rice, yuca and fried plantains.I highly recommend everything I ordered, ropa vieja is a must, might be the best I've ever had.

Use to like this place but not anymore. Food was below average. Even the bread was kind of hard. My theory is that everything is from 2-3 days old. Nothing tasted fresh at all. Not sure I'll be back in a while. Sorry. (Maybe new cook or owner?)

About last night......We went to one of the most amazing, authentic Cuban restaurants I have ever been to.  The owners of the restaurant are from the same town in Cuba as my mother in law and I believe this is the 3rd generation running the restaurant now.There is nothing that I can say that hasn't already been said in the other reviews so I won't belabor the point that the food, service and atmosphere is amazing here.After you eat here you soul will be happy!!!

Really disappointed. Saw that this place had great reviews and was really excited to try it. Everything is overpriced and the food was so bland. Feel like we paid $100 to eat white rice. Place seems outdated.Wouldn't recommend.

This place by far is definitely not the worst Cuban food i've had but at the same time it was definitely nothing special in my opinion. One of my friends raved about this place for so long so i wanted to give it a try and the reviews we're great.I came here on a Friday night and was seated right away. I ordered the ropa vieja which is classic Cuban dish with a side of sweet bananas. Right of the jump the ropa vieja was nothing special and was lacking that authentic Cuban flavor. I've been to a lot of great cuban spots in Miami as well as other places so i know authentic Cuban. THIS was far from it and something you can get at a bodega. Service was great and the ambiance and decor was cool. I would def come back and try something different that i might enjoy. Overall this place is decent and in my opinion the Cabana has way better food in forest hills. People make a big deal out of places and over exaggerate especially when people like Guy Fierri visited this resteraunt on triple D to eat. Also real cubans who were raised on eating cuban food a vouch that this place ain't nothing special. The Bronx got way better Cuban restaurants in my opinion.DON'T BE FOOLED BY THE REVIEWS..... this place ain't trash but highly overrated by Americans that don't know authentic Cuban food.
Flew call the Way from San Francisco Ca to The US OPEN and a Friend of mine told me about this Place n QuéenS New York,Customer Service was Êxcellent FooD was what i was Êxpecting REAL COMIDA CUBANA

Great Cuban Food!!! Definitely recommend the ropa vieja!  I got the rice and the side of Yuca!! A must. I highly recommend for birthday celebrations. You let them know and they sing and make it a nice small celebration. I went for my moms birthday and she loved it!! My brother got Oxtail stew!!! And definitely recommend!! You pick a main dish and two sides! Lots of choices so you can't go wrong!' Give this place a visit ASAP!! You won't regret it!!

Came in with my lady and bammmmmm automatically felt at home. It's a spitting image of grandmas house. The decor keeps your eyes and mind busy while you wait for your food which is amazing and always taste fresh. We have to recommend the fried chicken ! It was delicious. We had the pleasure of meeting Ester and the crew and they have team work down to a science. Congrats to you guys and we will see you soon.

Delicious affordable Cuban food.  The oxtail stew, vaca frita, yuca con mojo, tostones, are stellar.  There's alcohol too.  The wine soaked fruits in the sangria are tasty and not too boozy, which is how I like 'em.  If there's a birthday, the server will bust out the big guns to make sure there's a smile on the birthday person's face (or if the birthday person isn't into that, at least it'll be hilarious for you to watch).  Skip the desserts-- you can get better elsewhere, even at the bakery directly next door.  Service is occasionally slow when busy, but wait staff is warm and spirited.  Meat dishes are excellent.  Not suitable for vegans and vegetarians.  Nothing about Rincon Criollo is fancy n free, but everything is fantastic n fun.

I finally managed to get some take out via grub hub from here and it was well worth the hassle. The hassle being trying to find street parking for your pickup truck in Jackson Heights on a Sunday afternoon. It took awhile but I was determined and my stomach thanked me.I think the lack of parking is the only drawback to this place and the food more then makes up for it. We got the breaded chicken breasts which were golden delicate and perfectly seasoned and the ropa vieja. This classic dish was sublime, full of saucy earthy soul. The rice and beans couldn't have been better, so aromatic and homemade tasting. I'm far from a cuban food expert but I think these folks know what they are doing.

So. There are three options here:What's behind door number 1What's behind door number 2What's behind door number 3Door #1: New chef. New night. New microwave.Door #2: Thursday nights are, "bring your C game to the kitchen, night!"Door #3: Did Rincon Criollo used to be some of the the best Cuban food in NYC and now they're on an out of control, downward spiral? Don't worry, it happens to the best of us. Figured a safe bet, a standard, a staple... was the ropa vieja. Not this time. Sort of rubbery, a bit on the sweeter side and a very slightly reminiscent taste of a ketchup imposter. Someone else at our table ordered an avocado salad as his main dish. MAIN. Dish. It was basically the same side salad I got with my meal,(iceberg lettuce with a few slices of tomato), BUT with an additional 4 chunks of avocado. And not a whole, quartered avocado. I actually thought he had ordered avocado ON his side salad. Get it? It's a little weird. I'm just not comprehending the 700+ reviews and an overall 4.5 star, stellar review rating.The service was good & the tostones were the highlight at just above mediocre. End of story. Can all of these people be wrong? I just don't know.Props to the lawd baby j for good company at the dinner table, otherwise the meal would have been a total bust.

I've never had Cuban food before and when I saw that rice and chicken dish I knew I had to come. Fast forward a year and I'm finally here! Yay for procrastination! So when we get there a really upbeat and welcoming guy seats us at a 2 seat table. The guy saw me fumbling trying to take off everything and suggested we move to a table with 4 seats. WHAT A SWEETHEART. So we're mindlessly looking over the menu and he stops by again. Asks if we want any drinks and gives his pitch for the shakes they make in house. I was sold and got the mango one. One glance at me and he says "no pork?" I nod and he suggested the "stuffed cassava." Made with ground beef I was told. We do the rice and chicken pot and my friend gets the side of plantain chips. First comes out the complimentary bread, my shake. That shake was SO GUUUUUUUUUD. I could feel the bits of pulp in the drink. It was sweet and really flavorful. Nice pairing with the rest of the food. Her plantain chips I kept munching as though it was bottomless. The stuffed cassava was really good. It had a soft fluffy exterior. Filled with potatoes and ground beef. Fluffy pocket of food. PEOPLE DO NOT GET THE CHICKEN AND RICE DISH WITHOUT A MINIMUM OF 3 PEOPLE. So you know how on the menu it says "pot for 2?" That is a SUGGESTION. That pot was massive. It's made to order so you wait an hour for it. It literally came out in a massive pot! I took two plateful and had to tap out. My friend was a trooper and kept going. Now about service, our waiter was really peppy and engaging. He stopped by numerous times to check up on us, recommended both the shake and appetizer, also when the piping hot came out, he fixed our plates so we wouldn't be hit with that steam. But you know what makes this special? While he was waiting on other tables, I glanced up and noticed he has a limp. At first I thought I was mistaken. But no, I kept my eye on him and certainly the sweet man has a limp on his leg. He provided service above and beyond. Not once would I have known about his limp if I didn't see it myself. We tipped well and left the restaurant with smiles from the entire staff. While the food isn't spicy it is really flavorful and the staff is spectacular. You will have a wonderful time.

Wow. I whole heartedly enjoy my meals here every single time.Mind blowing mouth partying flavor! Every time I eat here, I stuff my belly to capacity and still have the audacity to munch on more.YOU NEED the garlic sauce for EVERYTHING, it's a must and a requirement for the meal. Trust me and thank me later.I love the rice and beans separate and mixed, and the sweet plantains are super sweet. The fish broiled in garlic sauce is amazing too. Literally, you can't go wrong with anything on this menu. The plantain chips are great, crunchy salty and just perfect before your meal. The fried snapper is awesome too.

Disclaimer: if you are looking for a BOUJEE night out, this place and neighborhood is not meant for you.  I suggest you run along to Beauty & Essex for brunch or something I was starving when I came here, and left not only satiated but happy that I found this gem of a restaurant thanks to friend who accompanied me here.Food is SOOO good (a side of side plantains, simple rice and beans, the flounder fish in garlic sauce, and the ropa vieja).  I loved all of it!!  The food tasted fresh, not gimmicky, and just very simple and clean flavors.  I wish we ordered the paella, because it was also incredibly reasonably priced and came in this huge pot for plenty of leftovers (caveat in ordering the paella was the time it took to arrive: one hour).I can see myself coming back here if I want a fun but casual experience with friends.  It's a shame we didn't order drinks (but we had to drive).  Also, I thought the staff was so friendly.  As soon as one of my friends mentioned it was my birthday - they did this very special birthday song and dance for me (I will not spoil the surprise for those yelpers who are considering coming here).  SUPER CUTE.
Come here to taste the best Cuban food around!!

Went here yesterday afternoon for lunch with the family. We were craving some Latin flavors and landed on Cuban. This was a nice in between spot for those of us who life in the Forest Hills/Kew Gardens area and those who live in Astoria. When we entered we were missing someone in a party, butt they told us we can sit down anyway and wait. This was greatly appreciated as it was snowing, and some restaurants are strict about waiting for the entire party before seating. The menu was large and there were so many options. We may have gone a bit over board. I ordered the leech on asado with a side of the black rice and beans and sweet plantains. My husband got the sautéed chicken with onions and peppers with white rice and French fries. Then he ordered a Spanish omelette just cuz! We also ordered some yuca boiled in garlic sauce for the table. The wait staff was very attentive and informative as we waited for our food. They checked in often. Once we got out food.... silence. It was sooo good! I ate way more than I intended, but it was so hard to stop. The portions were more than generous! I was shocked that the 2 sides that accompany the meal were so large. We could barely fit all the food on our table. While my husband's chicken sounded plain, it wasn't. It came in a flavorful sauce that livened up the white rice. As I'm writing this review, I'm just wanting to go back for more. We ended the meal with a tres leches, because how can you not. It was delicious. For 4 of us, we ended up paying $30 after tax and tip. We were amazed because we ordered quite a lot. This includes sodas, a glass of wine, and some coffees. The atmosphere was so homey and family oriented. A nearby table had a family of about 14-16. They ordered the arroz con pollo in a pot. It literally came out in a large kitchen pot and smelled amazing! I will have to try this next time. Well not a whole pot, but that arroz con pollo seemed on point. Needless to say, we'll be returning. This is a solid Cuban spot. Also saying this after visiting Miami and being severely disappointed with the Cuban food I tried there. NY, NY!

Two words! Legit Cubano! This place is the bomb when it comes to Cuban food. It is as legitimate as it gets. Totally authentic Cuban food made old school style and delicious!  We often have their Ropa Vieja (beef stew) and Vaca Frita (fried beef), plantains, tostones, potato pancakes, various appetizers.... All out of the park!I hear the paella is awesome as well but have yet to try. Lots of old pictures on the wall and decor that brings you back to a whole different era. Love it. Try it. You won't regret it. Just go and absorb it all.Warning... Waiters also come with personality! =)

I LOVE CUBAN FOOD. And I'll just keep coming here until I can actually go to Cuba because I definitely felt the vibes there. Celia Cruz playing in the background, cortaditos on the table - I'm already happy. Yuca rellena, croquetas de jamon, chorizo appetizer - ecstatic. I had bites of the pescado criollo & the lechon - the food was so flavorful. That criollo garlic sauce is my fave. And THE MOROS Y CRISTIANOS and maduros, wow. The portions are huge so my advice is to take half home so you can have room for dessert. Their flan is better than my mom's (please don't tell her I said that). You've impressed me, Rincon Criollo and make me want to spend more time in Corona. See you soon.

I've been to Rincon many times in the past and I've always enjoyed their food. They are most famous for their half fried chicken with garlic sauce but their side dishes (rice & beans and sweet plantains) were wonderful as well. After an event in Corona, I decided to take my family and friends here so they could share my experience. We were seated promptly and soon after the waiter took our order. We were all excited for the food especially since I hyped it up so much in the past. However, here is where things went downhill. After about half an hour we received our first appetizer (chorizo) and then we had to wait another 30 minutes for the next dish to come out. In between all that waiting, I looked around and saw that every table had a basket of bread except for our table. Now, to be fair, we ordered a seafood paella for the table and the waiter warned us that it would take an hour to cook, which was fine. However, we thought that it was common sense to bring out the other foods that we ordered first and then paella last rather than waiting a full hour for all the food to arrive. Nonetheless, we received all our food at the same time. We ordered two half friend chicken with garlic sauce which was good as always, grouper with garlic sauce, sides of salad, sweet plantain, rice & beans, and ropa vieja. All in all, the food was okay. I excepted a little better given how much I loved the fried chicken with garlic sauce but other dishes, especially the paella, didn't stand out to me. The paella was a little on the bland side and very wet almost to a porridge consistency. Would I go back? of course but only for their amazing fried chicken with garlic sauce.

Drove through the high traffic streets of Corona to try this joint (sounding like Guy Fieri now). It's a place that has gotten rave reviews so of course it's on my food bucket list.I came here with a few friends on a somewhat early Saturday evening, and was seated immediately. The decor is warming, a tad crowded because of the narrow aisles, but the ambiance is nice. Let's move on to the food.For appetizers, we ordered chorizo and and codfish fritters. Chorizo is sliced thinly, and doesn't have a strong flavor like I'm used to. The codfish fritters are delicious! So I guess you can tell which one won me over.For entrees, half of us ordered oxtail stew and the other half ordered chicken. I love me a roasted Spanish chicken from time to time, and it's almost always a hit, but I was the other half getting the oxtail. The oxtail is overly salty even when eating it with rice. My blood pressure was rising at a rapid rate. Okay, I'm being dramatic. You get my point. The stewing needs a lighter hand on the salt, and it would have been perfect. The meat tenderly falls off the bone like it should. That salt just ruined it for me. Couldn't even finish the entire entree.No complaints about the service. They are rather hospitable at Rincon Criollo so a good tip is well deserved!

Good service, good food for sure.I came with my wife and son for dinner and we were very pleased with our experience here. For appetizers, we had their ham croquettes and plantain chips along with the flattened bread they serve you. The ham croquettes in my opinion was maybe the worse croquettes ever. They were shaped like a breakfast sausage link and tasted ZERO ham. I even had to ask the waiter if this was the ham croquettes and even he acknowledged there was ham in there. Perhaps they blended it or something because there was no hints of ham in that croquette whatsoever. And the way it was deep fried, the batch of oil they used must have no been changed all day or they overcooked it. The plantain chips however were nice. Light golden color and crispy. The flattened bread was unique. I kinda wish it was toasted a little bit longer just it would be a bit toastier and easier for the butter to melt.For our main course, we kept it simple. We ordered the paella once we sat down because it takes up to an hour to cook. It well worth the wait. I've had my fair share of paella in my life and this would easily rank somewhere in my top 3. It's $51.99 to start with, so that kinda threw me off guard because according to their website menu, it's listed at $41.99. So expect $10 dollars more. They should consider updating their website and menu prices. But the paella, it was unbelievably good. It had seafood, chorizo, and chicken. They weren't stingy with the ingredients either. There was plenty of scallops, lobster, and shrimps. It was served nice and hot, straight out of the pot. It was so good and so hard to believe that this was suppose to be a serving size for two. My son loved it!We enjoyed the evening with sangria and I tried a bottle of their Cuban style ale. The bottle of ale was $7. I asked for something from Cuba, but its produced in USA. I was hoping for a actual Cuban cerveza. The sangria was delightful and refreshing. As far as the service goes, I think it could be better. We went on a weekday, it was really empty compared to the weekends here. Much of staff were chatting in the back or at the bar. We felt a little ignored at times. They didn't serve us the flattened bread until one of the main waiters or host noticed it roughly 15-20 minutes after we sat down. But all of the waiters were friendly. I would certainly love to come back for the paella. The biggest downside to dining at Rincon Criollo, they only accept American Express! For me, that's just a huge blow. Master/Visa is pretty much standard everywhere else and this spot is acting like the old Costco with their AMEX only policy. I mean even Costco now is accepting Master, Visa. For reward purposes, I really dislike the fact that they don't accept any other card except for AMEX. So either be prepared to bring cash or use their ATM.

I am refreshing a previous review of many years ago.What can I say about RC? The best Cuban food in NYC. I have been coming with my family and friends since the 70s.  The owners René & Baldo Acosta had a popular restaurante in Cuba. They opened this version of Rincón Criollo in the 70s in Corona, Queens.It's a family run business. Their nephews & niece took over the business and opened a second restaurant in Long Island.René Acosta died recently, it saddened me very much. He will be missed. RIP.The Ropa Vieja, Paella, Chicken & Rice, Frijoles Negros, Moros, Vaca Frita y Bistec Empanizado are the best. Cubano & Croquetas, Mariquitas, Tamales, Frituras de Bacalao.  The list goes on and on.Every day they have a special dish. Today was Rabo Encendido, a very popular dish.Their desserts are also very good. They used to make a Bread Pudding out of this world. Now Flan, Rice Pudding, Cascos de Guayaba, Dulce de Leche, Buñuelos are all good.They serve wine and beers.Ah! To top the meal Cuban Coffee, Cortadito o Café con Leche.And you will be coming back again and again.

If the menu item says it takes 1 hour to cook. Order it because it is worth the wait. Have a sangria or two while you wait and talk to the person/people you are with while waiting for some delicious meal. Enjoy!

We love this place.  First thing is the service which is so friendly and attentive.   I don't know anything about the authenticity of Cuban food as I've only tried it in NYC and Miami Beach but everything we tried here was amazing.   Simple avocado salad,  Vaca frita, oxtail stew,  steaks and all sides were wonderful.   The neighborhood is so much fun in the evening.  Lively and interesting and with the wonderful diversity of Queens.   We've been there several times and recommend it 100%
Best authentic  food in new york. I go to this place all the time. Everyone is amazing and they make you feel like home. Please go there, you wont regret it
I'll make it short and sweet, for truly authentic Cuban cuisine visit this place. It's very casual with  friendly atmosphere, great service, and traditional Cuban music ..

My husband and I were in a pinch for a very late lunch. We were hangry...which is NOT good when you're trying to enjoy a date-day. Rincon Criollo turned our day around! I am Puerto Rican, so Cuban food is right up my alley. My husband can eat rice and beans like they're going out of style. Our meals were wonderful! We had the deep-fried half-chicken (not battered, just deep-fried with the skin on) with a garlic sauce, the roasted pork, yuca, tostones, and rice with black beans. Flavorful, hot, well-cooked, and we didn't have to wait very long at all. Our servers were very friendly and refilled our water every time we needed it. Really, just a fantastic experience. THE ONLY BAD thing was the birthday singing...I know that sounds horrible, but for people's birthdays they play this horribly loud (like deafening) set of birthday songs. We had to cover our ears and stop eating for the entire 2 songs. This happened 3 times! We had to stop eating, chatting, everything...just to save ourselves from hearing loss. But, other than that...a fantastic meal.

Absolutely love this Cuban restaurant. Have been here several times and every time I want to try something different. Everything on the menu is delicious.  My favorites are the breaded chicken, breaded palomilla steak, oxtail, ropa vieja, paella..   etc.  You get 2 sides with your entree and it's a must for me to get the rice & beans! Also love the sweet plantains and tostones.  For dessert, get the flan and/or leches cake! So delicious.

BEST TRES LECHE CAKE / CAKE in the world! Read no further, just come and order a whole cake and that's all you need. But if you need to eat, you can eat their delicious food as well.I came here for a dinner after hearing about this place for so long and it was too long overdue. I should've came years ago, I had the oxtail and my lady had the ropa viejo(shredded beef). We ordered the tostones, maduras, rice&beans, and the famous yucca. Everything tasted darn near perfect, although I did expect bigger portions cause I was able to finish everything.... Regardless my oxtail was fall off the bone tender and flavorful. Also I love fried plaintains and they do it right here, not greasy at all with the perfect amount of crunch. But back to the main point, TRES LECHE CAKE. This is the only restaurant in my whole life I ordered extra cake to take home. *The flan was pretty bomb too!
lovely atmosphere! extremely friendly staff and the best Cuban food I've ever tasted!

This place was so good! My sister found it. I didn't know what to expect, but I love Cuban food.I ordered the grilled chicken, salad and plantains. Everything was amazing! I would definitely go back and order this again.The ambiance was nice and had a great Cuban decor. If it's your birthday they'll turn the disco ball on for you! I'd come back here for sure!

Went here for dinner with my mom on a Sunday; it was very busy with a lot of hungry folks being fed.  The ambience was festive, with the walls adorned with pictures of Cuba interposed with autographed images of famous patrons.  We ordered the chorizo espanol and tamal cubano for appetizers.  The former was excellent but a tad salty.  The tamal was tasty as well.  The main course was arroz con mariscos, which took an hour to prepare and was probably filling enough to feed four.  It was extraordinarily good, as the seafood was varied and fresh.  Attentive and friendly service as well (although it took several tries to get more bread due to the busyness).
I went there for date night and was completely blown away by the amazing food and service.  Everything was perfect and I'm looking forward to coming back very soon.

My family and I love coming here on special occasions.  The Cuban cuisine is authentic and delicious.  It's very popular and can be crowded at times so we try to plan our visit.  I have also tried their Huntington location as well.

Wow! Amazing! Ever since I came back from Miami I've been wanting some great Cuban Food. I haven't ventured out much for Cuban places around the city. However this is my favorite so far.The food is simply amazing. My favorite go to dish would have to be the 1/2 Fried Chicken with Garlic Sauce. The rice and beans with bacon, and Maduros is amazing! Oh yeah and you can't forget the Tres Leches. Also be sure to get the Lemonade it's made fresh.I'm going to explore more menu items, however this place is hands down simply amazing. It's simple food done right! I was very impressed with the quality and the freshness of the food.

If you want authentic and delicious Cuban food, come here! My family and I have been coming here for over 15 years now and they never fail to satisfy our foodie needs. My go to meal is fried pork chunks, white rice, black beans and friend sweet plantains - always delicious. Their staff are very attentive, friendly and welcoming. They also have another in restaurant in Huntington, NY, which is equally amazing.

There is a reason that this place looks like nothing special from the outside (as people say, you can easily miss it) but it has been around since 1976 and is still packed all the time.  It is simply one of the best Cuban restaurants you will ever find.  Period.  And if you factor in how reasonable the prices are, then forget it: there is not a Cuban restaurant on the planet that can compare.  None of this is exaggeration.  To begin with, everything we had was exquisite.  We had 3 appetizers (chorizo, croquetas, and tortilla española) and three entrees (ropa vieja, rabo encendido, and lechon) and a bottle of wine, and the check came to only $90.  $90.  For 6 dishes and a bottle of wine.  I was shocked.  I'm still shocked now.  The service was excellent, too.  The staff makes sure to take care of all of the tables, not just the tables in their section.  Everyone was very attentive, and super friendly and cheerful.  There are people who say that Rincon Criollo isn't what it used to be, that it isn't all that great anymore, and that this or that new Cuban place is better.  These people are all high on drugs, or they work for the other restaurant they are recommending.

This is one of our go to places on Long Island for Caribean style dishes. Our family enjoys eating out and this is always top of mind if we're not in the mood to try something new. The staff is friendly and the food is delicious.

I've had better, granted it was in Miami, so maybe its not fair to compare, but oh well. Came here with a decent sized group and pretty much ordered the entire menu. Had the ox tail, the breaded pork chop, rolled steak, fried pork chunk, ropa, fish, mixed paella, arroz compollo ( which is just a paella without the seafood ). The food was just okay here, there was no flavor in anything I ate, it was as if they just pretty much pan fried all the items here and just sprinkled a little bit of salt and presented all the dishes that way, where was the decadent beef taste that usually comes with ox tail? where was the strong hit of garlic that comes with fried pork chunk? the great flavor of stock and umami that comes with a great Paella? all in all although the items tasted ok at best all the items were incredible boring and bland. Spice it up rincon, its no comparison to the real thing

I had heard good things about this place and decided to try it for myself.  I had codfish fritters (appetizer), ropa vieja with rice and beans (entree), and natiila (a Cuban pudding) for desert, all of which were readonably priced. The food was great.  The servers were prompt and attentive, without making me feel rushed.

Will NOT go back.  Horrible experience! Just walked out !!!!!! Ordered food, than music starts LOUD is not the words to describe the music ! Couldn't get out of restaurant fast enough.  Ear shatteringly loud!!! Multiple waiters watched as we started to leave visibly upset, no one said or did anything.   Will NEVER go back.  Shame I used to really enjoy the place.

We (2 adults 3 kids) waited over 1 hour and 15 minutes for our food today. Had a terrible experience because of this. Other tables sat down, ordered, paid, and left while we still waited.And it's not like we ordered a paella or anything - we got the ropa vieja, fried pork chops, and breaded chicken. We checked in on the food after 30 minutes already and were told just a few more minutes. Eventually same story just a few more minutes. Finally I grabbed somebody else - manager/owner maybe. I tell him that we've been sitting here for an hour and 15. He asked what we ordered, went to the kitchen, and food came out 5 minutes later. Unfortunately we waited too late for my niece, fell asleep at the table with food in her mouth. At least all the food was good... I guess. Can't tell when you're that upset and hungry.

First time ever in the Queens location and we did take-out, which is usually a big no-no when it comes to vaca frita. We were proven wrong! The serving size was good, and the vaca frita was to die for. One of the best we've had in quite a while, this was recommended by a family member close by and told us to try any sides that had yuca- thank you! Both yuca frita and yuca con mojo were up there. And obvio. maduros, always get a side of maduros.

Didn't have Cuban in awhile so stopped by with my bro and cousin to get some meat dishes.The ox tails were pretty damn good, I snarfed those down along with the garlic chicken real quick.For sides I recommend the sweet plantains and rice w black beans to compliment the salty meats.Would definitely go for sure if the traffic and parking isnt bad. 7-8pm

Can I get a *whoopwhoop* for this place? What a cozy and inviting restaurant. Came here a few months ago for a small birthday celebration and truly enjoyed it. As other reviews mentioned, the wait is looong if you come anytime between 6-8:30pm. We came on a Friday night at 6:45 and waited about 45 min to be seated. This speaks to how popular this place is. Service is very friendly and go out of their way to accommodate. Also as we discovered, this is a popular place to come celebrate your birthday. Throughout the evening the severs performed a birthday song for just about every table in the restaurant. Straight to ordering: - Chorizo Espanol ($6.95): good way to start a meal for a male birthday. With meat. - Picadillo ($11.95): chopped meat w/onions and peppers. This was probably my favorite meat entree that we tried. Those grilled onions just added an extra oomph. - Ropa Vieja ($15.95): shredded beef in tomato sauce, thought this was a bit salty but flavor was good and beef was tender. - Rabo Encendido ($15.95): oxtail served in a stew-like sauce. Tender chunks of meat. This was delish too. - Bistec Enrollado ($15.95): rolled steak aka. steak cooked in a roll. This was ok.Two sides came with each entree, we ended up with a combination of: - Moros y Cristianos: rice and beans--omg...I have never had such addicting rice and beans in my life! I never even knew rice and beans could be addicting! Perhaps there were bits of pork fat cooked with it...whatever it was, I couldn't stop eating  them. - Plantanos Maduro Frito: fried sweet plaintains, oldie but a goodie, tho generally pretty heavy and you can't eat too many of them.- Plantano Verde Frito: fried green plaintains, also good.- Yuca con Mojo: cassava stewed with garlic sauce (butter)....yumm again. - Papas Fritas: French fries, not worth ordering here. I must pause here to mention the generous serving sizes of the entree and side dishes. You will not be left hungry. To top it off, somehow we managed to eat a a flan and the bunuelos Rincon Criollo (donuts soaked in syrup) between the four of us. Would recommend the flan, it had a good home-made consistency. Mmmm...rice and beans. I would come back for another plate of these any day (after a week-long workout). Not to mention to try some additional entrees. And certainly you can't beat these prices.
Yo the oxtail was bomb dignity bomb. I love me some good oxtail. I don't know what else to say but yelp wants to elaborate but I'll just repeat myself instead. I really like the oxtail. Ok bye.

Perfect, perfect, PERFECT example of TRUE Cuban cuisine. In NY, every restaurant touts anthem but really justa fusion or deviant of the of the culture. Not this place!....Authentic Cuban memorabilia all over and quality authentic menu. The place is busy, so don't expect super fast service, but expect super fast food, fresh tasting. We had The Boliche with came with red beans and white rice--with the Cuban Tamale, the ham croquetas, and an order of chorizo. We ordered a sangria, an hatuey (authentic Cuban beer) and had cortaditos for desert!Yum!!!!!!!

I love this place! I'm so sad that I grew up in Queens all my life and have never heard of or been to this place until now. It's such a great restaurant, food and service is fantastic. Parking is horrendous though, as it is only street parking. Can't wait to come back here again. And definitely celebrate a birthday here, it'll be the best surprise for them and you! Lol P.S. They accept only cash or Amex for payment!

This review is based solely upon my brief visits when I come in to have afternoon espresso.Upon entering, you are greeted with old world charm and decor. The restaurant is set up with Cuban decor circa 20th century. There is a small bar at the front which is where I exclusively set. The staff is very friendly and polite and attentive to my needs. The espresso is made with precision and care. Definitely one of the best espresso's in the area. It is strong and flavorful and meets the quality standards of a much more refined restaurant. The sugar floats on top of the coffee for a brief second prior to submerging itself. This is the sign of excellent espresso. In addition they serve the espresso with lime instead of lemon rind. A delightful surprise

Made a visit to this restaurant after visiting the science center. From entering it was very warm and inviting. We were immediately attended to. Our party included 2 small children and a baby with a stroller. They didn't even flinch, and sat and served us right away. The waiter helped us find our favorite Cuban dishes and gave recommendations. Food came out timely, was hot and delicious. The entire staff was attentive, restaurant was clean and we couldn't have asked for a better Sunday evening dinner. ¡Bien Hecho!

The vibe at Rincon is completelyContagious, lively with plenty of laughs to go around. This is the type of atmosphere you can only get at a family run neighborhood staple. Oh and the food is kind of amazing, all of it. Rincon Criollo can best be described like a mozzarella filled meatball: Straight forward and completely unassuming on the outside, soul satisfying surprise on the inside. Ironically, this analogy also can be used to describe the rolled steak(some things cannot be described, just order this!) If this is your first time eating Cuban, you're about to become a convert...

The wait is worth it but plan ahead! Go early!! They don't take reservations. Don't be like me and go on a rainy night because the place gets so packed you'll have to wait by the door and the lines go past that. The breakdown:Place - small, old school feel restaurant and you'll easily feel cramped because they pack the place up like sardines. Good luck with parking around here, it's horrendous. You're better off taking the train and walking less than 2min or take a car service. They do a relatively good job keeping the place clean. Service - average. They get bombarded so it's understandable. Drink - materva yerba mate soda! It tastes like a inka kola to me.Food - great quality food! I ordered the ropaVieja? Shredded pork and it was slamming. Keep in mind with your entree you get 2 side orders - I got the staple of rice & beans (Moro rice) and an order of the yuca which came out perfectly soft. Everyone that came out to eat enjoyed their meals. I'd definitely recommend checking this place out. Be back soon !
A very nice, friendly quiet establishment with attentive service and reasonably price food.

Breaded pork filet is for two, but leave room for dessert, the tres leches is amazing! With a Cuban Coffee (basically Cappuccino), you leave ready for anything! It is a truly Cuban establishment,  black beans, and white rice are what they do, enough said...

I've been on a tear of sorts for the last several months of dining at privately-owned Latin-cuisine restaurants & this is the only one-privately owned & chain-where the whole wait staff-all-male-paid attention to me simultaneously. The Ropa Vieja, which I was requested to purchase white rice & black beans separately, was everything that I'd expect. There was no long wait for my order. I was offered dessert also.      This restaurant only accepts American Express & cash.       I come to Jackson Heights at least monthly & I shall return.

This place has been there for years and I decided to finally go there to give it a try. They serve you fresh bread. I've ordered the lemonade and it's so good. The food overall is delicious and fresh. Definitely worth going!

I just can't believe how much this place change the food doesn't taste the same anymore the waiter didn't bring our right order the fish was nasty the rice was hard waste of our anniversary dinner we was very disappointed never again..

Yum! My coworker told me that there is a scarcity of good Cuban food in Queens. She's from Florida, so she knows. So we met a co worker and her hubby here to try good Cuban food, for a weekend lunch.We ordered 2 apps, and 4 entrees (includes 8 sides- 2 sides per entrée), to share family-style. We devoured thinly sliced chorizos, Cuban tamal, ropa vieja (shredded beef in tomato sauce), oxtails, roast pork, and liver with peppers. We wolfed down black beans, fried sweet plantains, fried potatoes, yuca with garlic sauce and fried plantains. After all that, we still had leftovers. K had a refreshingly cold passion fruit drink. My favorites: If you love garlic, you have to get the yucca with garlic sauce. Soft, starchy cassava boiled to a soft sweet-potato-consistency with this sweet savory garlic sauce. So good! I've never had yucca like that before! The shredded beef with tomato sauce was so good! Tender fall-apart-under-your-fork juicy beef in a sweet homemade red sauce. Yum! Everyone loved this dish.The oxtails was wonderful! Stewed soft cartilaginous oxtail in an tomato-spiced stew. I wish I had ordered two of these. The roasted pork looked dry but wasn't. It was tender and the pork juices in the sauce was excellent! Drool worthy savory pork sauce. My co worker loved the sauce more than the meat.Verdict: Definitely coming back to try more dishes! Everyone loved the food. I want to eat that beautiful breaded steak! And more oxtail please! Transport: This lovely Cuban restaurant in Corona, Queens is easily accessible via the 7 train or by car.

We stumbled upon this restaurant on a rainy Monday night and we will be back. Not only is the food fantastic but the people who work there are kind and attentive. The maduros were perfection and the oxtail was wonderful. My husband had the breaded shrimp....the best.

This is in a more residential area so parking was super hard to find. My husband and I probably circled 20 times around the restaurant before we found a spot. But anyways, we came here on a Friday and the wait wasn't too bad. I loved how they would blast the Happy Birthday song and wear a funny hat and glasses and dance around when it was someone's birthday. Created really good vibes.Now onto the food. It was AMAZING. Super tasty! We ordered the oxtail and shredded steak. Their entrees come with two sides each. The rice and beans are marinated with bacon which made it even better. I can't even begin to explain just how flavorful everything was, it's a definite must try.However the guava and cream cheese was a bit overwhelmingly sweet. But yes 5 stars.
This is the first restaurant I tried in this area. My friend ordered fish and I ordered liver. The food is good, but we don't feel anything special.

Omgosh!!Best cuban restaurant ever!Loved the customer service and the food was delicious, i wasn't too crazy about the appetizers but the meals were sooo good!!My phone died and couldn't take photos of it!I had the sangria and didn't like it because it felt like a water down red wine..The beer "presidente" was so good!Loved how pleasant the staff was and cannot wait to go back again

Just ordered the oxtail stew and tres leches cake based off of past reviews and common interest for these tender foods and it was absolutely delicious! Will definitely be ordering again or dropping by for dinner soon.

A little taste and feel of Cuba. This is a cute place and not pricey at all. It gives you a taster you can't forget about. I had the ropa vieja with white rice and black beans there was also some ham Crocketts delicious!!!! The staff is also very attentive and always asking if everything is okay. This place does get packed and the decor is of old little Cuba this place been here for years.  So my friends what I always say. Keep it tasty my friends and enjoy. Let me know what you think.

This is my second time at Rincon Criollo and I have no clue why I'm reviewing this spot now. The food was amazing then, and it's even more amazing the second time around! The Lechón asado is to die for! It's juicy, flavorful and trust me, you will want another plate! The Ropa Vieja is incredible; perfectly seasoned and not greasy. Please have it with the Moros and Christianos (Black beans and rice). I haven't been to Cuba yet but I have been to Miami and this rice beats any M&C that I've had there by a landslide. In addition, they offer Cuban beer! My favorite is their sangria though. If you're in the Corona/Jackson Heights area, look no further for an amazing meal. It's a quaint spot and everyone is very accommodating. You will not be disappointed!

First time Cuban food totally authentic old world restaurant in Corona. Street parking, had a 30 minute wait on a Saturday night Not bad at all.Had Cuban cerveza (beer) Hatuey, it's a heavy Ale that's not to my taste.Great service and the locals all friendly and having a good time, family oriented.The Smoked Pork Chops were great also Ropa Vieja shredded flank stake in sause also very good but personally not a fan of peppers. Rice and beans cooked together very good also fried sweet plantains.Almost forgot the Yuca boiled in garlic sauceVery nice. Fried dough for desertWill be returning want to taste other dishes

Long overdue review of this lovely spot. My family loves this place. We have also been to the long Island location as well after a baptism and it was also amazing. The food is the best Cuban you can find in NY and the service is always on point. My twin sister has 4 kids so when we go in at times it becomes a little hectic but they always make us feel welcomed and accommodate. I always bring people visiting me or foodies like myself here and it never fails. Their chiccharron de Pollo  so good with the yucca and garlic. The espresso is a must after the meal.
Everytime I order delivery, it's spot on. I usually get the oxtail stew and plantains but the sandwiches are always top notch as well. Every single time. And it is never late, neither.
Sabor cubano never tasted so good. My favorite is rolled chicken in garlic sauce...yummy! The old decor gives it a homie ambiance. Highly recommend it!

Small restaurant with old school interior decor. Pictures of Cuba and clients in the past that ate there. Light Cuban music on the background, Cuban clients and employees talking really makes the place feel authentic. Very charming. Now the food is okay. I need to come back and give it another try. I had the Pollo empanizado con arroz blanco habichuelas negras, tostones, y aguacate. The breaded chicken could've had some Spanish seasoning because it lacked flavor; it was literally breaded chicken. The beans were okay too. I'll get a Cuban dish next time for sure! Tip: Get here early! I don't like crowds (this place is small) so I went an hour after opening hours and it was slowly getting full. Another tip make sure your utensils are clean because mine were dirty and my dates' as well. It's a Small business with great clientele flow is why I would give another try and staff were funny and attentive. It's history and ambience was what really won me over.

I wanted to visit this restaurant for my birthday . I can say that the ambience is great ,the music is pleasant , the staff is polite and overall my visit went great . Now I want to tell you about specifics: The breaded pork was amazing , thin and not too oily . The yuca con mojo was just there not bad but not super ( it was kind of cold and the yucas were so tiny) The tostones were great , as well as the maduros. The beans tasted good , they had potatoes in them which I never seen before but surprisingly the combination  was tasty   . Now I went there because I wanted to try their Ropa Vieja which could have been better  , it was drenched with oil . The moro con cristianos rice was the loser of the night , it lacked Caribbean  sazón. I asked for salad and the waiter brought me plain avocado   I will say he got confused and I decided that it was ok since I love  aguacates. The dessert a flan was delicious and red wine warmed my tummy . I will definitively visit this place again.
About one of the last places in Queens to get an authentic Cuban sandwich. If you are sitting down to eat I recommend ropa viej, 4 people or more the pallea. Parking is limited.

It was pretty good. Food was fresh, but nothing to write home about. Portion were - non-latino portions (small portions) for the stewed/simmered dishes at least. Prices slightly too high. Maybe a little overrated.

Had seen this restaurant on diners, drive-ins and drives a couple of years ago and had bookmarked it in yelp. We to this place when I happened to be in the area. We reached there just 30-35 minutes before their closing time. Their service was very good.  My wife ordered crispy fried chicken and I got shrimp in Spanish sauce. Fried chicken was delicious, shrimp was ok. The side of fried plantains was amazing.

"Where the hell did they take me?" I thought about my girlfriends as I squeezed into my seat.  Tightly crammed tables fill this restaurant where English is hardly spoken and only American Express is accepted (besides cash).  A hole in the wall indeed.  But WHAT a treat!  Admittedly, my fluently speaking Spanish friends ordered for me.  But don't let that intimidate you.  The waitstaff is friendly and informed, and make you feel just like the food does - at home.  Ropa vieja, tostones, sweet plantains, rice and beans, stuffed yuca, shrimp scampi, rolled chicken stuffed with cheese and ham - all cooked perfectly, priced perfectly, and portioned perfectly for sharing and experimenting.  Flan and cappuccino for dessert.  And ohhhhh the sangria!  White or red - take your pick!Go here not just for lunch, but for a feeling of a country!

My party of 15 invaded the place for a not-so-small reunion during dinner on a weekday. It is a small homely spot and super lively. We are here for the infamous paella and we got not one but two! In order to enjoy the paella, you will need to call ahead of time on the same day.We started with red wine sangria - refreshing, fruity, and the best drink to accompany any Spanish meal. Let's keep that pouring! Various of sides started to pour in such as their sweet plantains, tostones, and rice and beans. Tostones was my absolute favorite side of the evening. They were so smash into big pieces and the texture was just the perfect crunchy and soft in the middle.  My companion and I shared the Oxtail dish together. The oxtail meat was so tender and falls off the bones effortlessly. The sauce is tomato based and filled with various spices. Since it was a big dish, I saved a big piece to go with white rice the next day. Seafood and Meat Paella made a grand entrance to our table. The pot was a lot bigger than what I imagined, not to mention how deep the pot is. After our server lifted the lid, the smell of seafood and saffron hit my nose leading to my mouth watering. (I hope no one saw that!) I see lobster, clams, mussels, shrimp, scallop, and chicken, all in there! Flavors of the paella was amazing! I did wish that the texture of the rice was mushy like it was but other than that, it was muy bien (very good)!To my surprise, this spot is a great host for dinner parties for it has a very lively atmosphere. If you have a birthday boy/girl, a staff member will wear a funny hat and glasses dancing to loud, exciting music while bringing a plate of dessert to them! It was very entertaining and I already figured out who I want to surprise! So watch out!

A staple in Corona and in the Cuban community, but I didn't actually come to eat here until I was looking for some of the best Cuban food in NYC. I ordered the Ropa Vieja con Moros y Cristianos y un orden de Platanos Maduros Frito. If heaven had a taste, it was in my mouth. The Ropa Vieja alone was so flavorful and so tender and so juicy. It was only further accentuated by the taste of the rice and beans. 12/10 would hiiiiiiiiiighly recommend!

You will not be disappointed. If you don't mind the parking issue, or don't mind taking the train, this place is a great little gem.The restaurant is kind of small but very cozy. It's a good place to come with friends and family. If it's your birthday, it's even better. I came here with my BF for dinner and we were able to experience how they celebrate birthdays (it was another customer's birthday). They turn the lights off, there is a disco ball on, lots of joy and singing and all the other customers are clapping as well! The food here is also really good. I had to ropa vieja. The entrees come with 2 sides. So I ordered the rice and beans, and the boiled yuca in garlic sauce. Although the yuca was a bit dry, the sauce made it tasty. The rice and beans, you can never go wrong with rice and beans. The ropa vieja was tender and full of flavor. The dish looks small but it was enough to fill me and my bf's stomachMy boyfriend ordered the oxtail and he enjoyed it! He said it was very tender and falls right off the bone. He ordered tostones and Maduras as his sides. The tostones were one of the best I've had. The maduras was sweet and tasted like a dessert.For dessert, we had tres leches cake and flan. My bf isn't a fan of flan but he really enjoyed it here! I love flan and this really was THAT good. Their tres leches cake mmmmm you cannot miss out. Their desserts were so good, we ended up ordering another order of the desserts separately!To top it off, the servers here are all polite and nice.
The food is good here and the staff is very friendly, give the place a try and you won't regret it.  Enjoy!

Best Cuban food u can get outside of Cuban Florida. Ive been goin to this spot since i was 10 years old and still take the drive to go there now being 35 years old. Place is tiny. Looks like a hole in the wall because of the location and the neighborhood u have to drive thru but the food is by far the best. Highly recommend. They have a much nicer and bigger location in Huntington which is where we go now. Far drive but worth it if u want a more exclusive scenery.

Such a small, cozy place which reminds me of coming home to visit relatives. When you come here, you're treated like family right when you step foot. I've been here several times and the food doesnt disappoint. Coming from somewhat critical Cuban in-laws (which I hope they dont see this..haha) they swear by this place. It reminds them of home which is why they keep coming back here. The menu is very authentic and contains a lot of amazing dishes. That cuban rice and that yucca frita!  Geez..Im getting hungry thinking about my meal here over the weekend. This area is very congested and there's so many food choices here but this is a definite must try!

This is excellent Cuban food...we walked over here from a house we were staying at and found everything about this place to be top notch...it's not in the best neighborhood area but you need to look past that because once inside forget about this place is the real deal. One heads up though if you want the signature Paella I would call ahead of time because this rookie didn't and we had to wait for an hour but lesson learned that just gave us some time to hang out and drink some wine and try out some of the other things on the menu...First off the plantain chips with garlic sauce....my kids loved these and even the garlic sauce with a little kick was a huge hit. They were sooooo good! Next sweet and green plantains hard to choose but both were again delicious...on to some more wine and some more of the bread as well they bring out. Need to throw in all of the servers here are awesome and walk around checking on people...one of the waiters even walked over to a table with a fussy baby and asked the mom if he could walk the baby around so she and her husband could eat their dinner...you don't see this kind of service. I asked him he knew  them and he no just want her to enjoy her food as he is showing us the cute little baby. Now after the anticipated wait out comes this huge steam pot of Paella and you can smell all of the deliciousness coming out with all the fresh seafood...time to dive in and watch out this has been cooking for an hour it is very hot, but OMG so delicious. The amount of seafood that is packed here is impressive with fish, shrimp, scallops, clams and crab...hands down one of the best dishes I have ever had. My girls ordered their grilled  chicken and stopped eating theirs just to help polish off all of this Paella it was that good. If in this area don't miss the opportunity to eat at this special spot....

I've eaten here plenty of times out of convenience - it's a solid Cuban restaurant that can be your daily go-to when you want to do takeout or delivery.  I think certain dishes like their ropa vieja are great but for the most part anything breaded and fried, or their fish, is really on par with most Cuban places.  Furthermore, Cuban food is largely peasant food so there's no reason why a dish should approach or exceed $20.  You can go to Jersey City Heights or Unión City or West New York and get good Cuban food at half the price.Aside from the food, which is what matters most, Junction Blvd isn't exactly a locale worth a stroll following dinner, the restaurant is small and cramped and the Birthday celebrations are super corny.All that said, I wish the restaurant well.  It's a staple in the area and the people who work there are first class.  But this place is overrated these days.

We came here on a Friday night around 8PM.Ambiance - great music. The tables are pretty close and the place is pretty small.The servers were very friendly and if you never had or are new to Cuban food they will explain in detail (which we really didn't need.)  We had the maduros, pollo asado, moro rice, rice and beans, ropa vieja. The Pollo Asado and Ropa Vieja were both in the salty end. The Ropa Veija was cooked to perfection and melted in your mouth, it was just too salty. We also had the tres leches and I was not really impressed. For $5 for a slice, I could barely even split it with my friend.  We also ordered "sangria." Do NOT get sangria here. The server went behind the bar got a slice of orange and cherry garnish and put it in the bottom of the glass and poured wine on top. That is not sangria my friend.In sum, whoever cooked on Friday night was very heavy handed on the adobo. The portions were on the smaller side for the prices we paid approx. $16 for ropa vieja. I was not impressed and I honestly do not think it was worth it for the price we paid.**Also, they only accept AMEX  but there is a Bank of America across the street, a Chase bank down the block or you can pay a fee and use the ATM machine in the restaurant.

Everything was excellent. Service was friendly and you can tell they are proud of their restaurant. My husband had the flank steak (marinated with lime) and I had the chicken (similar, but way better than cordon bleu). Sweet plantains were so good! Can't wait to be back for a visit just to eat here again.

I was looking for some colouring pencils for my little nephew. I came upon this place and was very disappointed that they didn't sell any. I mean. with a name like "Rincon Crayola" you would think they would have f***ing Crayola pens wouldn't you???????? I mean srsly???!!???!?!!!!111 So I am giving them a 1 star rating.Just kidding.What to get: Ropa ViejaWhat not to get: Coconut FlanWhat else: Don't ask for ice in your drink. They have a "Cube-ban" in effect.So I wanted some donuts. I came here and they had none. So why the hell are they named Rincon Cruler?I've been to Rincon Criollo twice and both times I had the Ropa Vieja. It is by far, easily, hands down the best Cuban food I've had anywhere in NYC. While it is very heavy and greasy, it is also absolutely delicious, and all fans of Latin food should try it. I've also had the Coconut Flan on one occasion, and I was not impressed. It was ultra-sweet to the level of sickliness, so I couldn't finish it.I came here for some healthy suplements. They had none. So why the hell are they called Rincon Krill Oil?Of course this place has been featured on TV, so you probably know about it already. Unlike many of the Food Network's pay-for-play choices, this one is "the real deal" as they'd say in their clichéd way. It tastes as good as it's supposed to. In fact, it tastes better.So I came here for some New Orleans Cajun food. I asked for Gumbo, Crawfish and a Po Boy. They had *none* of them. So why the hell are they named Rincon Creole?The only better Cuban meal I've had in the country, other than one in New Jersey which rivals Rincon, is Luis Galindo II's Vaca Frita in Miami, near the airport. Also Paseo's sandwiches are right up there, as are El Cubanito's in Chicago. Nevertheless, you won't get a better Ropa Vieja than this.I came here looking for Melissa Joan Hart. She was not here. So why the f*** are they named "Rincon Clarissa-Explains-It-All?"The meat is so tender and stringy and juicy and perfectly spiced and flavoured. Soaked for days, it seems like. The heavy, greasy dark brown rice is exceptionally tasty, especially if you ask them to pour some marinade/juice from the meat all over the rice. And the plantains that come with the dish are fried to perfection, very sweet but very delicious and satisfying. They basically taste like soft, mushy, sweet bananas. So tropical and so indescribably delicious.Get down to Rincon Criollo at your earliest convenience. I love it so much, that I would have written this review in Rincon Crayola if I had to.And I brought a girl here who was really into me. We couldn't wait for the hotel room so we went straight in the RC bathroom. After what happened in there, I think I'm going to rename the place "Rincon Creamalloverme."

I don't think Rincon Criollo is the type of restaurant you eat at all the time just because of the huge variety of cuisine in the neighborhood; but every time you do end up eating here, you ask yourself -"why don't I come here more often?". From the start, the ambiance they provide you with from the low salsa playing in the background to all the photographs of past patrons on the walls, to the way their waitstaff stands around at your order makes you feel like you're dining in a different era. The servers are attentive and as hospitable as it gets; very friendly, very inviting, and most importantly very honest. The menu is big enough to have something for everyone, but it doesn't lose focus or sabotage itself with irrelevant "universal" items like a burger for example that would only subtract from its Cuban identity. This is GOOD FOOD. The ropa vieja is probably what they're most known for, and yes it is as delicious as you've heard. On my last visit I ordered the half roasted chicken and man I left those bones clean. The meat just fell right off, no need for a knife. When cleaning the table our server joked saying "so you liked the chicken huh?". There is nothing in this restaurant that lacks flavor. The food tells a story.I've lived in Corona & Elmhurst all my life, and in many of the other hispanic/latino restaurants around here - sides like rice and beans, tostones or fried plantains are often bland or overcooked; just barely "meh". They don't get shown the love they deserve....but here, the sides share the spotlight. Everything is served on individual separate plates, which aside from giving you that classic feeling; allows you to appreciate each component on its own. You want to take a little bite of this, a spoon of that, a little scoop of this, another bite of that. A good meal is all about different textures, flavors, and the way they compliment each other; they nail that perfectly. Pricing is adequate and you'll never feel robbed. It's a casual enough place to dress however you want, and at the same time I can picture a dressed up date night situation as well. There is no pretentiousness at all. No matter what the occasion, the vibes are always right. Highly recommended, and a definite a top choice.

The ratings don't lie. Decor feels like a diner. Prices are good. Portions are good. Ropa vieja was great although a little on the salty side. Yucca melts in your mouth. Plaintain was perfectly ripe...nice n  sweet.

Excellent Cuban food. Chicken and Sausage Paella is a must try. The Paella advertises for 2 people but it serves 4 people!!! Ox tail stew is also very good. Great service on the staff side. Would come back again.

I truly love this place. My boyfriend's family has been coming here for years and I discovered it through them. We love it so much it keeps being a birthday spot for us year after year (not very true, we come on random occasions too). It's always great food that reminds you of home. The portions are always big so at times I may split a meal with someone and it's plenty to fill both people. The service is always pleasant and fun. If you go on a Friday, Saturday or even Sunday be prepared to wait for a table because they are always packed hence, go on a weekday! My fav dishes: ropa vieja, vaca frita, rabo (oxtail), rincón bistec (med rare if not they'll cook it well) not so fav: the fillet in garlic sauce has been the only thing that I wasn't a fan of because I thought it was just too greasy. I've never tried the Cuban sandwich but that's on my bucket list at Rincon. Great place !

if i could i would give them a zero!! i placed an order for delivery at 9:11 pm with an eta of my food being delivered at 10pm...i called the restaurant a little past 10 pm to see what's going on they tell me that the delivery person picked up my order.  now at 10:30 pm grubhub now sends me a text saying my order was canceled!! why wait an hour to cancel the order??? if you knew you wouldn't be able to make it just cancel it right away so that i could have other options!!! who runs thus restaurant??? is this the type of service you provide to your customers???

After two other wonderful experiences, I have decided to update this review and give this restaurant five stars.I refer to myself here as "el chino gordo," or "the fat Chinese guy" and they seem to appreciate my attempts at speaking Spanish, even though everyone here speaks almost perfect English.The Paella stole the show. I didn't get a chance to taste it until this time because I never ordered in, but it's amazing! Please do call an hour or two in advance to get it!!Rolled steak is another favorite, along with fried plantains and sweet fried plantains, I'm sold!The prior review still stands, of course.Birthdays are so much fun here! They gave me a flan that was out of this world!!

Definitely making a second trip. We were seated right away on a Saturday afternoon but it filled up pretty quickly. All I can say is everything was absolutely delicious! The food was piping hot when it came out and the bill was very attractive. The stuffed cassava it's stuffed with beef and the oxtail was my favorites. If you like Cuban food you definitely should check this place out.

Based on the positive reviews, we wanted to give RC a try.  We ordered the paella to go, unfortunately, it was watery, salty and tasteless.  Paella is not a Cuban dish, so perhaps they should stick to Cuban dishes.

When I want great Cuban food I drive 40 mins to get here and they never let me down. Food tastes like there's a little, old grandma in the kitchen whipping up authentic dishes. Staff are always attentive, energetic and upbeat. For birthdays, they bring out a coconut flan (which is amazing but not free) and they dance and clap to a happy birthday song blasting through the speakers. It's lots fun! I highly recommend the Chicharron de Pollo (fried chicken) and Ropa Vieja (shredded beef). Place is always busy but usually wait time is not too long.

I'm very disappointed this place only has four and a half stars, it definitely deserves five! It's a small, homey place with delicious food and the service is just as wonderful.
