The staff is very inviting and treat you like a part of the family. Portions are generous and are served tapas style, which allows you to try various items off the menu. I highly recommend stopping by this restaurant and try my personal favorite, ropa vieja.

Watched an episode of "Diners, Drive in's and Dives". Rincon Criollo was featured on the show. I was excited to learn that an authentic Cuban restaurant was located in Queens. I grew up as a young lad in Corona, so we decided to venture out to try this place.The joint is literally a few hundred feet  from the NYC number 7 train station off Roosevelt ave. When we first walked in the servers were polite and seated us quickly. We were also greeted by the chef/owner Rudy who was on the show and was working the floor that night. Unbeknownst  to me as we sat down, a fellow yelper and friend "Long K" recognized me and quickly introduced himself first via an instant message on Yelp. "Long K" was funny as he wanted to put me at ease to not think he was creepy for recognizing me. LOL!My wife thought it was kind of cool to have someone on yelp recognize me. It was nice to finally meet a fellow yelper for the 1st time without going to a Yelp event. I Hope to meet more fellow Yelpers in the future in Elite and UYE events though. Thanks "Long K"! because of you my wife actually thinks I'm sort of like a "Movie Star" minus the good looks and money!We were hungry and I wished I would have read "Long K's" review about calling up to place your order for the Paella since it does take an hour to cook, but we didn't have the time or patience to wait that long for our food. I'll savor the paella for another date. We ordered the Rolled Steak which was a Cuban version of "chicken cordon bleu" minus the chicken and rolled in what appears to be a flank steak pounded thin and stuffed with ham and Swiss cheese and deep fried. The rolled steak was delicious, I mean who doesn't like meat and melted cheese together, right? A huge portion size cut into 3 segments.We also ordered the 1/2 Rincon Crioillo chicken - Garlic chicken deep fried and topped with raw sweet onions coated with garlic. The chicken was moist and delicious and the raw onions coupled  together with the chicken made my mouth and taste buds happy!The sides were amazingly good, we had the beans and rice cooked together, cassava with garlic, sweet plantains and as the owner Rudy calls them "Cuban fries" actually they were regular cut fries that were a little on the soggy side. We were so stuffed we passed on the dessert, but had to have the Cuban coffee, my wife asked Rudy is it really Cuban?? Rudy responded by telling her "As Cuban as it gets". I agree, a Cuban man brewing Cuban Coffee beans is as Cuban as it gets! Veridict! The coffee was strong almost espresso like, but not bitter with a very smooth finish and taste.The staff here is so genuine and kind and you can see the love they have for the customer's and it's sincere and not contrived . This place truly is a Gem in an area heavily populated by latino restaurants. Rincon Criollo as Rudy said earlier to my wife "It's as Cuban as it gets! Que the "Charanga" music!

My girlfriend and I came spontaneously and were happy with our decision. The restaurant has a family vibe to it and the staff was very friendly. We were surprisingly seated immediately. We ordered the pitcher of sangria to start and I must say it was very good. For entrees my girlfriend had the chicharron de pollo and I had the arroz con pollo and for something so simple the food was great. Full of flavor and amazing. The portion wasn't big but the taste made up for it. Afterwards we shared the coconut flan and again so simple but soooo good. We Wil definitely be coming back

While on vacation in New York, we stopped by this place and wasn't disappointed. The food portion was a lot! The wait staff were very friendly. Got there around noon and was seated promptly. A few min later the place filled up quick!I ordered the breaded pork steak with rice and beans and fried plantain. When I received my food, I was overwhelmed lol. Taste and favor was on point and shockingly was able to finish the whole plate. Will have to try the desserts next time. Will definitely come back when I visit New York again.

Really delicious food.  We ordered la vaca frita and masitas and they were both great.  They only accept amex and cash. I am OK with those options since I have an american express, but for others it could be an issue.  Also the prices are slightly greater than other restaurants nearby. The portions for what you pay are not that big. The taste does help with these shortfalls the restaurant has.
Awesome food, staff is always happy and it feels like being at grandma's house when me and my wife are here. Very warm feeling eating here. Love love.
Best Cuban food in NYC and the staff are so friendly. Just don't forget to bring cash! This place has so much history and the food is amazing. I'm so happy to love close by.

PAELLA craving fulfilled. Pro Tip: Call in advance before arriving to the restaurant, the paella takes at least 1 hour to cook! Also pretty interesting to watch how this place does it, videos online from Guy Fieri's Triple D's!Advertised as portions for 2 people, this giant vat of steaming rice, chicken and seafood definitely feeds at least 3-5. A must order if you're coming here. Only complaint was that it may be a bit salty after a while. Vaca Frita was a good dish of shredded beef, which was a bit salty as well, but still delicious protein. We got sides of maduros and fried yuca (not on menu but our server had no issue getting that done for us) which were perfect. The Coconut Flan for dessert fills in the remaining gaps in your stomach and will make you sleep easy at night.Service is super friendly, but can fall off a bit when the place gets busy. You should come here for someone's birthday occasion...just to watch all the lights go down and hilarious celebration with disco lights ensue. They go hard for peoples birthdays here...

Every time I go to visit my grandmother, we stop by this place.  It is the best Cuban restaurant I have ever been to.  The tostones and ropa Vieja are my go to dishes.  It has a classic New York feel to it.  I will keep coming back every year.

Came here on a Saturday night because of the excellent yelp reviews, the restaurant is located in a very busy area in Queens, parking looks like it would be difficult but luckily we found a spot right away on the corner, by the way there are meters which end at 7pm. Okay now on to the food. We ordered our favorite the croquettes, which I always order when going to a Cuban restaurant, and unfortunately I wasn't impressed, I actually didn't enjoy them at all, I've had better at other Cuban restaurants, and for that they lost a star. We did have a appetizer with mixed meet, the pork was delicious, I also enjoyed the sausage, it also comes with ham, cheese, and olives. For dinner we both had the steak with onions, considering that's common Cuban meal, with the congri (rice with black beans) also a Cuban favorite, and it was absolutely Delicious!!!!!! I was in a food coma after finishing my meal. We couldn't leave without some cuban coffee, which was so good & strong, the flan was wayyyyyy too sweet. Service was good, but the food came out VERY fast, almost felt like we were being rushed out, wasn't able to enjoy or finish the appetizers before the entree came out.

Been here a few times and didn't realize I haven't given review. OMG my bad. This place is awesome Cuban food with great service. I always get the breaded chicken with rice and black beans. It is fantastic. They do have other stuff on the menu. While there on this visit, they pulled out 2 paellas. They smelled wonderful. I haven't seen a bad dish on any of my visits. I'm from Atlanta and have had to come to N.Y.3 times in last few months and I don't miss a chance to eat here. I recommend you do the same. You will love this place. Guaranteed.
Incredible meal! The shredded flank steak was incredible and my friends couldn't stop talking about the pork chops being so good! I will be back!

This is a small cozy spot that had some of the best food dood in New york.. It is nothing fancy.. it's simple and good.. And the Food is GREAT... yummy and simply delisioso. Our table had breaded steak, shrimp in Spanish sauce.. the red one..so good,and a yummy fish in garlic sauce..they all were very very good..and the cafe con leche... ahhh coffee so Good.. good good.. the way the crema was on the top .. mmmm just plain good is all i can say

So, I spent 3 years living in NYC. I had yet to find a good Cuban food establishment, considering im from Miami, no other ones really compared. This place though, was on point! authentic, good service and delicious food. Definitely the spot for real cuban food in NYC/Queens.Go check it out!

I went here for lunch and it was great! I got the cubano, paella, ropa vieja, rice and beans, and plantains. The complementary bread is so good. The paella was amazing and worth the wait. I would call ahead if you don't have time to wait an hour for it to cook but it was so good. The menu says it's for 2 people but i think it was good for 4 people, it was a lot. The ropa vieja was smaller in size than I thought, especially for 16.95. The plate was the size about 2 fists. It was good though. The plantains were good too. I would come here again. The service was really nice as well (:

Omggggg where do I even start! My family and me are long time customers of rincón criollo, we just love this cuban restaurant the staff is so friendly and attentive the food is delicious! I'm always happy to come here to eat!  La ropa vieja is our favorite and the pechuga rellena con jamón y queso! And also they have old vintage photos around the restaurant it's so cute, feels antique lol! Great place!! Rincón criollo! You rock!!! :)

Finally got to check this place out tonight! After having it bookmarked for a while now, I could not wait any longer. Brought my mom and hubby here and they also loved it! This place is surely a hidden gem in Corona that's not to be missed out on. So let's start with the vibe of this place. The restaurant is small, but offers a nice homely ambience. Staff is absolutely wonderful and friendly. We came here around 9pm tonight and it was pretty crowded for a Monday night, but things seem to be running smoothly. They gave us some complimentary, delicious, hot bread to start off with. All I can say is, "may I have seconds pls?". After reading many reviews, we decided to opt for their famous Chicarones De Pollo (Fried Chicken Bits) and Vaca Fritta (Shredded Beef with Garlic) with sides of Arroz Blanco (White Rice), Beans, Avocado Salad (that just basically just Avocado) and Plantano Maduro (Fried Sweet Plantains). Here's my opinion on each item: - Chicarones De Pollo: OMG! These little monsters are AMAZING!! Crispy, Juicy, Salty, Garlicky deliciousness that you make you say WOW! About $14 for 5 pieces that are well worth the price. This seriously stole the night for me! That sauce with the onions and rice....ah, now that was a killer! A must order when here! - Vaca Fritta: Being South Asian, we have a very similar version of this type of shredded beef, so I was really looking forward to this dish here. It was deliciously prepared and tasted great, however I thought that it was a bit salty for my taste. If the salt was a bit less, it would have been perfect! - The Sides: $3 for plain Avocado Salad (Plain Avocado that is), I felt it's a bit too much. Arroz Blanco, tasted delicious (white rice cooked in olive oil and salt). Pantano Maduro my mom and husband loved this side dish, I didn't try it because I'm not much into fried plantains. Beans were also good. Overall, all the side dishes were plentiful. Though our food took about 35mins to get served it was worth the wait for the Chicarones De Pollo. I'm really glad that I finally tried this place out! I'm definitely returning back here to try out some of the other delicious items on the menu!Tip: if you don't eat pork, don't order the rice cooked with beans as it has pork in it. Thus, I was unable to try this dish.

I ABSOLUTELY ADORE THIS PLACE! I saw the birthday celebration thingy on some yelp reviews and decided to come here for my friend's birthday. I don't take they take reservations but we were there pretty early so we were able to get seats. I walked in and quietly told the waiter it was my friend's birthday and he was like okay okay and gave me a few winks. We ordered the shrimp in garlic sauce, the stuffed beef, and the oxtail stew. Each dish comes with 2 sides so we got plantains and rice for the most part. Everything was delicious. My personal favorite was the beef. It was fried and was basically layers of beef, cheese, and ham. I usually am not a fan of ham but it tasted really good together. We also ordered a mango juice which was soooo good.For dessert we got tres leche cake and these little donut things I can't remember the name of. I can't have milk but my friends really enjoyed the tres leches cakes. As they were bringing out the cake with a candle, a disco ball came down and a super loud birthday song came on. The waiter did a little dance/performance that was so much fun and we were all cracking up. The entire restaurant was clapping along and saying happy birthday. It was a really nice and friendly atmosphere. My favorite thing about this restaurant though is easily the service. While everything was delicious, the service was just the absolute best. The waiter was so nice and so friendly to us. He had us try to order in spanish which was so cute. I just love this place and I would highly recommend especially if you're celebrating a birthday. It makes for great snaps and videos!

Meh. I came with a group of friend on a friday afternoon for a birthday celebration. It was EXTREMELY hot outside, probably 100 degrees. As soon as I walked in I noticed that there were only ceiling fans... no AC. As time passed by this just bothered us more and more. We couldn't enjoy our food because it was just so hot and we were sweating. The food was OK... The steak and rice were dry. I've had better and cheaper..The way the waiter sang happy birthday to my friend was super cute and enthusiastic. They also didn't charge for the birthday flan which was a nice surprise. Overall good customer service but they need some AC.

Came back to try the paella & my God is it delicious!!! We ordered it about 45 minutes before we got to the restaurant because it does take quite a bit to prepare. We got to the restaurant & we were sat within a couple of minutes. The bartender greeted us immediately & put a Hutuey Cuban beer in each of our hand. The paella was served within 5 minutes of us sitting down at the table & is served literally in a pot; it's a lot of food. This meal can easily serve 4 people, so we brought home a gigantic amount of leftovers!! I absolutely love this gem in Corona!!

My sizzling hot date brought me here after catching the movie Chef together at Regal Cinema and seeing close-up shots of buttery, cheesy Cuban sandwiches that looked more delicious than Sofia Vergara. The movie left us salivating and craving some good Cuban food, so we ended up at Rincon Criollo. We became excited after seeing a photo of Guy Fieri by the entrance. Apparently, this restaurant was featured on his show!  Good sign.I was half asleep (nothing to do with my date) so I ordered an iced coffee, which wasn't exactly my definition of iced coffee, but it was delicious nonetheless. My date ordered a sangria and enjoyed it.  We had oxtail and Ropa Vieja with white rice and beans, Yucca and sweet plantains as sides. We were also offered a complimentary flan which was a great way to end our already satisfying meal.What was more noteworthy is the exceptional service. Waiters were genuinely friendly and had smiles on their faces throughout our dinner. One even put the toilet seat down for me when I had to use the Men's room because the Ladies' room was occupied. What more can you ask for?It ended up pouring after our dinner while my date and I went hunting for his car. However, it was a memorable moment after a memorable dinner ... with someone I can now call my bf

Yes, I am Asian. Yes, I eat a TON of Spanish food. So having lived in a predominantly Spanish neighborhood my whole life and being a foodie, you learn to explore your surroundings. I never really cared where the origin of my food came from, at the end of the day, good food is good food. I can say that I have eaten Colombian food, Mexican food, Ecuadorian Food, Dominican Food, Puerto Rican food, Peruvian food, Argentinian food, Uruguayan food, and Cuban food. Rincon Criollo is a Queens institution and it's been open for the better half of 60 years. The decor seems like something straight out of Cuba and the service is always welcoming and friendly. Btw, their Bday celebrations at the restaurant are very "festive." I have yet to order the super popular dish here, the Arroz con Pollo, think I will try this when I get a group of people to go. Oh, and this place was also featured on Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives.The food:Croquetas de Jamon- Ham croquettes. This dish is so near and dear to my heart. A few feet away on Junction, there used to be the Broadway Sandwich shop and the croquettes here tastes exactly like the ones in the other restaurant. These are essentially ham croquettes, but don't think of the regular ham you normally think of, it's more like ground up pieces of pork with mashed potatoes with a slightly crunchy exterior. I love it! yelp.com/user_local_phot…Rabo Encendido- Oxtail stew. It's essentially an oxtail stew in a tomato based broth. The dish was really great, the oxtail was nice and tender and the tomato adds a touch of acidity. The oxtail itself was a good size and the meat was pretty easy to get to. The order comes with two sides, I chose the tostones which was good but could be a little more crisp and the Moros y Cristianos. yelp.com/user_local_phot… yelp.com/user_local_phot…Masitas de Puerco Frita- Fried pork chunks- I really enjoyed this dish, the pork was so flavorful and the texture of the pork was great. It was basically like a pork chicharron and it was tender, juicy and the raw onions added a nice balance. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Ropa Vieja- Shredded flank steak in tomato sauce. This dish is one of Cuba's most popular dishes and it didn't appeal to me in the beginning because I am not a fan of any kind of shredded meat. The dish here was really good. The broth was slightly sweet and the beef was really tender, this is a must order. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Lechon Asado- Roast pork. I ordered this roast pork dish on Sunday and boy is it a lot of food. The sides I picked were Moros y Cristianos and Yuca con Mojo. Moros y Cristianos was kinda like purple rice with beans already cooked inside with small chunks of pork, this was probably one of my fav rice dishes. The Yuca con Mojo is cassava with garlic sauce, the garlic was intense, don't exhale too hard lol The cassava was really soft and the garlic was nice but it's a little plain. The pork was nicely cooked, too bad there was no crunchy skin =( It was a nicely cooked roast pork dish, too bad it was on the salty side. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Sandwiche Cubano- The Cubano sandwich here was solid. It's a big ass pressed sandwich with ham, roast pork, swiss cheese, mustard and pickles. It's a nice sandwich but I remember thinking the bread could be a little better.Bistec De Puerco Empanizado- Breaded pork steak. It's a pork cutlet that is really pounded out. The flavors are nice and the pork was really tender but the dish was on the greasy side.Bunuelos Rincon Criollo- they are essentially doughnuts in a simple syrup. The doughnuts are made of yuca, sweet potato and anise. The doughnuts are nice and crisp, the inside is nice but it's a little redundant. And the simple syrup is a tad sweet. yelp.com/user_local_phot…
Authentic Cuban food made with love and true culture. If you haven't tried this place you are missing out!

After reading so many wonderful reviews about this place I had to come and check it out, so I came here on a Saturday for an early dinner. I had a hard time choosing a meal, but ultimately ordered the pollo empanizado con moros y cristianos, as highlighted in one of Amy C.'s pictures. The food did not disappoint. The piece of fried chicken was huge. I asked for an extra helping of grilled onions and this definitely did the trick. They were sliced thick and buttery. A great complement to the chicken, which doesn't come with a sauce. I also ordered some plantains, and they were nice and crunchy on the ends.To drink I had a glass of sangria for $5, which had the right balance of sweetness and alcohol.The decor was inviting, as many others have said, it takes you back to Cuba or perhaps a Spaniard restaurant. My only critique is that the waiter was a little cheeky when I asked him about the menu and I'm not sure that this was entirely appreciated; a straight-forward answer on what dishes were most popular would have worked just fine.

This was tough, was going and forth on 4 stars or 5 because I'm really a 4.5 stars.  5 stars won.First of all, this place is in such a busy part of town but really close to the 7 train which can be convenient as parking is scarce.  You walk in and you literally walk into a different country, which is a nice actually.  Nothing fancy, just friendly.  The servers and awesome and super friendly and welcoming.  On to the food:Toasted bread for the table - alright, kind of hard but butter helped.Red sangria - I've definitely had better but why not order some as you wait for the paella.Paella - delicious and huge.  It takes 45-60 minutes, but you have to get it.  It has everything from lobster, shrimp, sausage, chicken, mussels, and other good stuff.  This is also huge, probably good for 3 people.Roasted pork with white rice, beans, and plantains - plantains were nice and sweet, rice and beans were magical, but the pork was slightly overcooked.  Ox tail - came with rice, absolutely delicious.  It came tender and flavorful.  For 5 people, we had 1 order of paella and 2 entrees and ended up taking home 1/2 of the paella bc we were stuff.  The food, in flavor and quantity, was great for the price.  Highly recommend, I'll be back.

BEWARE...INFESTATION! Having such great reviews I went to this restaurant without hesitation. Half way into our meal I look down at my baby's high chair and a ROACH was crawling from the kitchen to my baby's chair  I immediately advise the two workers who were having lunch right behind us. He quickly stomped the roach and said "oh it's NY you know..." Excuse me ?! I wish I would have snapped a picture but I was so frighten about the roach that it didn't even occur to me at the time. I didn't know how to handle the situation but I think they should have given us a free meal or a discount. I just wanted to get out ... fast ! When it came to paying for the check they avoided eye contact & pretend as tho the incident did not happen. NOT OKAY ... Please think twice before eating in that establishment.

Heard great things about this place and finally decided to go.  Atmosphere is nice. We were seated immediately. Waiter was very polite and attentive. Giving only 2 stars because :  1) waiter accidentally spit on my plate as he was taking our order (ok it's an accident & happens but... ewww) 2) we were accidentally poured wine we didn't order , we thought it was a fancy freebee, lol, thankfully we didn't drink it before they ran to take it away without apology, 3) we ordered the Palomilla . It was very thin, dry and still a struggle to cut with the knife and almost impossible to chew. I literally had to pull it out of my mouth.  The ropa vieja was a little chewy and too salty but flavor was ok. The Spanish sausage was too oily but taste good. The yuca was delicious.  Maybe we just were not lucky with our order but I probably would not go there again.

I found out about this place from Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives a few years ago, so I figured that I'd check it out. It has been one of my regulars ever since. The decor is festive and inviting and the waitstaff is very friendly. Most importantly, the food is phenomenal, comforting, and packed with flavor. The Ropa Vieja is perfect: tender, juicy, pulled meaty goodness.. Exactly what it should be. Also love the oxtail stew, and the pollo asado: a generous 1/2 chicken with a bright, delicious marinade. Each main dish comes with two sides, and they are all phenomenal, especially the fried sweet plantains. For desert, the tres leches is a must! Definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who loves Cuban food, or just food in general.

Have to agree with most reviews... food was awesome, and great service. Had the pollo y bistec salteado, the pollo rc  asado and congris... all were amazing, I felt like I was eating at someone's home.  Definitely have the tres leches cake.. that was the best ever!
Ropa vieja is excellent, roasted pork was delicious with the sauce it comes with. I poured the garlic sauce from the yuca on the rice and beans and it was delicious. Cash only or AmEx.

So glad my friends brought me here! I will be sure to bring more of my other friends back! We ordered the chicken and seafood paella. They say that is for two but I saw it's more like for six people. Even with four people taking it down, we still have leftovers (I'm enjoying it for lunch right now and it still tastes and smells amazing!) In addition, we had the oxtail and the shredded beef. ALL MY FAVORITES! I would go there and have the same exact meal! Sorry for not posting photos. The paella took 30 mins to make so by the time the food arrived at my table, I was simply too hungry and ate everything in sight! For sides, we got sweet plaintains (yum), fried yuza (omg yes!!! i want more), beans (okay) and fried plaintains (I prefer the sweet ones instead!). Already trying to gather a group to go back! so good!! Maybe even my parents will like it!!Note: this place was featured in Food Network (a friend told me) so it's definitely worth your time!

Never disappointed whenever I come here!  I cannot help that this is my go to place for good ropa vieja!  Chinola juice!  The old pictures on the wall make you feel like you are in someone's grandmothers house.This place is usually packed on weekends so if you can go during the week it's not so bad!  Whatever you order I know you will be satisfied and you will be full!  After the Mets game today we went here because I was in dire need of a ropa vieja fix!If you want some great Cuban food then look no further!  You will not be disappointed!

I was in the area and stopped by this hole in the wall. This place is kinda dated. The outside needs some freshening up. Its in a very busy area right next to the train. Its very hard to find parking. I found a parking across the street after circling the block a couple of times, but i needed to feed the meter and it was only a 2 hour parking. The outside sign is very dated and dingy looking. This place needs a face lift. Its a little old. The floor tiles look old and i saw some tiles broken. It just needs a little TLC. When I walked in, I was immediately greeted and seated.  Overall It has a cozy vibe, and there's light music playing in the background. Its sexy. Pictures everywhere. Lights are dim. Its great for couples. They sat me down right away. I ordered the ropa vieja, maduros (sweet plantains), white rice and black beans. I also ordered cuban beer. Everything was delicious and came out right away. I loved the ropa vieja which is shredded beef and had an amazing aroma and tasted amazing. The maduros were perfect, just a little crispy in the outside and soft in the middle which I love!! The waiter was attentive, but not in my face which I appreciated. The food was fantastic and I would definitely return when I'm in the area.

We love this place. Everything from the food to the service. We had great experience here. The food were absolutely delicious! Don't be fool by the size. It may not look that big but it's definitely filling. We were stuffed! We ordered the 1/2 rincon criollo chicken which is pretty much a roasted chicken, filet of fish rincon criollo, fried plaintain, white rice, rice n' beans, & cassava with garlic sauce. Everything that we ordered were full of flavor. Lots of garlic flavor! If you love garlic flavor, you'll love the fish rincon criollo. The decor is nice. When we went in, it felt like we were in a restaurant in a different country. The service were definitely great! Our waiter were friendly, polite, & helpful. This place takes credit card but ONLY American Express. There's an ATM machine inside the restaurant. We'll definitely go back!

The food here is great! The roast pork is juicy, accompanied with two sides, and it's more than enough for two people to share and for such a good price!! The service here is excellent. Our waiter, whom I sadly didn't catch his name, was super friendly, funny and everything you could ask for in a good waiter. I only deducted a star because although the decor gives it an old timely look, the chairs weren't in very good condition. And the plate I was given was greasy from not being washed well.Other than that, I would definitely come back.

Really overpriced food and the paella wasn't to die for. I didn't find it to be flavorful at all, super bland and the seafood seemed to be extremely rubbery and over cooked. I don't think I would go again.

My boyfriend and I love this place! It's one of our go-to spots for Cuban food. The staff is amazing they greet us as soon as we walk in and thank us as soon as we reach the door to leave. Amazing atmosphere, the place itself is small I'd say but definitely not a shoe box, the food, music, and decor make up for it! We usually share the Bistec Rincon Criollo (steak on grill) with Moros y Cristianos (yellow rice with black beans) and Platanos Maduro (sweet plantain) sharing this usually leaves us both full. Amazing place, 5 stars!

A friend took our family here for dinner one night when we came to visit New York. The food was amazing and the service was excellent. We've never had Cuban food before and we left very satisfied. When we are in the area again we will need to go back for a meal. My husband got the oxtail stew. It was so moist and juicy and it matched well with the yuca side dish. I ordered the shrimp in Spanish sauce and poured the sauce all over my rice and beans. My meal matched really well with the sangria. Overall, we all enjoyed our dining experience.

I had been meaning to go to this place for years to get the famed Arroz con pollo. I finally went a few weeks ago with 3 buddies before going to a mets game. This restaurant is only about a mile away from the stadium so it's convenient for a pre game meal. We ordered the arroz con pollo and it was good but disappointing. The problem is that it takes an hour to cook. So we ordered a lot of other food and we were full by the time this came to the table. It was very flavorful but the wait time is what kept it from being as good as I had hoped.Our waiter was great and we tried three other entrees at his recommendation. A beef dish, a chicken dish and a pork dish. We also tried every side they had. Everything we ate was delicious and flavorful. When the bill came it was only about $40 each and that includes a big tip for the excellent wait staff.We ate our faces off and it only cost $40 a man. We also got sangria which was tasty and I usually don't even like sangria. The only bad thing besides the arroz con pollo wait was we were so full and it was so hot out it was hard to enjoy the mets game.
This place never fails to satisfy my Cuban food cravings. Food and service are always top notch!

This was our second visit to Rincon and it was every bit as good as our first visit.We started with the Rincon house appetizer, slices of fresh cooked ham, shredded pork, sausage, cheese and olives. It's perfect to nosh on while waiting for the main course. I put some of the pork, ham and cheese on a piece of their bread to make mini Cuban sandwiches.For our main courses my wife ordered the Lechon Asado, succulent shredded pork with just the right amount of fat that adds to the flavor. I ordered the Ropa Viejo again. It was just as good as the first time I ordered it. Flavorful shredded beef in an onion and tomato sauce.Each main course comes with two sides. We ordered the beans cooked together with rice, the fried sweet plantains, an order of papas fritas and a house salad. All were quite good and we both shared everything. They do not skimp on their portions and we had enough Lechon Asado, rice and beans and plantains to take home for lunch on another day.The best surprise of our first visit was their homemade frozen lemonade. We ordered it once again it really goes well with their cooking. I also like the fact that they can tailor the sweetness to your liking.We will be going back because there are many other dishes on the menu that we want to try.Give Rincon Criollo a try. It's like having a Cuban mother cook for you. Appitite del bon

The food is authentic on the homey side of things.The waitstaff is friendly and always courteous.Great oxtail guisado, Ropa vieja, black beans and Maduros that bring you back home.  The beer and wine selection keeps getting better.

If you want a homey type of restaurant than this is your place! La ropa vieja is my very favorite! The staff here is great. Very energetic and they make you feel at home. I noticed they have a of of regulars come in which shows how much people love coming back here. I been here a few times and its always been an enjoyable meal and awesome time!

Been coming here for years.  Can't believe I never wrote a review on this place. Let's start with the Morir sonando, it's made with fresh squeezed orange juice.  Moving on to the cuban sandwich. It's just light, crispy and perfectly pressed.  The Thursday steak special, tender and flavorful. And I end it with the cafe con leche, that I could get nowhere else but miami.

Aww... Rincon Criollo brings back memories and transports me to another time, another place. I have never been to Cuba but I get the similar vibe in the old school restaurants in the Dominican Republic.The food here is cooked and seasoned the way it should be. We ordered croquetas de jamon (fried sticks made of potato and ham pureed), frituras de balacao (fried salted cod), Rabo Encendido (stewed oxtail) and flan de coco (which I took to go, because I was so full! The flan is good, goes great with unsweeten tea or coffee).The croquetas took me back in time, when I used to snack on them during recess back in grade school. Croquetas de jamon with a cup of soda. Hmm... good times.If you ordered appetizers, I would suggest you to share the entree since the portion is generous. The oxtail stew was delicious and well sized for the price, dare I say that you won't be getting this much for $14 with 2 sides if you were at a Jamaican restaurant. The rice is cooked perfectly, with right amount of oil and salt; the beans were cooked long enough that they are flavored and half broken. Before you pour the beans on the rice, put some of that meat sauce on the rice. Hmm... good times.I must point out that their maduros (yellow plantains) were cooked perfectly. Riped plantains, right thickness and pan fried to the point where it is slightly burned on the edges to bring in that crisp of caramelization. To wrap up your meal correctly, you'll need some coffee. We ordered cortaditos which were fabulous! Don't skip this unless you don't do espresso.The food is good, 4 stars. What take it up to 5 stars is the service and the atmostphere. The waiting staff is friendly and attentive. The vibe of the restaurant is just so Hispanic Caribbean old fashion: you just want to relax, sit back and enjoy your meal.

It may not look like much on the outside but open the door and step across the threshold into a little bit of heaven from the Caribbean. From the plantain chips (mariquitas) to the moro, chuletas, pernil asado and fish. Everything was spot on perfect.  Great job!

Rincon Criollo never disappoints. I always get the broiled flounder with the garlic yucca. Delicious! The food is so flavorful and tastes like someone's grandma made it. That's when you know IT'S GOOD. The restaurant itself has a very homey feel to it, which I love. The staff are always friendly and treat you like family. Pro tip- always finish your meal with a cafe con leche. You won't regret it.

These are the restaurants I LIVE for - delicious food, homey vibe, lovely service. I had such a delicious, jovial meal with my friends at Rincon Criollo, and I can't wait to take my other friends and family here next time we have a hankering for Cuban food (or just good 'noms). The place is small, so be wary of brining parties more than 5 (I assume there will be a wait - my friends and I lucked out and got seated right away.) The service was sweet, and were more than happy to give us suggestions. Oh but be warned: the place ONLY takes cash or AmEx (usually it's the opposite).All the food is great, but let me start with the only negative part of this review: avoid the croquetas. I'm sucker for those things, so I ordered them, but they were a little too over-fried for my tastes. Not terrible by any means, but I would not order those again.Everything else was superb - the mariquitas (plantain chips) were thin, crispy, and addictive. I love how here, every entree comes with two sides of your choice. I went with the chicharron de pollo with maduros and moros y cristianos (rice and beans). THIS is what I consider comfort food. The crispy, juicy chicken pieces with garlic and onion made the chicharron more than live up to the hype. The rice and beans were hearty, and the maduros were the ideal combination of crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. I also got to try my friend's Pechuga Rincon Criollo with grilled onions, which was delicious.I can't wait to go back to try the ropa vieja and other specialities there. Also a bonus are the reasonable prices for such generous portions. In a culinary heaven of a neighborhood/borough, Rincon Criollo is a gem.
I guarantee you'll love the El JEFFe combo (arroz con pollo, oxtails, and sweet plantains). If you're a real boss tres leches cake for dessert. You're welcome!

A destination truly worthy of grabbing an uber if your flight is delayed (my reason) as it is 5 minutes from La Nastia airport--don't fall for any of the airport food concessions! On walking in I was greeted by the warmth of Cuba in the form of music, aroma, and a hustling-to-serve waitstaff who dropped a fresh ice water, bread, and butter before my coat went on my seat back. This review is short as my plane is taxing and I hope the pics are helpful.

Dell.li.c.ious yummmmy :) I may offend a few with my garlic breath but I am smiling ear to ear with the amazing neal I just had. Yes they use garlic like there is no tomorrow. The flavor is a burst of deliciousness. So you may order pork, or rice and beans but it aint like the other Latin places. This is honoring Cuban home cook meals. Price is right. Staff friendly, not pushy.

The food was so delicious, and the Cuban sandwiches are also very good. It tasted like authentic Cuban food full of flavors. We ordered the breaded flounder and the oxtail. I had been trying to get my husband to come eat here to years but he hadn't, doubting how good it was. Once he began eating he was amazed, and said it was beyond good. He is a picky eater so this was definitely a home run.

Holy Motherland of Fidel Castro!!! (Too soon?) Can I tell you that my boots were completely smoked after having one of the best meals ever here?!Ok so I heard about this joint on Triple Ds on food network. I've been to a couple places featured on it and have been completely underwhelmed. Even peeping the pics on Yelp before coming through, I thought the pics were "meh". But sh*t!! if you ever were judge a book by its cover? Rincon Criolla is not the one to be f*cked with, in any sense of the word. Literally everything was SPOT on from soup to nuts.The vibe here is no frills casual but super lively, the staff, patrons, service and most importantly when dining out THE FOOD was on pointttttt. There isn't  one flaw that I could think of to dock a star, this is one of the occasions where I wish there were 6 stars! Alright my fan girl rant is done..I went with a food buddy of mine and we covered all the bases to get a feel for what Rincon had to offer.. I pregamed beforehand so I skipped over the alcohol (beer and wine only btw) and opted for a mango shake minus the milk because I'm a lactard, damn these Asian genes!! And it was yummers without it; fresh mango and not diabetically sweet. Even the house bread was good, they press it on a panini grill to ensure you get hot crispy greatness. Now onto the main event..For appy's we got the chicken soup; super home-y.Chicken Salad that consisted of grilled chicken, sliced tomato, avocado, iceberg lettuce in a simple vinaigrette. As simple as in sounds this would be one of those cases where less is definitely more. And lastly the chorizo appetizer that came on a hot plate; delish! Especially after dunking the bread in the sauce.For the mains (which came with 2 sides each) we opted for:Braised oxtail; ridiculously tender!! So much so that if you were to even glance at it the meat fell off the bone the sauce was heavenly to boot, I found myself dunking the bread in more than I'd like to admitRopa Vieja (English translation) means torn clothes, shit if my torn clothes tasted like this I'd have no wardrobe. It's shredded flank steak that's stewed in an unctuous tomato sauce I didn't even bother taking pics because it truly would not do it justice. I swear someone's abuela was in the back putting her foot up all in this dish.The side were definitely nothing to sneeze at we got the fried sweet plantains, yuca in that garlicky mojo sauce, and of course black beans and rice. Coming in thinking that this would be way too much food and we'd have leftovers I found myself about ready to lick the damn plate!! And in true Cuban fashion finished the meal with the traditional Flan and Cafe con Leche, it was amazeballs!! Perfect ending for the best Cuban food on the planet. The cafe con leche cured the itis that I would later endureService was great without being annoying or overbearing so salute to them for that. I'm seriously fantasizing about my next trip here, leaving the restaurant I couldn't help but think out loud what an awesome foodie experience it was....P.S. If you're in the area and pass this up, you will be the biggest ass clown ever!?P.P.S I was not paid for this kick ass review

Return visit and still a huge fan. I can see myself making a special trip here every time I'm in the metro area. Today... a massive feast for lunch, one which our eyes clearly were bigger than our stomachs. But who's complaining?Ropa Vieja - a massive plate of finely shredded beef in a tomato sauce accompanied (for the rest of the meal as well) with a very garlic laden butter. Oh dear... marvelous.Half Roast Chicken - falling off the bone tender and moist, flavor packed, a few nice crispy bits on the ends we eagerly devouredTwo orders of black beansOrder white ricePlantain chipsTotal bill, around $35.00. A steal.Honestly, the chicken and one order of rice and beans would have fed us without the rest, but we did our best and plowed through as much as possible. What a marvelous and filling meal, possibly our last of the day. So, my last visit I rated it four stars but I'm going with five this time which is about what 200+ other Yelpers have agreed upon at 4.5. I can't argue with food this good. Perfectly seasoned, plenty of it, solid all the way around and no shortcuts. Clearly an area favorite and likely the best Cuban cuisine in the entire metro area. Oh, and the music playing over the speakers today, superb. I'll be back!

The smoked pork chop at Rincon Criollo is one of the best pork chops I've ever had.  Most places will overcook and serve you dry pork chops.  This place makes their pork chop perfectly.  This is the only dish I order every time I come here.  My friends loved the ox tail, but for me, the smoked pork chop is their signature dish.It is a small place and it does get crowded.  But the staff and service is fantastic.  I only come here once in a while but they always seem to remember me.  I love their birthday celebrations here, they turn on the birthday music, the lights go on and the waiters come dancing :)

This is the ONLY restaurant that I have ever been to that advertises itself as Cuban, that really meets the challenge. Not even Cuban restaurants in Miami, measure up to Rincón Criollo. the only complaint I had was the parking situation but now, that´s no longer an impediment because there is one in Long Island with a huge parking lot!!I would have to review everything!!  It is delicious, hands down!!! I have never ever had a bad experience here and I've been going since I was  15 years old. It has NEVER changed!! Always delicious!! If you want to eat well and reasonable, treat yourselves!!

Belly about to explode!!!! For apps, ordered the yucca in garlic sauce and croquettes, which were so damn good! Also got the rolled steak to share. Rolled steak was great as everybody else was saying here. But my god, when we saw the paella...menu says for a party of 2, but really, they coulda fed a family! What a huge pot! I thought the paella was a little on the soupy side, maybe it's supposed to be saucy but a little too much for me. Doggy bagged everything and had it again for next day's lunch and dinner. Such goodness.Call in advance to order the paella... takes an hour to cook!!!

So I had been craving Cuban food and I decided to take my husband and son to Rincon Criollo. We all ordered different foods. I ordered the Vaca frita, my husband ordered Masas de puerco and my son ordered Ropa Vieja. Almost towards the end of the meal, my son found a long black hair in the Ropa Vieja. He took it out and placed it on another plate. I discretely brought it up to the the attention of the waitress who was cleaning our table. She immediately looked at my son who happens to have dark hair and said, "oh, there is no one with black hair working in the kitchen. But, we see this all the time." I was perplexed and extremely annoyed. Did she think we wanted a free meal? If that were the case, we would have made a far bigger deal.If they really see this all the time, then they have bigger issues in their kitchen. By the way, we paid our entire bill. Yes, I am Cuban and will not be returning to Rincon Criollo!!!

Came here on a whim based off the reviews, everyone was rite!  I took my order to go and the kid came off the soup, and they replaced with no friction.  Authentic Cuban, great cod stew on fridays, enjoy!

Reminiscent of a spot you would find in Cuba/Caribbean with the way the tables are set up, the waiters are dressed, and even the linens. Regardless of the cool/funky p ambiance of the restaurant itself--This place is no short of excellent when it comes to Cuban food. After more than a few visits here, I can recommend a couple items that I can guarantee a lay person would love. Vaca frita (shredded beef)Rincon criollo "house" steak Seafood paella (f.y.i. takes over an hour) Ropa vieja (in almost everyone's review)
One of the best cubano's I have ever had . The yucca was fantastic!! The ox tail was fantastic and the wait staff was tremendous!!

WOW Blown away by this place unreal Cuban food very authentic. I got the steak rincon criollo with side of tostones and white rice. The steak was seasoned to perfection, easy to cut and very enjoyable. The tostones were not over fried or thin. You could taste the plantain in every bite. White rice was light and fluffy not sticky or stale. I can't wait to go back.

This place is a true gem!  The food is soooo delicious! It is consistently good.  My favorite thing about this restaurant is the service.  Everyone makes you feel welcomed as if they have known you for years.  We went on Saturday night, it was a little busy but we didn't wait very long for a table.  For appetizer we ordered the ham croquettes, which are always amazing!  For my entrée I ordered the fried pork with rice and beans, as always super flavorful and delicious.  You know it has to be good if Guy Fieri (whom i love!) has been here!  Definitely will visit again soon!

Do NOT come here expecting authentic Cuban food. Maybe I'm too picky because I'm actually Cuban and grew up eating legit Cuban food all day every day, made by my mom and in amazing Miami world known restaurants such as Versailles, La Carreta, La Havana Vieja. And I've been to Cuba a handful of times.Lol, these people didn't have media noche which is what I came looking for in the first place. Then I ask if there was Milanesa de res. they tell me yes, and bring out a simple bistec empanizado. I later did my research and found out that Mexicans refer to simple breaded steak as Milanesa. I guess I put my hopes too high up for New York after finding amazing Cuban cuisine such as Havana Social in the meat packing distract (totally worth the money).The worse part of it all was being contradicted.... I'm Cuban and I ask what's up and the waiter has the AUDACITY to tell ME that that's not how it's served in Cuban restaurants LOL. Maybe he just didn't realize I was Cuban but that's very disrespectful and offensive. And even then I explained. They were nice enough about it at least to offer something else but I was too hungry out of work to ask for something else. Then the other guy was nicer about it but again not Cuban and again talked about things he didn't know about. He asked me why I didn't get some real Cuban food and not Milanesa. Yes, Milanese obviously has an Italian origin but it's a staple food for Cubans hence why they serve it in world renowned Cuban restaurants. At this point I was too annoyed to keep explaining myself. Pizza is Italian so it's no longer an American staple food?? Lol tsk tsk. So much for boasting about "authentic" Cuban food. Whatever, I just don't like when people talk to me like I'm stupid when I'm trying to eat. I thought my most offended moment would be somewhere in Manhattan but nope it was now in queens. It's tactless to try to correct someone's culture when you aren't actually from there.To make things worse, I wanted sangria and it wasn't great at all. Very small glass with just a slice of orange inside. Lol....Not coming back! I'm sure the food tastes delicious when you don't have expectations or when no one is being rude.  Maybe some of their other dishes are okay, who knows. There was one girl working there who seemed to have a good attitude and looked very nice. For authentic Cuban food that is even better than some in Miami definitely visit the meat packing district! I was definitely impressed.
Best pescado frito I've ever had in my ENTIRE life ! Don't even get me started on the black beans.. this was a hidden gem and I'm so happy I found it. Not to mention the prices are amazing !
I went here for multiple birthday celebrations and this place never fails to disappoint! The food is to die for

Don't listen to Guy Fieri, by far the worse tasting cuban food in NYC in my opinion.The food is tasteless, no flavor whatsoever, I had to add salt to all of the dishes ordered. I chicharon the pollo needed to be cooked more, it was a bit undercooked, the yuca had no taste, nobody even touched the beans, the rice with Black beans was also flavorless, the carne Frita was a fried mess.The atmosphere is pretty nice, they play nice music and the staff is very friendly and attentive. I do not recommend the food, Guy Fieri is a liar, when have you ever heard him say that something was flavorless or not good on the show?

Disappointed. Food was not fresh nor tasty. Went at noon on saturday, pollo asado chicken had barely any meat on bone nor flavor as if wasted away on rotisserie from day before. Black beans lacked flavor with no bay leaf in sight. Fried yuca was flavorless, had strange coating & was  served luke warm not freshly fried - was this frozen? Rice was ok but maybe this was reheated too was not stellar. Fried red snapper was ok but did not come with amy sauce like a mojo. Only reason not giving 1 star is because servers were super friendly and attentive and cuba style coffee (cortaditos) were good. I had not been in couple years but seems it went down hill. Maybe because there's barey any Cubans left in the hood. The cuban chains Sophie's and Tina's are better.

Don't understand the raving reviews here. I mean it's not bad, but its nothing spectacular. I think of every average Spanish joint I've at ate before when I tasted their food. My bf really wanted to try this place out after we watched it together feature on Guy Fieri's Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives show... And this is ANOTHER let down by Guy from the places he checked out in New York. (But I don't blame him, he would never says anything is bad &with the competition in the Food Capital of NY, I'm sure he just wants to give low key places some publicity)So 2 food dish I'll point out :Oxtail Stew - we ordered this right after having this whole cuban oxtail stew obsession since coming back from our Miami trip, &well Puerto Sagua's cuban oxtail stew was that phenomenal that I guess I was wrong for hoping to seek that theirs would come close... But errr no. I mean it was alright.Ropa Vieja - this dish was so bland, and the meat was dry and chewy...The other accompaniments and dishes were... well, just not memorable enough at all.Maybe I should've ordered the arroz con pollo that Guy also reviewed... We just thought it'd be too much food and it takes awhile to be ready. Maybe there other stuff are winners? I don't know, I just know I wouldn't ever go to Queens again just for this when Brooklyn has low key Spanish joints that taste the same too and Queens have so many other better endless food options.

I like this Cuban restaurant. I keep coming back here. This place is good for group. My favorite menu are Rincon Criollo Chicken and Codfish Fritters. I try to make sure to eat Rincon Criollo chicken every time I come here. It is my boyfriend's favorite, too, so even if I don't order it, I will pick his, and taste it:) You can order Rincon Criollo as either entree or appetizer. When you order it, tell the wait staff to chop the chicken and add extra garlic sauce (or garlic sauce on the side). This is the best way to eat Rincon Criollo chicken,I think. I saw many groups were celebrating birthday here. If you tell the restaurant that you are celebrating a birthday, one of the wait staff( maybe he is a manager?) will bring a flan with a candle with happy birthday song. He wears funny glasses and after happy birthday song, he does funny dancing, too. We talked with him before, he was very friendly and told us his story how he moved to New York. I think the best way to enjoy this restaurant is going there in a group, and share different appetizers and try each others entree.* I am adding this after I posted the review, but I forgot to mention Rincon Criollo Appetizer. This is assortment of appetizer. (Chorizo, ham, cheese, olive and turkey(chicken?)) It was good, too. I want to order again.

This place is so crowded but the environment is cozy! Maybe hard to find street parking, just like anywhere else in NYC!The food portion is on the large side, so it's great for sharing. We ordered oxtail, fried pork chop and roasted chicken rincon criollo for 3 of us to share. Each entree comes with 2 sides, and they are all very filling. My favorite was the oxtail, so tasty and tender! It was awesome to go with the white rice. Fried pork chop was great too, and it's HUGE! It's even bigger than the plate! Chicken was good, with very strong garlic flavor.The price was decent. I will definitely bring my friend/family there if I'm in that area.

Service was excellent, smiles from every staff member and our waiter was just an all around people pleaser. My daughter ordered a Cuban sandwich (not listed on the menu) which came out extraordinarily fast. I ordered the fried red snapper with tostones and congri. Everything was cooked to perfection and my filet was topped with onions and limes, for taste.My partner ordered the ox tail stew with congri and sweet plantains. We each tried one another's meals because each bite was delightful. I will definitely make this my go-to for any future cuban cravings.  Keep up the good service!!

I like the way they celebrate bday. Hah... The most exciting and energetic person in the planet will sing n dance for you. The way too loud but great for bday party. Its home made sangria is a little off my expectation. Fruits in glass is a bit too simple, hopefully it's the matter of season. Roasted chicken is better than oxtail ( the two main dishes I ordered). Anyway, worthy of trying.

My husband and I came here on a Friday at around 5 o'clock. My rating is more of a 3.5 stars. The place, for the most part, was empty and we were seated immediately. The restaurant in conveniently located just steps from the 7 train.The food was pretty flavorful but nothing spectacular and memorable. As an appetizer we had mariquitas with the garlic mojo. The mariquitas were freshly made, but the mojo was a a bit too "garlicky" for my taste. I had the fish in garlic sauce with rice and beans and my husband had the chicken in garlic sauce with rice and beans as well. The rice and fish were cooked to perfection but the beans lacked flavor. We also had desert. I had the bunuelos they are small but very good. We also ordered a pitcher of so-called sangria, which is just a slice of orange and one maraschino cherry in each glass with straight up wine. No brandy, no juice, no real fruit, just wine. We felt duped. As far as alcoholic beverages they only have wine, beer, and "sangria."Make sure you take cash because, for whatever reason, they do not accept debit cards and the only credit card they accept is American Express (really?). The waiter was nice and attentive. I am not sure if I would come back.
Delicious!!!! Real authentic Cuban food!!! Love the pork chops, oxtail, ropa vieja! Basically everything on the menu!

Date night this evening. We checked Yelp for Cuban restaurants and came across this one with very good reviews. I now know what everyone loved about it! Small cozy place and packed which generally is a good sign it means people like the food. Greeted by friendly staff ordered the white sangria a  bit on the sweet side but I prefer it sweet rather than dry. We ordered the ham croquettes and yuca relleno squeezed a bit of lime onto it and they were gone in a minute! The ropa vieja is delicious the hubby had it with white rice and black beans. I ordered the Cuban sandwich because I've been craving one for a hot minute. It was authentic that first bite when you feel the crunch of the bread and then the layers of the sandwich was what a Cuban sandwich should taste like. Not dry, not soggy just perfection. My side of choice boiled yuca with a garlic sauce and sweet plantains! I love yuca especially fresh not frozen , it melted in my mouth the garlic sauce was just enough flavor not to be overpowering! We will be returning and with friends! Oh and the price was low! Took dessert home cause we were full so to be continued...
The food here is simply delicious! The waiters are very nice and attentive. The restaurant itself is clean. I love dining here, highly recommended!

Excellent food, clean, and superb staff. I must say this is one of my favorite top 5 restaurants in all of New York City. Fried pork chops, white rice, black beans, avocado and tomato salad, cafe con leche, and tres leches=HEAVEN ON EARTH. I can't wait to try the Paella next time (looks divine). Omelettes here have a lot of flavor. It is also very relaxing to come during the day. Weekends are busy and crowded but a ton of fun (especially if you are coming with family, friends for a birthday or special occasion). I would give this food establishment six stars if I could.

There's quite a homey feel to the restaurant and very cozy inside. The walls are decorated with wooden plaques of Latin countries and historical motif. The food is classic stick to your ribs home cooking. We started with the grilled sausages that were flavorful and a good starter. Each main course comes with two sides. The rice with black beans side was called Moros y Cristianos which was an interesting name. The Tostones were freshly prepared and really good. The boiled Yuca was cooked in a very tasty garlic sauce. However, the yuca itself was a bit fibrous. For the main dish, I had the Ox Tails which were in a tomato based stew that was falling off the bone. The other dish we tried was the Shrimp Scampi that was baked in with a garlic butter sauce that was perfect in drizzling over the rice as well when eating.They have a very loud recording of a Happy Birthday song when you go and request that one of your party is celebrating a birthday there. It's quite fun and embarrassing if you weren't expecting it.I definitely have to come back and try other dishes on the menu.

Had a wonderful dinner here tonight. Shared everything...yucca in garlic sauce, stuffed cassava, and Spanish sausage for apps followed by oxtail, chicken, rice , beans, and tostones...coconut flan and tres leeches cake....all good!

I finally got a girlfriend to come with me to check out the restaurant after having bookmarked it a few months ago but our meal was terribly lackluster.We both ordered the sirloin steak medium rare. All the entrees came with two sides. The steaks came out, looking impressive, although our waiter joked that he looked for the smallest ones for us. (Or was it a joke?) My steak came out almost well done so that completely ruined the meal for me. My gf's was better but even she said that it was getting dry and tough as she ate more into her steak. Granted, we aren't at a steakhouse and we didn't order their traditional, well-acclaimed dishes, the temperature of the steak was just so off.The staff was pretty great though. We witnessed how they gave a birthday shout-out and it was the best I've seen done by a restaurant. The waiter who headlined it was very cheery and enthusiastic.

Love this Cuban spot. Been going to this restaurant as far back at the late 90's. I love their food. Ropa vieja is legendary. Arroz con pollo is as good as it gets. I really like their pork chops as well. I'm Brazilian so black beans and rice is very close to home. Love restaurants that have history and don't skip a beat. Rincon Criollo is awesome.

We went to Ricon Criollo Easter Day and it was very crowded.  The waiting to be seated was overwhelming but it was worth  it. It was our fifth or six time that we have had visited this place and as we expected the flavor and the service were outstanding.  The friendly atmosphere made us feel like we were visiting some relatives.My wife ordered Ropa Vieja with white  rice and black beans and I was craving Picadillo with Moro (rice with beans together ) and were pleased as we expected with the rich flavors. If you love coffee do not hesitate to try their cortadito, it is delicious. As for dessert  I am sorry to report nothing about it because after the meals we didn't  have any space for anything else but the coffee.  We love this place! Don't mind the waiting it will be worth  it.

Had a great meal here. It was the rincon chicken ,black beans , white rice and some fried plantains and salad to help balance it all out . Everything was fresh and delicious . I also loved the decor of the restaurant . It really made me feel like I was in a different part of the world even though my Asian looking waiter sorta subtracted from that . He was incredible though . Very active and attentive . The only negative on this place was the bread they served . It tasted like it was stale but I overlook that because of the great entree .

A group or friends and I were staying at an airbnb in Queens. None of us had been to Queens before, so we knew nothing of good places to eat. Found this place on Yelp, and it more than made up for being so far from the rest of our friends who were staying Uptown.The service was fantastic. Our waiter went over the entire menu, including all the specials for the day (he even brought out some food for my indecisive friend to try before ordering). The atmosphere was great and felt authentic. That food, though. A few of us ordered the chicharonnes, which I would highly recommend. The sweet plantains and red beans made for good sides. Had a Cuban style beer, which was good but overpriced at $7.If you're in Queens, and especially if you're near Junction, you have to try this authentic Cuban restaurant. I would definitely go back.

I really have no idea how this place has consistently held 4.5 stars - I'm starting to wonder about you these days, Yelp...Came here on a Friday evening for dinner and was stoked! to try their Cuban, considering there were so many rave reviews. I got the Pechuga Rincon Criollo - grilled, thinly sliced, chicken breast topped with seared onions - with rice & beans and sweet plantains as sides. The chicken was  tasty, simply seasoned; however, oil just pooled at the center of my plate. Rice and beans were good, a tad too salty for my taste considering the flavoring of the chicken. On to the best part, my plantains were BURNT. Not slightly over-baked by several seconds, but burned to the point all I tasted was charred honey. I didn't send them back because... well I work in the food service industry and I just don't take risks...I did tell my server at the end of the meal, and asked him "Wtf..." (not in so many words) and all he said was ,"Oh, okay," and walked away to pack up our leftovers. Woohoo. Though I didn't expect a better answer considering we were in Corona...Probably won't be back. There are WAY better Cuban places to go in Queens... with normally cooked plantains!

I went to this restaurant about 1 hour before Sheldon S. and he has captured a lot of what I'd write. I'd cosign his "Cuban Soul Food Restaurant." That sums up this great little Cuban restaurant in Corona. My goal this month is to Yelp my way around the best food in Queens. And I, like many others found Rincon Criollo. It's not far off of Roosevelt Boulevard in Corona in a small non-descript shopping district. Parking was easy enough to find and inside was a pleasant surprise.There are pictures everywhere of Cuban folks. (Of course, the requisite one of the Queen (Celia Cruz) and many others. It has a look that must not have changed since the 1970s -- and that's a good thing. Intimate maybe, 20 feet wide.The service was excellent. They are helpful. One concern non-Spanish speakers can have is accessibility. (Learning Spanish bridges that gap.) But the wait-staff here were friendly and attentive and willing to explain.We had oxtails, ropa vieja, cafe con leche, mango milkshake and rice and black beans. Let me say as someone who makes and eats rice and black beans several times a week, that this was awesome here. Really just come for that. The cafe con leche was as I remembered and the bread was that Cuban bread that many imitate and few duplicate. Excellent.The oxtails were very good. I've had many, like many, many many. Although I am not a fan necessarily of the tomato sauce, the rest was awesome.I also had Ropa Vieja. This was decent but a little too salty for my taste. Decent but I've had slightly better.Of course the mango smoothy was as one would expect.The only downside was the drink menu. It was sparse. (I had a Presidente, but a Dominican beer in a Cuban place was not quite what I could have predicted.) Overall, the experience was excellent. Now those of use who are more diligent will see the Guy Fieri sign and worry. (I do everytime I see it.) Worry not. The FN has not ruined the place with lots of folks who are not palate particular.The other point is this feels like a warm diner. Like folks who know eachother. There's such a sweet spirit about this place that it seems like a perfect place to go to remember a happier time with some great food. And that really is it's own reward.

I had such an amazing experience!!! It was my first time here? I was starving and waited two hours, but so worth the wait! It was my farewell dinner with my co works & the most epic moment was our hostess RUDY doing a surprise dance congratulating me on my new job! THE FOOD was amazing!!! Pernil, pepper chicken, breaded chicken, coconut flan, maduro, tostones everything was on point! I'll be returning.

Great food and great service. I've had the broiled red snapper, oxtails, pernil over time. I highly suggest the moro rice. You are given substantial, delicious food and will walk away full and content. Highly recommend!

I had an omelet with white race and black beans and it was amazing. The service was phenomenal and the waiters truly do outstanding work. I was checked on and always got a refill on my water. Thank you Rincon Criollo and I will make sure to come back in the near future. Thank you.

I just finished having a great meal and plenty of drinks at Sabor, but the glutton in me had to come to Rincon. Thanks to my glutton I found a Cuban spot that I'd like to come back to. I initially came here for dessert but then I looked at the menu--casava con carne, jamon y pernil con queso, y bacalao. Oh man! I haven't had some of this stuff in so long. How could I deny myself the pleasure? :) Yeah, so I ordered a bunch of appetizers with some Spanish beer then finished off with some flan. Everything was perfect and the price was super cheap. They may not be converting to dollars or something, which is fine by me. This is just a simple old school restaurant without the loud music or glitz & glamour like some other Cuban places. I love it.

Have been wanting to visit this place for quite some time and just recently had the opportunity to check it out with my boyfriend.  We were given the chance to pick out our table since we got there at a time where it wasn't too busy. Sat down. Friendly waiters took our orders and then later placed some warm/toasted/crunchy bread on our table.  Such a good way to start!!! We ordered two lemonades and I thought it was going to be like like from the instant lipton lemonade mix or snapple bottle but nopee! Our lemonades we LEGIT freshly done on the spot superrr refreshing. Food didnt take too long. Food was great!  Everything was just how we had expected. And to end things off,we had flan with a nice cup of coffee! Would be definitely coming back to try more things!

Talk about things you love about Queens and Rincon Criollo might just be part of that conversation. The diversity of foods just makes you forget about your passport and grab a metro card! Rincon Criollo is in a crazy busy part of Corona (which part isn't busy?). But its pretty much the best Cuban Restaurant I know in NY. (I don't know much, so take it as you will) Not only is the food great, but the service is pretty top notch! Not only are the servers attentive, but polite, amicable, and you're not limited to your 1 server but any of the servers in the restaurant. They all kinda just come by the table and ask if you need anything! (I posted a pic of one of the servers going ALL OUT, dancing, singing and shouting congratulating a couple on an anniversary dinner. They really make a scene of it!)The best part of the place is the food:The Chicharon de pollo is pretty much the overall winner so far. Hands down one of the best entrees in the place!If you're craving a little red meat at a great price, the Bistec rincon Criollo is pretty good. Good portion size, its not a Great steak (its pretty much flat and cooked well done) but its well flavored with the onions on top. The breaded pork chop cutlet was HUGE! Each entree comes with 2 sides.My favorites are the Sweet Plantains (maduros) and the Cassava in garlic sauceI hear the desserts are good, but there's always so much food I never have enough room for dessert! A gem in Corona!

Being part cuban my standards are very high for cuban cuisine. This is my favorite restaurant in NYC. The staff treats us like family, and they never disappoint. I dream of their ropa vieja. When you're in the area or even just want some amazing food in an amazing atmosphere, go!

Corona is a magical part of Queens where Latin America is alive and well, especially when it comes to food. One place representing the hood well is Rincon Criollo, known to many in foodieland as one of the (if not the) best real Cuban establishments in NYC. Despite never having been to Cuba and having only spent a little bit of time in Miami's Little Havana, my love for Cuban food has always remained strong. Rincon Criollo is, simply put, fantastic.From first impressions alone, this place doesn't look like much. The decor is undeniably old school - everything from the wall decor to the rickety dining furniture and generic table cloths. The waiters are a friendly bunch, usually extremely bilingual, a bit of a rarity in these parts.The food, especially when enjoyed within a group of people is almost always a feast of it's own. Fans of the famous Cuban dish ropa vieja, are sure to find a delectable version here. Stewed to perfection and deliciously tender, at $14 is a steal considering it comes with two sides. Another winner is the chicharon, it's practically fried chicken at it's juiciest and crispiest. The vaca frita is incredible, salty and juicy, a mesh of fried shredded beef with garlic has never been executed better. It just might be my favorite dish in the house.The sides are plentiful and really add to the meal. Moros y cristianos (rice and beans combo) and platano maduro (fried sweet plantain) are a killer combination with any entree. Even their papas fritas (fries) are good -  homemade, long and crispy, irregular but hearty. I would heed caution on the yuca con mojo (cassava with garlic sauce), a side that hasn't fared well with any of my dining companions, which means it's an acquired taste.Their menu is so vast that every visit has resulted in a new meal. I've heard such wonderful things about the rest of their food that it justifies more and more future visits to one of the best restaurants in Q-borough.

This place has amazing food. Everything tasted like it was home made and fresh. We went on a Saturday night and were seated promptly. All the waiters were super friendly and helpful. On to the food... We ordered the     de pollo and ox tail as entrees, getting white rice, rice with beans, tostones and mundoros as the side.

I have pros and cons! I do have to say I do love the food. In house service is great and friendly. Food is always good but now that they deliver on seamless I was excited to then be disappointed! They are not the cheapest and I don't mind paying a little extra for good food but why do they have to be sooo cheap with the portions! For the price they can give much better rations. Rice and maduros are usually inexpensive but you get so little. Let me say I'm speaking on behave of DELIVERY. Eating at the restaurant is nice and portions are good but I ordered multiple times now and for them to even charge a delivery fee on top of everything and short handing on sides for the price they charge is ridiculous to me. I will continue to eat there AT THE RESTAURANT but unfortunately will not order anything for delivery again.
One of best Cuban restaurants in New York City after in Miami and Havana. It is not same one as other restaurants around in New York City. It is taste much similar where eat in Miami or Havana,Cuba.

It's been so long since I've been here. Last time I remember that I was here was when it was my dad's birthday couple of years ago, If I'm not mistaken. This place gets 5 stars due to the fact that the food is too die for ! Every plate here is wonderful, Especially the Cuban sandwich w. A mango milkshake that's my all time favorite grub at this place. It's straight up Cuban w. Cuban memorabilia all over the walls w. Cuba & there restaurants history. Great food. Great people. Great atmosphere. Plus food is reasonably priced also.

They were pretty good. The thing that got me the most was the culture and service. When we went it felt like we were automatically in a different country. While we were about to order it was someones birthday and they did a birthday song and celebration very different from most restaurants which made it very entertaining. The drinks were all white which was a little odd cuz he ordered lemonade and i ordered the papaya shake. They were dialed down but it was still pretty good. Not too sweet. We decided on this restaurant because i was craving sushi. So when we yelped it, it sent us here. I ordered the oxtail with avocado and sweet plantains while my friend got the sirloin steak with rice and beans with potatoes with garlic. The oxtail was a bit salty but woulda been nice with some carrots perhaps but honestly i've had better. His Sirloin Steak was good but even the medium rare felt over cooked. The sweet plantains were really good but they only gave five pieces. Where as the avocado they were really generous with but didn't taste ripe. The rice on beans was a compliment to the salty oxtail and the garlic potato we had a bite each and that was enough. Overall would I come here again, yes but will definitely have to try something new.

There's an autographed photo of salsa legend Celia Cruz that hangs on the wall of Rincon Criollo. And her trademark shout of "¡Azúcar!" is appropriate for the one dish I enjoyed the most at this family eatery dating back to 1976: casco de Guayava con Queso , also known as Guava Shells with Cream Cheese. The english translation, mainly 'cream cheese' diminishes the appeal of this dish as I'm thinking Philadelphia brand and keyfood. Don't go there as this queso is nothing like something you'd find in a little gray tub.Our intrepid team of eaters, organized and led by Rachel A., occupied the center of a surprisingly empty restaurant for a Thursday night. We started with a plethora of appetizers, including codfish fritters, ham croquettes, cuban tamal, yucca and chorizo. We were also given sliced bread (average) and frequently refilled water. A pitcher of sangria was also shared.The chorizo was thinly sliced and not overwhelmingly salty. I enjoyed the tamal, a holiday yule-log shaped treat of masa. Our fleet of appetizers devoured, entrees were up next. I'd say that while the appetizer size was easily conducive towards sharing, the entrees, while large, weren't going to result in any seconds. There was also a small delay in the arrival of our oxtail that in no way detracted from the overall spread of Cuban treats.Beef liver steak with onions was my by far my favorite. Is it steak? Is it liver? Is it an odd fusion of the two concocted by a mad scientist? Large enough to be a steak but rich enough in iron to be moderately healthy, this one tender internal organ!For those seeking a unique birthday experience, the song and dance number performed will be quite memorable. Flashing lights and music are involved.Which brings us back to where we started, mainly with mention of guava. I actually had expected the guava shell dessert to be a pastry as I've had such treats in the past. (At the now defunct Puerto Rico Cafe in the Newport Mall long, long ago).
