I think I must have walked by this place a few times in the past without even noticing it.  I think the last time I past it I was thinking "what the hell is that??"  Well, my wife and I finally stopped in today, and we went kind of nuts ordering all kinds of stuff.  We ended up taking some left overs home.  We even called a few friends and family in order to bring them a few extra dishes to try.Yes, it really was excellent, as the other reviews state.  Some of the best soup dumplings, veggie dumplings, shumai, etc we've ever had.  I normally wait until I've been to a place a few times to write a review.  But, everything we ordered was uniformly good.  So, I feel confident that we will get the same great food the next time and the next.  The place itself is located right next to the 112 Pct.  (I worked there as a rookie lieutenant about 14 years ago).  So, if you go about it that way, it's hard to miss.  You enter though a long, narrow driveway like entrance, where they've placed a couple tables for outdoor dining in fair weather.  You will see the LIRR trains speeding past about 100 feet directly in front/above you.  The restaurant itself is very tiny, with only enough seating for about 10 customers.  That includes the seats at the counter.  Don't plan any big parties here.  LOL.  You can see the entire kitchen right in front of you if you sit at the counter.  We watched 3 women making dumplings the whole time we were there.  The chef was in the back area of the kitchen.  I can see how everything remains amazingly consistent if it's just him cooking everything.  (Hopefully they don't outgrow their place and become like so many other great places that start out small and great, but expand and lose their way??  I hope they make tons of money just by staying there.)The dough/skin on the XLB and various dumplings, baos, and shumai we ordered were perfect.  Just the right consistency.  The innards were all soft and delicately flavored.  Not too overpowering or salty as in so many other places.  These foods should be flavorful enough to eat without dipping into any sauces, and that's exactly how these were.  If you want it more savory or sour, it should be your choice to dunk them into a sauce.  It shouldn't be a necessity.  My only gripe was the scallion pancakes.  They were crispy and had a nice texture, and had a nice amount of scallions for aroma.  But, they were a bit on the bland side.  They really needed to be dipped in a sauce.  Service was what we expected from a mom and pop Chinese place.  LOL.  I won't say much more about that.  But they got the job done and allowed us to enjoy the food.  Was there even a bathroom in the place??  I'm not sure.  We didn't need to go, so I didn't even take notice.  The whole dining area was smaller than the rug in my living room.  LOL.  Our family and friends all loved the food we brought back for them.  We'll be back next week, with extra company.  Update 1/16/2020:Went back with a larger crew this time and tried all different stuff, except the XLB.  You always have to have XLB.  The taro puffs were flaky and fragrant, with a stuffing that was just subtlety sweet.  Not overpowering. The rice cake had fresh bamboo slices!  Not canned bamboo.  That added a whole other dimension to this classic dish that almost all other places miss. Their chive pancakes were actually stuffed full of chives.  Most other places  stuff it with mainly vermicelli, with just a bit of chives.  Again, they were just so fresh and fragrant.  The scallion noodles, however, took the honors.  I have to say it again.  It was just so fragrant and flavorful.  The chef fried the scallions until the were brown and crispy.  It's tossed on top of the noddles along with some greens and a couple dried shrimp for extra flavor.  We all shared everything.  But, I swear I'm going to get my own bowl of scallion noodles next time, which is probably next week.  LOL.  I also saw another customer with a bowl of curry beef with vermicelli soup  that looked amazing.  Gotta try that next time too.  Can't wait!

Cute little place to eat! The food is delicious. The soup dumplings are to die for, fried rice flavorful as well as the noodles, and the fried scallion pancakes are amazing. If you come here to eat, then you better get the fried scallion pancake with beef and the soup dumplings. Only complaint is the service, don't expect the staff here to thank you or anything.

Delivery for a location 8 minutes away. Two orders of braised beef noodle in soup and one shanghai sticky rice shaomai. Tasted fine, but one of the beef noodle soups only had two small pieces of meat. The other had five. For $9.25, given the quality of the meat, I would be fine with five pieces but not two. Many other places nearby sell this item at the same price, same quality, but with more meat. Delivery isn't ideal, but the noodles arrived as a giant sticky clump. If you try to separate the noodles from themselves, you won't be successful. So enjoy eating all of the noodles before you notice that there isn't much protein underneath. The shaomai was overpriced.I'm sure the food would be better if I sat down and ate there. But would it be more consistent? I don't think I'm willing to find out unless I'm already a few blocks away.

I love Memories Of Shanghai. My partner and I decided tonight was the perfect Saturday night for pork buns and a bunch of yummy dumplings and realized they opened back up!! Everything hit the spot but the real MVP of our order tonight was the scallion pancake with beef. Oh man.

This place is super tiny with only 2 tables, 3 bar seat and the wait is always long in the weekend. We suggest to come on the weekday if you would like to try their delicious dumplings and pan fried noodles.My auntie in law who is really picky to Shanghai food loves their Xie Ke Haung puff so much and she always asked us to bring her an order if we visited her. I also love their taro puff with creamy taro inside and crispy puff outside.

I am sure if someone who never had Shanghai food will volunteering to walk in here alone.  There are other food choices on the block.  However if you do crave the food and don't want to go all the way to Flushing this is a good place for to-go or 1 or 2 friends to seat down in this tiny restaurant. I think maybe when the weather is better they will put out table and chair to seat outside. From what I tried so far I believe what they offer will not be bad if not great. Seems to be a family run shop that cares for what they offer.

Ventured to Queens and came here before a Death Can for Cutie concert at Forest Hills Stadium (about a 5-10 minute walk). Great "hole in the wall" dim sum place, it's literally located in an alley way and feels super authentic with a modern twist. It's super small place with only 2 tables inside but they do have some tables outside to eat at as well, which is probably better for nicer weather. Probably best with small groups or for take-out/delivery.We ordered the veggie pot stickers, xia long bao, shao mai, and chili wontons. Each dish came out to between $6-$8 each. We also had taro and pumpkin pancakes for dessert. Not sure if it's because we waited too long to eat the dessert (it came out first) but they were a little too dry for my taste. Would be down to try some other sweets they have.

Came here on a Thursday night for soup dumplings and Fried Rice. A filling meal for 1-2 person(s) - about $20! The place itself is very small but there's an alley way with seating which would be really good for the warm seasons. Def a hidden gem in forest hills. Must try!

What a nice surprise in Forest Hills! As a native Shanghainese living in NY, I am always searching for that familiar taste from my childhood. And what find! This place is easy to miss. It's right between the police station, and a parking garage. A long entry way takes you to the little shack. They only have seating enough for about 12 ppl inside. It's a self serve place, order your food, and find a place to sit down and enjoy. Everything we had today was tasty, the pork stuffings had very good flavor, and not greasy. Only down side, I wished the xiaolongbao's skin was thinner. Will definitely go back try other dishes on their menu.

Around Forest Hills, there isn't quite a lot of good Chinese food and I'm super glad this spot opened. My boyfriend and I love to come by for their beef noodle soup and Shanghai dumplings. The beef broth is flavorful and the dumplings are always great. The prices are a bit pricier than the usual Elmhurst/Flushing due to location but not too bad. Seating is very limited but we've been lucky every time to get seats. If you come when it's warm, you can even get a good seat outside!

Memories of ShanghaiLocated in forest hills. It's a short walk from the forest hills subway station and on the strip of the busy Austin street. As you approach the spot you will see 2 big banner or flags that specify its name. Right next to a parking garage. You can't miss it. As you walked further in you can see some outdoor seatings which is good for the summer time. We came a little after 12pm on a Sunday and there were plenty of seats. At most you can sit up to 14 people. The menu is on the wall or you can take the paper version from the cashier. Once you are ready make your order and take your receipt. When your order is ready they will call your number. What we order: Pork soup dumplings: ($6.75) (6 pieces) the soup was delicious and very flavorful, just the right amount of pork fillings. Crab soup dumplings: ($7.75) (6 pieces) usually at every soup dumplings spot we go to we eat the pork first and we always end up loving the crab. But at this spot, we ended up loving the regular one more. There just wasn't enough of crab to spark the dumpling. It was still good but needed more crab in the mixture of filling. Scallion pancake with beef: ($6.25) maybe like 2 pieces of sliced beef which was wrapped in scallion pancake. The pancake was crunchy on the outside and they put the hoisin sauce inside the beef.  After you're done dispose the chopsticks and the sauce cup, return the spoon and the bamboo steamer basket to the cashier. I notice a lot of people order take out here since it's a tight spot.

I really didnt have high expectations but it's true what they say never judge a book by it's cover. This place is very small which consists 2 small tables, counter seatings and outdoor seating, I guess you could call it a take out place. Okay now onto the food: The beef noodle soup is delicious! Generous amount of noodles, the beef is so tender and the broth is really flavorful. You can have it spicy or not which is a good option for my 2 year old toddler. The soup dumplings were not bad at all. The rice cakes were just ok thou, a little bland for my taste. Skip on the curry vermicelli noodles. This place is a good option if you dont feel like venturing out to Flushing to satisfy your soup dumplings and beef noodles cravings! I also ordered from them for delivery and the soup dumplings were still warm and tasty! (just fyi it takes 60 mins for delivery, so order ahead of time).

Their pork wanton in chili sauce is amazing with peanut butter sauce.  Dumplings and buns are tasty as well.  Braised beef in noodle soup is a bit on the salty side but great as well.The store is small and has seating for about 6 people max.  I would recommend you pick up the food because you may have a hard time sitting down for food.  If you order delivery be on the cautious side.  Not only do they take forever (1 hr plus) they often forget to give utensils.Terrible service.

Food was excellent!! Sounds cliche but my favorite soup dumpling place is Joes Shanghai (yes, I like it more than Shanghai Cafe in Chinatown and Nan Xiang Xiao on Prince St). While I don't think these soup dumplings are as good as Joes, they do compete with Nan Xiang or other less-known places. The wrapper wasn't too thick, but thick enough to hold the dumpling so it doesn't fall apart. Both the pork and crab had great flavor and a good amount of soup in it. My only con, which is forcing me to give MOS 4 stars instead of 5, is that they don't give you proper soup spoons, they are way too small and lead to make a mess while eating. They also don't give you cabbage, which I like to have to soak up any soup that spills.Other than that, I tried the scallion pancake with beef and that was perfect; perfect crisp without feeling too oily and just enough hoisin sauce to give it flavor but not overpowering.The steamed chicken dumpling with curry and onion was a must have!! Such a unique flavor and good consistency. I almost ordered a second order.The shaomai with sticky rice and mushroom was also delicious. I would also order it again.Lastly, I got the panfried noodles with seafood. It wasn't my favorite but pan fried noodles never are so I can't be a good judge. My gf said the noodles were a little too chewy. The amount of vegetables and seafood was also a little lacking.For a small little forest hills spot, definitely excellent and as a forest hills person, I would definitelUpdate: they changed to regular soup spoons!!!

Pretty awesome that they have a soup dumpling place in Forest Hills now. When it comes down to it the food was great. The soup dumplings have a clean broth that don't make your teeth feel disgusting after eating them. As long as you try to eat them while they're hot, they don't fall apart while you're picking them up (aka hearty skins) and the flavor is on point. The scallion pancakes were pretty standard. The fried rice cakes were actually amazing. I was so surprised, because I was disappointed that they didn't have meat, but the flavor was really on point for it. Seating is a bit weird. Definitely more of a summer place when you can sit outside, but wouldn't recommend bringing more than 4 people. Even 2 people will be hard to get a seat, and then if you take away the soup dumplings, it'll be weird to eat them cold. That's the only downfall of this place. Also don't be concerned that you're walking down a well lit nice alley way. You're going the right way. Overall it lost a star for the seating and also the prices are higher than what you would pay in Flushing. But for any time I don't feel like going to Flushing (which is most of the times) I would definitely come here to get my fix.

This place is aptly named - biting through the delicate skins of the soup dumplings (上海小笼包) transported me back to summer days spent walking along the Bund and through the gardens of the French Quarter in Shanghai, the city of my dad's family.The place is tiny. There is one four-person table, 2 two-person tables, and a few counter seats, and the kitchen space is so small, the counter space quickly disappeared under bags of takeout orders. (There are tables outside, so during summer months, I imagine the place feels less cramped.) Yet somehow, Memories of Shanghai manages to churn out lovingly prepared dishes that would make any Shanghainese native nostalgic for home.Standout dishes included the 牛肉卷饼 (I think they called it "夹饼" on their menu), or scallion pancake with sliced beef - the pancake was so crispy, airy, and flaky, one of the best scallion pancakes I've ever had. We would have liked a bit less sauce and a bit more beef, but would 100% order it again. The 上海小笼包 were excellent - the skin was so thin and delicate, the filling was generous and flavorful, and the soup had that perfect, mouth-coating gelatinous quality. The 蟹粉小笼包, or crab meat soup dumplings, could have used a bit more crab flavor, which was more of a faint aftertaste. The 生煎包, or pan-fried dumplings, were very tasty, but the bottoms were not quite crispy. We also had sweet soy milk (甜豆浆) and savory soy milk (咸豆浆), both served hot - some patrons stopped in just for the soy milk, and after taking a sip, you'll totally understand why.For the price, this place can't be beat. Everything we ordered was under $7 and reminiscent of the good home-style cooking found in Shanghai alleys of old. I desperately wish a place like this existed in Washington, DC, and look forward to stopping in again, hopefully in the summer months, to inhale copious soup dumplings with some more elbow room outdoors.

We have now come to Memories of Shanghai two times now and the second time just hooked us even more. First though, it is way down on Austin street. About a 10 minute walk from the subway. But it's worth it. The dining room only sits a couple of people literally. And you're up close to where they are making the dumplings. That's very cool. I started off with a scallion pancake. Normally when I have had them they are always greasy. But it isn't here. It's so good!! I wish the sauce was a bit thicker but it's still delicious. Jeffrey got the beef noodle soup and he had them make it very spicy. They really did. He actually started getting red in the face. Funny but worth it!!Then I got the shrimp dumplings. They were so good!! The shrimp was very large and the dumpling pastry was delicate. Just the way it's supposed to be. I wanted to try a sweet puff but I'm apprehensive as in almost every Chinese sweet party I have never found one yet that was sweet. Maybe next time I'll give it a chance. Hey MOSH we will definitely be back!!!

Great soup dumplings at a GREAT price.  The dumpling skin was thin and soup was flavorful. My only gripe is that I had a thirst after eating them which I guess was from the MSG. But what's Chinese food without MSG. Definitely my new go to place for soup dumplings. Also their chive pancakes are EXCELLENT. Crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. It looks like a big dumpling but it taste really good.

I'm not sure what experiences folks with less than stellar reviews had at this place, but my boyfriend and I went and the food was spectacular. We ordered the scallion pancake with beef, the soup dumplings, the shrimp dumplings, and the beef noodle soup with bok choy and asked for it spicy, and for $30 total for two people we left stuffed! I loved the beef scallion pancake and the soup dumplings the best, and my boyfriend loved his spicy beef and noodle soup. When they say "spicy" they are serious, it was a good amount of heat with plenty of kick. The soup dumplings are adorable, not too big, not too tiny, and the thickness is just right where they don't burst when you try to pick them up, but you can easily bit into them and slurp out the soup without it spilling all over everywhere.As people have mentioned this place is TINY, but it is fresh, homemade, and with a limited item menu. If you have a spare afternoon, I highly recommended taking the train or a drive out to Forest Hills, park near Austin Street, get some dim sum at memories of shanghai, and then walk around the neighborhood.
Great food, but one of my soup dumplings arrived torn...I will still order again and try their other appetizers and various noodle options

I'm definitely biased when I give them 5 stars. I order from them a lot, and the delivery is always very fast. Their beef noodle soup is my favorite in NYC, if you like a little spiciness in your noodle soup, then definitely give it a try. I also had their sesame pancake, spicy wonton, fried rice, they are all delicious. The price there is very reasonable as well.

This restaurant is probably the best kept secret of Austin Street. It's about a seven minute walk from the 71st Street subway station, five or so from the Forest Hills LIRR station, so it's well away from the throngs of people on Austin Street. It also does not even have a store front; it has a sign and the actual restaurant is about a 15 yard walk past where a normal restaurant's entrance would be.The place is well kept with a very spartan decor. It's also tiny, seating about 6 people at two tables and four at the bar. There is seating outside at two other tables, so it's the usual "great on nice days, not viable when it's cold or raining". Plus the LIRR is less than 10 yards behind the restaurant so when the trains go roaring by...I would definitely rank this as the best dim sum I've had in New York as far as overall quality. I've come across some other places in Flushing and Chinatown that come close, but I prefer this restaurant. The people making these tasty morsels are experts at their craft, for they are not some dough-heavy wads, nor are they so thin that they pop like a teenager's zit when you pick them up with your chopsticks. The steamed chicken dumplings with peanut butter are utterly heavenly, with a hint of said peanut butter, not a gummy and overpowering blob of it, the pork and vegetable wontons are are delicious, and the pork wontons in chili sauce have a nice kick to them. The beef noodle soup also really hits the spot, especially on a cold winter day.In summation, to say I'm a fan of this place is like saying water is wet, and I love the fact this place is about a three minute walk from me as of this update. If you want some great Chinese food for a good price and don't want to go scouring in Chinatown or Flushing, here ya go.

I really like memories of Shanghai.I have gone a few times and everything I have had has been good to very good.Soup dumplings are as good as I have had.  They finally started giving soup spoons with the soup dumplings!  I have to say my favorite thing has been the scallion pancake with beef.   You get two giant pancakes stuffed with beef and sauce that reminds me of Peking duck sauce.   It is out of this world.

Very solid Shanghainese restaurant in the FoHill neighborhood. Very refreshing and much needed, the location used to be a sushi restaurant. The food was very authentic and definitely comparable to Flushings Nanxiang or Shanghai You. The sweet tofu was extremely soft and tasty. Soup dumplings, what everyone comes here for was also solid. They didn't break too easily and had ample amounts of soup. Definitely give them a try!

Unsanitary and unsafe food practice. The food is not bad. Get the pan fried pork buns and steamed soup dumplings. PASS ON THE SCALLION PANCAKE WITH BEEF!!!!! Thank god I saw this after I finished my soup dumplings. Because they had onions, potatoes, and ginger under a dirty table next to the broom pan !! GROSS !!! The entrance is also very hidden and easily passed by. Also a lot of rukus inside the kitchen.

Finally came to this hole in the wall and it did not disappoint. For the soup dumplings, flavor was on point but the skin was faulty. Overly thick like joe's shanghai and they were so big, they were touching which caused them to stick to one another and break. Scallion pancake with beef was the best we've ever had! Size is smaller than usual but the skin was extra flaky and crispy with a generous amount of sauce. Beef Noodle soup was savory with just enough spice. Beef could've been a tad less chewy though. Prices are average and affordable.

Not Americanized Chinese food, which I really appreciate.The restaurant is small so I do not recommend large groups coming for a sit down and eat here. Groups of 1-4 will have the best chance of getting a seat. Everything here is made from scratch daily so you'll often find some dimsum menu items no longer available if you go too late in the day.Soup dumplings are pretty good here; skin is a bit thick for my liking, but not that much thicker than nan xiang's (which closed down T__T)I like the size of their menu and the fact that they're not trying to do too much.As for pricing, probably $1-$2 more than what it would cost in Flushing, but it saves me the trip. There is street parking available (metered & free after a certain time)

Tiny tiny place fits 12 ppl max elbow to elbow. Clean with good quality food. It's a residential neighborhood with little to none similar cuisine available. So expect waiting even if you like to pick up. I have visited 3 times and it haven't failed yet.

I expected chinese food around 71 continental to be american chinese food but this place is legit. I would say it is on par with food in flushing actually. The soup dumplings are full of juice, and the hot and sour soup has good ingredients in there.They are cautious to remind people that one of their sauces has peanut in it but if you're not allergic to peanuts, I would highly recommend the pork wonton in chili sauce (it isn't actually that spicy). If you want something soupy, pork wonton soup is also great.It is definitely quite a walk from where most of the shops are on Austin street though, but I drove so it didn't affect me. Ample parking where they are located usually since its far apart from the other shops.

Cuisine: 8Service: 9Decor: 6Value: 8Overall: 8I know it's cliché, but there is no better way to describe this newly opened restaurant than calling it a hole in the wall hidden gem. Formerly occupied by Tokyo Teriyaki, it literally is a tiny Shanghainese dim sum (snack) shop with two extra outdoor tables in an alleyway between the 108th police precinct and an underground parking lot. As for the gem part, let me explain.First of all, I am Shanghainese and my mom is a former dim sum chef in Shanghai, China. Therefore, my family likes to try every new Shanghainese dim sum restaurant that opens in NYC. Thankfully, this place is better than most in the five boroughs and it's minutes from my home.Instead of trying to do a million things, they were smart to stay away from too many cooked dishes and stuck with Shanghainese dim sim. Not everything is fantastic, but what is done well beats 90% of what's out there. My family's favorites are both soup dumplings, pan fried dumplings, sticky rice shaomai, radish puffs, and the awesome xie ke huang puff.The owner was the original head chef of the popular Shanghai You Garden in Flushing. They make everything daily fresh from scratch, and some of the items run out quickly. If you want something specific, you may want to call and order in advance. Not sure I should be sharing this tip since it might prevent me from getting what I want. Oh well! Enjoy!

Love that we don't have to trek to Flushing or further for soup dumplings! Our family decided to come try this place since there are no nearby Shanghainese cuisines in the area. It's a tiny place that looks the same as it's previous Tokyo Teriyaki occupant. We were able to get our stroller down as there were three tiny tables and bar seating. The outdoor space to dine is super cute at night. Pork soup dumplings - wasn't expecting much but this was good. Done to the way we love our dumplings - thin enough skin, great broth and good chunk of meat. So good, we ended up placing three orders total. Scallion pancake - another pleasant surprise. Great texture, crispy, and cut into cute tiny triangular pieces. Dipping sauce comes in a separate container. Pan fried seafood noodles - be careful because the lid can be hot! I managed to sting my hand trying to get this open due to the heat inside the container. Not your average presentation for pan fried noodles as the noodles weren't as crunchy as we expected but still good. Noodles decked out with sauce, scallops and vegetables. Not bad. Pan fried buns - this was delicious. We try this dish everywhere even though it takes a long time since it's freshly made. Super soft bread with a slight crunchy, seared bottom. The meat inside was just enough to eat with the carbs and nicely seasoned. Certainly a favorite of mine. Staff was friendly and helpful, especially when we were navigating the menu and figuring out what to get. Mad props for that fancy credit card machine where you can swipe or insert your card. Wasn't expecting that at all!Overall, this tiny place surpassed our expectations. Takeout is tough because you do want to eat it fresh while you can so I'm hoping they can expand some of their outdoor seating. The quality of the food is there and it is wonderful to have a Shanghai option in the neighborhood.

This location used to be a takeout sushi shop. They don't have a big dine-in area, as there are 2 tables outside and 12 crowded seats inside.The restaurant looks operated by a family from Shanghai. The staffs are friendly and the service is reasonably quick.I tried their steamed soup dumplings and pan fried buns. The soup dumplings were generally OK. The dough was thin enough but easy to get broken. The spoon they provided was just too small and kind of annoying. The pan fried buns did not meet the expectation, with too less soup inside.The pricing is 10-20% higher than Flushing, while tip is unnecessary. The good thing is they accept credit card.I'd say the food quality is not as good as their peers in Flushing, but they should have no problem to survive in Forest Hills, cause we don't have other authentic Shanghai restaurants in the neighborhood.

Had dinner at Memories Of Shanghai on Thursday night. The food is awesome, but the small indoor space made dining tough to enjoy.Quality: Delicious food. The only item I did not like was the Spring Rolls. The Steamed Soup Dumplings are fantastic, some of the best I have ever had. I also loved the Scallion Pancake With Sliced Beef. Tender meat and a wonderful patty. So much more to try on the menu, and from the crowd reactions everything is great.Quantity: Always tough to judge how much to get with dim sum. Don't be afraid to go up for more if you underestimate.Value: $6.25 for Steamed Soup Dumplings. $6.25 for Pan Fried Pork Buns. $4.25 for Spring Rolls. $6.55 for Pork Wonton in Chili Sauce. $5.55 for Scallion Pancake With Sliced Beef.Ambiance: Memories Of Shanghai is located on Austin Street in Forest Hills, but slightly off the main stretch. Down a small alley, they have an outdoor seating area, but it was too frigid to use on this evening. Instead everyone was packed into the small and tight indoor space. You will likely have to fight for a seat or get your meal to-go during standard meal times.Crowd: Small space with a lot of people. Probably better on warmer days and nights when the outdoor can be used.Service: Food comes out as ready. No table service, grab your meal at the counter.Parking: Right near the police station, so most of the street parking is taken up by police cars.

Memories Of Shanghai(MOS) is a great addition to Forest Hills.The menu here is a bit limited but satisfying.  MOS makes a great steamed pork soup bun which can't be found in the area less a drive/Uber to Flushing is available.  The bun wrappers are the right thickness, the soupy interior clean and the pork filling flavored packed.  It's a fantastic soup bun and a good hallmark for MOS.All the fried food is good.  It's a bit oily but just as much as it should be.  The pan fried dumplings are nice, the order I got didn't have a crispy bottom but the filling, the same as the soup bun, made up for the lack of crunch.  The scallion pancakes have a nice onion flavor.  The seafood pan fried noodles are similarly tasty, with diced scallops/squid, mini shrimp, bamboo shoots and flat beans all layered on top with the fried noodles underneath.Don't make the mistake of removing the spicy component of the beef soup noodles.  It's kinda bland without the spicy.The environment is an old dingy outpost for a takeout Japanese restaurant.  The inside is well lit and fresh which is a welcome sight compared to the old Japanese outpost.  They've added a table or two inside but the seating is really tight.  I wouldn't come here as a group for sure for fear of having to wait for a table.  They do have a table or two outside as well but when it gets cold it's going to be tough to sit outside.  Still, MOS is worth a visit, definitely grab the soup buns if you do.

This place is tiny but the flavor is mighty.  I have tried the food here twice and have had great experiences both times.  There are only a few tables and counter seating inside but there are a few tables outdoors in the ally.  This place is BYOB and if the outdoor seating is available, great with a small group so you can share different foods.  Most recently I got the crab soup dumplings which were spectacular.  We also got the pork shumai and fried pork bun, which I would happily order again.  The pork bun was a doughy soup dumpling.  The shumai was a perfect balance of rice and pork.  Everything came out steaming hot since it's freshly put together in the open kitchen.  This place definitely hits the spot if you're craving dumplings!

this place is a gem! best soup dumpling ever. the skin has the right thickness and it doesn't break that easily hence we can lift it up with chopstick with ease, but not too thick that it's still transparent enough for us to see the soup inside. the taste of the broth is amazing and the meat filling is so flavorful too! honestly we are so in love with the Shanghai xiao long bao. the pan fried dumplings are gold too! satisfying size and it has a crispy base. to my surprise it also has some sort of soup inside. the filling tastes great. I really enjoyed it toowe tried the stir fried rice cake, hakau (shrimp dumpling), and sweet tofu pudding as well. they were all good but to be honest not as exceptional. however the soup dumplings were so good I just had to round up my 4.5 to 5 stars. will definitley come back to try the other menu

...or as my wife would've put it "some memories should be left unturned".  I would be a little more charitable to it, but it's still not some place I want to come back to often.  This place used to be Tokyo Teriyaki until it closed down in 2018 (not surprising to anyone as the area around 112th precinct on Austin has limited foot traffic), and its claim to local fame were cheap fast teriyaki and spam musubi, both with the quality and care you expect from your local shopping mall food courts, which is to say, not much.  No one over the age of 18 was sorry to see that joint go, and both me and the missus was hoping that the space will be redeveloped into something not ridiculous (why would anyone consider running a restaurant in something as small as the Bluth frozen banana hut coupled with a massive and useless outdoor area situated behind the LIRR embankment without trees or awnings, really?).  But nope, someone decided to open up a soup dumpling place here - let the cringe begin.David K, the owner of the Bund (you know, the other Shanghaiese eatery with soup dumplings in Forest Hills, on Queens blvd near 67th) admitted to me recently in a well written comment on my review of their place - soup dumplings are a bit of a racket.  It's designed to extract higher profit margins from diners as it doesn't take much to make (as long as you master the techniques) and they usually sell at good prices (most of them are at least $1/bun) - it's tasty, but it's sucker food, much like garlic knots at pizza joints or dimsum at Cantonese restaurants.  As far as he is concerned, he doesn't mind people eating Soup Dumplings as it's more money in his pocket, but he also wants his diners to try the rarer, more difficult to make dishes (and I totally respect that), They also manage well - you can keep cranking them out when the day is slow, freeze them for storage, and they thaw and cook in about 10-15 minutes.  I recently developed a rather dim view on them - I call them banana soup knots (you know, because Bananas are how I refer to Chinese folks who are yellow on the outside, white on the inside and basic all over).  Bananas will go on and on about "XLBs" (what's that?  A trim level for their Acura MDX?  No, it's the pinyin abbreviation for xiaolongbao, or 小籠包...yeah, I know, Chinglish once again) like it's the rapture in their mouths.  Look, It's not like you cannot enjoy them, just remember that it's not the freaking avocado toast of Shanghaiese cuisine, that one-hit wonder that you stake the reputation of a restaurant upon.  God help me if I read one more review of someone at a Shanghaiese restaurant ranting nonstop about their soup dumplings, it's almost as inane as someone going to a pizzeria and raving about their mozzarella sticks and garlic knots. Okay, so rewind a bit and think about it.  You are in a tiny restaurant with 5 tables, their signature dish takes 10-15 minutes to make, they are awkward to eat during "run-n-gun" situations, you are planning to serve it at a tiny hovel with a ridiculously large outdoor eating area that (unless it's a mild day in Springtime/fall) is completely useless, and next to an embankment where the LIRR trains rush by every 7 minutes, kicking up dust and noise down below.  So yeah, welcome to the game of Forest Hills hot potato where you are eternally fighting for a table inside to eat your damned banana soup knots.  So yeah, how were they?  Quite good.  Decent skin, juicy interior, and with the usual ginger black vinegar, quite decent - assuming that you won the game of tables to snatch a place to eat.  It's everything else that's kinda "meh".  Their stir-fried rice cakes 雪菜炒年糕 contains edamame, shitake mushrooms, bamboo shoots and cured chinese mustard greens, and are considered a Shanghaiese staple dish.  When it comes to cooking rice cakes, it's difficult to stir fry them without going soft and sticking on the cooking surface.  The secret is to keep the heat high with a thin layer of oil on a non-stick surface, and to keep it stirring - preferably while a flavorful, slightly runny meat and veggie stir-fry is on the other pan, then combine before service.  The problem with Memories of Shanghai is that they got the hot oily part down by a massive overdose of hot oil, but then also went heavy on the sauce. All you taste is the greasiness and a massive hit of MSG, and you  taste it long after you leave the restaurant.  According to the missus, their wonton soup (上海餛飩) is kinda flavorless (and I agree) - and their chive dumplings 韭菜盒子 tastes only of oiliness and not much else.  So yeah, if I really have a hankering for banana soup knots...eh, fuck it.  I'll get Tibetan momos (since it's one express stop down in Jackson Heights), or I'll take the Q44SBS to Queensborough hill or Downtown Flushing for the joints there.  At least I can get other decent Shanghaiese dishes.

I ordered takeout on Yelp: scallion pancake with beef, Shanghai sticky rice shumai, pork wonton in chili sauce. The food was ready when I arrived 5-10 minutes early. The food was great. Leaning toward being heavily seasoned. The menu's harder to understand than most, but expect $15-20 per person for dinner. The restaurant is located in an alley, but it's not too hard to find if you look for the banner on Austin St.

This is the definition of a hole in the wall gem!  Quite literally located at the back of an alleyway, this is a must stop visit when in forest hills. Everything is made fresh so expect 10-15 for them to make and cook your dumplings etc. My personal favorite is the crab soup dumplings but honestly everything is tasty. Most dishes come with 4-6 items so you can taste a lot of the menu if you come with a group. The place appears to be family run and everyone in this small restaurant is very friendly. They have a few tables inside but if the weather is nice I recommend eating outside where there is much more space. We don't live close by but have been to Memories both times I have been in Forrest hills this year. Will be back!

There aren't that many Shanghai restaurants nearby so this place is god sent.  A lot in the menu is what my mom makes.  I like their soup dumpling but especially, I like their pan fried beef noodle.  The place is small but cute, but if you lIve nearby, they deliver!!!

This review is only for their take out. I had ordered on seamless, and took a quick walk to pick up. The food was already ready when I got there so it was quick and easy. The soup dumplings were good, but not great. The Seafood over crispy noodles were actually very disappointing. Since it's such a saucy dish, it would have been better to separate it from the noodle. The noodles were so soggy, and the flavor was so bland. I took about two bites and didn't even want to eat any further. I hesitate to go back, but maybe the sit in experience would be better with other items.

Read the NYT review of Memories of Shanghai and knew I had to go. Went for the first time this Sunday and almost walked right by because the restaurant is so tucked away. From the pictures this place looks small, but let me tell you, it is actually TINY! There is a counter that seats 4, another counter that seats 2 and 3 tables tops. There is seating outdoors for nicer weather to come. It seemed like a lot of people were ordering takeout because there was no place to sit. My friend and I arrived around 12:15 and ponied up to the bar. We ordered steamed pork dumplings, soup dumplings, scallion pancake, shrimp dumplings and some seafood noodles. My favorites were the dumplings - they were all quite tasty. This is an excellent alternative for people who live in Forest Hills and don't want to make the schlep to Chinatown. I was a little bummed they didn't have tea but the hot soy milk made up for it. Service was accommodating and friendly.

Great dim sum but this is probably a place better for take out than dine in. There are only 3 small tables and a counter. It's located off of Austin St further back.Food wise, the soup dumplings are legit and were tasty. I wouldn't say they are the best I've ever had but it's really good for not being in Flushing or Chinatown. One thing I really loved were the spicy wontons with peanut sauce. I've never had them with the peanut sauce before and it added a great flavor.

Updated review: I have no idea what they changed from the first time I got the soup dumplings here, but WOW! The soup dumplings were good before but now they're insanely amazing. My issue with this place now is consistency. Some days they deliver some days they don't. But what really got me was yesterday I called to see if they were doing delivery. They were. After placing my order, I was told that for delivery orders they only take cash. That makes 0 sense to me. I asked why and the woman said "just because"I don't understand this. If you take cards why wouldn't you take cards for delivery unless you're trying to limit your delivery services by saying this so less people ask for delivery. It's really odd to me since the two previous deliveries I had from them I paid by card

Yes the wait time for delivery is long (60 mins) but it is worth it. My husband loves the soup. The dumplings were also very good everything comes really warm and tastes fresh. Husband is dying to order the beef soup again.

Great soup dumplings and great hot soy milk. Great service on weekday. On weekend encountered arrogant clueless counter person who took order of later arriving person and paid no attention to us. We left without ordering. I've decided to forgive that one strange weekend slight5 stars is more reflective of the excellence ofI upgraded too quickly After doing so I ordered pan fried noodles with shrimp and vegetables. What I got: clump of fried noodles sitting in bowl of gravy, few tiny shrimp and few little pieces of vegetable... for $11.95Ridiculous

It's sooo small. Somehow we fit in with three adults, two kids, and a stroller. Eventually we were split between the "bar" and a table.The staff handles the crowd well, and people generally ate quickly to let other people waiting sit.I love their menu. The execution was mixed. Highlights were the hot soy milk, the soup dumplings, and the chicken dumplings.

This use to be the place I got my spam musubi. I feel bad giving it only three stars. My dad is from Shanghai and I'm  always looking for Shanghainese places to take him. I was told that the chef is from NanXing in Flushing so I had high expectations. The Xiao Long baos were pretty good but not the best I've ever had. The skin was a little thick but the meat was flavorful. The scallion pancakes were passable, not as crispy as I would have liked. The pan fried dumpling's skin was soft and doughy. The beef soup noodle didn't have a lot of beef and the noodles were mushy. Nothing was terrible and the price was right. But the food is slightly disappointing. We will probably go back to try the other offerings. If you are in the area, it's not a bad place to stop by for a cheap lunch.

Memories of Shanghai is a new member to the Forest Hills food scene taking over the former residence that Tokyo Teriyaki occupied for as long as I can remember (RIP). I had heard good reviews from friends about this place and decided to give it a try on a cold rainy night. I was craving soup so we ordered the Beef Vermicelli soup, Wonton soup, and scallion pancakes. Hardly tasting the menu at all, but the soups were very good.  My only complaint about the soup would be that they were a bit heavy handed with the seaweed in the wonton soup. The scallion pancakes were some of the best I have eaten, and believe me, I am a huge scallion pancake fan. Excited to try the soup dumplings as those are next on my list.

This place is literally a hole in the wall, as I barely found it on the street and had to walk down an alley to enter the side of a building.... but that's how some amazing places are located. We got the steamed soup dumplings, pans fried dumplings, and the vegetable potstickers. All 3 were different and really great. Moist, tasty, and cheap priced. Will be back again!

This place is legit! Their soup dumplings are so delicious and it is absolutely worth the wait. The staff is experienced and take their soup dumpling craft seriously. Amazing addition to the neighborhood and I hope they can expand their space someday! Highly recommend this place.

The hype is legitimate, and this purveyor of Shanghai style snacks has officially joined my list of best dumplings in the city, as well as my favorite establishment in Forest Hills (although sadly the latter statement isn't really saying that much IMO).  While the house specialties, the soup dumplings, both the crab and pork and straight up pork varieties, are very tasty indeed, my favorites here are actually the other dumplings on offer, particularly the Pan Fried Beef Dumplings.  They are just as succulent and nearly as juicy as those soup dumplings. so be prepared when biting in or you just may end up with a stained shirt!   Almost as delicious are the pan fried pork, with the quite tasty steamed chicken curry and shrimp dumplings coming in right behind them on my list.  Just don't go in here expecting Chinatown-cheap prices or you'll be jolted with some serious sticker shock.  Despite being located this far out east in Queens the prices are fairly in line with, or even upwards of what I have come to expect in the gentrified, updated "artisanal" dumpling shops in the chic-er parts of BK and Manhattan, like (my beloved) East Wind Snack Shop in BK or Mimi Cheng's in Manhattan, around 8 bucks an order of dumplings.  But, hey this is no doubt at least in large part due to the use of more premium ingredients, and again the dumplings are damn delicious so stop whining that they aren't a buck an order or just go eat some lesser dumplings.....

Fairly new spot in Forrest Hills. It's a very small spot in the back with two seats inside and a small outside seating outside. Even though this place is small, the good is very good. My favorite is the seafood pan fried noodles and the pork soup dumplings. Everything they make is on point I don't have any complaints here. Just make your way here and order some food to go. You won't be disappointed.

Took out didn't eat in. Maybe it's better if you eat there and it just doesn't travel well. We picked up soup dumplings that were too doughy and chewy. Pan fried noodles that were too soggy and scallion pancake with beef that was too greasy. Obviously no comparison on Nan Xiang in flushing or Joe's shanghai any location. However, it's nice to know it's here we have cravings that can't be satisfied. Maybe we willeat in next time. The place is tiny btw.

My fiancé and I placed an order for pick up on Friday night. We ordered in person and had to wait for about 20 minutes so next time we know to call ahead. We ordered a few different dumplings including the soup dumplings and pork buns, which were our top favorites. Everything was so fresh and delicious. We will definitely be trying their other menu items in the near future.

Thankful to have a soup dumpling place in FH. The food here is good but not as good as places in Flushing but definitely not bad at all! We ordered take-out- two types of soup dumplings, beef noodle soup, and scallion pancakes. Scallion pancakes were A+!! Beef noodle soup was decent but not the best I've had. The soup dumplings are a sticky business with delivery because obviously they stick together and burst open. The skin was okay- a little thick and I wish the soup flavor was better. Overall though, I would come back if I was super desperate for soup dumplings but too lazy to go to flushing.
review remains the same...adding photos from my visit

Really small "hole in the wall" restaurant.  They have two tables, and a counter, but I think when the weather is nice, they have some tables outside.  Not a great place for a large dinner party, but if you're a couple or eating alone, it's great.  I'm sure delivery is fine as well.The food is great.  I was introduced to Soup dumplings for the first time ever and they are delicious.  Definitely a new favorite of mine.  Dumplings, soups, and scallion pancakes made and cooked fresh.  I really enjoyed the food here, and would definitely come again.  This place also accepts Apple Pay, which is always a bonus.

This opened after the other place closed and I have to say this food is amazing. It's a small hole in the wall but I would say that if you can come here when it's not crowded it's the best dumplings you'll have in this area. This is walking distance to my apartment and the food is amazing. Had panfried dumplings and the soup dumplings are also great. Tastes fresh and prices are reasonable.

I was excited to try this new Forest Hills spot. We ordered a few dumplings, scallion pancakes, and pan fried noodles to get a taste of everything! It's the perfect spot to grab a snack or a light meal.Scallion pancake with sliced beef is a must try. The outside is crispy and it had just enough hoisin sauce.The steamed chicken dumplings (curry with minced onion) has such a unique flavor. We also tried the Sticky Rice ShaoMai, which I didn't like the texture of it. BYOSDS: Bring your own soup dumpling spoons! They provide small plastic ones but the soup from the dumpling doesn't fit. The soup dumplings (pork and crab) were good, but I didn't enjoy seeing the fat in the soup.Oh and the seafood and vegetable pan fried noodles lacked seafood and veggies. Stick to the dumplings and snack items!

Very good soup dumplings. I also ordered the beef curry soup which I enjoyed with a little bit of chili oil. I have had soup dumplings all over nyc and these are definitely my favorite, which is great because it's close to home.
Excellent xiaolongbao, plus they have youtiao with sweet soy milk which I struggle to find, and also jiu nang which is an amazing treat.
Great Shanghainese food. Love the noodles and vegetable dumplings. Very friendly service. Authentic. Will definitely return.

5 STAR PORK DUMPLINGS! And a lot of other great dishesThe place is a small room in the back of a large building. Not really a place to sit down and eat dinner on a date. But the food is fantastic! Great for take out or delivery.

Food is usually good.Except fried rice (very bland) Chive pancake and radish puff tastes freshly made.Delivery literally takes ages. Do not order while you are already hangry. Points deducted mainly because of the delivery service.

Went to get the salty soft tofu pudding and it was delicious! Really yummy flavor and perfect as a little snack. The place is clean and the people are friendly. Would recommend and a great addition to the neighborhood.

I love this place. I miss tokyo teriyaki. But this place is a solid replacement. I wish the menu were a little more expansive and they had a solid dinner dish that I could always go to. Instead I settle for one order of soup dumplings and some scallion pancakes which is pretty close to a meal. I hope one day they expand a little to something more hearty. In any case the people working there are lovely and always very courteous. I'll be a frequent customer for the forseeable future.
Favorite Soup Dumpling place! Everything on their menu is Delish!! Pork soup dumplings are the best, The spicy beef soup with bok choy one of my favorites as well, also the scallion pancake Yumm

As a Shanghai native, I approve this place!A few things are REALLY good. The soup dumplings, spring rolls, shaomai, wontons are amazing! Salty tofu pudding (which is quite hard to find) are really really delicious and authentic as well - they remind me of my childhood. The rest of the menu items, of course the ones I have tried, were decent, but not out of this world. This place is really a neighborhood gem. It's a shorter trip compared to flushing, and satisfies my craving for nostalgic flavors.

This place is just amazing. It's a tiny little place and doesn't seem like it would be much but holy amazing soup dumplings. We order at least once a week now and everything we have tried has been delicious. I swear I dream of these dumplings. Delivery has been super fast through seamless (even when it says it should take an hour it usually arrives in 15-20 minutes). My favorite place in Forest Hills, hands down.

Forest Hills is finally becoming a place to get authentic and interesting food (I've always walked by TGIFriday's wondering 'what is wrong with you people?' But, alas, the hood is changing!Memories of Shanghai has become my go to spot for when I don't want to go to Flushing. The food is delicious - yes, the soup dumplings are wonderful, but so is just about everything else that I've tried so far. The service is great too, everyone there is very nice and helpful. The space is tiny, so expect a wait even on a cold, rainy night, although I'm looking forward to warmer weather so that we can sit outside.All in all, a great addition to Austin Street.
Went on the advice of a family member. The braised beef noodle soup was delicious. Steamed pork dumplings....AMAZING!  I shall return!
I never give 5 stars unless I've eaten there more than once. I took food to go and I have to say it was amazing !!! Really hit the spot - tasty

One of the best kept secret in queens.  Really yummy Shanghai soup dumpling and scallion pancake.  Noodle dishes were so so.  Taro cake bun is a must to try. Not too sweet.  Reasonable prices.  Very limited seating.

My biggest problem with this place is a health department concern. Even if food tastes good I am a bit worry when I come to order and find two employees sleeping on the tables. One behind counter and the other where we eat...the others are all on their phone. first it's disgusting, unsanitary  second is how inhuman to keep tired staff in without anyone. What about things we do not see...seems like there is a lot of neglect and This is a shame!  This needs to change so we can keep going there! It is worrisome I have pictures I will post

Just ordered (and devoured) a huge order of delivery from this place, and we were honestly floored. Food arrived well ahead of schedule and was piping hot, and everything was absolutely delicious. Shanghai beef noodle was delicious and spicy while still being flavorful: we ordered three kinds of dumplings and each was delicious and obviously handmade. The star of the show was the pea shoots with garlic. I could easily eat my weight in this. As someone who writes about four reviews a year, I highly recommend this place. Go go go.

Incredibly tiny hole-in-the-wall kind of place that is far greater than it may appear at first. Two tables plus a few counters available inside, but their is extra seating outside in the alleyway by the door. I am fairly inexperienced with this kind of food, but the steamed chicken dumplings were incredibly good, by far the best I've ever had to this point. My girlfriend and I ate a good sized meal for 20 bucks including drinks, so it doesn't seem to break the bank either. Only thought I had was you may not like eating inside of you want good conversation, as another party will probably be right on top of you. That tiny nitpick aside, would highly recommend this place!

Saw that this place had great reviews so I decided to give it a try. The place is very small two tables with two seats and four seats. I ordered the Vermicelli curried beef soup, pan friend noodle with beef along with two dumpling orders , steamed soup dumplings with crab and steamed chicken dumplings. The curried beef soup had a good flavor... very fresh tasting with lots of cilantro. I added hot oil to it to give it a kick of spice which made it even better. The dumpling were the best. If were to return I would order more of the dumplings. For dessert I ordered the hot soy milk and a few pastries. I wouldn't recommend the pastries I suggest getting dessert elsewhere.

There is only one picture of the interior. You know why? Because they have on 10 places to sit. Four at the counter and maybe a tight six at two tables. And I took a car there only to find there is no place to sit.So I cannot comment on the food. Then I took a car home. It was a joke. And the joke was on me.

Soup dumplings, sticky rice shumai, radish puffs, sesame puffs, and all the other things I've had here that I do not remember, were excellent. Living in Forest Hills, not too bad after all when summed up with these good dim sum dishes.

This is my new go-to spot in Forest Hills for soup dumplings when I don't want to make the trip to Flushing. I came here 3 months ago when they first opened, service was slow, the staff was not familiar with the menu, and there was a language barrier. I've been back twice since then, and the service has improved a good deal. The food here has been consistently good. The soup dumplings are perfect - thin skin, with just the right amount of meat, and flavorful broth. I love their piping hot sweet tofu pudding, although when I first went there, they didn't have the syrup and just served it with sugar crystals. They have salty tofu pudding as well. I also really like their beef noodle soup, a large bowl of deliciousness!

I had the chicken soup dumplings. I really loved it!! But wasn't a fan of the inside but ate the soup and dumplings. The scallions pancakes were really good not greasy like most places. I'm definitely going back to try the noodles.

Disappointing. We had heard so much about this place but the food did not hold up. Soup dumplings much better at Joe's Shanghai. Scallion pancakes also not up to par. The noodle dish was also very average. Probably won't go back with seats at a premium anyway.

My favorite soup dumpling place! What makes their soup dumpling top notch is the clean and rich broth inside. Other highly recommend items: their shrimp dumplings, chive pancakes, and fried dumplings. If you like soup dumplings, this place is a must try!

Sneeze and you would miss it.  The small sign and side entrance make this place easy to miss.  Best soup dumplings I've had since Joe Shanghai in Flushing.  The scallion pancakes and pea shoots in Garlic sauce were also delicious. I gave it 5 stars even though there is minimal seating space but the prices and the friendly staff more than made up for having to wait a few minutes.  Enjoy!

I've got one word for this place -- meh! The dumpling aren't the worst I've ever tasted and it's definitely enough to satisfy the dumpling craving without going to Flushing. I got 1 order each of the pork dumplings and soup dumplings.Both types of dumpling were too doughy for my tastes. The pork in the  pork dumpling was succulent and juicy. While the soup in the soup dumpling was rather fatty and thick and the meat inside was super mushy (not a fan). The soup they give for service (I assume is the beef noodle soup?) was gelatinous and sour tasting. I had to throw it away immediately. With just the dumplings alone though, I could not finish them and was super full. Service was super slow too. I had to wait around 40 minutes to get my two orders. This place is not that bad, but it's not good either. No other places that serve dumplings in the nearby forest hills area has anything better or fresher than Memories of Shanghai. And it's definitely better than the sushi restaurant it replaced.

So delicious! Loved the soup dumplings and other dumplings as well. I'm just worried once winter hits and there is no seating. While this can definitely be a take out place - soup dumplings don't travel well. Staff is clearly new but very sweet. I'm excited for this restaurant and I hope it does well!

This place is very small but the food is good. I like their Shanghai Steam Soup Dumpling, it's is very juicy with very thin wraps. The Sweet Tofu Pudding has very fine texture and not too sweet. If you are like me, don't like very sweet dessert, this is perfect for you. I am a bit disappointed about their Beef Soup Noodle, its a bit bland. The Pork & Veggie Wonton Soup is good. Soup base has seaweed in it which I love.But this place is really too small, you should not go with a group. A few tables outside is good for summer eat-out but it's too cold to eat outside in winter. Whatever food I eat, I never like take out because food will not taste the same if you take it to go. I waited a while to get seats at the bar and saw a lot of people take theirs to go.I'll give 4 stars because this place is just way too small. However I will still go back and try other dishes.​

An unexpected delight.  We have been coming back once a week.   The soup dumplings are a must along with scallion pancakes.   The noodle dishes are also good.   Good quality food and friendly service.  Will be back to try the beef noodle soup and other puffed items.

Came here for lunch and it was absolutely Amazing! I went back the day after! Their soup dumplings are probably one of the best I've had. Normally other places make it a bit too greasy for me but this place has such a fresh taste. Also I saw two ladies making it fresh in the ordering area, really nice to see.The area is a bit small but I appreciate that. It has that authentic small eatery experience. Love it love it love it! 100000% recommend!
Amazing food / service.The staff is very friendly. The food brings me back when I visited Shanghai and had similar dishes. Happy customer.

Very small place, but clean and not noisy. Very delicious soup dumplings and spring rolls. Fast service. Stuff little slow but I think it's because they got this new cash register that they have to use to. Would visit again, delicious food)
It located next to the police station in the forest hills. The place is very small but homey. Food is made is fresh on the premises, so it might take a little longer when it is busy.

You'll probably walk past it a few times before you'll see the flag at the beginning of the alley. At the end of the alley there's a door to the left. That's the place! Inside you'll find a tiny space with a few tables, some counter space and seating for around 14(?). Small space but BIG flavors. When I went there were about six people, all busy at their tasks to make this machine operate. Go straight to the counter and place your order. Service was fast and polite. The Xiao Long Bao were my favorite! The skin was thick enough to prevent breaking while transferring to your spoon and the broth was clean and flavorful. We also had Pork Wonton in Chili Sauce (with a peanut sauce on top), Sticky Rice ShaoMai (with mushroom) and Pan Fried Pork Buns. Oh, while it's not on the menu, the have hot and sour soup. If you live close by just grab your stuff and enjoy it at home with tea or a cold beer.

While trying to cheer my niece up, we found this restaurant hidden off of Austin Street. At first I was curious all my friends know me I am the adventurous one when it comes to trying new restaurants. So my first thing to try was their wontons with chili sauce. It was amazing the wonton were soft and smooth texture, the sauce was the right blend of spices. The next try was the soup dumplings talk about me loving them the right amount filling to soup ratio. They are soo good. My friends and I have made it our official dumpling spot.

Amazing dim sum!! I wish I had taken a picture but I die right in. Order the T1 and T2 pork and crab respectively. Amazing! Next is the scallion pancake with beef. Nice to know it's in the neighborhood.
Just read the nytime's article and we had to try them. The dumplings were super tasty and the sauce was a perfect pairing. Will definitely go again... finally a dumpling joint in Forest Hills.
Really cute hidden jem. Great soup dumplings. Place is very small so not good for big crowds. They do have an outdoor area when the weather starts getting nicer. Would recommend.

Very authentic and excellent Shanghainese alley dishes (弄堂菜). We came based on a NYT article and ordered soup dumpling, fried rice cake with preserved vegetable, sticky rice shaomai, wonton soup, and radish puffs. All were very good. The place is literally in an alley with limited seating. This place is geared for takeout orders including their utensils but to do justice with the freshness of order-to-cook dishes like soup dumpling and fried rice cake, I suggest you eat there.

SO excited to see this place open in Forest Hills! Great soup dumplings and pan fried pork dumplings. The pork dumplings had just enough chew to them. Delicious!  I also ordered the seafood pan fried noodle which were tasty and had tiny bits of black mushroom, bay scallops, tiny shrimps, bamboo shoots, peapods and baby calamari. I wish they would up it a notch and have large pieces of seafood and charge more. They have the flavors down but not making it restaurant quality. We also had spring rolls and they were good, but a bit greasy. I'm looking forward to trying some other items from the menu like the beef vermicelli soup and pan fried pork buns. It's a really tiny place hidden down an alley, but super clean and has inside and outdoor seating. They have only been open one month and will deliver in the future. I'm a fan so far!

This is a cute restaurant in Forest hills. Was difficult to find the first time I came. Very tiny restaurant inside but there are tables outside, but not preferable during the winter time. Very kind service and food was good too!

Husband and I arrived around 5:30/6:00pm to a full house, full house being three tables. We waited a little longer than I cared to as the lady was dealing with a phone/ delivery order gone awry. We placed our order after she sorted that out and waited only a little while longer for our food. We ordered baby wontons that turned out to be bigger than expected. The skin was also thicker than is traditional but it tasted like my childhood. We also got soup dumplings, also thicker skinned than is traditional but the taste is there. Husband also got the beef noodle soup which he ordered spicy (which was a mistake) and a hot and sour soup that he praised highly. Last thing we ordered is the turnip pastry which is better than some other places we've had (also larger in size). The price is cheap but not dirt cheap. They may be located in an obscure corner of my parents' neighborhood but they get swamped with delivery orders. Make sure to go slightly before the dinner rush otherwise you might have to wait. The taste might not be as authentic as my parents remember their childhood to be but it certainly hit the spot and taste good enough to me, even if the skin of both the baby wontons and the soup dumplings is too thick. We'll be back to visit next week when we visit my parents again!

It's a 4.5 star but I'll leave it at 5 since you can't do half star. Soup dumplings taste great. Pancakes are good. Been here couple of times and tried a number of dishes there and really liked it a lot. The half star deduction is for the thick dumpling skin- I like it thin. This is one of my fav in Forest Hills area. To other reviewers- I don't recommend delivery because fresh hot dumplings won't taste as good esp. soup dumplings and if there is something missing..most likely it's because delivery guy took it. I heard a few customers never got their delivery at other restaurants- prob delivery guy ate it.
Horrible delivery. Missing one dish and they can't find my address even though I ordered through Grubhub??? Then they tell me that the missing dish will take an hour???? Ridiculous!

Super eager to find authentic Chinese regional cuisines in Forest Hills, I arrived at Memories of Shanghai for the classic Shanghai dishes - Xiaolongbao, Shengjian (fried dumplings) and rice cakes. Happy with all three and would have been happy if this had been served in any Shanghainese restaurants outside of Shanghai in China. That says a lot I think. ;) Welcome to the neighborhood! And keep up the good work!!!

I didn't have high hopes for good Shanghainese in Forest Hills, after many people recommended the Bund and I found it terrible (in terms of taste, quality and service). I simply thought: people in FH have very low standards for Chinese food. When I was told to try Memories, I kept putting it off. I finally went by for a sitdown meal on a Sunday afternoon. It was cold and rainy, and lots of people came in expecting to eat in but realized there were no tables/seats left and were forced to order takeout or abandon mission. I was arrived early enough to grab a table for three. I'm pescatarian, so I was limited quite a lot considering there's a lot of pork in Shanghainese food. I ordered the chive pancakes, because they sounded the most similar to chive/egg fried buns that I usually get at other Shanghainese places. It turns out the chive pancakes are essentially the buns I'm used to, except flattened. They are more like a stuffed flat bread, not like a scallion pancake. They arrived hot and crunchy, and tasted great, but I imagine they would get soggy and chewy if ordered as takeout or delivery. I also got the fried rice cakes with pickled cabbage, which is my usual fried rice cake dish. This one tasted great - lots of flavor, edamame and cabbage, unlike the Bund's version, which was bland and was mostly fried cake, few veggies. This one tastes even better with the chili oil on the tabletops. My friends ordered the regular pork soup dumplings and the crab soup dumplings, as well as the pan fried dumplings and the chili wontons. They liked all of their food, but especially liked the soup dumplings (both kinds). I am really pleased there is a LEGIT Shanghainese place in FH, and I sincerely hope they expand seating (or at least get a canopy for the outdoor area, as Tokyo Teriyaki previously had) and work out their kitchen kinks. During my visit, they gave my friends two regular soup dumplings instead of what they ordered, and when this was brought to their attention, we watched as the family working the kitchen then blamed each other for the mistake. They ended up giving my friends the crab soup dumplings they ordered, so my friends got two orders of regular soup dumplings as well as the crab one. It seems like they have a lot of staff helping but not efficiently.
Best dumplings in Queens in my opinion. Order ahead for pickup because the space is really small and you don't want to be waiting around awkwardly.
Yum yum yum! Love the soup dumplings and the noodles! It's so great to not have to travel to Flushing or Elmhurst to get a taste. It's a tiny place

I've been here several times. Sometimes it's a little hectic/hot mess because it's so small inside, but the taste of the food makes up for it. Their soup dumplings are very good. I'm not crazy about their beef noodles but that's not the main attraction here anyway.

As originally from Shanghai, food here are pretty authentic, the owner and chef speak Shanghainese, which brought back my childhood memory every time I eat there. I took one star off because of the pan fried pork bun, this is totally not authentic. But the thing is I couldn't find anywhere in North America that have authentic Pan fried pork bun. Other than that, food are great and good to eat at the patio in summer.
The soup dumplings were some of the best tasting dumplings I've ever had!! I highly recommend the purple yam buns as well!!
Can't complain. Never had such fresh dumplings in my life. 100% beats dollar dumplings in the Lower east side! will be coming back!!!

NYC is a tough restaurant market; the first year survival rate is often reported as low as 20%. Memories of Shanghai (MOS) has only been open for 4 months as of Jan 2019 and is off to a good start. Xueling Zhang's family made some smart choices.First, the location is on the less developed western end of Forest Hill's Austin Street in a little alley next to the NYPD's 112th Precinct, meaning the real estate is likely affordable.Second, they are starting small. The entire restaurant might charitably seat 12 people in the couple of tables and wall bar. There is almost as much kitchen as there is seating. There appears to be outdoor seating, so accommodations will be better in the warmer months.Third, they have a relatively limited menu considering the wide variety of possible Shanghainese dishes. Initially specializing in dumplings is logical from both a dine-in & take-out/delivery perspective.Choosing the soup dumplings (6) and pan fried pork buns (4) as a litmus test for the talents of the chef, revealed nuanced choices of ingredients & excellent execution of these Shanghai classics.In soup dumplings or XLB, three parts must be balanced together: the wrap, the fill & the juice. Each soup dumpling forms it's own little pressure cooker as they steam away in the paper lined bamboo container; too much wrap means less juice, too little wrap or too much meat means a soggy mess, the wrong balance of meat to filler means less flavor, etc.  MOS served perfectly formed soup dumplings that held together when lifted from the steamer; they got the critical  balance right. The meat mix of pork and aspic was acceptable & yielded a rich and flavorful soup. There did not appear to be any vegetable filler/binder. The wrap didn't absorb too much juice (freshly served of course) and had a pleasant firm chewiness. Best XLB ever? Well no, but certainly flavorful, exceptionally well executed & worth the price.The pan fried pork buns were a tad on the oily side, but were also well made and flavorful. This bun appears to start with a similar pork filling as the soup dumpling but wrapped in a rising (ie yeast based) dough bun that is reminiscent of steamed roast pork bbq buns.  The cooking technique for this style bun seems 2-fold. They are first steamed to cook the pork and raise the dough, then fried until the bottom is golden brown.  This combination yields a crunchy first bite with the softness of the raised dough and savory meat filling (where some of the juice has absorbed into the soft dough). The sensation was like a toasted bagel with the crunchy exterior & soft, chewy interior.MOS is a good choice for a quick bite to eat & I look forward to trying some more of their dishes in the future! Based on the smart choices they've made so far, I'm predicting long term success if they keep executing their food at this level.
Food was tasty overall. Certain dishes were a bit on the salty side..but still worth a try! Nice and friendly staff made it a nice experience. Will definitely visit again!!

This new place opened up in the old Tokyo Teriyaki space on Austin Street. Finally!! A good Chinese restaurant in Forest Hills! There has been a dearth of good Chinese food ever since Mama Liang's closed. This is a small spot and the menu is limited but what is available is great! Today we tried the Shanghai soup dumplings, soup dumplings with crab, beef noodle soup, pan fried noodles, scallion pancakes, and fried rice cakes with pickled vegetables.  The pan fried noodles were supposed to come with seafood but when the chef heard me say my daughter likes beef, he was able to accommodate! And when I said the beef noodle soup was for my son, he toned down the spiciness. The soup dumplings were juicy and not greasy. The noodles were crispy and the gravy was flavorful. The beef that came with the noodle soup was tender and not difficult to chew like other places. Scallion pancakes were crispy and not greasy. We're so happy this is here. This isn't your typical takeout place! We'll be here often and can't wait to try the other items on the menu!

Crab and pork soup dumplings - made by same chef who worked at Joe Shanghai so you know they're good Rice cakes with pickled vegetables- perfect consistency Pork wontons in chili sauce and peanut sauce - you know when it's too spicy but you can't stop eating it because it's so good? That's this Chive pancakes - my least favorite but still good flavor Tofu with sweet ginger sauce - not a lot of gingery taste but could be because it was the bottom of their last batch Total: $35 !!Can't wait to come back and try more!
Food was ok, nothing wow tho. Very small space as well so not ideal for larger groups, great if you wanna just have a quick bite and keep it moving.

Oh yeah, the world's best soup dumplings are not across the street from my apartment! I'm a HUGE fan of Joe's Shanghai and the chef from Joe's opened Memories. So, Ali ordered were the crab soup dumplings but they didn't disappoint. Same soft tender dumpling, same exquisite broth. I can't wait to sample the rest of the menu.
I'm so glad we have a good dim sum place in Forest Hills! The pan fried dumplings were especially delicious. I'll definitely be adding this to my list of regular dining spots.

I'm hesitant to rate this place because I want to keep it quiet and unknown but to be fair, it's a hidden gem in Forest Hills. It's really great to not have to go to Flushing every time for soup dumplings.

Food is very authentic and really great,  hands down!However, A Chinese lady who works as a cashier is very cold. Very rarely saw her smile. Her attitude is not very welcoming. Besides that, this is a great place for take out as long as you neglect her cold attitude.....

We love their soup dumplings, shao long bao!  Very happy that it's so close to our home,  The scallion pan cakes are also very tasty, with or without beef.  When you're craving the soup dumplings in Forest Hills/Rego Park this is where you go.  Thanks for your kind and quick service, we will be back soon.  Best of luck all!

Really good authentic Shanghainese classics.I'm so happy a place like this opened in the neighborhood. Place is small but the food is what matters. It's a small mom & pop family run business and they're really nice. We've had the xiao long bao, beef noodle soup, vegetable potstickers, and scallion pancakes. All delicious. Looking forward to trying the rest of the menu.Cons: waiting for the food takes a while whether it is to stay or to go. Also, almost everything is disposable from the dishes, noodle bowls to chopsticks, bowls, and cups. Not good.

Hole in the wall Shanghai spot is much needed in this area. You order and pay and food is brought. We ordered the soup dumplings, wonton in chili sauce and scallion pancake with sliced beef. Out of the 3, didn't find the wontons anything special but soup dumplings tasted like every other place and the scallion pancake was a great thickness and texture. There's about 6 table seating and 4 countertop as well as two outdoor tables. No free water unfortunately. Decently priced for the quantity and this area I suppose.
I come from shanghai. This is really a suprise! The dumpling is the best! Fried rice cake is very good too. I'll come again!

Great dumplings!
