The decor give you a feeling of ocean/boat type of feeling, it's was very clean and didn't have a Fishy type of smell. Also it isn't very big it's more of an intimate settings. For an appetizer I order the Catfish strips that came with fries, a corn salsa, and tarter sauce. The catfish was omg good, nice and crunchy. The fries had an authentic taste as if they used a secret seasoning, the corn salsa with fresh and had an little spice to it. For my entree I had one of the seafood combo's, which included snow crab legs, shrimp, corn on the cob, & red potatoes with the garlic butter sauce. My friend had the crawfish & snow crab legs and shrimp combo with the spicy garlic. I swear that garlic butter sauce was the best I ever tasted. I swear I wanted to take some of the garlic sauce home. The shrimp & snow crab leg combo was $35.00, definitely worth the price considering the serving sizes. I enjoyed the food so much I came back a few weeks later with my mom, sister, Aunt, & niece. Who enjoyed it as much as I did.
Everything was good about this restaurant. From the food, the drinks and the customer service. The long trip was worth it.

The food was so good and I enjoyed it so much! Beginning, the environment of the restaurant had a really calm and relaxed vibe. We ordered crab cakes which came with fries and the crab cakes were delicious and you could really taste the crab. Also, the garlic noodles were to die for!

Our only regret is not coming here before now. We've been missing out!Only downsides: 1) Acoustics are really loud, so inconsiderate parties like the one next us, make it very hard to hear each other and my ears are ringing, but the 90's R&B and hip hop help make up for it. 2) I'm a bit of a tree-hugger and can't help but have a heavy conscience about all the plastic waste (bags, bibs, cups; also all the rubber gloves, which are nonetheless brilliantly useful). But the food is OUTSTANDING!!!

I went here once I loved the shrimp and the crab legs. Price is reasonable. The staff is friendly and very attentive. My favorite is the sauce. The oceanic sauce is very good. Especially spicy. I was super happy when I found out they do home delivery. If you are looking for a night in food or don't want to eat anything heavy before a big night out. This is the best place to go to.
Went there for the first time and it was great! The wait was not too long and the staff was very helpful! The Mac and cheese appetizer is delicious! Music is nice too!Will definitely be going back!
Extra spicy sauce with old bay was really good! Picked it up on the way from work, very good and very fresh. Only thing is the need for more corn in the boil because it was so good!
It was okay. I have had better.. didn't like their side dishes or other entrees... it's good for one time try. But very cheap compared to other places.

In search of clam chowder close to our hotel and we found it.  It was a yummy chowder!Cajun Mac and cheese was very cheesy usually they are not cheesy enough.Calamri was nicely spiced!Fish taco...ok that was the one piece I didn't care for.Fries Cajun I wish I had back homeClam chowder I really miss!Staff was attentive and the place had nice decor.  Not to far from the subway and in a safe area.

The place is very dim with the lighting the chairs are very uncomfortable . Upon your arrival they bring you a cup of water nothing else on the house !  I ordered the coconut shrimp which comes with fries , the shrimp had to much breading the fries were to spicy .  We also ordered some chicken wings I did not like the weird taste ! My boyfriend ordered the salmon it came with sautéed spinach , it was just ok . We had two drinks from the bar , I had a apple martini , the worse martini ever . Overall due to the hard seats alone I will never return , Sorry !

Good food. I only sipped on my mom's daiquiri but it was good. We had lobster shrimp and crab legs spicy and lemon pep. It was not overly garlicky like other places (not too far away ) im all about the crab so it was awesome for me nice fresh snow crab legs that were not small or dried out. Parking is horrible

Overall pretty good! I thought the snow crab meat was a bit too salty on its own that you can taste the sweetness of the meat. However, the saltiness with the sauce and a bit of white rice was such a good combo. The Dungeness crab was perfectly cooked though be ready to "clean" it since it's a whole attached crab.

Came here with my wife and a friend on 8/5/18.  The food was excellent.  The Oceanic sauce is the closest thing to the sauce "The Boil" makes, very flavorful, not overly salty.We sat at the bar and one of the owners spoke to us throughout the night even though it was insanely busy.  He joked with us and provided us with some Pina Colata for free.I would definitely come back again.

Place wasn't big but we got seats, got lobster and crawfish spicy, shrimp and crawfish mild, snow crab legs and shrimps spicy, 2lb shrimps spicy all in lemon pepper sauce, fried catfish, a strawberry and a mango daiquiri made from sake.  I like this place a lot, the sauce is thick and VERY flavorful. Lobster was sweet and juicy, I personally think crawfish wasn't worth the money because there wasn't much to eat. Catfish wasn't overly greasy or battered and the drinks were delicious, forgot the price but it was cheap! Staffs were working hard and super friendly. For sure coming back!!

I decided to give this place a try out of curiosity. The staff is wonderful, especially since they seem to be doing multiple jobs (bar, wait staff, and bussing tables). Also, They give a toothpick/fork contraption that helps you get the meat out of the crab legs. I chose the garlic butter sauce and it was alittle salty. My lemon drop martini was ok. All in all, it's a convenient  spot located in queens if you don't want to travel to the city or city island for your seafood craving.

Came here off a friend's suggestion to experience the cheaper end of the  popular seafood spot in the city called the "The Boil"...The place is small but spacious. Really simple but appreciative oceanic themed. Seats are made of metal and uncomfortable due to being tiny and bare metal. Staff were very friendly and helped us first-timers choose off the menu. She also gave us two sauces on the side to try first before choosing. We ordered the crawfish and shrimp combo... This was my time trying crawfish. It was tiny and had pretty much no meat. So half the entree was a waste of money, but nothing to blame them for. The shrimps were sizable and fair amount. Unfortunately even though they were smothered pretty well, the sauce didn't seemed to stick and even tasted lighter / less flavorful. To make things worse, the gloves they provided smelled and everytime my hand came close to my mouth I lost my appetite because of it. In the middle of our eating, the waitress asked how things were and to give her honest reviews on the spot. So I mentioned everything lol. All in all, it's a great idea and addition to the neighborhood but for my first time here im disappointed. Worth a try. P. S - don't get crawfish! Unless you're a crawfish lover, and if you are, crawl back fish.

So me and my buddy try out Oceanic Boil for the first time. Its Wednesday night and the place is packed. After about a 15 minute wait we are seated. We orderd the shrimp basket as an appertizer and my buddy ordered a lemonade cocktail. The shrimp basket (about 8 small shrimp with spicy fries) came out in a reasonable time . Nothing special about the shrimp. Actually the fries were better than the shrimp...Im not much of a seafood person so I ordered the Angus steak(medium) with sauteed spinach. My buddy ordered a whole lobster and crab legs, which came with potatoes and corn on the cob. After finishing the shrimp basket my buddy informed the waiter that he was still waiting on his drink. After about another 7 minutes ny buddy recieved his drink. My steak dinner came out first, I figured his seafood meal would be coming out immediately after(even though they should have been brought out together) so I started on my meal. My steak was seasoned well but it was well done and not medium as I requested. No big deal,I continue eating my dinner. Spinach was average. I finished my entire meal before my buddy food was brought out. He said he was satisfied with his meal as it was well seasoned and delicious...At this point im just ready to leave. ...So its a good spot for seafood lovers, but still a little rough around the edges. I would probably dine there again with one of my seafood loving friends or family

I liked the interior and decor of the place. The service was great as well. Ordered fried catfish app and that was fresh, hot, and delicious. We were getting excited for a good meal.When the lobster, crawfish, and snow crab legs arrived...disaster.None of the food was hot. Lukewarm at best. There was barely any sauce and the quality of the seafood was just alright.I've been to other boil places and definitely had better experiences there than here.Sorry Oceanic Boil :/ I really wanted to like you

I rarely go to Queens way too confusing and everywhere in bk is much closer. I was looking for a new seafood place and somehow I decided on Queens. Oceanic boil is tucked away in a tight cozy dim lit spot on the block if your not paying attention or not using gps it's possible to miss it. It was busy but there wasn't no wait to sit down. There are chairs along the wall and uncomfortable stools in the floor space that I get is there for efficiency but had my butt been a bit bigger, I wouldn't be able to sit there comfortably. The food was pretty good. I enjoyed my fried shrimp and French fries what I didn't like was the so called lobster Mac and cheese. The lobster mac and cheese contained 1 half of a 1oz lobster tail that was chopped up and put on top of the Mac and cheese. I am not exaggerating that either there was no additional pieces of lobster in the dish and the mac and cheese tasted very similar to the nasty kraft mac and cheese from my likkle youth days. I get that it's a business but to charge $18 dollars for that?? I felt like I got robbed forreal. It was decent food but I wouldn't leave Brooklyn to come back here.

What a great place for a boil!!! Hubs and I had the Oceanic Boil combo and it was delicious!!!! Of course we showed up on a Saturday night and had to wait at the bar. But the lychee martinis made the time pass very quick!! Ugh the food, the music (mostly R&B) was spot on! Definitely recommend and definitely will return!!

So went here for my 2 year anniversary let the waitress know we drove all the way down from PA. The service was awesome and quick very clean and fast paced spot the smells at the moment of coming up to the door we're exhilarating and couldn't wait to grab some grub. Now that me and the babes are not newbies we will know exactly what to order. The flavors were amazing the food was great and the drinks we're good. I will definitely be coming back here again
Excellent food , drinks !The waiters are very nice .Little hard time to find parking around in the evening , but was definitely worthy

I enjoyed my meal thoroughly!! The best part was everything! The fries, the mac and cheese and the spicy garlic sauce and old bay sauce on the  fresh seafood was simply delicious. I will be back very soon and bringing friends!!
Amazing food.  Great service.  Awesome drinks.  Perfect ambiance.  All around great.  Oh yes and yummie dessert. Never disappoints

Really love the food here everything is well seasoned and flavorful. The staff is prompt and nice - but let me tell you I'm no light weight but the cocktails here are good and strong. The seafood awkward tastes fresh and the garlic noodles are good as well as the fries.

Its became our regular seafood spot now. The snow crab legs are so fresh, and the lemon garlic butter sauce is so yummy, and creamy. Their coctails also amazing. But my favourite is the Corona margarita ( which is perfect when paired with seafood).The staffs are very helpfull and attentive.They even give me a free "oceanic boil shirt" as the appreciation to the Regular customer.Overall, its Highly recommended.

I wish there's more sauce in the basket. We barely had anything to dip with and it was just overall not very strong. Garlic noodles could use a bit more garlic. But to be fair, the amount of food is pretty good for the price. We paid 70 bucks for crab, shrimp, garlic noodle and fries.

I've been here about 10 times. I brought my friends, and family as well. Everyone love it! The house sauce is amazing. I usually go for happy hour for the $1 oysters, and get the shrimp and king crab boil. I've tried other dishes, but these two are my top favorite. Will go again soon!

I went to eat lunch during father's day. The server asked if we made reservation, thankfully we were only 2 so they were able to seat usWe ordered to share: fried calamari, 1 lb of shrimp on garlic butter lemon pepper and side order of corn and garlic noodle. At first we were thinking it won't be enough but after eating the fried calamari and garlic noodle we almost couldn't finish the shrimp. The shrimp came a little late but it was so good! Everything we ordered was super yummy and we downed it with beer. The shrimp was large in size, unlike other boil restaurantsThe staff are super attentive and they keep on refilling your water.Definitely will come back. Too bad we were hungry and wasnt able to take photos.
Superb food and drinks! Customer service is excellent, super clean place and friendly smiles all around! I will be coming back and I would definitely recommend this seafood place to my friends!

We arrived about 7:00 p.m. on a Saturday and the restaurant was busy.  There was one table open, so we were seated right away.  We started with the shrimp and sausage gumbo.  As another reviewer noted, the heat level in the dish seems to be enhanced by the use of hot sauce.  While we like spicy food, the heat level in this dish needs to be toned down just a bit.  Having said that, it is delicious just the same.  We had the lobster and shrimp boil for our main meal.  For a sauce, we selected the garlic butter and Old Bay.  The meal was absolutely delicious.  We kept dipping the food in the flavorful sauce at the bottom of the dish.  These meals are very messy.  Everyone is given disposable gloves so your hands stay clean.  We had the coconut flan for dessert.  It was pretty good, especially for the $4 cost.  A very satisfying and delicious meal.  We really enjoyed it.Update:  Back for a second visit.  I tried the shrimp and sausage gumbo and found it to be unnecessarily hot again.  When the heat level is higher than it should be, the taste buds get desensitized, not allowing the diner to fully enjoy the underlying flavors.  The restaurant owner indicated that he would discuss the gumbo issue with the chef, so I will try it again next time.  Tried the garlic noodles this time, which is garlicky spaghetti and is good.  Hubby ordered a side of sausage, and those were good also.  We both had shrimp boils, which we enjoyed as much as our first visit.
Went few weeks ago.. ordered lobster, shrimp, prawns and fries ...the fries were very good however the seafood wasn't all that great. It was too slimey and not cooked properly.

This is a great seafood spot!! Drinks are good the apps is good the food is great and ambience is awesome they playing nothing buy good music and its not overbearing where you can't hold a conversation... I would definitely definitely recommend this place if you looking for Great seafood

Ok - SO I was craving seafood boil last night & I didn't want to leave my apartment so despite my best judgement I ordered delivery. TBH I don't recommend ordering delivery for boils b/c obviously it's best served fresh anywho I was pleasantly surprised. It seems they've reverted to using the original sauce w/garlic chunks & all. It also hit the spot. I didn't regret this decision at all! Will be back to visit or even order delivery soon =)

This was my first experience with ordering the seafood in the bag. I recommend that you go with some that likes to eat and likes seafood because they serve a lot of food and is all seafood. We ordered the Oceanic Combo, i think i wasn't impressed because the seasoning didn't let me taste the seafood flavor. They do give you a lot of seafood for the price. I really liked the decoration and the cozy atmosphere

First of all the food is seasoned exceptionally well and there was plenty of it. The place is a little dark, but I'll call it ambience. I was wondering why we were  given rubber gloves. Ta da! The gloves were to protect your hands from the seasoning on the food. I had shrimp and it had the heads on and obviously were  not cleaned. I had to devein the shrimp and try to wipe out as much of the intestine as possible.  My daughter had crawfish that she said were tasteless. Because of the in the bag seasoning and shaking, the corn and potatoes were delicious. If you don't mind the working and cleaning, enjoy. It was quite the experience.

Maybe it's the fact that I've had seafood from the boil in they city and their flavor was incomparable. Oceanic boil was good, the seafood was fresh. Their oceanic boil special sauce has a nice kick. The server was nice to give us a heads up that crawfish was out of season and that they were frozen, but for frozen crawfish, they were pretty good.We ordered a combo of 1lb shrimp and 1lb crawfish with an extra pound of shrimp also the seafood mac and cheese. The seafood mac and cheese were okay, you can pass on that. The crawfish were pretty big. Each pound of seafood came with a corn and potato. The corn was sweet and the potato soaked up the seasoning making it flavorful. Only complaint my friend and I have is that we wished they would attempt to clean the back vein/dirt of the shrimp. But for the most part they're good. Service was very friendly and attentive.

The best place to go for seafood , the best thing I had was the lobster Mac and cheese which is simply amazing. Everything here is pretty good . I love there oceanic sauce . I can't wait to come back here. My favorite place to go when I'm craving seafood

Was so excited to discover this broil and waited days to go. I really wanted to give a better rating but, in all fairness, had to settle with overall 3 stars. From the outside, it's a tiny storefront so you can walk past by without realizing it. Space is narrow and long but, decorated throughout the restaurant. Interior and the bathroom was clean, server was nice, nothing to complain about there. Menu had a lot of items.  We ordered several items and the waiting began. Hum.. there was nothing that stood out nor, very flavorful enough to be praised. We wondered how it received so many 5 star ratings and, I kept looking through the menu to order more items.Shrimp was okay.. garlic butter sauce was pretty standard. Noodles were better flavored than the seafood. At the time of order, they were honest about some items we ordered were not fresh but, frozen. From this visit, oysters were the best part of the entire meal... they were served fresh and cold.

The food was good. Took a little while to come out but it is made fresh so that's to be expected. We went on a Monday so it wasn't too busy. The staff was nice. The chairs are a little hard though. Enjoyed myself. I didn't drink but my friend had the passion fruit drink and she enjoyed it. It's a cozy spot but nice. I'd definitely come back. Just cushion the chairs for those of us who don't have as much cushion please! Thanks.
Great Food and service!! Everything was perfect!! Would definitely eat here again. Seating is a little cramped but worth the food! Thank you

If you are a seafood lover, this is a restaurant you should consider in trying.    Menu prices are very reasonable. Especially for how much seafood they give you. I live for the garlic butter sauce, I would double dip my shrimp in the bottom of the bowl it's that good.

This is a place you must visit! We went for happy hour and they have $5 drinks, $1 Oysters, and $3 off baskets. We ordered calamari and Cajun fries for an appetizer...amazing! But when I say the crab leg boil with the Oceanic Boil season is the best I have ever had!!! Flavor out of this world!! Service was great and the food came out fresh and hot

Cajun Seafood sauce was pretty watered down. 2 of the dozen raw oysters we ordered were very sandy and inedible. For a better bang for your buck, there are other better spots for Cajun seafood than this.
Good and delicious. Staff was a bit disorganized, but friendly. Will definitely go back.

This is a review of the food only: By far the best seafood boil in queens. Crab legs are extremely meaty and juicy, no matter what time of year they are delicious. The crawlfish is rich and the texture is just right, the wait staff always informs you whether or not it is in season. I order it once when it was not in season, and it is noticeable when it comes to the texture of the meat.Now the sauces are extremely tasty, my favorite has to be the garlic butter Lemon pepper. I tried the oceanic boil sauce once (mixture of all sauces) and it just too much; the sauce has to much going on and it completely mask the taste of the seafood.If you come, you must order the garlic noodles. It's garlicy buttery what can go wrong with that.A huge plus to the place: the beers are dirt cheap.

After browsing on yelp, chose to have dinner here on a random Saturday night. Thank Goodness for the option to "Join the waitlist" for this particular restaurant because as soon as we arrived, we were up next on the list to be seated and maybe had to wait only 5 minutes. It was our first time here so we asked the waitress for her recommendations. Ultimately we decided on sharing the Oceanic Combo with their mild oceanic sauce and OH. MY. GOD. hands down the BEST seafood I've ever had!! Usually, I develop an allergic reaction right away to eating seafood if it's not fresh, which was not the case with the seafood here. You can just tell the difference with the way it tastes. Their drinks were also pretty bomb. Place is clean and small, staff is super friendly. My one and only complaint is that the restaurant is located in an area where parking is almost close to none. We got lucky and found street parking quite a few blocks away with circling around the neighborhood twice.
This is hands down my favorite seafood restaurant ! Every time I had been there its always packed, which speaks in itself for how great this place is. Their original sauce itself is just so good!!
decently priced fresh blue point oysters considering there are close to no fresh oysters nearby, and decently priced macallan. definitely will be back to try their seafood boils

I definitely recommend the piña colada and daiquiri which comes with sake. The dishes to try are the calamari, lobster bisque, clam chowder, lobster roll, and crawfish. They have some dishes that are discounted during happy hour so I would recommend to come early because it gets packed.
This is a hidden gem in queens!!! Absolutely delicious!!!! The staff are all so friendly!!! Margaritas were delicious!!! Bloody Mary's were a little thin but yummy!!

I love this restaurant!!! Great food, ambiance was greatI went with my family and we were able to have a conversation without shouting..while we were having lunch. The place is small but cozy, service was great. M.L

I've been looking for a go-to seafood place in Queens, and I'm very excited to say that my search is over. I had the fried calamari and snow crab legs. I would highly recommend both items. A note to anyone who decides to try the calamari: make sure you ask for extra spicy mayo. Their spicy mayo is delicious!

I've been to several fish boil places in Queens and this by far ROCKs all of them. My wife and my daughter were in the area recently and were hungry. We didn't want anything too heavy but we definitely wanted tasty seafood. We came upon this gem and instantly fell in love w/ the shrimps, snow crab legs appetizers. The sauces were absolutely amazing. I would highly recommend Oceanic Boil to anyone who loves delicious shrimps, snow crab legs and lobster mixed in an amazing boil!
Very fresh and delicious yum yum Drinks is so excellent . Great service definitely I will Come back again

I adore this food! It brings back fond memories of my time in Chiangmai.. So far I've tried the Khao Soi, Jor pak kod, beef noodle soup, pearl pad see ew, and the fermented pork ribs.. It's hard to pick a favorite but I think the jor pak kod (Northern style soup) is the winner. (What kind of greens are those?)I do wish they would bring the lunch special back so I can try more of the menu without skipping out on my favorites.

Lamoon means "delicate, deliberately, well-taken care of" in Thai language and represents their faith of running the restaurant. They serve authentic cuisine from northern Thailand, It's kind of different from the Thai cuisine we are familiar with. The decor is adorable with beautiful drawings on the wall and the ambiance is relaxed & cozy. Their food was amazingly delicious with surprise and creativity. We ordered Angie (Crispy papaya salad with shrimps), Hnam Kadook Moo (fermented pork ribs), Yum Jin Gai and Thai Tea Pad Thai; the portion of each was huge and we ended up bringing all the Pad Thai home. My favorite dish was the Angie. It was my first time to have fried papaya salad and it was super tasty, crispy at the top but wet on the bottom. The mixed texture was extremely addictive. My husband's favorite was Thai Tea Pad Thai which is infused by Thai iced tea. We tried it out of curiosity but with kind of hesitation and felt in love with this delicacy. There are still some options on the menu we would like to try next time. However, there is one complaint that they are Cash and Venmo only .

I absolutely love Thai food and Elmhurst is known for having some of the best Thai restaurants. This place right off Grand Ave specializes in Northern Thai cuisine and everything is super spicy so come prepared!Be sure to check out their unique Thai Tea Pad Thai along with their spicy Larb Kuy. They have a wide selection of appetizers so it's best to come with a large group and just order a bunch of dishes to share. Also they take reservations if you want to call ahead with a large party.

So according to others this is Northern Thai cuisine and this was my first time eating it. I hesitate to call the food bland, but that is how I honestly felt about it. The flavors of the dishes were not only not at all spicy, but the ingredients themselves seemed to be used too gently. Nothing stood out, nothing shined, and the quality of the meat and seafood was not very good (overcooked, too much bone, small in size, etc.). Yum Woon Sen (Spicy Glass Noodles Salad) was odd. The noodles were dry, a faint scent of fish sauce wafting off them, with just a hint of spice - but this was still the spiciest dish we ordered. It comes with shrimp and calamari - neither seemed to have any flavor and were small and sparse. Shredded pork, carrots, peanut, and onions rounded this out, it was just a dry, strange salad. The Hat Yai fried chicken was badly overcooked, the meat dry and tasteless. Fried shallots sat oddly at the bottom of the takeout container, and a very small sweet chili sauce did not make up for the meat. Finger Root Pad Kee Mao tasted nothing like any version I've ever had, it's a completely different dish which isn't an issue but I just didn't care for it because it didn't really taste like much. There was no heat whatsoever, and it had a light, airy flavor that I couldn't place. Maybe like a very muted citrus without the bite. The Hnam Kadook Moo (fermented pork ribs) were pretty tasty. This was my first time having fermented meat and I can't say I could taste it. They're bone-in rib tips and a little chewy, not overly so, but there was too much bone for the small amount of meat you got. Their Northern Green Curry was the best item of the night - but not for $17. I have nothing bad to say about it, but nothing amazing either, it had the boldest flavor, but that's not saying much.Their Blue Moon drink was delicious! Fresh coconut slices inside the cup makes this taste exactly like sweet sticky rice in drink form, loved it.Edit to add an extra star: The owners response to my review was incredible. I really appreciate having a new cuisine explained to me, it helps me better understand the flavors, cooking technique, and what to expect, and it's fair that delivery can effect the food. Lamoon didn't have to give such a detailed and thorough response but I'm grateful they did, and they did it with kindness. Thank you!

Food: 2.5/5Ordered for delivery. We got the northern green curry, the pink pad thai, the yum woon sen and the pearl pad see ew. The northern green curry (4/5) was the best dish out of everything. It had a lot of flavor and it was packed with peppers and chicken. The pink pad thai (1/5) was interesting but nothing special. It looked pretty but the taste was bland and slightly sour. I had to put extra soy sauce and hot sauce. The yum woon sen (2/5) was decent. It was spicy and packed with shrimp and vegetables -very fragrant but smelled too much like fish for my preference. The pad see ew (2/5) was just.. average? It needed more soy sauce or salt. The noodles arrived all stuck together and it was dry. Again, nothing special.Overall, I did not enjoy the food here. I ordered for delivery for me + three of my Thai friends and nobody enjoyed it. There are so many better Thai restaurants around the vicinity. I don't think I'd give this place another try.Delivery: 4/5Came within the expected time frame.

Shades of blue with pops of green and red fill the interior of this small space. It is reminiscent of listening to the soft flow of waves while sitting by a quiet waterside with a gentle breeze blowing against the blaze of the sun. The color contrast on the stark white walls serve a dual purpose in making the shop feel inviting as well as providing the perfect background for pictures. We ordered the fried lemongrass chicken wings, tum kanoon, yum woon sen, khao soi with chicken, kang hung ley, nam prik ong, rainbow sticky rice and mango, butterfly pea flower juice, and Thai iced tea. The wings were crispy and meaty, the yum woon sen was tangy with a hint of spice, and the pork belly was super tender. The tum kanoon was somewhat of a disappointment. I was looking forward to this dish the most as I love jackfruit but I felt like I couldn't really taste the jackfruit flavor. The khao soi with chicken was my favorite. Its broth was rich and silky smooth and the chicken was juicy and succulent. The rainbow sticky rice with mango was delicious despite being a bit too sweet for my taste. Staff were friendly, attentive and helpful. Street parking is available though it's tough finding a spot. As for public transportation, it is easily accessible by the E, F, R, M, and 7 trains.

This is why I travel over 1,200 miles from home, because of the availability of restaurants like Lamoon. I'm here for five days on a self-guided combination work/food tour. To be clear, food is not the subject of my self-employment. That's computer work. My hobby is eating spectacular food, and less than an hour after having lunch here, if someone could foresee the future and tell me this was the best meal of the trip I'd be totally OK with that. And it could be.Nam Prik Noom was the centerpiece of my lunch, savory fried rice in a chili paste with chicken added. Just the right amount of heat, intensely flavorable, perfectly moist. As part of the lunch special I had one appetizer available and chose the fried rice balls which were crisp, crunch and savory, small bits of Thai basil (I believe) protruding and contained within. A wonderful texture to pair with the entree. Two rice dishes at once for lunch? Hell, yea! And a Thai ice tea to boot, sweet, but not cloyingly so. Perfection.Better yet, and especially to my liking, the portion sizes are just right. I get that it's in vogue to serve way too much food for lunch, but please, not everyone wants that. This was just right, not only in portion size, but in every other way possible.Cash only. Seats maybe 20 if packed. Menu is packed with photos of the actual menu, helpful for folks like yours truly. Very highly recommended.

Check out my Instagram page for more photos of food: instagram.com/louloubear… I came here with my partner for the first time. First impressions when I walked in was that there isn't a whole lot of space so it is nice and cozy. If you have a large group of people, I would recommend making a reservation a day or two before so that you can make sure you have a table for your party. If you are going in a small group of 2/3 people you will have a much better chance getting seated right away. The bathroom is located in the back where the kitchen is so if you need to use it just ask your server and they will point you in the direction. The dishes were all very unique and different from your typical thai cuisine. It displays Northern Thai Cuisine which is less sweet but more spicy and savory by using herbal ingredients. We had: Khao Soi Chicken (egg noodle in creamy coconut curry top with crispy noodle On side: shallot, lime slice & pickle lettuce) $12: definitely the highlight dish from the meal. I particularly liked the flavor from the Khao Soi. It had a very rich and flavorful broth and it complimented the egg noodles quite well. The only thing I would say is that the chicken tasted a little dry because the majority of the skin was not there. Thai Tea Pad Thai w/ Shrimp (Thai tea infused rice noodle sauté with tamarind sauce, sweet turnip, black tofu, chive, grounded peanut, beansprout, dried shrimp flake) $14: the technique of infusing the pad thai with thai tea was really interesting and brought a unique flavor/taste to the dish. In my opinion I would still prefer regular pad thai over this dish, but that is a personal preference. Hnam Kadook Moo (Homemade old fashioned fried fermented pork ribs) $9: I don't mind eating meat with bones in it but in my opinion, a lot of the pork ribs were small portions of meat and too much cartilage. I thought the cook and the seasoning of the ribs were acceptable. I definitely recommend trying it and judging it for yourself whether you like it or not but if you are looking for something new to try, this is the perfect place to go. Check out my Instagram page for more photos of food: instagram.com/louloubear…

Lamoon is a tiny spot in Elmhurst (Queens) serving Northern Thai cuisine. My brother and I stopped by for lunch a couple of weeks ago when we were in Queens. They brought us a free starter of popcorn. I got  the tum kanoon (green jackfruit, ground pork, homemade shrimp paste, plum tomato, kaffir lime leaves, cilantro, and scallion, and served with sticky rice and pork rinds), which was really spicy (I ordered it medium) and delicious. My brother got the khao soi (egg noodles in creamy coconut curry topped with crispy noodles) with chicken, which was good. We also shared the kung pare (pan fried crispy baby shrimp cloud cake served with sweet chili sauce), which was so crispy and shrimpy. Overall, the meal was very good, and I enjoyed that they served regionally specific Thai food. And I liked the vibe inside the restaurant. They are cash only FYI. I'd go again!

This is another one of my bookmarked restaurants that I hadn't had time to check out.  A friend recently went and said it was a must try...so 5 of us went.  I had high expectations, given the high yelp ratings Lamoon has received, but honestly, I was so disappointed.  How did I have such a drastically different experience at Lamoon?  Did they dummy down the flavors/spiciness level because there were two caucasians in our group?  Not sure but everything we had seemed to be under-seasoned and not spicy at all.  Even the Leng Oh Ho Soup, which was stated on their menu as being "brutally spicy", was not really that spicy!  I would say it was mildly spicy, at best!  All in all, I'm glad I finally tried Lamoon but NY has so many better Thai restaurants.Here is our menu (shared by 5 ppl):~ Leng Oh Ho Soup:  the meat on the huge bones were hard to eat, but the soup itself was quite tasty; albeit NOT "brutally spicy" at all.  This was probably the best dish of the night.~ Tamarind Fish Fillet:  mild in flavor;  just ok.~ Hnam Kadook Moo:  these rib tips were really overcooked and hard; again, mild in flavor.~ Kung Pare:  we were expecting a mound of crispy goodness (judging from the menu photo);  instead, we got a flat, super crispy (hard) pancake which was greasy and had no flavor.~ Khao soy w.chicken: the curry sauce was the blandest curry I've had in a long time;  again, very mild flavors.~ Kee Moa:  not much wok-heat flavoring; again, very mild flavors.On a positive note, the pandan water they served was fantastic!  Hospitality and service were friendly and wonderful!  I also loved their pretty murals.

Hands down some of the best Thai food I ever had. Each dish cooked perfectly and packed with immense flavor. Came around 11am and got sat immediately. They got bonus points right off the bat by serving pandan water.Kung Pao: I'm not sure what spicy leng sauce is but it was very tasty. It tasted vinegary and garlickly and paired so well with the grilled shrimp!Fried Lemongrass Chicken Wings: Simple but very delicious. Subtle notes of lemongrass, not too overpowering and perfectly cooked wings.Larb Neua: Another amazing dish. It had a nice heat level to it and the meat itself was super flavorful. Huge fan of larb so this hit the spot.Chicken Fingeroot Pad Kee Mao: My favorite dish of the entire meal. The medium level spice works well with the dish and each bite kept getting better and better. Kang Hung Ley: Melt in your mouth tender pork belly. This dish was actually just okay, something about just didn't match the level of the previous 4 dishes but still solid.

4& 1/2 A newer entry into Elmhurst's wildly thriving Thai-town, this brightly colored little joint is serving some of the cities best Thai RN IMO.  The northern-Thai flavors on the plate are as vibrant as the eye-popping and playful murals adorning the walls.  Highlights include northern stalwarts like sour sausage,  pumpkin curries, pork-blood stews, fried mini spareribs and papaya and mango salads, all delicious.  The sleeper star of the show for me however is surely the Pearl Pad Se Ew, the proverbial best in the city.  A rare dish I haven't been too wild about is the house special Pink Thai Tea Pad Thai, which while not achieving the establishments normal level of deliciousness, was nonetheless still at least an interesting semi-misfire.  Stick with the Pad Se Ew and you can achieve true Thai transcendence.  Staff is super cool and inviting and best of all the place is that loveliest of acronyms BYOB!
Got food to go and it was good again!This time I tried the noodles with siracha and the flavor/heat is on point. It isn't over sweet like other Thai restaurants. My favorite place.

We came across Lamoon a while ago but didn't go in for some reason or another. But today we wanted Thai food without going into manhattan.  After reading reviews on several places we decided to pop in. First when you go in you see the amazing art murals on opposite sides of the room. It's a very small restaurant, maybe sits 15-20 people. A lovely server told us that we can sit anywhere so we choose a seat by the window. It's right across the street from a park and the subway entrance is right outside the door so you can people watch. The menu looks very enticing but can be intimidating if you've never had authentic Thai food. But luckily it has photos of everything. It took us a bit but we finally ordered: Crab Egg Plam $9grilled scramble eggs with crab meat in banana leavesYum Jin Gai $15flamed hot pot with chicken & herbs in Northern Thai style soup Kang Hung Ley $13tender pork belly, ginger, peanut, pickled garlic with masala curry. served with riceThai iced coffee $3We chatted with the crab egg plam. It was interesting. Strange but interesting. It was exactly what the menu says. Scrambled eggs with crab meat. It did lack spice and tasted a little fishy. I had to ask for hot sauce. She brought over some red chili flakes that were very spicy. That made it more palatable. Then we had the Yum Jin Gai and the Kang Hung Ley. The soup was very cool visually and the flavor profile was delicious. You could taste the floral notes of the flowers. Decent portion too. I ordered the Kang Hung Ley for my meal. I've never had taro or anything with curry in it so I said why not. The dish is beautiful. The pieces of pork were very large and juicy! Now the taro egg nest I didn't care for at all. I don't know if it was supposed to be the way it was but it was fried into a bird nest shape. It was very hard. The hard boiled egg I wouldn't even touch because it looked very strange. The sauce with the curry was interesting. Again I have never had it before. When I asked the server about the masala curry when we were ordering, she said that it was a mixture of the Indian traditional curry and the south East Asian curries. I was intrigued and it turned out pretty good. Now after all of this very long review I have to say that I have marked this restaurant off of my list. It's beautiful, the food is interesting, the service was perfect and the prices were decent. Would I go back? Probably not. Just wasn't a huge wow factor especially when there's so many other places out there to try. Don't let me discouraged you though. It might be amazing to you. Whatever floats your boat you know?

Authentic Thai food with an above average flavour coupled with an above average price. The complimentary pandan water was unexpected, but it's really the aftertaste that hits you. If you drink it after you eat a bite of food, you might not even taste it. Just treat it as regular tap water, although it is definitely a good talking point if you're with others.The large Leng Soup is what you want to get as long as you're not weirded out by seeing whole stretches of spine in your soup and separating it vertebrae by vertebrae to get all of the meat. The meat on the bone is oh-so-tender and plentiful. You will be overwhelmed by how much meat there is- it's basically a buffet. The soup is sour and citrusy with a huge kick from all the green chilli. You get two bowls of jasmine rice with the soup, but can easily feed 3, possibly four, with the one dish. The menu says that it is brutally spicy, but keep in mind that you can ask them for a less spicy option if you can't handle it.The Crab Egg Plam was a pretty ordinary hard scrambled egg with crab meat. Probably not something that I'd get again.Abb Ong Oor was a steamed pork brain mixed with shrimp paste and a bunch of other seasonings including chilli and turmeric. It's not too spicy, but it tastes like it has a million spices mixed in. The texture is super creamy from the pork brain, but you don't taste the brain at all. It's so well hidden that I wouldn't have guessed it was in there without having seen the menu beforehand. Get this solely for the novelty, though. It's not something that is going to fill you up, because the amount that you get will be a bit less than the size of your smartphone(excluding the flip phones of the past and the needlessly large Samsung Note-esque devices).The Pink Lady really just tastes like a sour Pad Thai. But it is dissimilar to simply adding lime to pad thai, which results in a sharp sour taste.  This sourness is more mellowed. Really interesting and a great way to switch things up. The Thai Tea Pad Thai is a must try for foodies. I can't say that I'd order it again, but it was a very unique experience. The noodles taste strongly of thai tea. You can say that it's a gimmick and I would totally agree with you, but I recommend you to try it once in your life.

I went here one night with a friend and my husband. Overall, we were very satisfied with our meal (we ordered several dishes and ate family style). We ordered one of the curry dishes, the lemongrass chicken, a papaya salad and the mango sticky rice for dessert. The curry was amazing...hands down, the sauce was some of the best that I've ever had. And the mango sticky rice was delicious, with a unique take, as there were six different small samples of flavored rice along with the mango.I will say though, that the papaya salad and chicken were average at best. I usually love papaya salad, but their version left much to be desired.I did leave feeling very full and satisfied. If I am in Elmhurst again, I will definitely return if I am in the mood for a curry dish (or if I am feeling like a fat kid and want to binge on some savory sticky rice). I just don't suggest ordering the lemongrass chicken or papaya salad though.

Yummm I love Thai food! What's great about Lamoon is that their cuisine is from the Northern part, so their dishes are different from what you will usually see at other Thai restaurants.For a table of three people, we over-ordered. Do we regret it? Hell no. We got:- Angie (papaya salad) - standard fare- Khao soi with chicken leg (egg noodles in coconut curry) - one of my friends liked this, I thought it was just ok- Kanon jeen nam ngeaw (vermicelli in pork ribs shrimp paste stew with blood cubes) - had a nice spice to it, I was expecting more but not bad- Leng soup - this was my FAVEEE! It's a subtle sour flavor and spice that hits you (I didn't think it was that spicy though even though the menu said it's brutally spicy) and it comes with a huge pork spine and lots of meat, also lots of chili, scallion and cilantro- Thai tea pad thai - this was interesting; it was sweet and smelled of Thai tea. I'm not sure if I would get it again as it started tasting too sweet as I kept eating it- Kang hung ley (pork belly with curry) - pork was tender and fell apart but I felt the flavors were a bit lackingI would come back to try the other dishes and the leng soup again. Pretty solid establishment and the staff is really nice.

Unassumingly located at the top of the entrance to the Elmhurst Avenue subway stop, Lamoon is home to arguably the best Thai food in all five boroughs.Confronted by a colorful menu popping with high-quality pictures and mouthwatering descriptions, my friends and I did the wise thing and asked a Thai friend who had previously eaten at Lamoon for his recommendations. Here is what he suggested:- SAI AUA (Herbal Thai Sausage): To be honest, I had never had a Thai sausage before, but I could be convinced to make them a staple of my future diet based on these fragrant, crispy links filled with lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, and pork ear- KHAO TOD (Rice Ball): Very similar to the arancini of Italian cuisine, but obviously Thai with curry paste and coconut flakes. Not a must order, but packed with heat and at $1 a certified steal- KANG HUNG LEY: Very tender pork belly with masala curry - solid but not spectacular- THAI TEA PAD THAI: No, that's not a typo. As far as I am aware, the only Thai joint to whip up a Thai tea-infused rice noodle. The flavor is relatively subtle when surrounded by all the wonderful ingredients that constitute a pad thai, but it is certainly there and a must-order- PANANG CURRY: Have you ever come across a sauce so good you just wanted to drink it? If not, you will after getting a taste of this curry. The most amazing mix of sweet, spicy, and umami, I ate this over some jasmine rice and scooped the leftover curry straight into my mouth holeThai food in New York usually evokes the restaurants that dot a long stretch of Ninth Avenue in the Manhattan neighborhood of Hell's Kitchen. However, with a few more spots left to try, I would not be surprised if my vote reverted to Elmhurst as the destination for Thai dining.

Stopped by the other day for some lunch and ordered the sriracha noodles and Pad Thai.The Pad Thai - its a different variation from what you'd generally be served at many Thai restaurants, namely they serve theirs with shredded coconut and I felt like they also have more lime and tamarind paste in it. My husband ordered it with beef, which was over cooked and tough to chew. The sriracha noodles - I definitely don't think this is 'authentic' Thai, more of a makeshift dish, basically wide ribbon noodles with chicken and egg then doused with sriracha on top. In saying this, I thoroughly enjoyed it. The portion was HUGE, you need 2 people for this one, at $13 (before tax and tip) I was happy. The noodles had that delicious chewiness to them, the sauce clinging and coating the noodles well. Even with the sriracha, the spice was still fairly mild, the chicken was well cooked without being dry. The egg added some additional background texture and flavour too.I've walked passed here a few times and knew it would be a small restaurant but upon actually entering, it was obvious they've tried to cram too many tables in such a small space making it very awkward to sit down and for other diners squeezing in and out from the table next to you. Nonetheless, this place is fairly popular and gets fairly busy. Not family friendly for those with a large group or small children/babies, you're definitely not getting a stroller in here without drawing attention to yourself. No restrooms either.Pricing is slightly more expensive than other Thai restaurants (2 mains with tax and tip is about $35) though they have a very extensive menu featuring some dishes that I haven't seen at other Thai places. The decor is quite colourful, Thai street art inspired but not as vibrant and modern as it looks in the restaurant's advertised pictures. The staff are very attentive and the wait times for your food isn't too bad at 15-20 minutes. Originally, I anticipated the portion sizes to be on the small side (from how it appeared in the menu), however they are VERY servings.All in all, a decent Thai restaurant to visit if you're in the area. A few doors down you'll find a Thai/hainanese place doing steamed chicken and rice, another doing few varieties of crispy pork dishes....then ANOTHER standard Thai restaurant. Yu Tea is there too in between them all. You've really got a lot of variety on this one block, take you're pick! :D
Value 5/5Taste 5/5Service 5/5Presentation of food 5/5Appearance of the establishment 5/5

People who love pure, authentic Northern Thai have called Lamoon one of the best Thai restaurants in New York City, and I can see why. This underappreciated charmer serves Asian-infused cuisine you don't normally find at most Thai places. For me personally, this isn't necessarily my type of food. But that doesn't mean I can't recognize what a culinary and delicious option this is for foodies and fans of this culinary fare.Lamoon is a very small restaurant. But it doesn't really feel that way. With it's bright colors and big windows, it's a very comfortable space to dine. Being small and cozy, the service is stellar and attentive. The menu is inviting and extensive, with colorful photos and descriptions that definitely gets you wanting to try a little bit of everything. The menu is full of what they call Lanna dishes, inspired by the ancient Lanna Kingdom, also known as "a Million Rice Fields."  Popular in the 13th-18th centuries, Lanna food is less sweet but more spicy and savory by using herbal ingredients, such as lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, and onion. The Northern Thai cuisine mainly uses pork and components that easily found locally, which cannot found in the regular Central Thai cooking. It also uses a variety of organic vegetables and fresh herbs.We started out with the Crab Egg Plam, grilled scramble eggs with crab meat in banana leaves.Then we had the Kang Hung Ley, tender pork belly, ginger, peanut, pickled garlic with masala curry. I'm not a curry fan, but OMG, this was delicious. The pork belly was mouthwatering. The sauce was perfect.We then had the Yum Jin Gai, which is their flamed hot pot with chicken & herbs in Northern Thai style soup. This wasn't my favorite. There were pieces of skin and fat. And, I'm not a fan of Thai soup. But, for those who like this kind of flavor, it's a definite.It was a lovely night. I don't know if we'll be back, only because it's not my kind of fare. But if it's yours, it's definitely worth checking out.

It's a simple joint: small place, cash only, BYOB, and some damn fine Thai food. I had just spent a week traveling around Thailand and was craving more northern Thai specialties. This place didn't disappoint. The tom yum noodle soup and khao soi were both on point. Staff were friendly and explained to all the diners how they traditionally eat each dish in Thailand (i.e. mixing mustard greens and shallots into the khao soi). The chicken wings were unfortunately pretty greasy (even sitting in a puddle of grease when served), but that didn't change the fact that they were piping hot and tasty. If only it didn't take me 75 minutes on the subway to get here I'd be a regular, because there's so much else on the menu that I'd want to try, like the Leng soup, "BRUTALLY SPICY" pork spine broth with a metric buttload of chilis.

Real. Authentic. Thai food. Hands down favorite Thai restaurant in NYC right now. So long I wondered when real Northern Thai cuisine would arrive stateside and maybe the time wasn't right until now, maybe NYC wasn't ready for it before...but baby, we're doubtless ready for it now. Came here twice so far, and excited to go back again soon. If you're a fan of SE Asian cuisine (hint: sweet, spicy, sour--all together) and enjoy eating at authentic restaurants in Asia, you can't order wrong, everything here is good. Beautiful presentations too. First time I tried: 1) mango salad with ant eggs: kinda like a papaya salad, but with mango, so a bit more of the sweet mixed with the tanginess of the vinegar and spiciness of the peppers. The ant eggs look like little white beans, and taste pretty bland, like tiny steamed edamame that has a little snap when you bite it. 2) Khao soi with chicken: creamy coconut-based curry. Tender chicken, generous portions. Noodles in the sauce, topped with the same noodles deep fried. Great textural contrasts. 3) Kang Hung Lay: Thai style pork belly stew...super tender and savory, ginger and soy in the broth along with a number of other spices. Topped with taro chips. My friend practically wanted to pick up the plate and lick it clean. 4) mango sticky rice: one of the best versions of this desert I've had outside of Thailand. Second time:1) Khao soi beef: I didn't think it could get better than the chicken version but boy was I wrong. So tender...2) jackfruit salad with deep fried pork rinds on the side. A heartier salad, this is has multiple textures and a both fresh and earthy flavor. Might not be for everyone but my one friend loooved it. The pork rinds added a nice crunch. 3) shrimp pad Thai: ordered by a less adventurous friend, this was surprising in a delicious way, the flavors aren't your normal pad Thai, they use a bit of Thai tea in their noodles, so they are a little on the sweeter side, but very tasty. 4) herbal chicken hot pot: savory, sour and spicy like they do it in Thailand. Not for the faint of heart. If you can eat a tablespoonful of sriracha and be okay with that level of spice, then please try this soup. My mouth was burning but I still ate/drank all of this. Btw, they don't serve mango sticky rice if they don't have ripe mangos, andAND they serve water flavored with pandan leaves, a fragrant plant used to flavor many SE Asian desserts--not sweet, but provides a fine fragrance to the water. Friendly servers and owner checked in on us periodically when we were eating both times, even when it was packed. Keep up the great hospitality!

I was never really into Thai food in the city until I went to Bangkok; everything was so amazing and I actually made tasty food in a cooking class that I now crave Thai food regularly. When I saw Lamoon featured in a NY Times article, I had to go with my Bangkok travel buddy.Lamoon is conveniently located right off the Elmhurst Ave. stop - so close that we actually walked right past it. We were seated immediately on a Wednesday night and I instantly fell in love with the thoughtful, beautifully blue decor. Customer service was great, but on to the food! + Pandan water (complimentary) - I was going to order a Thai iced tea until I had a sip of this. I LOVE pandan - like, I'm a total sucker for anything pandan - and this was absolutely perfect. The pandan came through strong and fragrant, but not too grassy. It was addictingly refreshing and an excellent complement to the rich food we got. + Khao soy with tofu ($13) - Who needs meat when a vegetarian dish can be THIS good? The tofu was prepared as one of my favorite renditions - puffy and airy with a crispy (though not after being soaked in the soup) exterior. The airiness soaks up the khao soy perfectly. The flavor of the khao soy was phenomenal - rich, intense, totally addicting with layers of flavor. Even though this was primarily my friend's entree, I couldn't help sneaking more spoonfuls. + Thai tea pad thai with chicken ($13) - Not sure if this is traditional; I've never seen pad thai made with tea but I loved it. The tea made the noodles a bright orange color and added a subtle layer of tea flavor, which really lightened the dish. The chicken was great, but I think I would get the tofu next time. Totally recommend this. The portions are large; I ended up taking half of my food home, though I probably should have stopped after half. It was an excellent meal and I would absolutely come back. Also my favorite dessert chain from Hong Kong (Hui Lau Shan) just opened down the street, so it was a perfect pairing :) The mango sticky rice here looked amazing - with rainbow colored rice, just like in Bangkok - but I was in the mood for something lighter.

Came here with a group of friends and they do take reservation so that is a plus. The restaurant has a minimalist designed and I really like the cloud decorated shades hanging on the ceiling, which gave it a simple, yet relaxing vibe.The service was also great and our server always made sure to fill our water to the top so we don't have to keep on asking. However, food wise, I can't say I'm a huge fan. Our soup was tasty but when it came out it was lukewarm. Also the portion overall was more like tapas size, which I was a bit surprised considering the price tag that came along with it. Taste wise, I had better. Our filet tamarind fish was way too sweet and they only gave one fish filet for this dish was really small considering they chard $13 for that dish. Also their fermented pork rib ($10) is was not actual ribs but instead they used rib tips, which made the pork taste dry and chewy. We also had their Khao Soi Chicken ($13), and flavor wise, it was just bland. Overall, I'm glad I came here to check this restaurant out but I'm not sure if it's one that I would recommend to my friends if they ask.Ooh and one more thing, the benches they used as seats were not comfortable at all. It was hard and just annoying to get up and down from.

Really cute little Thai restaurant with lots of meter parking around the area! This spot has really unique items on their menu and they even serve pandan water (i thought i misheard the waitress for a sec but it actually did have a pandan aftertaste)!! I got to try the Thai tea pad Thai noodles and I didn't taste the Thai tea in the noodles, but I must say the noodles were cooked extremely well. I'm still craving it now as I type up this review. I also tried the egg wrap fried rice and the menu pic is a bit deceiving. The rice is not actually wrapped with a full blanket of egg. However, the portion size is much bigger than pictured so it made up for it! Enjoyed both entrees and the Thai iced tea as well! Servers were attentive and I would come back to try their other dishes.

Ordered for pick up and was happy to get my order in the span of about 15 minutes!Got the lunch special Pink Lady (pink dyed pad thai basically) along with the kaho tod which is fried rice balls?The pink lady was very interesting especially the pink color. It tasted like pretty standard pad thai to me but less sweet for sure...mmm more sour? I'm not sure what the taste is but it was good! The crushed peanuts added a nice touch to it. Pretty filling too.The khao tod was nicely seasoned. Couldn't quite pinpoint what the exact spices were though.Nice experience of what Northern Thai food is like!

I've been here twice now. I find Lamoon unique even among only the Northern Thai places in NY. I've been to most of them by now and the cuisine is being better represented nowadays.  Lamoon and one or two others are leading the charge. Even their water is pandan flavored. Expect authenticity here.There are two dishes that I feel are a must get: the Sai Aua (signature Herbal Thai sausage) and the Leng soup. Their sausage is unique. Kaffir lime leaves and lemongrass pops in your mouth as soon as you bite into it.  The Leng soup is a like a beast that needs to be tamed. You have to approach it with caution. I think people can get intimated by the description in the menu because it says BRUTALLY SPICY - yes, in caps, on the menu.  I found it a lot easier to handle if you take your time with it. The heat comes in waves and it's a slow burner that doesn't interfere with the wonderful sour notes in between. The broth is really flavorful and you really can't go wrong with pork spine in a delicious broth.I saw khao soi on the menu and I had to get it. However, this is the first time I have tried this dish in all of North America that hit the mark for me.  Crispy noodles, flat soft noodles, an amazing coconut curry broth, a stupendously large piece of chicken leg and a side of pickled lettuce and shallots which I just threw into my curry (because I like to live dangerously). I don't  think you will find a better khao soi in NY and if you do, please drop me a note.The Abb Ong Oor is just your daily steamed marinated pork brain. If you are squeamish about this type of stuff, probably better to stay away but I grew up eating brain masala so this was comfort food at some level. However if you are feeling adventurous, the addition of shrimp paste and herbs should ease your induction into the glorious world of brain gastronomy. Good luck.The larb neua didn't taste like any other larb I've had before because the flavor was more earthy but this was top notch as well. In addition to the ground pork, it comes with bits of liver and belly. Pork is king here.
Absolutely love this place! It's one of my favorite places in Queens/NYC. The best most authentic northern Thai food, really cute interior, and just great overall experience. Will 100% be back!

Ordered through yelp.  Delivery was smooth but thats the only good part about my experience.Ordered the chicken pad thai.  Noodles were the most bland I've ever tasted.  Zero flavor what so ever.  Expensive food as well.  Side was the steamed tofu which was nothing to write home about either.

Honestly I didn't expect much when I walked into this place because I thought it's just another hippie restaurant and not as authentic as other OGs in the area. I was so wrong. I actually have never tried Northern Thai food here in the States. Pretty much all Thai places have the same things - pad thai, pad kee mao... but this one is different. I highly recommend the Northern Thai Pork Blood Soup and Jor Pak Kad for share - both made with flavorful and hearty pork broth, one with pork meatballs and blood cubes and the other with ribs. Their signature Chili Pork Sausage is spicy and just okayish. I love the Fillet Tamarind Fish!! The fillet is battered fried and crunchy in sweet and sour sauce with lots of fried onion and garnished with pomegranate seeds. It comes great with rice. Also recommend the Kanom Jeen Nam Ngeaw which is rice vermicelli noodle with ribs in shrimp paste and tomato broth. It's sour and spicy, very flavorful. For dessert I tried their colorful sticky rice with pumpkin custard because they ran out of mango that day. Nothing special. Staff is very friendly and attentive. Price is reasonable. The only minus is probably they only have employee restroom, which they will let you use if you ask.

I came here for the famously instagrammable mango with rainbow coconut sticky rice. The mango was very fresh, but I thought the rice balls would've been better if they were a little less sweet. The different colors are different flavors but it's a subtle difference. It was interesting. The brown is coffee, the green is matcha, the red is Thai tea, the blue is butterfly pea, the yellow is gardenia flower, and the white is coconut. Overall a good place to chill. I should mention, they're cash only.

We loved this place! The staff were so friendly and helpful in talking about the food. They add pandan to the water--which is delicious. We ended up trying the fermented pork, Hanam Kadook Moo. It was so tender and packed in so much flavor. We also had the Yum Jin Gai, the herbal chicken soup. This had a ton of delicate flavor and was a little spicy but not too hot. Then we had the Kang Hoh, which is a glass noodle dish with pork. The pork is a little sweeter and there were some bits of sour in the vegetables. It played nicely with the spicier soup. For dessert we had the floating lotus, which anyone who likes cream top and tapioca pearls will like!We loved this place and definitely will come back! It's really special.

Heard really great things about this place and I'm really trying to find better and better Thai food all the time, so I stopped by. The restaurant was smaller than expected, but very cutesy. I got the Northern Red Curry while my girlfriend got Pad Kee Mao. Wow man, the red curry was so delicious after one taste of it that I was actually in shock. It was amazing. I didn't really know how the jackfruit and grapes would add in to the curry, but it was such a unique sweet and savory taste and I couldn't stop eating it. The pad kee mao was also exquisite, it wasn't as salty and oily as a lot of places make it, but it still retained a rich flavor. The food at this place actually WOWed me, MUST come back.

Our thai food streak continues! This one was another great find. I mainly came for the leng soup (tangy, sour, pork bone soup adorned with a lot of green onions and herbs). Even the small portion is big enough to share among two people. The Thai tea pad thai was made with coconut milk and was very fragrant. I'm not sure if they used tamarind to make this version, but it definitely captured the creaminess of thai tea somehow. The deep fried baby shrimp takes 20 min to make so take that into consideration if you're in a rush. Not much of a pancake, it was fried to a crisp. It stayed crispy for days in the fridge. I'm glad we tried this place, there's lots of stuff that I wish I tried on the menu. Will come again! Friendly staff too!

Took way too long to try this place because was under the impression that everything is spicy--not at all the case! Was more than impressed by the--not spicy--pork blood soup with an ever so slightly sweet aromatic broth, tender pork, liver, pork balls, sprouts, green onions and herbs, with plenty of perfectly cooked rice vermicelli--egg noodles are also an option. Note that this noodle dish is not on the web site menu, along with a number of other non spicy and spicy ones. The printed menu also has spiciness ratings. Also had the ever so slightly spicy rice ball: crunchy on the outside and coconut and herb creamy within. Cute tiny place with Thai pop and rap music. If you take the M or R from Manhattan, get off the back and you'll be right there. Will definitely be back!
Small but cute place! Staff was friendly, but the wait for food was a bit long. Ordered some Thai Ice tea upon waiting. Their beef jerky is really good and chewy! Loved the food overall!

I was in the mood for some Thai food and checked out yelp for some good spots.  I decided to check out this fairly new spot and I wasn't disappointed.  The staff were very friendly and the service was pleasant. It's a small but very clean and modern looking dining area.  I ordered from the lunch special menu which consisted of an appetizer and main course. I chose the rice balls as an appetizer and they were amazingly delicious and very fulfilling. For the main course I had the chicken fried rice with chili sauce which was spicy and yummy.  I also ordered the Thai iced tea which was just Ok, I've had tastier versions. The prices were fair and the menu items were a lot different from your typical Thai spot. I would definitely check them out again when I am in the area.

I'm sure this place is incredibly cute in the afternoon with the very instagram-friendly decor and the very pretty food presentations, but this feels more like a dessert cafe in Williamsburg than an authentic Thai restaurant in Elmhurst. When the Portlandia theme-song came on, very loudly, my friend and I laughed at one another: where are we? This spot used to be Ploy Thai, which advertised itself as BYOB, but just as soon as my friend and I opened our beers, a couple of police officers (seeing us through the windows) came inside the restaurant and gave us tickets, because BYOB is illegal in Queens. So I may hold a bit of a grudge. All of the above would have been meaningless had only the food been good. But--just the beginning--the menu listed "oysters with your choice of meat," we chose pork, and what we got was maybe 2 ounces of pork in 2 ounces of oyster sauce! I love Thai oyster sauce, but this dish felt like a robbery, even if it had come with oysters, it was so skimpy! And then there were the overcooked clumpy dry noodles that we ordered with tofu that tasted like it just came out of the container, it had zero flavor. But I guess the Kao Soi had some positive qualities, namely that there was nothing wrong with it, but it definitely wasn't remarkable or outstanding at all... I'm not going into detail about the forgetful waitress but we had every intention of coming back again tomorrow evening as well until we actually ate here.

Delivery order: Very fast and delicious food! I really want to try this place since they open because its just in my neighborhood and I'm glad they have a delivery through yelp. We got thai iced tea for our drinks and it was a little to sweet. For appetizer we got the crispy papaya salad with shrimp and squid. Wow! Amazing. Its my first time to try crispy papaya and surprisingly it taste really good. The sauce is great too. For food I got the jor pak kad- its pork soup with vegestable. Its perfect! Very good for cold weather and you can match it with rice. Taste so delicious and similar to one of our filipino soup dish. My bf got the kung hung ley- pork belly with ginger, peanut and masala curry served with rice on the side. My bf really like it. Pork is tender and sauce is tasty. We both agreed that the food was great and we can't wait to dine in! Yum!

Updating due to the response: I appreciate the effort made. I hope this is how situations are handled during the conflict.  Ordered some delivery from here. Food wasn't bad decent flavors. However, they didn't provide the Thai iced tea that I ordered. Which is honestly not that big of deal. My real issue is how they handled the situation.We called and said we ordered but didn't get our Thai ice tea. He insisted that we didn't order it, so I thought maybe I didn't and ended the call.Then I checked my receipt in my email and it's clearly there so I called back. He argued for about two minutes saying we didn't order it. When I'm looking at it on my order/receipt. Then he said let me get my manager. They then came back and said we'll remember you next time and give it to you. I asked how would they remember and he said idk maybe you can do something in the app. Wut?? He never said sorry or offered anything else. First off don't say I didn't order something when I did. Second don't argue with me when I have proof. Third say sorry and come up with better sol. Also take Accountability of mistakes. A simple "sorry we missed that do you want a refund?" Would have sufficed I honestly would've just said no it's fine but thanks for offering. But NAH argue and say I didn't order it.

Love it, everything about Lamoon is perfect: the food, the decor, the staff, the ambiance... they also accommodated my request to make my noodles vegan and very spicy, and my tea not so sweet, I love it. It's less than a train stop distance from home and I plan to come and try the fried rice next time :)

First time here with my friend. We ordered the Thai tea pad Thai and the pearl pad see ew. I can see the creativity in the dishes. My first time trying a dish with tapioca pearl. The dishes were good. The Thai ice tea and chrysanthemum drink were good. The waiter were friendly. The environment was fun. Lots of art on the wall, plants near the window, lights hanging and the greece colors. The blue and white colors made this place feel comforting. Northern Thai food is good. Wish they can take credit card and not just cash. Hope they change that for my next visit.

A fairly new Thai spot in Elmhurst that I've been waiting to try out. Finally I got that chance & Lamoon surely didn't disappoint!Lamoon brings all the brilliant flavors of northern Thailand in this casual hipster joint. From beginning to end, the taste of the dishes were amazing! I ordered the kao soi while my friend had the tea flavored pad thai. Deliciousness in every bite without the flavors being too sweet or salty. We also ordered the fried baby shrimp pancake & mango sticky rice to share. I know, overkill for 2 people but we had to try it all! Needless to say, we left stuffed, happily satisfied.I will definitely be coming back regularly to this neighborhood joint. Thanks for a great time & amazing food!

Came here for dinner and there was some good and some bad. The seafood soup was too fishy for me and I didn't enjoy it at all. But everything else we got- shrimp skewers, rice balls, fried rice, and green curry were excellent. I'd go so far as to say the fried rice was one of the best fried rice dishes I've had. And I've tried a lot of them. Will definitely be coming back!

lowkey weeknight dinner with my bro.  came here shortly after they opened for dinner and we were the first ppl there.  the place is small but had colorful decor.  everything looked good on the menu and we finally decided to get the following:-pad thai with shrimp:  pretty good according to my brother-pad kee mao with veggies:  didn't look like much but it had really tasty stir-fry flat noodles, crunchy veggies, decent portion size.  solid choice!-mango sticky rice:  my favorite thing to order at thai places, this version is unique as the sticky rice is organically dyed with different foods (thai iced tea, butterfly pea flower, coffee, etc.)  the coloring agents gave the sticky rice slight hints of flavor but not too overwhelming.  the mango was ripe but slightly sour, i'd like sweeter ones.  -thai iced tea:  standard fare, good pairing with spicy thai foods.the service was really good and attentive.  needless to say, i really enjoyed the dinner and can't wait to come back to try their other offerings.

I'm in love with this place after my first visit today! It might just take over as my new favorite Thai place in Elmhurst knocking my old favorite Boon Chu (which is only a few blocks away) off my radar.Here is a few reasons why:-Vibrant aesthetics upon entering - loved their hanging "lanterns". It is a small space with limited tables but very comfortable homey vibes.-Service was very attentive. The owner personally took our order and gave us some recommendations and suggestions on the menu options.-BEST I EVER HAD OUTSIDE OF THAILAND - not even exaggerating. I do not know what northern thai cuisine is like but now I know. Ever since I came back from my Thailand trip in 2015. I wasn't able to find any true authentic Thai restaurant that gave me the same level of spice and kick to my tastebuds. My palate seemed to have change to a higher level of spice tolerance and all of the other Thai restaurants I've tried can no longer satisfied what I was truly seeking - that fiery kick - and I found it at Lamoon Thai!We started off with the Yum Jin Gai which was the spicy thai herbal chicken and banana blossom soup! The soup was so hearty and packed with chicken (both dark and white meat)! It was a perfect warm me up soup for a cold winter day! Bonus feature- it came out in a flamed hot pot that kept the soup hot for the duration of at least 10 mins.I really liked the Jackfruit salad with the sticky rice and fried pork rinds - the jackfruit salad was so aromatic and the perfect spice level for me !! The pork rinds added a nice crunch for texture and the sticky rice paired so well to balance off the spice of the salad itself. Another dish that I found super interesting was the Thai Tea infused pad Thai ! It's a must try. I was hesitant at first because pad thai is super basic dish that you can get anywhere and I didn't think I would find it any different from other places and boy was I wrong. It was a pleasant surprise because the noodles came out bright orange like the Thai iced tea color and tasted just like Thai iced tea. I was mind blown by how they actually incorporated the Thai tea flavor into the noodles.Not only did they pay close attention to details with regards to the taste of their dishes, the creativity of the presentation is unique in its own. From the banana leaves to butterfly pea flowers, goes to show how simplicity can take things to the next level. The Le Neptune Dessert was so fun to assemble, color changing water jelly using butterfly pea flower tea as you break into the jelly shifts the color from blue to light purple, add in another burst of color from the mango nectar and raspberry sorbet. It's an art canvas in dessert form.Can't you tell how obsessed I am already ? Go visit! Your belly will thank you later!

I was a really big fan of this tire restaurant that was located on the busy street in Elmhurst. My favorite dish was actually a mango with a sweet and salty shrimp sauce. It kind of tasted like a sweet and salty honey but I really enjoyed this dish and hopes to bring some more home. I also had their Thai tea pad thai which was really good I could only taste a little bit of Thai tea though. Some other dishes we ordered was a fish based tamarind dish, blue coconut water, and the mango sticky rice flight set. I'm really excited to go back to this restaurant to try more dishes.

My wife and I have been coming here for lunch for almost a year now. We trek all the way from Astoria on our day off because we love it so much. They offer great northern Thai food and even put their own spin on classic dishes. We always have to get the Jackfruit Salad and the fermented pork ribs! This place is a gem and worth a train ride.

I've never had northern Thai food before so most dishes on the menu looked somewhat foreign to me...So next thing you know, I don't remember the names of the dishes we ordered...All I remembered was we ordered a vercimil soup that came with pork blood, pork and shrimp paste which seem to be the ingredients of most of dishes on the menu. Another dish we had was jackfruit salad that came with sticky rice and fried pork grind. I want to say if the food wasn't so spicy I would have enjoyed them a lot more. But hey whose fault was it?
