I asked for spicy so I got what I wanted...The service was super quick and our servers were nice and provided accurate information.

We came here the other day for dinner. It was a refreshing change from the old Thai restaurant that took up the space years ago. It was much brighter and welcoming. It's a small space but they manage to pack people in comfortably. Upon sitting the staff let us know that if we checked in on yelp (only applicable on certain weekday dates I believe; not applicable on weekends from what I remember) we can get a free Thai Iced Tea or chrysanthemum tea. A very nice gesture. The menu has a variety of things to try. The Kanom Jeen Nam Ngeaw (vermicelli with pork ribs, tomato, pig blood cubes  in soup) was nice and flavorful. The pork ribs fell off the bone. The soup had a nice fragrant flavor and heat that sneaks up on you. The Yum Jin Gai (flamed hot pot with chicken, banana blossom, coriander in spicy herbal soup) is the Thai version of a chicken soup with HEAT! LOVED!! It came with chunks of chicken. But was nice and refreshing  because of the coriander and lemongrass.  We had some leftover and brought it home. The next day it was even better!!! Be prepared to sweat though!!The Larb Nena was another well executed dish. It packed a lotta heat but was so good that we kept eating it and by the time we finished that fish, my entire mouth needed to be hosed down by the FDNY. Staff was super friendly and accommodating. We will def be coming back to the try the other stuff soon!!

Good more than I thought . Its just 9pm  a lot restaurant start closing just hungry and nothing to eat Waitress is nice she have a worm smile give me time to read a menu. And a food come out very quick thank for good food

Outstanding - astounding, even - Thai food with a terrific interior design and friendly, friendly service. The sai oua (herbaceous grilled pork sausage, redolent of fragrant, aromatic lemongrass, makrut limes perhaps galangal?) and leng soup have stayed in my mind for days, even weeks, after eating them. The leng soup is especially arresting: a shock of pork neck or spine in a pool of collagen-rich broth, and showered with finely-chopped herbs. The vegetarian at our table broke rank and proclaimed it a highlight of our meal.But there were so many highlights - the nam phrik ong should be served in a trough. The jackfruit was unexpectedly meaty and spicy. The "brutally spicy" leng soup was anything but, despite my earnest plea for a "Thai spicy" bowl, but this was for the better. Everyone got to enjoy it, and we left Lamoon for Broadway's night-time thrum sated and blissfully.P.S.: Lamoon, if you're reading this, please publish a cookbook.

Authentic Thai food always has a twist from the generic Asian fusion cookie cutters.  The spices pop in your mouth and the decor and experience is always unique.  The service was quick and the food was tasty.  The portions seem small but rest assured it is very filling.  It is also very convenient as it is right in front of of the subway entrance so you don't have to worry about walking in the cold during those brisk breezy NYC deep cold winters.

I have been to northern Thailand before and came with grand expectations of what the food would be like based on that, the high yelp reviews and also just a good impression of the Thai food in this area. My friends and I ordered the Som Tum Thai (not spicy or tangy enough for me), Khao Soi with chicken (seemed to be lacking a certain punch) and Thai tea pad Thai (good but nothing to write home about). I think that the food here was decent but definitely not to the standard of Ayada, Khao Kang or Chao Thai in the surrounding area. The clientele of the restaurant also does not seem to include as many Thai people as the aforementioned restaurants either which leads me to wonder if the food has been toned down to suit American tastes.

It's been a while since I've written a review but since I had Lamoon last night, it's fresh in my mind!I came with one other person around 730-8pm and it wasn't too busy so we easily got a seat. It's definitely a cute little spot and they also have a bathroom in the back just in case you're wondering since you won't see it when you walk in.The water they give looks like water but it's actually pandan water! Interestingggggg! Also, our server was super nice.For an appetizer, we ordered:Hnam Kadook Moo: grandpa recipe homemade fried fermented pork ribs- Loved how crispy it was on the outside and it was pretty garlicky but I felt like there was flavor missing. Maybe cause it's not a lot of meat around the bone so it was a little more on the dry side.Entrees:Chicken Khao Soi: egg noodle in creamy coconut curry topped with crispy noodle. Comes with shallots, lime slice & pickled cabbage on the side- The chicken was fall of the bone good! Loved the creamy coconut which was a little more on the sweeter side. And obv love anything crispy so the crispy noodles on top were a plus. Overall good flavor!Thai Tea Pad Thai: Thai tea infused rice noodle sauté with tamarind juice, sweet turnip, black tofu, ground nut, beansprout, dried shrimp flake & topped with splash of coconut milk (I got it with shrimp)- The noodles are actually orange and really do taste like thai tea. Very interesting concept but it was good! I feel like the overall flavor isn't too strong so it doesn't overpower the thai tea noodles. Liked that there were lots of pieces with shrimp.Overall, I felt like the food at Lamoon was good! It didn't blow me away and I'd def come back to try other dishes on the menu but also don't need to go back lol. TLDR; Chicken Khao Soi!

This is the new Thai in town, in an already busy Thai restaurant area representing Northern Thai food. This is not the typical food when you think of Thai food since this is not central Thai cuisine. The restaurant is on the small side, so make sure to go early. Update, I have read some reviews with some commenting on the portion size of the dishes, I have been here 4 times now and as you can see from my pics, I tried a lot of the menu and never once did I think the portion size was small.The foodTum Kanoon(Jackfruit salad)- Green jackfruit, ground pork, homemade chili shrimp paste, plum tomato, kaffir lime leaves, cilantro & scallion served with sticky rice. I think this is my new favorite dish here, it's spicy, sweet and savory. I really enjoyed the texture of the jackfruit with the ground pork and I really liked the flavor of the shrimp paste. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Larb Neua- Mixed 9 herbs homemade shrimp paste with ground pork in Lanna-Thai style. Flavor wise, this was my fav. I really enjoyed the flavor, I loved the crunch from the fried noodle to the earthy flavor of the spices with the ground pork. You eat this with the side of veg and I ordered a side of sticky rice since I like larb with sticky rice. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Khao Tod- Homemade crispy rice balls with curry paste, kaffir lime leaves, and coconut flakes. Think of these as like a crispy Thai Arancini, I thought this was great, I really enjoyed the texture of the rice and I thought the flavor inside was so unique and tasty. I think this is a item to try. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Fried Lemongrass Chicken Wings- Fried marinated chicken wings with coriander root, lemongrass and kaffir leaves. I really enjoyed how flavofull and juicy these wings came out. The wings come out nice and crispy but the wings are on the same side. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Angie- Crispy fried green papaya salad with squid & shrimp. I thought this dish worked well, I enjoyed the seafood with the nice crunchiness of the fried green papaya. I would recommend eating this quickly since the bottom will get soggy. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Kung Pare- Crispy baby shrimp cloud cake. They let you know ahead of time but this dish does take like 15 minutes to make. The dish is something I had when I was a kid and it was good. It was nice and crispy and it was a pretty large order. I enjoyed this dish but the dish did come out a little too crunchy, like shrimp pieces were flying everywhere when I cut into it lol These also pair with with a sweet chili sauce which was nice. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Khao Soi Chicken- Egg noodles with chicken in creamy coconut curry topped with crispy noodles with a side of shallots, lime and pickled lettuce. They offer the option to do chicken leg or chicken breast but I feel you should order it the way they do it in Thailand which is the chicken leg. The flavor on this was great and I really like how they have the boiled yellow noodle as well as a crispy noodle on top. I enjoyed this dish but this dish came off spicy and this dish is typically not. I also enjoyed how tender and juicy the chicken was and I really liked the pickled lettuce that came with it, the pickled lettuce offer a nice counter to the savory and rich broth. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Sai Aua(100 grams of herbal Thai sausage)- Ground pork with chili paste, kaffir leaves, lemongrass, cilantro & pork ear. I enjoyed these, they tasted like the traditional Thai fish cake called Tod Mun but this one had pig ear which offered a really great crunch. This is a something to try. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Kang Hung Ley- Tender pork belly, ginger, peanut, pickled garlic with masala curry served with rice. I thought this was really good, I enjoyed how tender the pork belly was and I thought the sauce it was served it was great. yelp.com/user_local_phot…Kanom Jeen Nam Ngeaw- Vermicelli in pork ribs shrimp paste stew, blood cubes, red cotton flowers, plum tomatoes with a side of bean sprouts, long bean, lime slice & pickle. I enjoyed this dish but this dish is not for everyone, there is shrimp paste which has a very unique flavor and it also has blood cubes which some people are not familiar one. Overall a dish to try if you are adventurous. yelp.com/user_local_phot…
The food was soo yummy! Portions were perfect. The restaurant is very conveniently located next to the Elmhurst Ave subway stop. And the interior was very nice as well. Will definitely return
Great dishes to try if you want to experience Northern Thailand at first glance. Drinks were great as well. Can't wait to go back next time to try other dishes on the menu

Yum yum yum! Everything here is one of a kind. Superb authentic Northern Thai cuisine. A must-try. The restaurant is tiny and we went there around 5pm on a Friday, and by 6:30/7pm there is already a line and it was packed. We ordered so much food and every dish was just absolutely unique. They even have pig's brain on the menu (they called it 'pork brain' on the menu) but we didn't feel adventurous enough to order it. Someday....
Loved the subtle sweetness of the Tea Pad Thai. Going back for the Khao Soi. Pad Kee Mao looked bland but friend said it was delicious. Attentive and quick service.

was not that impressed with the food here,  I don't know whats going on lamoon but were these dishes made to cater to the local folks? cause if so stahp, ordered the mango salad, curry and ended it all with the mango sticky rice, and was not impressed with any of the food items I had. Curry was average with the soup base being more watery than i liked, but maybe thats the style of curry, mango salad was okay enjoyed the sweet with the savory kick of the fish sauce mixed into it, but again nothing about it screamed out to me. mango sticky rice was cute but again uninteresting and uninspiring.........with so many thai food options around the elmhurst area, the asian fushion joint that is lamoon is probably the least impression

Lamoon is a gem, the Thai Tea Padthai was amazing especially with Shrimp, and the Yum Jin Gai is a must, its a hotpot dish with amazing flavor, its a little spicy, but you wont be able to stop helping yourself to it! I can still taste the flavor, its so salivating and rich.The desserts were amazing, and the kitchen even sent us a very nice experimental dessert to try, it was so unique!Oh the Art is so cool here too, love the decor and it just makes the vibe that much more fun!!I'm gonna come back, so see you there!!!

Cute and unique! The interior was chic and clean. The staff was very polite and friendly. The food was great and impressive. We enjoyed the signature Kanom Jee nam ngeaw and Khao Soi we ordered. While we were having our meal, the waitress offered us some pandan water and it was quite interesting. I love food and try new things. This is definitely a go-to if you want something extraordinary in your Thai taste.I like this place a lot and I'm craving to go back already! Highly recommended!On the side note - The boss and waitress are hypebeast on Supreme!

I heard good things about Lamoon from a friend and was intrigued by a photo of their rainbow sticky rice on her Instagram, so I came here with my brother to check it out. I love checking out the growing amount of Southeast Asian spots run by Southeast Asian immigrants and their descendants. I'm a fan of mainstream Thai food, but it's nice to see restaurants trying to showcase Thai food from different regions.My brother and I got the Thai tea pad thai, the kang hung ley, sai aua, rainbow sticky rice, kung pare, and a khao tod (rice ball) to share. The khao tod was interesting but not particularly remarkable, and the sai aua had a strong, somewhat acquired taste that neither my brother nor I loved. We did love the kang hung ley, which is a tender pork belly with ginger, peanut, pickled garlic, with masala curry. When I think and dream of pork belly, it looks something like this. I loved the kung pare, which reminded me (and my parents who tried our leftovers later) of a Filipino dish called okoy, but like a distant cousin/relative of that dish. It was really big and basically a bunch of tiny fried shrimps and batter. I'm a fan, but my brother didn't love it as much. He did love the thai tea pad thai, which was good and surprisingly the Thai tea taste really went through.The rainbow sticky rice was a perfect way to end the meal. The different colors actually have different flavors you can taste - coconut, Thai coffee, butterfly pea, Thai tea, jackfruit, and matcha. Delicious, and something you should definitely get no matter what you choose for your main courses. Even though we didn't love everything we got, I did love a lot of what I got and the vibe of the place. There's a lot of other things I want to try on the menu. The service was also great, as was the art on the wall.

Nothing but positive. The food is the star of the place but the place itself is charming and the staff was super nice as well. I was super excited for the Khao Soi and it exceeded my expectations. Everything was also very fresh tasting.

This would be in my have-to-go suggestion list ,all the best taste in the restaurant ,also the waitress and waiter are super nice , highly recommended for someone who wants to try the traditional Thai food

Came here to try the Leng Soup. It did not disappoint, the soup was spicy but rich in flavor. The meat was tender and juicy. I highly recommend if you love spicy food. It's big enough to feed 3 people. Also ordered Thai Iced Tea and it's the best one I've had so far. The taste of the black tea is right on point unlike other ones I've had that are just full of sugar... Our server Sky is delightful, very friendly and accommodating. She knows everything about the food. Highly recommend!!!

So I came across this northern style thai place in Elmhurst. If you've never tried northern style thai, I will say go check them out, it's a very different taste and everything we ordered was very good. It's a very small place so I cant really tell you if there is a wait on the weekend or during the dinner hours. They are known for their pork dishes but like my usual self I always like to try the stuff they are not known for. I'll let the pictures do the talking. Check them out if you are in the area.

Never been to a restaurant that makes you feel so welcomed like Lamoon does. The food were all so delicious. The ribs were so easy to pulled out and the flavor was all soaked into the meat! The thai tea pad Thai was so innovative and yummy. And also need to mention the sticky mango rice! There were six flavors of the sticky rices, we liked the green tea one the most! Any way, it's a great place to hang out with friends!

The food was delicious....the service was VERY good.  We are total novices of authentic Thai food...so I can't even tell you exactly what we had...we relied upon our waiter for much of what we ordered......but it was all good.  For a group of 5, 3 women, 2 men....the bill was $100...unheard of in NYC!   Two warnings, it is BYOB (which they graciously served) and it is all cash...no credit.

Great food! I really liked both the taste and thr design of the food. I ordered Tum Kanoon (Jackfruit salad) and it was amazing and spicy. Also tasted their Larb Neua which a friend of mine ordered, and it was tasty and nicely designed. I will definitely go back to try other menu options.

The food here is good in general though the papaya salad is somehow abit tough for me. Anyway I really like the staffs here who are very friendly and they even suggested to give me a bag for my painting. 5 stars for their service
Well food wise, not tasty compared to other thai places, but some great people serving in the restaurant, if i would ever go back then its only because of their warm welcome.

All the food taste amazing, decor was modern and cute. What I love about the place is that they don't put MSG.  After the meal, I was not thirsty at all. The portions are just right, not too much but definitely enough for 1, dessert was pleasing and staffs were very friendly. Will definitely come back!

Epic fried rice. If you're torn between two fried rice providers, go with this one. Normally it takes me a few days to get it together and compile my notes for a comprehensive Yelp review, but I felt tonight that it would be an ethical issue if I didn't write a glowing review in real time:First of all, I have never found a fried rice that upon delivery has been able to maintain its integrity and flavor. Luckily, Lamoon spared me the floppy vegetables and soggy rice. Whoever made this is on top of his or her game.I ordered the "Fried Rice Nam Prik Ong," which is fried rice with homemade plum tomato chili paste. The vegetables, especially the broccoli stalks, were crisp and firm, and I have never even tasted a fried rice this delicious on site. Anywhere in New York. I would also like to thank the kitchen staff for accommodating my request to prepare it "as spicy as possible."I walk by this restaurant all the time, and the venue looks beautifully conceived as well as clean and prosperous. I look forward to sitting down and supplementing my next savory experience with the "Floating Lotus" organic tapioca trio.

I saw Lamoon opening up a few months ago and really wanted to try it out! They have such a beautiful interior with a huge mural on the walls. The space isn't that big. They have a huge wooden communal tables that's really pretty with a bunch of other seating on the side. The day I came in there was 2 added make shift tables in the back which is where I sat. The place was crowded so I'm pretty sure these tables for just a last resort because they were the kind of tables you have in your backyard for a BBQ but you cover up with a table cover because it's not the prettiest.For the menus it was on a clipboard and looked pretty used since they were just using normal paper so some of the menus were folded or dirty. I started off with their Thai Ice Tea which was really good! My group ordered a bunch of stuff to try and sample everything. We ordered their Mango Salad, Nam Prik Ong, Nam Prik Ong Fried Rice, and Khao Soi. All the dishes were fairly big and easy to share. The mango salad I thought was a little tart but I loved the crispy anchovies they put on it! There was a little too much sauce on it but it was a good starter to have. Their Nam Prik Ong which I used to make lettuce wraps out of I thought were a little too salty. It helps that it came with rice to tone down the saltiness. The best part was the Khao Soi! I recently found out about this dish about a year ago and it's my favorite Thai dish! I love the crispiness of the noodles. For meat I was kind of hoping for more but it was a good amount with the noodles you get. The service was really quick and I could see myself coming here more. It's especially easy because the train station is right outside! It's such a convenient location. I saw they have a good amount of lunch specials too which I would probably do to avoid the dinner rush.

One of the best thai restaurant in Elmhurst/Jackson heights. I walked by this place seeing the nyt articles about this place hanging on the wall a few times and finally I walked in! The interior is very pretty, blue and while tone makes u feel like close to the ocean/nature.I tried the 3rd thing on the special menu, I forgot the name but it has pork chops and blood curd in the noodle soup. Very tomato-ish flavor with a little luck of spicy. And the noodles are well cooked and soaked with the soup which is exactly the way I liked it! For apps we got crab egg palm. The omelette is served with palm leaves and u can taste the palm tree with the eggs. It's a special flavor and definitely worth trying. Also heard good things about coconut drink and rainbow mango sticky rice dessert. Need to come back.

DO NOT COME HERE! I only came here because I saw that they had a good review but no, this place is a trap. I don't know how this place has almost five stars on yelp. As for the dining experience bring your jackets and layer up as there is no heat despite the staff claiming that it's on. We were then sat next to the portable heater at a foldable table... I didn't come to a restaurant to be seated at a FOLDABLE TABLE... This also created a very awkward vibe as the table is 4 feet next to the staffers (we were the only ones.) The plates were all scratched up and dirty. We ordered the lemon grass chicken wing appetizers and I'm not sure if it's lemongrass or the chicken hasn't been plucked. The water is definitely not clean or the ice machine hasn't been cleaned as there is a noticeable flavor to it. My bf ordered the pad see ew and he's never had a pad see ew with boba/tapioca bubbles in it. And I got the panang curry and I only had two bites and I was done. The chicken was super hard to chew, it was rubbery and had a fishy taste to it. This whole experience was disappointing and we felt very uncomfortable.

Service was very good. Host came quick, talked to us with his big smile and carried the nice attitude all the way. Northern Thai cuisine seem to have slightly different flavor compare to the Thai I'm used to here. Less salty and more sourness I would say.Ordered the Thai Tea Pad Thai and was mentally ready to suffer. End up it does taste sweet, but Lamoon had it balanced pretty well. My gf was satisfied with her dish as well. Will come back to try some more.

This is definitely will be one of my favorite thai restaurant!Came here at lunch time, they have a lunch special and i think it's a good deal. And the server was so friendly and nice. She asked me to check in on yelp to get a free drink , so nice The food was delicious. Almost everything that i ordered was so good.My fave is their baby shrimp (kung pare) and the rice ball. The portion is pretty good, not too much but not too small.Will come back soon!!

My husband and I have been here twice -- and each time we were very impressed by the delicious dishes and awesome service!FOODFor appetizers, we had the fried lemongrass chicken wings and rice-balls. The former had a good zest to it and the meat was juicy. The rice-balls were done perfectly: crunchy on the outside and softer on the inside. Not sure what herbs were added, but I could probably eat a bucket of them :)Then for the main course, we've had the khao soi beef, glass noodles, and nam prik ong fried rice. Everything was delicious! Be sure to denote how spicy you'd like it to be though! I have a very low spice tolerance so mild was a bit spicer than expected.Their Thai iced tea was just right and the pea flower tea is as delicious/refreshing as it is pretty. We also indulged in dessert (rainbow sticky rice) and it, too, was tasty.SERVICEEveryone that we met was super nice and helpful. Our waters were constantly refilled and were pandan infused.  A+ for attention!MISCELLANEOUSI love their decor and ambiance! I also thought that their bunny dish was very cute. Overall, highly recommended and we look forward to being repeat customers :)

Love the menu, albeit limited, but flavors were excellent. I didn't recognize a lot of the names of dishes offered but the ingredients and execution are authentic Thai. Did not bother with Thai tea pad Thai because I like authentic pad Thai (actually prefer the egg wrapped kind). You won't see generic dishes you normally see in Manhattan (like green curry and drunken noodles) but this is an excellent choice to try Thailand's many other good eats. The rainbow sticky coconut rice and mango was ok. I would go elsewhere for dessert. Savory items are excellent

**2.5 STARS**To start on a positive note, the service was certainly nice. The restaurant is very very small. The restroom is through the kitchen. Not every restaurant is for everyone and everyone knows this. We ordered:1. Kang Hoh-glass noodle with marsala curry with assorted vegetables and peanut, served with rice. $112. Kang Hung Ley-tender pork belly, ginger slivers, peanut, pickled garlic, with masala curry served with rice. $123. Khao Soi-with a drumstick served with egg noodle in coconut curry with the crispy noodles on the side. Garnishes included raw shallot, lime and pickled lettuce. $124. Rainbow sticky rice with mango $9From all the restaurant experiences in my life, the portions at Lamoon were small for the price. Maybe I am too used to other Asian places that serve much larger portions for smaller prices but for $12 a dish I did expect to leave full and we were not. We were still hungry afterwards. For $11 I thought my friend's dish, Khao Soi, would have at least two drumsticks. Drumsticks are so cheap but she only got one. I saw drumsticks at the store today for under 60 cents a pound. My friend also mentioned it was not hot in the center of the drumstick. She felt it was cold inside. The flavors in my opinon were very muted, dull and unremarkable. Personally I was not wow'ed by anything at Lamoon. As a warning, there was a large portion of the menu that my entire table could not eat. We are all allergic to crustaceans. Being allergic to shellfish is super common, allergies to crustaceans even more common. 90% of the menu had shrimp or shrimp paste. We went to another thai place a few days later in Corona, paid under $30 and we got 5 filling meals from the order. I had leftovers for lunch for days. At Lamoon we spent near $60 and three of us were still hungry afterwards. As I said, everyone has different taste and requirements from eating out. Personally if I want Thai, Lamoon would never be a choice for me again. I rather go to Corona to my regular Thai place where I pay $10-$20 and it feeds two people until we are full with leftovers and the flavors are much more yummy and stronger.

It's always a pleasure to dine at Lamoon.  I'm a huge fan of their Pink Pad Thai (originally called Pink Lady) and their Thai Tea Pad Thai.  Yesterday my spouse and I tried Angie for the first time and it was perfect to start.  During winter I'll definitely recommend their Yum Jin Gai if you can handle the spice.
Soooooo delicious and yummy. Portions are perfect and the price is just right. Friendly staff and beautiful decor. Love this place. Definitely a gem.
Food was vibrant and refreshing, the service was amazing.  Thankyou to our lovely server , Sky and also to the owner , Otto. Definitely worth the trek to Elmhurst. Can't wait to come back!!!
Good Service (Thank you, Sky) and Super Yummy Food!!!! Can't wait to try the other dishes when i go back!!!!! Worth going to Elmhurst for good thai food!!!

Small place and trendy at the moment. A bit porky and great if that is your thing. Slim on the vegetarian choices which is usually one of the big draws of mixed groups in Thai cuisine. Good attentive staff. Could benefit from a little more varied menu.

Lamoon has a great n original taste of Northern Thai food. Since they called themselves the origin of Northern Thai, I'd say, obviously they are and even better than I thought.Jackfruit salad is a hit. You can't refuse the combination from the juiciness of jackfruit, and herbals that spiced up this dish. With sticky rice it's heaven. lmaoYum Jin Gai is an offer that you can refuse. sounds like a godfather but it's true. You can't resist the scent from number of herbals they put its in. Also the banana blossom and Vietnamese Coriander are most suitable ingredients. I LUV THIS!our server, Otto was very attentive, lovely n handsome. Strongly recommended to come and try. Don't forget to check in for FREE-DRINK TOO.

Great innovative Thai food (three words: Fried. Chicken. Curry.) and unbelievable service. We ordered through Grubhub/ Seamless and when their contracted driver never showed to deliver our food, the staff at Lamoon stepped up and delivered it themselves. We've broken up with Grubhub, but Lamoon, you've earned yourselves loyal regulars. Foodwise, we love the Khao Soi-really rich silky broth and tender, flavorful chicken. Also LOVE LOVE LOVE the mango with fish sauce appetizer (very similar to Filipino green mango with bagoong from back home!) Also, did I mention you can get fried chicken as a protein choice in your curries?!?

Even in Elmhurst/queens it can be hard to find a Thai place that doesn't "water down" their menu to accommodate non-Thai customers. Enter...Lamoon! In some ways, its northern Thai menu is even more authentic and diverse than places you'll find in Bangkok. Ingredients like ant eggs and pig brain and the fact that they don't ask you for your spice level should speak to their unrelenting commitment to authenticity... Although they are relatively new so hopefully they won't give in?!We ordered takeout, but everything (including fried chicken wings and the pork skin) defied physics and was still crispy when we got it! Some standouts were definitely the Kang Hoh (pork belly with glass noodle) and the Jack fruit salad that came with the best sticky rice I've ever had.So... If you're looking for a "Thai" restaurant that serves calamari and Thai ice tea cocktails I would look elsewhere. But if you want your mind to be blown by authentic Thai food and all its exciting flavors, definitely pay Lamoon a visit--just please don't complain about the spice level.

I've been to pretty much every Thai restaurant in Elmhurst and this place is definitely one of the best. Their menu is like no other Thai place that I've ever been to.  It is very unique. The food is absolutely authentic and flavorful. This is coming from someone who lived in Thailand for 2 years. The only complain I have is they took quite a while to bring out the food.Advice to management: I would change the storefront sign and make it bigger and interesting because I always drive past the palace and didn't notice it was there for a long time. I don't want you guys to go out of business because I like your food  and I want to come back for more.

We thoroughly enjoyed the pork belly curry stew and their famous pork rib and blood vermicelli soup entrees. The noodle soup was infused with fish sauce, tomatoes, soy, meat and shallot herb broth flavor so well that I could've, would've  breathed the whole thing in if I weren't in the presence of civility. So I just went in for seconds and thirds, slowly of course. I cannot wait to eat in and have their jackfruit salad, heavenly wings and more literal bloody fare.

This cute little restaurant serves really great Northern Thai food. Kanom Jeen Nam Ngeaw - Just the right touch of sour and spice, the perfect kick for a rainy dayKang Hung Ley - Loved how sweet/sour this wasShrimp Cloud Cake - Way bigger than expected but a nice and crunchy appetizerPork Brain - YUMCrab Egg Plam - I liked it but it could have used a bit more flavor

Wow wow wow. So blown away. I've never been inclined to write a review until now. I went during lunch hours which had a lunch special for $10 that included an appetizer and an entree. The best thing hands down was the northern style soup. The ribs just melted off and the soup was rich, sweet and overall a heck lot of deliciousness.If you're ever down to go an inch out of your comfort zone with Thai food, this is the place to go. It's authentic, affordable and as far as I can tell, there's nothing else like it here in NYC.

Very cute restaurant at corner of Britton.   Authentic northern Thai cuisine.   Really enjoy kow soy chicken and fried papaya salad.   So happy to have another authentic Thai restaurant besides Sripraphai to go to.  Excellent friendly staff

Lamoonnnnnn has a great reputation in Northern Thai food, I've heard quite a lot about them. So today I gave it a try, I ordered Angie(green papaya salad), its fried green papaya salad, flour covered the green papaya, and absorbed the sauce into its. Perfext combination between crisp n juicy.YummmSecond is the Kung-Pare. The baby shrimp cloud cake. Its huge and looks like a cloud. I recommended strongly!Third is the kangaroo hung key, it's very popular , I formed by the server. The atmosphere is quiet nice and different from the other places around this area. I was so full! Three of us with 2 appetizers n 1 main dish. About $35 for whole meal with this price its steal.I definitely come back again to try. The rainbow sticky rice with mango.

This is going to be my fav northern thai food in town, since there is only one. Lol. I like spicy food, and their LARB NUEA is very tastyone. Its perfect combination of great spiciness and herbal flavor together. Not very spicy as my standard but luv it. Kanom jeen nam ngeaw is a must. The flavor of herbal stuffs they put in n red cotton flower imported from thailand will make u fly in the air. Lol#2Fried rice nam prik noom was a great too. Without interuptation from any veggies it represented the green chili flavor 100%. Sadly numbers of restaurants that i visited, they felt customer may not like fried rice with chili paste so they mixed with scallion r tomato, that ruined the chili flavor. Understand? Lol#3Baby shrimp cloud cake is crazy atomic crispy n tasty, like in thailand but it takes like 15 mins for tgis order, which longer than in thailand. Lol#4Obviously will come back again for anothrr meal.

It pains me to issue Lamoon only three stars here.  The staff here are soooooo nice and attentive.  It's just the majority of the food here, while executed well, lacked any real flavor.  I kinda expect Thai food to punch you in the face with flavor and honestly I didn't get that here.The fried chicken wings and the fried shrimp cake were pretty good.  The shrimp fried cake in particular was a very large dish and not too oily.  Order this if you've got three other people with you.The Crab Egg Plam and Kang Hoh were not great.  Both of these dishes lacked flavor.  The Crab Egg Plam in particular was super thin and really didn't contain much crab.  Same with the Kang Hoh, just kinda bland.There were two other specials, one was a chicken noodle and other a fried branzino filet.  These were executed better. The texture of the chicken was very moist.  The filet was fried perfectly.I will most likely try Lamoon again given that the service was very good however I may wait a bit before doing so.

Had a great experience. Me and my friends passed by prior to opening and thought it was a cafe as the decorations were very cute and different from most Thai restaurants we have been to.There are many Thai restaurants in this area but not many that are specified to northern Thai food.Must say that the service was definitely A+! The staff was so attentive. It's a pretty small restaurant so there's limited seating and as its a pretty new restaurant and being a weekday me and my party were seated pretty quickly.Had the Kang hung leung (brasied pork belly) and the Khao soi (egg noodles in creamy curry). The food was not spicy so that was a little different from hat I expected. I really did enjoythe Khao SOI. It was a pleasant surprise. Me and my friend really enjoyed the creamy yet notes of the curry base. The egg Noddles were soaked well with the soup which made it enjoyable to eat. We both agreed that his was something we would come back to get.While the pork belly was not bad it was a little dry and nothing to write home about.The blue moon juice was a coconut juice with a fruit exlier that was blue in color (they did mention it was a type of flower). The color was too pretty to drink but was refreshing and did taste strongly of coconut juice. The colors went well with the blue interior around :p Definitely a must try and I'll definitely be back ;)

Really was looking forward to this place, sad to say it was disappointing. Came for an early dinner on a rainy weekday, ordered the Fried Papaya Salad, Pad Kee Mao and Garlic Oyster with Pork. The appetizer salad was the best out of the three.... The Pad kee Mao was too greasy and the oil flavor was overpowering. The Garlic Pork was so underwhelming I had to force myself to finish it as to not waste $13.  I'd have been happier with the Chinese food takeout I normally get. Not worth trekking the 30 minutes on the train to eat here, my local Thai restaurant in Woodside makes better quality food. What really drew me to the place was the decor and ambiance.....It looked cute from the outside but upon stepping in, the interior was tainted by the pungent odor of Fish Sauce, as if someone had wiped the floor with it....And when it rains, don't sit by the entrance window it leaks!!!

First of all, the interior is so cute and the vibe is very chill! Service is also pretty good.I'm so happy that there are so many different Thai cuisines in this neighborhood. So this place specializes in Northern Thai food. When it first opened it does not offer the more common Thai cuisines like curry. But I noticed that they have added several curry dishes to their menu. Anyways, I've tried three dishes: the Kanom Jeen Nam Ngeaw (pork rib noodle with pork blood), mango salad, and Khao soi noodles with chicken drumstick. The pork rib noodle has a lot of tomatoes in it and the broth is really greasy, so I did not like it very much. The mango salad is quite regular. But the Khao soi noodle is SO DELICIOUS! It's my first time having khao soi curry and I loved it so much that I finished all the broth.I think I would be interested to explore other dishes here. All in all I would recommend this place as the ambience is lovely and the menu is interesting.

This is my first time to visit this place and though it's small space but clean and more natural lights from those wide windows... the food meet my standard as for Asian Cuisine and the Price is fair...Our server is very attentive and the rest of the staff are friendly... Probably I'm coming back here...

Stopped in for lunch on Thursday, Feb. 7th. Odered the pork jerky and chicken wing appetizers as well as thai tea. All amazing! We both had the Pad Seau with pork for entrees. We asked for their spice tray and received the house spice which definitely kicked things up a notch. We both will return.

Four stars for taste and creativity. Thai restaurants are a dime a dozen in NYC and everyone basically serves the same tried and true fare. Kudos to Lamoon for trying to make things a little more interesting. I had the pad thai infused with Thai iced tea, which was very sweet and tasty. A corworker had pad see ew that was mixed with tapioca pearls (like the ones in bubble tea) for a interesting texture. Even the water is flavored with pandan leaf, which I enjoyed but some of my friends did not.  All served in simple nautical interior with plenty of natural light. I would definitely come back here to try some of the other dishes.

The food that I ordered came on time and hot. I think this is the first time in any place I've ordered that it was fresh and hot . I wish u would have put a menu in the bag but no worries I got your number , thanks so much , it was also delicious

What you need to know:- This restaurant specializes in Northern Thai cuisine, offering items that are not commonly seen or experienced in other Thai restaurants.  Lamoon makes food that is reminiscent of their home in Lampang. - Hip and modern ambiance, but their food is traditional Lanna cuisine, from the Lanna kingdom of Northern Thailand. - Accepts credit cards- Small and intimate, with approximately 20 seats. What we ordered: - Khao soi with chicken price $12 - Khao soi might be the most well known Northern Thai dish among foreigners.  It is easy to see why, it is sweet and creamy from the coconut milk, it is not overly spicy, it has egg noodles and crispy noodles for crunchy texture and it includes a chicken drumstick (and who doesn't like drumsticks?).  This dish comes with pickled mustards, lime and red onions - make sure you include all these in the dish! I just wish that this khao soi was a little more spicy! - Khanom jeen nam ngeaw $12 - While khao soi might be the most well known, this dish might be the most beloved in Northern Thai cuisine.  It is like a stew with influences from Myanmar and the Chinese southern region of Yunnan.  It is made with a tangy tomato base, with lots of chili, pork ribs, minced pork and cubes of congealed pork blood. The noodles are thin rice vermicelli (khanom jeen).  It tastes tangy, savory, and is bursting with spiciness! I'm very thankful to my special Thai friend who introduced this to me! - Sai Aua $12 - Spicy northern Thai sausage that is most famous from the city of Chiang Mai.  It is usually filled with meat, chilis and herbs such as lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves and galangal. I felt like this sausage was 50% chilis, it was way too spicy for this weak sauce Cantonese! :( I do like that it was presented in a small bird's nest-like basket. **Conclusion: I will most definitely be coming back to try more Lanna cuisine!

great tasting food and wonderful service. if you like spicy, come here. if you do not eat spicy i would recommend you find somewhere else; basically EVERYTHING on the menu is on a spectrum of the spicy scale lol or you can just have water and white rice, but thats not exciting.i never had fried papaya salad before, it was quite an interesting dish but it kind of felt short for me. sad. the fried papaya slivers were clumped together so many were stuck together and mushy when served. maybe the chef can tweek that.
Good Northern Thai food , flavorful...Desert Mango & sticky rice is unique with different flavor of sticky rice ... highly recommend

Different than every other Thai place you have been to. So unique and so gooood! I remember in one of those steaming hot summer days, I don't feel that well before the dinner. But after I have some LaMoon sour yet spicy hot soup down the throat, I feel the whole body was elevated. My head no longer dizzy and my appetite was raised. I tried many dishes and they rate from not bad to amazing! I don't think you can possibly be disappointed here. The waitress was super friendly. She recognized me the second time I came back. I will definitely keep going back for some more spicy dishes!

I love this place! Amazing customer service and i love the people here. They are amazing and love what they do. I recommend getting their tamarind fish and their origin dishes. Personal preference for the pork blood rice. You can get real authentic northern thai food here.

One of my favorite Thai Northern restaurant. Restaurant 's design is cozy.We Ordered Khao kun jin,Abb ong oor,Kanom jeen nam ngeaw,Tum kanoon (jackfruit salad),Kang hung ley,Sai aua,Yum woon sen. The food is original taste and sooo good. The service 's awesome. Servers are nice and friendly! :-)

A small but beautiful and bright restaurant in Elmhurst, Lamoon provides flavors and ingredients that are definitely unique and delicious. Specializing in Northern Thai food, their menu is free of the generic Thai food that can be found around the city. The standout was the Jackfruit Salad. Amazing spices, flavors, and textures that cannot be described in words. It must be experienced to understand its flavor.We also got the Brutal Spicy Spinal Cord dish - another absolutely delicious dish with succulent meat and amazing seasonings. Overall the food was amazing and definitely worth a return visit. I highly recommend coming.

Try this place today. And we try lunch special and $10 you got 1 app .  Crispy pork app for lunch it's not my favorite but sup it's ok and pad kee mo it's good it's different and pad Thai it's good too and fried rice it's good . But dessert sticky rice with taro it's yummy sticky rice the have so many flavors. Definitely we will back to try different food

Love this place! My first visit left me with a great impression.It's a small restaurant but the thing that pops out at you is the murals on the wall. They're very bright and interesting that it brings a smile to your face.The menu seemed extensive and what I liked about it was that it also had realistic photos of the food items.I came with two other people so we decided to order a few dishes that we shared. It was a tough decision but hands-down, everything we ordered was a hit. Papaya salad, tea infused pad thai, pineapple curry, khao soi, crab egg plam, and khao tod. Service was fast and friendly. I would come again to try some other dishes. I am a fan!

The food is amazing as others commented. We loved the pork rib and organ soup. On top of the food, every staff is friendly and super helpful. We had a big group of families with kids, it could get chaos as people could imagine. Every staff accommodated our needs and took care of kids needs every moment. This is a really warm experience in NYC as any family could imagine.

The menu has some unique dishes that you wouldn't see at other Thai restaurants, and they are really tasty - Leng Soup is a must try. The staff is warm and friendly.  This is going to be my go-to when I'm in the mood for authentic Thai food.

Service was good. But the food and the portion size served was no bueno. After sharing an appetizer and two entrees, we were still hungry. The dishes either lacked flavor or most of the them had the same flavor profile. Or maybe, just maybe I didn't order the right food..? I liked the glass noodle salad, but didn't have the same liking for the other two signature entrees. I don't think people mind paying more as long as an entree is fulfilling and satisfying. Or one could easily compromise the small portions for the flavor profile, but that deliciousness of lemongrass galangal herby freshness was just not there.

Food is pretty good, service is exceptional! What I really came was for the rainbow sticky rice that everybody was posting on Instagram a while back. Aside from looking pretty, the taste it all the same pretty much. I had ordered a coconut water drink that actually was the best part of my meal honestly, but the curry I ordered was really good too
Food taste so good.I really enjoy eating.Order 3 thing tum ka noon, hung lae , larrb nurrAll taste good

Lamoon is a great Thai restaurant worth a visit. The service is great and so is the food. I had pad sriracha noodle which I recommend if you like pad see ew. It is spicy but if you like sriracha you will definitely enjoy it. The coconut juice was also very good. To start there is complementary lemon grass popcorn which is great and unlike anything I have ever tried before.

I debated between three and four stars. But here's the thing: it's much better than most three but it had too much hype but the food didn't quite impress me the way I thought it wood. I tried the pork spine soup which of all the dishes were my favorite. It was unique had great fish like (Umami) and lime flavor and the herbs were great. It wasn't as spicy as I thought to be and it could be less salty. But overall a unique dish and I kept on going back for more. I also ordered the red curry, som tam and fried chicken. Som tam was not very good. It was too salty but lacked that nice snazzy flavor of lime and chili. The crab was not too special on the salad. Red curry and fried chicken especially the fried chicken were quite good. But the place is new and clean and modern looking. It's cute and small. It's great for a date or to catch up with a friend. The staff was super friendly and it makes you want to come back. I would come back to try some other dishes like they had Thai iced tea noodles. How fun!The decor and menu is pretty.

First time coming to Lamoon and we really enjoyed it. The jackfruit salad was particulalry good, and the panang curry as well. Want to come back and try some more dishes. Sky was our server and she was super friendly and helpful.
Fabulous Thai food and service. Northern Thai food with a number of dishes that are less typical. We loved the three dishes we tried and are looking forward to going back to try more!!

Preferred to take out. The food was just awesome.Fried rice egg wrapped- whole fried rice literally wrapped by thin layer of egg- very interesting. Fried rice is really tasty. I tasted the mango salad for the first time and I was not disappointed- it's just unique mix of sour, sweet and chilly- just amazing.

We went there on Sunday evening with the nice weather. We decided to give it a try and let me tell you it was not disappointed at all. They offer a authentic north Thai food which is very hard to find a food like this to eat in NYC. In fact, even you live in Thailand, food like this is hard to find. It was so perfectly delicious and well made that it took our breath away once we took the first bite. They mostly cook pork just to be as perfect as my mom cooking. That reminds me of my hometown. Their location is in Queens, Elmhurst R,M station, and right across from Top Line supermarket where you can buy Asian grocery to cook yourself. Believe me it great location to hang out. Thank to Lamoon, They have made my evening so beautifully perfect.
Great food, friendly customer services, clean and cozy dinning environment. First time experience: great
The place is the bomb! Food is really good and the environment makes you feel like you are on an island in Thailand. Staff are super friendly as well, will definitely come back!

We went here around 5/6pm which was a good time as it was fairly empty and it got crowded after we ordered. We ordered a couple of dishes. All had different flavors. I recommend their spicy sausage in appetizer. The crab egg dish in the appetizer section was light in flavor but still good. For entrée we had a beef glass noodle dish that was flavorful and filling, but I might be interested in trying their other dishes next time...there will be a next time. The coconut snow pea drink is a must if you love the coco. ;) We also had their very colorful mango sticky rice. It was tasty. This is definitely one of the better Thai restaurants in the neighborhood.

Stopped by on a weekday for lunch. The interior design is adorable with paintings on the walls. The service was excellent. I ordered the Kanom Jeen Nom Ngeaw and my friend ordered the Khao Soi. I loved my dish because of how flavorful the broth was. The meat was tender as well. It definitely had a kick from the spices, so be careful! The curry from the Khao Soi was not too thick and had a strong coconut flavor. We ended our meal with mango sticky rice. It was my friend's favorite dish of the meal. The mango sticky rice came in a variety of colors and flavors. Definitely a must try!

It's hard to find inexpensive, authentic, quality food in NYC but Lamoon is an exception. This isn't a takeout pad Thai joint. This is real Northern Thai cuisine. I highly recommend the signature dish. It's called Kanon jeen nam ngeaw: vermicelli in pork rib shrimp paste stew, blood cubes, & red cotton flowers. You can't go wrong with the mango salad either. It compliments the hearty signature dish because it's a cold refreshing dish. They even sprinkle some ant eggs over the top for you. The coconut water is really good too, but I wouldn't have minded an adult beverage with such a great meal. The staff was really friendly as well. I will be returning to Lamoon.

Really delicious authentic northern Thai food This is not your normal pad Thai Each dish is thoughtfully prepared The rice balls for example were amazing We had Yum Gin Gai and every savory spicy flavor sticks with you Nice people and delicious food !We have traveled to Changmai in past years and this like much of the food there really is delicious and made from the heart!

Description: A unique Northern Thai food restaurant whose menu vastly differs from all the other typical Thai places Service: The waitresses working there are super nice and will do anything to accommodate you Atmosphere: It is a small place so it's better for really small parties. The walls are cute and there is a cozy feel to the placeItems Tasted:- Oh Liang: This is a milk based coffee drink. The taste was okay, but my bf liked it. It is more milk based than coffee- Thai Ice Tea: This is amazing and one of the prettiest Thai Ice Teas I've seen- Fried Rice Egg Wrap: I really enjoyed this. The seasoning on this is perfect-Khao Soi: Get this if you're a curry lover. I got a chicken drumstick for this curry and it was moist and tender-Hnam Kadook Moo (fermented pork ribs): I wouldn't recommend. There's no taste to this other than salt

Brightly decorated, very attentive wait staff! I enjoyed the Thai tea Pad Thai, Finger Root Pad Kee Mao, Green Curry , Panang Curry & Filet Tamarind Fish on the lunch specials! Everything was perfectly seasoned, delicious and I will definitely be looking forward to going there again. I had it accompanied by the Thai Iced tea. Yes they were in the NY TImes, Yes, they were in a local magazine but it does not change that this is possibly the best Thai food .

We came here for a dinner with friends and ordered a bunch of dishes to share family style. The Lamoon beef was nicely flavored, chewy but not like jerky. The pork brain comes out as a paste wrapped in a banana leaf - smelled delicious and was a bit too spicy for my husband. I wasn't brave enough to try it. Tamarind fish also good, a tad sweet but has a little bones so be careful and def not for little children to eat. Fermented pork ribs were the most flavorful and were very homey and were nicely fried like kurage. Lemongrass fried chicken was not marinated enough, had hardly any lemongrass flavor. Baby shrimp cloud cake needed the sauce, crispy. Thai tea pad thai was only ok - I couldn't really appreciate the Thai tea flavor and wouldn't order this again. The food is good but we felt most of the dishes had similar flavors and felt almost like eating the same thing over and over again. Service was friendly.

Seems like a few restaurants had changed-over at this same location. Now it's Northern Thai cusine.  At first try I think I will come back to try other dishes however it's not too my liking because the flavoring to too sweet when I wanted spicy for Thai experience.  I liked the fish itself, it's not fishy so even my friend who doesn't like fish ate some. I would just ask them to do the sauce on the side next time.  The minced pork is also sweet and not spicy at all (compare to other Thai who makes minced pork with basil oyster sauce soy-sauce fish sauce they made it with heavy with tamarind sauce is it's super sweet.  The rice portion is smaller than I expect with something so heavily seasoned you need more rice. The banana leaves crab meat egg is not good, sorry.I give 4 star because it's a clean place and hope they will continue to use better ingredients.
A cozy spot for some authentic Thai cuisine. Definitely will be coming again for their amazing Pad Thai.
The food was amazing and the environment is really nice too. The And sky our server was awesome!Great date spot!

This is probably a disappointing experience for me. Driving 1.5 hrs from Staten Island to try this place on Jun224. And yelp said they open 11:30 and when we got there on 11:30 on time and their door is closed and not t day until noon. What a bad timing management.The service was ok the Decor is new and cute. But the food was so normal. I when ask the pork noodle soup for mild and they make it spicy. Which I feel very stomach after eat. Def not returning back and not recommend. I think the Ayada or spicy shallot or thai hainanese chicken restaurant around that area are way much better than this restaurant.

A friend brought me here and told me it was Thai food like I had never tried. And Lamoon didn't disappoint! The food was amazing and I felt like we only scratched the surface. We had the Leng soup-  and it was amazing!! Sour, spicy, and the meat was perfect.. so tender and flavorful. I couldn't get enough. Definitely one of a kind restaurant. I can't wait to return to try all the other dishes.

First time for this place.I started with the Koong pare (Crispy baby shrimp)  10/10 it was so good /// Nham kadook moo (Crispy fermented pork) 7/10  Since there is no flavor maybe they should fermented it longer for intense flavor. ///Tum kanoon(Jackfruit salad)10/10  If you come you must try///Kang Hung LayI 4/10 Since I cannot tase the ginger or the masala curry. I am disappointed by this dish.

Me and my husband love Thai food, especially from northern Thai region. Lamoon is one of the best Thai restaurants that I have ever been. My husband enjoyed Leng soup and I had northern Thai red curry. Both of the dishes were very good and with right amount of spiciness. Btw their Khao Soi is beyond delicious and always reminds me of Chiangmai :)

This place is a true gem and definitely worth venturing to in Elmhurst, away from the row of popular places in woodside. They feature many authentic spicy dishes (some that I personally can't handle but spice lovers would, well.. love lol) but one that stands out for me is the Khao Soi Chicken. It is probably my favorite curry dish in all of NYC - perfectly balanced with rich flavor. Make sure to add the pickled lettuce (cabbage?) and shallots that comes on the side. Finish your meal with their one dessert (that I know of), the rainbow sticky rice & mango, it is so tasty without being overly sweet.On top of the great food, the atmosphere is great with their incredible murals and staff. My server Gift was always attentive and had a smile that deserves a Michelin star. I'm definitely hooked and will come back often!

This restaurant  is awesome. I came here for lunch potions is good and the taste is great yummmm. I ordered yum woon sen. i luv it and definitely recommended for everyone. U wont disappointed . Guaranteeeeee!!!!  5 starssssBtw, its not only tasty food that lamoon offer, but also our server was very nice , and he knew what service supposed to be.

This is a cute little restaurant in Elmhurst. I would estimate they can only seat about 20 people at a time (I wouldn't go with more than four people).  They serve northern Thai cuisine so if you're going for the usual Pad Thai or curries, you may be disappointed.  We tried the chicken wings, Kang Hoh (glass noodles with pork belly in a masala curry), Gai Toon (chicken noodle soup), Crab Egg Plam, Crispy Baby shrimp, and the fried fish special.  The chicken wings were fried and crispy and came with shrimp chips! The Kang Hoh had a nice flavor to it and it reminded me of something my dad cooks. The Gai Toon also had a nice flavor to it and was served with rice noodles and two large drumsticks that were rather tender with the meat falling off the bone. The chicken was flavorful and had a five spice flavor to it. The crab egg plam was basically an omelette with crab meat. The Crispy Baby shrimp was very interesting. It was a rather large portion, the size of a dinner plate. I'm not exactly sure what the baby shrimp was fried with but it was like eating one giant, crumbly shrimp chip. As an appetizer, it could probably feed 8 people! It was probably a mistake for us to order it because we couldn't finish it as it was quite filling (we were only 2 adults and 2 kids).  The crispy fish special was good - it wasn't a whole Fish served on the bone.  It was two filets served with vegetables.  They are also BYOB which is nice.  There is one bathroom but you have to walk through the kitchen to get to it, which is slightly weird but cool because you can see the action going on.
Went here for lunch with the bestie. Food was authentic with a great taste. Would definitely eat her again.

Truly spectacular, tingle-on-the-tongue Thai cuisine at an unbeatable price. From the $1 crispy rice balls to the gobsmacking green curry (rich with lime juice and heaven essence...I dunno what's in it but I want it in me!) to the sweet, family-like service vibe, my pals and I were over the moon with Lamoon. Go now. Tip big. My goodness, our spectacular lunch ended up being $20 pp with a generous tip. Holy Buddha, this is marvelous.
Cute place, nice vibes inside. We tried a bunch of stuff. Some unique spins on typical thai fare. They have the northern Thai specialities I enjoy.

Very delicious food!  Forget about Pad Thai.  Tamarind fish, coconut milk curry, pink ladies noodles, egg covered fried rice.  So good.Great introduction to Northern Thai food.  Everything that we had was nuanced and affordable.Friendly staff keep this restaurant with its modern decor regularly packed even during off hours like 2pm for a late lunch.  Right next to the M and W subway.
Great food, wonderful service. The pandan water is so refreshing and I could drink that all day. Discount available to Elmhurst employees part of the week.

Wow!! The food here is fucking orgasmic! We ordered a few things we had the lemon grass chicken wings (i could live without it) the curry noodles is so delicious! You can see a picture of food baby eating it, what food baby likes we do too  I had the stewed pork with Jasmine rice! YUM!! The coconut water was so different but tasty  I highhhhhhly reccomend the crab egg omfg I hated that I had to share that I'd devour that all on my own, Thai food with an awesome twist is what I think of with lamoon

This place is awesome Thai Northern food restaurant around Elmhurst ave. Yiu will not find simple Thai foods like Pad thai, Tomyum soup, etc. Today, I got Noodle with Thai Northern spicy and sour soup (we called it "Kanom Jeen Nam Ngeaw"); they served rice vermicelli with grounded pork, pork blood, tomatoes, and red cotton flower.I recommend this place if you want to tried something new.
Their menu is way different from regular Thai restaurants. Very unique and delicious deserts!

Horrible. I don't understand the other reviews. I love Thai food and this was the worst I've ever had. The beef in the khao soi was inedible (could not be cut or chewed), the pad kee mao was greasy and sour, and the kang hoh had two tiny pieces of pork in it. Expensive and it all went into the trash. I feel sick from the few bites I had.

I like mango salad despite no ant eggs. We would like to try ant eggs in salad. This no have.That's ok.I also like it tastes layered. Ice water drinks up has a special aroma. I asked waitress,she said its pandan.This is my first time drink pandan water.That's cool.Here is worth recommend!

This place is the best northern Thai food i never had in nyc. Saiaua (herbal thai sausage) omg so delicious don't forget to get Mongo & rainbow sticky rice that so yum yum. Everything i had today so good. Thank Lamoon i will come back to try new things again.

The Tea infused chicken pad Thai had a sweet interesting kick to it. Unique and original. Pearl Pad see ew, although not on the dine in menu (present on online menu), also equally original and tasty. The quality is present and although costs slightly more-- you get what you pay for. Not really sure how northern Thai food is different than the rest of Thailand- but this place certainly accentuates something different from a regular Thai restaurant

Out of all the Thai restaurants that I've been to, this one definitely stands out the most. Their menu is a bit different from other typical Thai restaurants but everything we got was really tasty and the owner patiently explained the ingredients in every dish that was served. Their sticky rice is a must and if you can't handle spicy food be sure to let the owner know because I find them to be spicier than other Thai places.

I gave this restaurant a 1 even though I rate it a 2.5, because something must be done to bring down this very misleading high rating on Yelp. This is an average restaurant, at best. I live in Elmhurst and am constantly on the lookout for good restaurants, especially cheap eats. The high yelp score, plus it being on a NYC best cheap eats list I saw, I decided to check it out. I took a friend and both of us were disappointed. The seafood was fishy smelling, in very bad way, and tasted terrible. Also, the portions were very small.  The service was inattentive and uncaring, and we were the only people there. The water had some strange herb in it and we were not told. When I said my water tasted strange my waitress brought me more of the same. I had to make a second request for normal water.

The Epitome of Northern Thai Homestyle cuisine brought to the comfort of a cute sized restaurant. Don't expect your typical yellow curry and pad Thai, there's plenty of that in this neighborhood - come here if you want a new experience with beautiful flavors - guaranteed to please the tastebuds.

New thai restaurant at elmhurst. This place have a nice interior and decend food. I start with the mango salad and it was awesome. I also got the fried rice with chili sauce but the taste is kind a tasteless.. but I definitely will go there again next time!

This place has a nice atmosphere and the staff is very pleasant. The Northern Thai food is OK but the portions are large. They don't have their own private parking. I recommend coming here for FREE drink!
The Angie (crispy green papaya salad) was delicious. The papaya was perfectly fried and the seafood was marinated in a tangy vinegary sauce. Perfect food to eat after a workout.

today my friends said they wanted to try Northern thai food, and weve heard the new business in Queens, called Lamoon. so lets go try it. once when we arrived we found the Lamoon's atmosphere were different from the other place around this area, Elmhurst. it was quite nice and grungy, with big female graffiti ( her name is Red Cheek, she s from the moon. lol what the idea!we had their signature dishes, Sai Aua, Khao soi, chicken wings. there were so great, it's very tasty. however, i have to give 5 stars for the dish called "Larb nuea" we ordered it twice. OMG!!! i love it. T.T it reminds me my nostalgic. mwah mwah!I definitely will come back again for sure.

Lamoon is a great restaurant and thats true. Their foods are very delicious. I recommended Khao Kun Jin for everyone. You wont be disappointed. Its jasmine rice with pork blood. Yakkkkk! I know it may sound very yakky but trust me its very great. The crisp purple from blood marinated into the rice. It hasnt had any yakky smell at all. YummmmNam ngeaw , one of their signature is awesome as well. But i have to tell you that im a big fan of pork blood. So this dish is one of my fav every time when i came here. Its my A MUST. However, its a oittle bit spicier than any places i tried before. So u gotta prepare you stomach.And we ended our meal with the only one of their dessert, the mango with rainbow sticky rice. Its very colorful. With six different flavor and colors. Server is very nice to explain us every color came from. Nice job. I recommend everyone to come and try their local taste northern thai food. Lamoon is one of a kind.
This is my new favorite Northern Thai style food in NYC ! Everything was fresh and tasty , Attentive staffs , friendly environment

The dishes that we had were delicious and very authentic to Northern Thai cuisine. The staff (male and female) was very attentive, friendly and caring. The food arrived quickly and I will be going back and refer friends and family.

This is a beautiful little restaurant right next to the elmhurst park~ (I don't think this is the name of the park, if you guys live in elmhurst you know which one I'm talking about.) The food is delicious and very well presented~ I really like the egg wrap fried rice~ one of the best fried rice I ever have~ and their signature sausage appetizer~ they added pig ear into it which give it a really satisfied chew~ the coconut juice is a must try~ and they also have dish like pig brain for anyone feeling really adventurous~

Randomly picked this place for dinner. A small place, nice and clean. Foods are really good. Totally diff than the other Thai restaurants I went so far. Fried papaya salads was amazing. Yes, it's fried. Perfect with the chili dressing. Lemon grass chicken wings were good too. Fresh, but not dried. Thy used a cute dish for display. We also ordered the tender pork, which I forgot to take pic because we finished it so fast. Thai iced tea was good, nth to complain. Had a good time there. Will come back to try other dishes.
The best Thai food in nyc ever !!! The waitress sky was so helpful and lovely !!  I highly recommend here !!

This was the best thai place I could find in NYC. Stylishly painted walls and the super funny and charming server - her name was Gift - made it a great heart warming and healthy lunch! Also: try the iced thai coffee!

Cute and small restaurant.  Not your typical Thai restaurant.  Decor is very different from the other Thai places I'm used to.  I had two good dishes but one was okay.  If you're looking for traditional Thai food, this is not the place.  I believe they specialize in northern Thai food.

Authentic northern Thai fare. Interesting interiors- almost like a beachfront cafe! No regular Americanized Thai fares like Basil fried rice or Pad Thai - but great alternatives. Lunch special is two course meal with an appetizer and an entree. Unique selections, if you like a Thai food and ready to experience a new take on it -- go for it!

I've been a loyalist to sriprapai since I moved here in 2009. Lamoon however has taken NY Thai to a new level with real authentic northern Thai food. I hate mango, but I will devour Lamoons mango salad. The noodles with green peppercorn was a spicy revelation. If you think you know Thai food, come here and see for yourself. 5 stars!

The restaurant was small and the bathroom was through the kitchen . I came here for dinner , the food was good but nothing special. I had Kang Hung Ley  which is the ground pork that served with rice , the meat was dry but managed to eat it with the curry and rice. We also had Nam Prik Ong Fried rice was homemade with the plum tomato paste . Both dishes was good just a little pricy.
Food delicious, l like the sweet and sour with mild chili they just make it right for you.
I went there at 10am in the morning. There were a lot of semi live and dead roaches everywhere, mostly on the floor. I will not be going back there.

I've been there several times and never had a bad meal. Each dish I ordered was so delicious! Their service is also great. I ordered a delivery today and they calculated the money wrong. They not only returned the $1 back but also gave me a free ice tea Thank you~Feel sorry to let you travel a second time and feel I owe you some tips now.
Really wonderful experience. Small, intimate place with great food and friendly staff.

Omg !!! Lamoon haz sucb a great foods. One of my fav jn thailand is gang hoe; which is sth like a glass noodle daute with nunch of veggiessss, yummy. It tasted very authentic. Sai aua aka spicy herbal sausage, it was homemade. It may looked a bit too small for the price but its one of a kind! I can tell this is the best one jn nyc. Obviously come back for its.

Wow over the past three weeks, I think I've been back here for dine in and take out for about three times already. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed the nam prik ong fried rice. It was very nicely cooked with a burst of flavors, the "heat of the wok" was very sufficient thus the rice came out very hot and smelled amazing! Of course the smears of shrimp paste on the side dish was not only a plus for the presentation of the dish but added additional flavor to the rice. The slow cooked kang hung ley ( curry pork belly) was also very good with the pork belly fully immersed in the not so spicy curry flavors.( even though I personally prefer the more spicy type of curries) . The papaya seafood salad was also really good mainly because I really liked the spicy sauce. My absolute fav though is the fried baby shrimp cloud cakes. It's a match made in heaven with the sweet chili dip. It's the reason why I've been making my boyfriend go back two additional times for take out because as I'm watching my dramas after work, it's just a snack that I can't stop thinking about. ( just to show how much I like it, we're still willing to go to elmhurst for just that alone even though we live in flushing) anyways def must try is the baby shrimp cloud cakes for those whom haven't bad a chance to visit this restaurant yet.
This is simply the best-- the food is very good -- the staff is very attentive to all your needs -- I could eat here everyday-- the best of thailand in queens, nyc
Loved the food,., Thai ice tea is the bomb,.,, the owner is very nice guy,., good price,., it's small but perfect for two,,
2nd time to try this restaurant , authentic Thai northern style, Very good food and nice ambience in crowded Elmhurst area.

Great Northern style Thai food. Had Angie ( Crispy Papaya salad with shrimp , calamari ) , Lemongrass Chicken wings and Jackfruit salad. Everything was grwat with perfect amount of spicy. Will try Kho Soi next time. Highly recommend

love love love Lamoon. the workers/owners are super kind and welcoming. they really care about the quality of the food + your dining experience. service can be a little slow because it is a small, intimate restaurant and the food is freshly made as you order. I haven't had a problem with the service, but i've just seen how it can be slow at times. The food makes up for it exponentially! Love the fried pork ribs and the Angie (best appetizers). the Angie is the best seafood/catfish salad you'll have at a Thai restaurant. The portions may seem small but they're suprisingly huge, I always leave with leftovers! I've had the pork curry/adobo type dish (don't remember the name), but it's delicious. Ultimate favorite was the garlic chicken served with the egg and rice; I could barely finish half! The sauce was delicious and fresh tasting. I have yet to try their fried rice and noodles, but can't wait to. Will be back!

Don't know what I am missing here but did not like the food. The egg on our beef curry was cold! ( is it supposed to be like that ??? )  Asked for water and the glass smelled of something weird - like coconut water or sth- seems wasn't washed well! Had the crispy pork with sticky rice- umm the pork was more like soggy and cold ( AGAIN- is it supposed to be cold- don't know ) so Yep- not for me-Decor - cute

Ahhh, such a good spot. Chill atmosphere and attentive servers who helped me through their menu. Came here twice in a month, both times for weekday dinner- not too many people, quiet and cozy. And they played kpop  Jackfruit salad was yummy, filling, and fresh!
The customer service is great. The decorations are unique. The food is great!! It is very unique and delicious!!!

This place was great! Very, very clean. Every table was taken on a Monday night. My friends and I ordered the baby shrimp cloud, the thai tea pad thai, the pink lady noodles, and the tamarind fish. It was all very good. I didn't care for the baby shrimp cloud, but that's just my personal taste buds (it wasn't bad, but I didn't love it as much as the other dishes). I can see why other people would like it, though. I absolutely loved the tamarind fish and cleaned my plate! We also split the mango rice. I'm normally NOT a fan of mango rice at other restaurants and wouldn't have ordered it if my friends hadn't wanted it, but it was actually delicious at Lamoon! Each color of rice was a different flavor, which made it so interesting to sample! We thought the portions were fair for the prices. I will be back!

Came here last night with a friend. Had the curry rice with pork. Pork was fine but presentation could've used work. There was nothing that tasted special or even Thai about it. In fact, it tasted like Taiwanese braised pork. Waitresses were friendly though!
Great place to eat Thai food . ILove this place service was great food to guysMust join this place .
This place is very cute. It is a hidden gem. The fried rice was delicious and very flavorful.

Its my ffirst rst time t try pure northern thai food here. Hmmmm, its hard to say but im not typical thai who knows about thai food. Hahaha. Pretty much i have around 50% knowledge about Thai cuisine, dont mention about specific Northern thai cuisine. LolSo i decided to give it a try @lamoon, which i chose the Nam Prik Ong as my entree. I was impressed by the dish itself. Its white blue color contradicts to the food which is reddish. Hmmmm. Thats impressed. The taste of Nam prik ong is quiet a bit spicy as informed by the server. However the assorted veggies on the side compromise the spiciness very well. It saved my stomach from the heat of food. So far i liked it. If you cant handle the spicy food probably rhai ice tea would calm you down. Enjoy!!!

Food was delish! They don't have a generic menu. Their dishes are from north Thailand. So if you want to try something different, I recommend this restaurant. The place is hip with really nice graffiti art.
This is a good thai restaurant place. Aside from the good ambience, they serve quality and savory food. I strongly recommend this. Thanks, too for the good accommodation!

Characteristic food , Nice art decoration, and Nice service .This is my first time to come here , My first impression is for the art decoration at this restaurant ,they can mixed street art and uniqueness of Thailand with perfect !!
The soup that i had was pretty good. Staff was friendly.. Ambience was cozy. Clean bathroom.
Such a nice restaurant in Elmhurst!!! If you would like to know about Northern Thai food, come here to try it. They have a lot of special food here. Yummy!!!
Newly opened and the food and service was outstanding. Definitely would be back to try their other dishes! Keep up the amazing work.
Nowhere else is like Lamoon! They are the best when it comes to Northern Thai food. Cozy and friendly vibe + perfect for family. JUST AWESOME.

Lunch special $10 is an excellent budget item. I tried the jor pak kad ....Fresh and crunchy... also Savory and  also listed on the $10 special lunch menu.
